PUB-DATE: October 1, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
2 CAMPAIGNS BEGIN DIRECT DISCUSSION ON DEBATE FORMAT

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
After charges and countercharges, ever-changing ultimatums and ever-passing deadlines, the two Presidential campaigns opened direct negotiations on debates last night, as Gov. Bill Clinton warily responded to President Bush's new eagerness to face off on national television.
Mr. Bush scrambled for tactical advantage by casting Mr. Clinton as the candidate who was afraid to go man to man in the four debates that Mr. Bush suddenly proposed Tuesday and that would begin Oct. 11. 
 Mr. Clinton, noting that Mr. Bush had previously resisted debates for weeks, offered his own proposal, suggesting that the two candidates begin to mix it up this Sunday in a previously scheduled appearance by Mr. Bush on CNN's Larry King program.
Top officials from both campaigns were huddled at the negotiating table in Washington from 8 P.M. to 11:45 P.M. last night.
 
Day of Frantic Movement
 Both sides had compromised by the time they reached the table, and the upshot seemed to be a campaign that was finally, perhaps, lurching toward an agreement on televised debates. At the end of last night's session, spokesmen for both sides said that the discussions were "ongoing" and would resume at 8:30 this morning.
It was a strange day on the campaign trail, with furious exchanges of public letters, negotiating meetings scheduled and canceled and rescheduled, and stylized catcalls from the candidates across the airwaves.
At the same time, much of the political world was focused on Dallas, where Ross Perot was on the brink of announcing whether he would re-enter the race.
Mr. Bush, trying to jumpstart his campaign by calling for Presidential debates after long resisting a bipartisan commission's plan for them, told a campaign rally in Wisconsin yesterday that Mr. Clinton was "missing in action."
"Governor Clinton," he said, "has responded to my challenge the same way he's responded to issues like free trade, fuel-efficiency standards and middle-class tax cuts: he waffles."
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, was even harsher, scoffing at Mr. Clinton's attachment to the commission's plan. "First he wants the commission; then he wants to go on 'Larry King Live,' " Mr. Fitzwater said. "He'll want to go on Arsenio Hall and 'The Gong Show.' "
A spokeswoman for the Bush campaign dismissed the idea of a debate on the Larry King program and said the campaign awaited the results of direct negotiations between the two sides.
But the Bush campaign clearly felt that, at least for 24 hours, it had regained the high ground on the debate over debates.
A banner at a campaign rally demanded, "Who's chicken now, Bill?" turning back on the Democrat a charge that his supporters had lobbed against the President for weeks as Mr. Bush stonewalled on debates.
The Clinton forces were, in fact, on the defensive much of the day. Caught off guard by the President's sudden shift, the Clinton camp tried to keep the negotiations under the auspices of the bipartisan commission, but finally agreed to a direct meeting with the Bush forces last night. Still, a campaign often accused of excessive caution and sitting on its lead lost a day of control.
Paradoxically, it came on a subject that the Clinton forces had skillfully played for weeks. Mr. Clinton signed on early and eagerly to the commission's plan, and Mr. Bush's resistance to it was widely seen as being politically costly.
Campaigning last night, Mr. Clinton said: "The President offered four dates that seemed impractical because they're during the World Series and Monday night football and all of that. I told my folks to go work with the debate commission tonight and then meet with his people as quickly as they can and work out dates. But he said yesterday, 'Let's get it on.' "
 
More Questions for Perot
 Referring to the bipartisan commission's plan, Mr. Clinton added: "The next debate was scheduled for next Sunday night. Larry King ought to have us both on there and let the American people call their questions in."
Mr. Perot, meanwhile, found himself on the defensive, amid continued questions about his method of gauging support for a possible re-entry to the campaign; many Americans were discovering that a call of any nature to his 800 number was automatically counted as a vote for his re-joining the President race.
"I'm a businessman," Mr. Perot said yesterday on the CBS program "This Morning." "I'm not going to pay for the phone call for some fella that says, 'Don't do it.' He can set up his own 800 number."
Aides to Mr. Perot said state coordinators were asked to report back on the sentiment at the grass roots by noon today. A news conference was scheduled for 4 P.M. Eastern time today.
 
Lowering Expectations
 Behind the positioning on debates yesterday was a growing recognition that debates, sooner or later, would be held. The surest sign, perhaps, was the pre-debate spinning that was already under way, with candidates and their seconds trying to lower expectations for each man's performance.
Vice President Dan Quayle, campaigning in Detroit, told reporters of his opponent, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee: "He has a big advantage over me. He grew up in Washington, D. C., and he's the son of a wealthy United States Senator. He went to the most expensive private schools in Washington, D. C., and I'm the product of the public schools."
Mr. Quayle himself had a privileged upbringing as the scion of a wealthy newspaper family.
Mr. Gore, campaigning in Ohio, responded to Mr. Quayle's analysis with a laugh and then said, "What puts the Bush-Quayle team at a disadvantage, not only in the debates but in all their communications with the American people, is that they have presided over the worst economic performance since the Great Depression."
The struggle over debates yesterday reflected the shifting dynamics of this race, as the Bush campaign tries to persuade voters to take a second look at the race after weeks when public opinion seemed ominously stalled for the President. Mr. Clinton retains a double-digit lead in most of the national polls. And he was hammering Mr. Bush for weeks because of the President's resistance to the commission's plan for debates.
The commission has already been forced to cancel three proposed debates.
The Bush campaign was widely seen as resisting debates in September because it hoped to first tighten the race; many analysts said taking the stage with the Democrat at this point would allow Mr. Clinton to "close the sale" and cement his status as a potential President.
Still, with little if any movement in the polls, Mr. Bush on Tuesday suddenly announced a proposal for four consecutive Sunday night debates beginning Oct. 11.
The debates carry advantages and risks for both candidates. Mr. Clinton is obviously advantaged by the status quo, but as a challenger he could still be helped by sharing the stage with the President. Mr. Bush badly needs to make his case to the American people, but he also runs the risk of presenting Mr. Clinton with another opportunity for attacks.
 
Figures in Negotiations
 The two sides met last night at the Washington law firm of Mickey Kantor, the chairman of the Clinton campaign and its lead debate negotiator. At exactly 8 P.M., the Republican delegation entered the offices: It included Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman; Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director; Frederic V. Malek, a close Bush adviser, and Bobby Burchfield, the campaign's general counsel.
The Democrats were represented by Mr. Kantor, Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee; Thomas Donilon, a Democratic lawyer involved in several previous debates; Bev Lindsey, a Clinton campaign staff member; Jack Quinn, a Gore aide, and Harry Thomason, a television executive and Clinton supporter.
Both sides had some victories to claim by the time they entered the room. The Bush campaign succeeded in getting the Clinton forces to the table for direct negotiations, without acceding to the bipartisan commission.
The Bush forces were said to particularly dislike the format of the commission's plan, which involved a single moderator. But the Clinton campaign was getting debates, and, its strategists asserted, had already gotten substantial political mileage out of Mr. Bush's resistance.
"He didn't yell uncle; he screamed it," said James Carville, a top strategist to Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: Municipal Bond Yields Rival Taxed Issues

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Tired of watching your state's services deteriorate even as taxes and fees head higher? Now, there's a way to profit: simply buy some of your state's notes and bonds.
A glut of municipal offerings has pushed even some tax-exempt yields slightly higher than those on taxable Treasury issues of similar maturities. After the effect of taxes on the Treasury yields is considered, the municipals' advantage is wider still. 
 Although municipals come closest to the yields of Treasury securities at shorter maturities of three years or less, longer issues in both Treasuries and municipals pay out much more.
At the short end, California's offering of $5 billion in notes, including $3.75 billion sold yesterday, sets a record for a municipal issue. The notes were popular enough that underwriters led by Lehman Brothers cut the yields by 10- to 15-hundredths of a percentage point yesterday, to 2.65 percent and 2.85 percent for notes maturing in January, April and May.
These rates are still generous considering that Treasuries of similar maturities yield about 2.7 to 3 percent. "The municipal market has one problem: heartburn," said Howard Burstein, sales manager at E. A. Moos & Company, a municipal bond firm "That comes from indigestion of supply."
States and municipalities are issuing huge amounts of debt to refinance higher-cost issues and keep governments running even when tax receipts fall short. Bond yields increased slightly yesterday as states and municipalities sold $2 million in longer-term debt.
Coming as a result of California's need to keep operating, despite a weak economy and budget woes, for the next several months, the $5 billion record is nothing that anyone wants to brag about. The Guinness Book of Records lists the fastest snail and the loudest snorer, but not the largest municipal debt issue.
The volume of new issues carries the risk that the ratings agencies will cut their grades, hurting the prices of notes and bonds investors are already holding. California investors have been hit by several downgrades.
But with so many states pumping out so much paper, the yields from California and many other states have gone high enough to more than compensate for any added risks, some analysts and investors say.
"If you have a job, you're in a tax bracket right now where munis make sense," said Joe Dean, who manages four municipal funds, including a California Fund, for Shearson Lehman. Some insurance companies that don't even need the tax exemption are buying municipals for the yields, he said.
 
A Steep Yield Curve
 A-rated municipals maturing in three years or less pay more than Treasuries. A one-year municipal pays about 3.16 percent compared with 3.03 percent for the issue from the Treasury.
Long-term Treasuries still have a pretax advantage over municipals. The 30-year Treasury bond yields 7.37 percent compared with about 6.18 percent for AA-rated municipals. But these yields are so much greater than for the shortest maturities that Mr. Dean recommends the longer municipal bonds.
"I've been in the business 23 years, and this is the steepest yield curve I remember," he said.
California plans to sell the remaining $1.25 billion of its notes, at adjustable rates, today. Frank Murphy, the manager of short-term municipals at Lehman Brothers, said that the two largest previous issues were $4.1 billion for California last year and the same amount for New York State in 1990.

HEADLINE: The World of a Drug Bazaar, Where Hope Has Burned Out

SERIES: 'The Well': One Block in Brooklyn -- First of two articles

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
The hum of the streets rises to fever pitch as dusk settles on a battered block in Bushwick.
"Most Wanted, Most Wanted," calls a man leaning against a graffiti-filled wall. "Lamborghini," another whispers to passers-by. A third paces the sidewalk, chanting, "Jungle Fever, Jungle Fever, Jungle Fever." He stops by a rumpled woman whose grocery bags hang like weights from her wrists, and trades a tiny package -- "Jungle Fever" heroin -- for a crumpled bill. The deal, one of hundreds made here each day, is done.
 
Lurid Brand Names
 The police call it "the Well" -- this block of Knickerbocker Avenue, between Troutman and Jefferson Streets, that has become the most notorious drug bazaar in Brooklyn and one of the toughest in New York City. 
 To spend two weeks in the Well -- to talk with its residents, addicts, dealers, police officers and social-service workers -- is to see how the drug trade can invade and occupy the entire life of a neighborhood.
Infested with dealers hawking vials of crack or glassine bags of heroin stamped with any of a score of lurid brand names, the Well provides an endless stream of drugs for buyers from as far away as Connecticut and Long Island. It is a constant source of arrests for the police, and of killings and of infection with H.I.V.
And like any center of urban drug trade, the Well has become an utterly persistent and hellish vortex. It not only sucks the life from the addicts who walk its streets but also the hope from the officers who police them. And into its midst have been drawn the hundreds of people who live in the six-family frame houses that line the block.
Some use and some sell. A few fight back. Many more have simply turned their heads and tried to tailor their lives for safety.
"The whole neighborhood is into it," said Inspector Robert Baumert, commanding officer of the Brooklyn North Narcotics Bureau, which has made hundreds of arrests on the block in recent weeks. "We are talking about a people where this is a way of life."
China J. is a 29-year-old mother of seven who tried to keep her building and herself free of drugs before surrendering in despair. "I've never seen a neighborhood where it's so widespread and so intense as Knickerbocker," said China, who lived on Jefferson Street until several weeks ago. "It's like Knickerbocker is controlled by drugs. The dealers will make it part of your life. You don't have any choice but to live with it. You can't complain to them, you can't complain to the cops, because you will die."
On the surrounding streets of Bushwick, an old industrial neighborhood whose name has become shorthand for urban despair, new housing and social services have finally begun to appear, even blossom.
 
Murals to Victims
 The Well is another story entirely. It is a place where street sellers congregate on every corner, where they grab buyers for other middlemen who stand in doorways or down the street. Teen-age girls sit on stoops and call out "bajando" (Spanish for "coming down") when they see the police moving in. Prostitutes and addicts roam back and forth from abandoned buildings nearby.
On all but one of the corners are murals painted to commemorate the casualties of the drug wars. "Rest in Peace" reads one. "Siempre te recordaremos" ("We'll always remember you") says another. In a four-block radius of the Well, there have been 23 homicides since January 1991, most linked to the dealers.
The busiest building on the block -- far busier than the pizzeria, the "Botanica" selling religious statuary and the dry cleaner -- is the AIDS research center near the corner of Jefferson, which provides AIDS tests, condoms, clean needles and referral services for as many as 100 residents a day.
No one knows how many of the neighborhood's residents are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, but of those who have been tested for the virus at the clinic, 45 percent have tested positive -- 15 times the citywide rate.
Just a block away, at Starr Street and Knickerbocker, is Maria Hernandez Memorial Park, named for the 34-year-old woman who was murdered in her apartment in 1989 by dealers angered by the efforts that she and her husband, Carlos, made to rid the street of drugs.
It was that shooting, residents say, that sealed the already tight lips of the community.
 
Standing Up
Price of Courage Can Be Exile
 Maria D. still faithfully attends community meetings about drug problems on Troutman and Knickerbocker, but she never says a word.
Maria Hernandez's murder, she says, was stunning enough. But shortly afterward, when two known dealers were spotted at a community meeting with the local police, rumors quickly spread that the drug organizations were sending spies to find out who was informing on them.
Many people stopped going to meetings at all. Those who continued to go were instructed by the police to pass on information anonymously.
"I go to the meetings, but I never say nothing because I live here," said Maria, one of many residents who spoke on condition that their full names not be used for fear of reprisals. "I go. I listen. I keep my mouth closed."
Silence. Lies. Dusk curfews. Locked windows. Group shopping. Disconnected telephones to avoid charges of informing. Such are the changes that Maria and others have made to their everyday routines in order to survive.
 
'They Know Us'
 "I try to only make two big trips to the grocery store each month," said another resident, who also told of the nightmare trek that she and her two young sons must make to and from their school each day, pushing through the crowds on the corners. Their curfew is 7 P.M. In her desperation, she hopes to scare them into obedience by telling them stories of children being kidnapped.
"It's very dangerous for my kids," she says, anxious that no specific information be used to describe herself or her children. "They know us."
Sitting in the kitchen of the house she owns on Troutman Street, Maria said she had tried such a live-and-let-live strategy. But she insisted on shooing the dealers away from her stoop and threatening to call the police.
Then, this past July, when one of the dealers cursed her, her 18-year-old son, Robert, pushed the dealer and the two began to argue.
A friend later told Maria that some dealers had put an $18,000 bounty on her son's head. Quietly, Maria sent Robert to live in an apartment in Queens, which costs her $600 a month. He carries a beeper, in case she needs him.
Nowadays, the dealers call out to Maria as she scrambles to and from Knickerbocker to shop, but she tries to ignore them. Neighbors have told her that a bullet wedged in the house next door was meant for her. But Maria tries to ignore that, too.
 
Local Task Force
 But she insists she has not given up. One of a handful of residents bold enough to join the Jefferson Street Task Force, a group formed three years ago to help fight drugs and to improve living conditions in the neighborhood, this stocky woman, whose eyes flash with frustration as she talks about her block, continues to fight -- albeit silently. She has left one apartment in her house empty, preferring to take the financial loss than rent to dealers. And she continues to shoo the dealers away.
Still, traditional community tactics, like street patrols, are out of the question.
"Look at them all out there," she says, nodding toward the window. "We can't go out on the streets. They'll kill you."
 
Joining Up
Guns and Money Create Intimidation
 Preferring the risk of the drugs to the pain of withdrawal, many of the Puerto Rican and Dominican residents on the block have clung fiercely to the lucrative trade to supplement welfare checks or support their own drug habits. And while many people on the block say they hate the sight of dealers and users on streets where their children play, many also concede that these soldiers of the drug trade are less invaders than part of the community's tangled web of blood ties and friendships.
Track marks travel up and down Candy H.'s legs like fingers, knotted only by abscesses where she injected heroin too many times. The 43-year-old prostitute with blue eye shadow smeared above tired brown eyes pulls her sleeve up to show more tracks on her arms, then points to her left breast. "I've got one there, too," she says.
Candy came to the area in the late 1960's, looking for heroin for weekend use. Soon, however, the checkout clerk-turned-topless dancer turned to prostitution to finance her habit, and moved into an abandoned building on Jefferson. She sold crack for a short time on Knickerbocker because the money was better than prostitution ($20 for a "date," $300 to $400 for a half-day selling drugs).
 
Expendable Street Workers
 In recent years, she said, she has kicked her heroin habit, buys crack only now and then, but has stopped selling, because she is afraid of being arrested. But there are plenty of people to take her place.
"A lot of new families are getting involved in it. You see it with moms and kids. Everyone gets involved."
And with so many unemployed or money-hungry youths willing to sell, street workers are considered expendable.
"If you get busted, they don't even come get you out of jail," she said, referring to the dealers.
China (pronounced CHEE-na) says she had given up heroin before arriving on the block last year. She moved her children to Jefferson Street, she says, because her old apartment had no heat or hot water and she had been told the building on Jefferson was "clean."
Within two months, however, drugs began to appear in the hallway outside her two-bedroom apartment. Tenants on the second and fourth floors began storing drugs for the dealers across the street. Soon, heroin and crack, she said, were everywhere. Complaints to her landlord seemed to go unheeded.
"Either he was afraid of them or something was going on," she says. "It got to the point where they wouldn't let him in the building. "
Hoping to keep the trade away from her children, she put a lock on the basement door. The dealers quickly popped it off. She tried to keep to herself as she walked in and out of the building. The dealers, however, accused her of calling the police.
One day, she said, five dealers kicked down her door, pointed a shotgun, an Uzi and a handgun at her and her children and accused her of stealing their drugs. "I told them I didn't do it," she said, "but they made me pay for it anyway."
 
Trying the Other Side
 Tired of fighting, she finally broke down. "I thought if I can be like them, they will leave me alone," she said.
She found a dealer, bought some heroin for herself and also agreed to sell some on the street. She left her children at a local playroom and headed out into the Well. The occasional $10 stipend for doing chores in the building paled next to the $80 or $90 a half-hour for selling drugs.
Her stint as a seller turned out to be a short one. After a week, she said, she resolved to stop again and sought help from a detoxification center. A few days later, on Aug. 5, an electrical fire severely damaged her apartment, and she found herself and her family on the street. But hers was a bittersweet escape from the Well: Unable to find or pay for a new apartment, they moved into a family shelter.
"Either you learn to survive in the street or you die," she said. "It's one of the two. I just thank God I'm still alive and that I got out of there."
 
Fighting It
A Vicious Battle, Seemingly Endless
 Ask the officers of the 83d Precinct about their work and they usually talk about robberies. Ask them about the Well, and they talk about drugs.
Lieut. Charles Meyer, who headed the precinct's street narcotics enforcement unit until his promotion last week, grew up only blocks away and played in Bushwick Park, now named for Maria Hernandez. There were always drugs around, he says.
But in recent years, the trade has become harder and meaner, first with the crack epidemic and more recently with the renewed popularity of heroin.
He rattles off known drug locations on Troutman and Jefferson. He describes different surveillance strategies -- all of them made harder by residents' unwillingness to help. Last year, his four-man unit made 247 drug-related arrests in the immediate area. Many of the dealers -- especially the youngest -- were back selling within days.
 
Revolving Door
 Late this summer, he said, they arrested a 14-year-old boy for selling heroin on Troutman Street. They released him to the custody of his mother, who promised to keep him out of trouble. Three weeks later, he said, the boy was arrested two blocks away for selling crack. This time, still unable to prosecute him because of his age, the police turned the youth over to his father.
"Two weeks after that," Lieutenant Meyer said, his voice rising in disbelief, "we arrest his father for selling crack in the same spot."
The lieutenant also talks of growing hostility toward the police from a community that claims some officers are too rough. That tension has made his work more difficult.
Two weeks ago, on night patrol, he and his partner got into a fight while trying to arrest a dealer near the corner of Knickerbocker and Troutman.
"We had to wrestle him down," Lieutenant Meyer said. Within moments, he said, residents surrounded him and began throwing bottles. One hit him on the leg, another hit his partner on the side of the head.
The incident, one of several bottle-throwing episodes in recent weeks, merely heightened the lieutenant's frustration.
"It's an embarrassment for me to go down there and make arrests and yet nothing changes," he said. "It's a disgrace, really. But we try the best we can."
 
Escaping It
Grasping For a Slender Rope
 Florencio Agron stands in the doorway of the Hispanic Service Society, one of a handful of social-service agencies in the area, and watches the drug trade in the Well.
"So many people are involved," he says quietly. "I feel so helpless," he confides later.
On a shoestring budget of $70,000 that has only been partly financed this year, Mr. Agron and two staff members get more than 3,000 requests each year to help residents from Troutman, Knickerbocker and Jefferson. Many of the residents, who do not read or speak English, come for assistance in filling out government forms. Some bring their children for after-school tutoring.
But it is clear that as they step into the modest two-room office that many of the parents and children have simply come seeking refuge from the Well.
The numbers have been overwhelming.
Last year, 150 elementary school students signed up for a tutoring program intended for 15 students. He took 25 students but was forced to refer the rest to programs in other Bushwick neighborhoods. Since school started this fall, 50 students have signed up. Fifteen now come each afternoon -- several of whom arrive on a fall day with their mothers grasping their hands firmly as they rush in off the street. Of the others, Mr. Agron said, "I have no choice but to refer somewhere else."
 
Fear, Apathy, Hope
 Mr. Agron said he has made repeated, unsuccessful requests to recruit volunteer tutors from local high schools and the community. The high schools, he believes, are skittish about sending students to the Troutman and Knickerbocker neighborhood. Parents, he says, decline to get involved out of apathy or fear.
"If there's no incentive, monetary or whatever, people won't show," he said. "And a lot of people are skeptical about coming into agencies when they are trying to hide something."
But there has been progress.
Since he arrived at the crumbling office in 1987, the floor has been tiled, the holes in the ceiling have been filled. The wooden facade and broken windows have been repaired.
He says that of the 25 students who were tutored last year, 20 saw their grades go up. All but two passed to the next grade.
"In a special way, the children here tell you 'Thank you,' " he said. "That keeps me going."
NEXT: Trying to clean up the Well.

HEADLINE: Conference Committee Approves an Energy Bill

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 1

 BODY:
With time growing short before the Congressional session runs out, Senate and House conferees approved early today a compromise version of a wide-ranging energy bill.
During nearly 12 hours of negotiations, the lawmakers agreed to drop proposed restrictions on coastal oil drilling and to dilute two provisions involving alternative fuels and revamping utilities regulations. 
 The legislation would grant tax relief to independent gas drillers and set higher efficiency standards for plumbing products.
 
Drilling Ban Is Dropped
 Early this morning, the conference committee agreed to drop a proposal to ban oil drilling along most of the nation's coastline and to buy back leases off Alaska, Florida and North Carolina. The proposed ban had been a major area of difference between the House and Senate versions of the energy bill.
On Wednesday, the committee agreed on requiring the Department of Housing and Urban Development to link mortgage rates with energy efficiency standards, and on streamlining licensing procedures for new nuclear power plants. The procedures had been hotly debated on the floors of both the House and the Senate.
Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, the chairman of the conference, also convinced House conferees to drop a provision that would have restricted the right of gas-producing states to limit the output of their wells, presumably to support prices, a practice called pro-rationing. In its place, a single line will appear in the final version of the legislation saying, "It is the sense of the Congress that natural gas consumers and producers, and the national economy, are best served by a competitive natural gas wellhead market."
In exchange on Wednesday, Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, leader of the House conferees, put restrictive conditions on a measure Mr. Johnston wanted establishing tough federal mandates on Government and private vehicle fleets to employ growing numbers of buses, cars and trucks that run on alternative fuels like natural gas, methanol and ethanol.
Mr. Dingell, who feared the measure would hurt the auto industry, wants the regulations to be linked to the availability and price of fuels.
In another important development, Senate and House conferees merged their differing measures to revamp regulations on electric utilities and ease the way for newer and smaller utilities and producers to sell and buy on the wholesale electric market.
Senate conferees had strongly objected to a House provision giving smaller producers access to transmission lines owned by larger utilities. A broad coalition of environmentalists, consumer groups and some power producers said the proposal would increase efficiency and decrease prices.
Senators softened their opposition to the access provision, and in exchange House members agreed to some Senate terms on competition and to a loosening of regulations on electric utilities to operate power plants abroad.

HEADLINE: Hospitals In 2 Boroughs Join Efforts

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
The New York Hospital will replace the Salvation Army as the controlling force behind Booth Memorial Medical Center, the largest voluntary hospital in Queens.
Under the change, announced yesterday, the New York Hospital, on the Upper East Side, will appoint the board that sets policy at Booth Memorial, a 487-bed hospital in Flushing, Queens, but it will remain, a New York Hospital official said, an "independent, free-standing hospital." 
 Officials at both institutions said Queens residents would benefit from the change because it would enable Booth Memorial to offer more sophisticated, high-technology care.
The officials also said the agreement -- officially a change in Booth Memorial's sponsor -- would enable both hospitals to be more competitive by, among other things, allowing purchasing on a larger scale.
Booth Memorial's executive director, Lieut. Col. Ronald Lyons, said the Salvation Army was cutting its ties to Booth Memorial because "hospitals have become more economically and business driven" and it does not have the resources to sustain a hospital the size of Booth Memorial.
Dr. David B. Skinner, president of the New York Hospital -- a 1,370-bed, voluntary, nonprofit hospital that is part of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center -- said that New York's new relationship with Booth Memorial is part of a "long-range strategic plan" for a future in which it will benefit medical institutions to "have a network of facilities in different parts of the metropolitan area."
An affiliation agreement between the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and Lenox Hill Hospital, also on the Upper East Side, will end next July, but that had no bearing on the decision to become involved with Booth Memorial, Dr. Skinner said.
As part of the sponsorship, New York Hospital will pay the Salvation Army an unspecified amount to compensate it for part of its investment in Booth Memorial over the years.
The Salvation Army, founded by William Booth in 1878, opened Booth Memorial in Manhattan in 1914 and its center in Flushing in 1957.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The goal of middle-class tax relief is elusive, despite political rhetoric promoting it. New evidence shows that the average family's Federal tax burden -- including Social Security, corporate and excise taxes -- has failed to shrink at all. The richest 1 percent, however, have seen real tax relief since 1980. [D1.]
Weak economic conditions seem right for another Fed rate cut, particularly if Friday's unemployment report is a poor one. But the prospects are clouded by a lively debate inside the central bank that has divided its governors and unusual outside pressures. [D1.] 
 Senate and House conferees reached agreement early today on a wide-ranging energy bill. [D1.]
Sales of new homes fell 6.1 percent in August, despite soft prices and the lowest mortgage rates in nearly 20 years. [D8.]
 
Companies
M magazine is ceasing publication with its November issue. Conde Nast, parent of GQ magazine, M's leading competitor, has acquired M's subscription list and name rights. [D1.]
ITT plans to spend $680 million on its insurance subsidiary, ITT Hartford, to cover continued losses from asbestos and environmental liability litigation on policies written before 1986. [D5.]
Touche Ross, B.C.C.I.'s liquidator, will sue its auditors, Price Waterhouse and Ernst & Young, seeking billions of dollars in damages, people involved in the case said. [D4.]
P. Roy Vagelos, head of Merck, spoke out against "play or pay" health care legislation, contending it might endanger American leadership in medical research and innovative technology. [D5.]
Pennzoil agreed to swap nearly half its Chevron stake for oil and gas reserves valued at $1.1 billion. [D4.]
Computervision's shares plunged $3 to $6.25 after the company said results would be "substantially below" expectations. [D5.]
Corporations issued a record $224.7 billion in securities in the third quarter bringing Wall Street unsurpassed fees. [D4.]
The F.C.C. cleared the way for Hallmark Cards to sell a Spanish-language television network to a company owned by broadcasters in Mexico and Venezuela and a Los Angeles producer. [D7.]
 
International
American officials gave the European Community a Thursday deadline for agreeing to binding international arbitration of a trade dispute over soybeans and rape seed. [D2.]
Canada's leading banks raised their prime rate by two percentage points, to 8.25 percent, which could hurt confidence. [D8.]
 
Markets
Stocks edged up on buying related to the end of the quarter. The Dow industrials rose 4.86 points to 3,271.66. [D12.]
Some tax-exempt yields exceed those on taxable Treasuries of similar maturities, thanks to a glut of municipal offerings. Treasury bonds were mixed in sluggish trading. [D19.]
The dollar was mixed in light trading. Gold prices slipped. [D20.] Hog and pork belly futures prices rose, but after trading the Agriculture Department reported a rise in pork production. [D20.]
 
Today's Columns
President Bush is at a disadvantage running on his record in a recession. His campaign might discuss indexing taxation of capital gains to inflation and overhauling the auto insurance system. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Oldsmobile's stunning review of its account, which has been at Leo Burnett, is part of an overall reassessment at the lagging G.M. division. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]
The 1980's insider-trading scandals are moving to Dallas, where a unit of Maxus Energy is suing Kidder, Peabody; Martin A. Siegel, its former mergers and acquisitions head, and Ivan Boesky, seeking at least $2.75 billion. Market Place. [D12.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH
 In a speech yesterday in Fond du Lac, Wis.
"And so it boils down to this. We cannot take a risk of a candidate with no experience, no track record, whose ideas and agenda are wrong for America. That is the basic thing. Governor Clinton is wrong for America.
Let me tell you something. In the Oval Office you face tough decisions. You cannot be on all sides of every question. You've got to call them as you see 'em. And I've made mistakes, like any American I'll admit it when I make mistakes, but I believe I've been a good, strong leader, willing to make the tough calls. And I'm a leader whose ideas are right for America, and I stand before you today asking for your support so that we can change America just as we have changed the entire world. 
 And I want a second term in office so we can continue to renew our schools, reform welfare, give our children a better shot at the American dream. "
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON
 In a speech yesterday to small-business owners in Clinton, Md.
"We have got to find a way, if we want a vital small business economy, to control health care costs; they're going to bankrupt this economy if we don't. Indeed, the difference, the single difference between my health-care plan and the Bush plan is that he proposes to put more money into the same system with minor modifications. I propose a plan that will bring health-care costs in line with inflation, not just the government health-care costs, but your health-care costs as well.
I have done this after spending literally more than a year talking to hundreds of people, including business people. I don't know how many business people I've met who have had to give up insuring their employees because they couldn't afford the premiums. I don't know how many people I've met who can't change their jobs because they or someone in their family has been sick, and they have a pre-existing health condition."
 
ROSS PEROT
 When asked yesterday on the CBS program "This Morning" about complaints from people who called his toll-free number to tell him not to run but got a recording saying their call would be counted as support.
"Well, they can send me a letter. We do have an 800 number. It's 925-1300. We had a million and a half calls the first two and a half hours after the Larry King show the other night. So folks are calling in and basically I said, If you want me to run and you're outside the volunteer movement -- Larry brought this up -- I said they could call that 800 number. I'm a businessman, Harry. I'm not going to pay for the phone call from some fellow who says, 'Don't do it.' "

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Consultant;
The Whirlwind Is Over for Perot Adviser

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
For the last four months, John P. White was on what he described as something of a whirlwind. In that time, Mr. White, a senior executive with the Eastman Kodak Company, was on leave from the company to oversee the drafting of the economic plan for Ross Perot's off-again, on-again Presidential candidate.
Mr. White has had considerable experience in business and with the Federal Government, but it seems that nothing was been quite like being Mr. Perot's chief economic adviser. 
 "I've had some relationship with government and with corporate life," Mr. White. "But with Ross it's unique. You never quite know what's going to happen next."
 
An Abrupt Halt
 But this week Mr. White spent several days in private discussions in Texas with Mr. Perot, then returned yesterday to his job at Kodak. The leave of absence had been intended to last through the election in November.
Mr. White insists that his decision to return to the company's headquarters in Rochester not be interpreted as a harbinger of the direction Mr. Perot's campaign might take.
No matter what happens to the Perot campaign, the 55-year-old Mr. White said, he will continue to champion the economic principles he crafted on Mr. Perot's behalf. Although many economists have assailed the plan as being politically naive and unattainable, Mr. White defends the proposals, which calls for eliminating the Federal budget deficit in five years through sharp tax increases and harsh cuts in Government spending.
"It's clearly attainable," he said. "We said it should be done in five years because it's hard stuff to do and you have to keep people's attention."
Mr. White, a vice president and general manager of Kodak's integration and systems products division, came to Kodak in 1988 after a computer software company he headed, the Interactive Systems Corporation, was bought by Kodak.
Previously he served as deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget and as an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Carter Administration and worked at the Rand Corporation, the research organization based in Santa Monica, Calif.
Mr. Perot had heard of Mr. White through mutual friends. The economic plan was put together after months of soliciting ideas from economists, policy analysts and academics, regardless of their political affiliation.
 
Graduate Students Help
 Armed with a wide array of suggestions, Mr. White called the deans of graduate schools of business and public policy, like Harvard, the University of California at Berkeley, Duke and the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, asking for graduate students to help in the drafting of a plan.
Within three weeks, he had hired about a dozen graduate students who worked virtually around the clock to assemble the Perot plan. "We had a priority list of issues," Mr. White said, "and we tackled them one by one, from the economy to competitiveness to education and health."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 4.86 Amid Concern on Jobless Data

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks closed slightly higher yesterday on buying related to the end of the third quarter, but enthusiasm was capped by anticipation of tomorrow's release of September unemployment data, traders said.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 4.86 points at 3,271.66. Advancing issues led decliners, 1,038 to 706, on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was a moderate 184 million, compared with 170 million on Tuesday. 
 Analysts said investors were preparing for the jobs report amid speculation that a bad unemployment number could provoke the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again to help the listless economy.
"We're all waiting for Friday," said Alice Sadlo, a first vice president at McDonald & Company. "People are expecting the number to be weak. They are expecting the Fed to lower rates again, but with the dollar situation, it makes you wonder how much good that would do."
The dollar has come under severe pressure lately, largely because of the gap between low American interest rates and high German interest rates.
The stock market was also weighing the impact of a restructuring by International Business Machines Corporation, which was announced after the close of trading on Tuesday.
"People were worried about what effect I.B.M. would have on the market," said Newton Zinder, a senior vice president with Shearson Lehman Brothers.
The computer giant said Tuesday that 20,000 more workers than expected had accepted early retirement incentives and that it was reducing its manufacturing capacity. Yesterday, I.B.M. shares fell 1/4, to 80 3/4. Several analysts lowered their earnings estimates.
Analysts noted that some of yesterday's buying was related to the fact that Wednesday was the last session of the month and of the quarter.
Among individual issues, Computer Vision was among the most actives, falling 3, to 6 1/4, after the company said it foresaw lower-than-expected results in its fiscal fourth quarter.
U.S. Healthcare rose 1 1/4, to 44 5/8, as Alex. Brown repeated a strong buy and Salomon Brothers upgraded its rating to buy from hold.
Community Psychiatric, a psychiatric hospitals company, slipped 3/8, to 8 7/8. It said fourth-quarter earnings would be near the 5 cents a share it posted for the third quarter.

HEADLINE: Dollars From Kin in U.S. Now Sustain Haiti

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 30

 BODY:
In the cramped downtown offices of Boby Express, a large international money-transfer company, there is a bustling business this morning.
Although the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has just marked the first anniversary of his overthrow with a rousing call for a "total embargo" of his Caribbean country, the cashiers here cannot keep up with the customers who have come to receive wire transfers of support payments from relatives in New York and Miami. 
 Most of those who line up each day say they fervently hope to see Father Aristide return soon as President. Yet few seem willing to forgo the monthly payments that sustain their families and, indirectly, Haiti's army-backed Government. "We all want Aristide back," said Naftia Juanita Casseus, a 20-year-old student, smiling as she clutched the $100 she said her father, a hospital worker, had just sent her from Miami. "But you can't stop us from getting our money. That would make a lot of people unhappy."
Funds transferred by firms like Boby Express and Hatrexco, the other major company in the business, are not recorded by Haiti's treasury or by international financial agencies. But economists estimate that the payments sent by the 750,000 or more Haitians in the United States are worth at least $250 million a year, by far this country's largest source of income.
Father Aristide and his supporters complain about the ineffectiveness of a hemisphere-wide trade embargo that was imposed on Haiti by the Organization of American States shortly after he was overthrown last Sept. 30, saying that many members still sell Haiti everything from petroleum to bullets.
But experts on the Haitian economy say that for all the leakiness of the embargo, it is ordinary Haitians themselves who, without reflecting on the politics, have provided the cash that pays for critical imports and keeps the exiled leader's enemies afloat.
"This is the main explanation why, when they imposed a trade embargo on the hemisphere's poorest country, it didn't crush this place," said one Haitian economist who asked not to be identified. "For years, the biggest foreign-exchange earner in Haiti has been cash sent home, not exports sent out."
A businessman who finances imports from Europe, which were largely unaffected by the embargo, agreed. "This is our biggest source of hard cash," he said, displaying a handful of checks from Haitians abroad and missionaries living here that he had exchanged for Haitian currency. "What this coup has taught us is that anybody will sell you anything as long as you have dollars."
Perhaps in recognition of their desperate dependence on relatives abroad, Father Aristide himself has never publicly called for his supporters to stop sending cash to Haiti. Similarly, his Government in exile has never sought to stop scheduled airline service, another lifeline to the Government of Prime Minister Marc L. Bazin.
Because of the heavy demand, American Airlines, the largest carrier between the United States and Haiti, will begin a second daily flight from Miami on Thursday.
"The diaspora has always kept this country afloat," said the Rev. Antoine Adrien, an adviser to Father Aristide, acknowledging the support that the funds from abroad had indirectly provided for the military, partly by keeping the level of human suffering from reaching explosive levels.
After the coup, the United States threatened to freeze the assets of the coup's financial backers. But nothing has been done to impede the flow of cash from individuals, which United States officials concede may have grown since the embargo.
"As the perception that things are getting bad back home has grown, Haitians in the States have been sending, say, $120 rather than $100 to their families," said one diplomat. "A 10 percent change alone would have been enough to offset the embargo."
Asked why Washington had not stopped the transfers, an Embassy official here said, "The idea was to make an impact on the coup makers, but not to totally suffocate the country that is the poorest in the hemisphere."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Perot, No Longer Unfamiliar or Unmarked, Has Yet to Live Down Criticism

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
What a difference a campaign makes. When Ross Perot first leaped into Presidential politics, he presented a tantalizing yet unfamiliar face unmarked by the arrows of political combat.
Now that he's back, the wounds show.
Dropping from a strong showing in the polls to a shriveled 9 percent, Mr. Perot abruptly pulled out of the race July 16. This week, poised to re-enter the fray, he faces the same questions left hanging when he vanished from talk shows. 
 In the days before Mr. Perot's sudden withdrawal, criticism of him fell into three basic categories: his supposed lack of sensitivity and autocratic style, his business dealings and use of political connections, and his judgment. Most of those criticisms and accusations have yet to be silenced.
 
Personality
A Man Who Likes Things His Way
 Some of the most pointed criticisms raised in the press and in opinion polls in July focused on doubts about Mr. Perot's character, particularly his attitudes about race, religion, homosexuals and women.
Voters also expressed fear that the billionaire executive might prove too autocratic if entrusted to lead the nation. Mr. Perot dismissed that notion as "an election year fantasy carefully crafted by the Republicans." He particularly lashed out at Vice President Dan Quayle's assertion that he was a "temperamental tycoon" who lacked respect for the Constitution.
Several events during the campaign and reports of Mr. Perot's actions in his computer empire, Electronic Data Systems, fueled those fears.
Just five days before Mr. Perot declared he would not run for President, he departed from his usual round of speeches to enthusiastic supporters to address the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. While calling for racial harmony and economic development, he managed to alienate a large part of his audience. Citing his father's treatments of poor blacks in Texas, Mr. Perot told the Nashville audience that his father used to tell him, "Son, these are people, too, and they have to live."
That remark, coupled with Mr. Perot's references to blacks as "you people" and "your people," distanced him from his audience and perhaps from many other black voters. Critics pointed to his minority-employment record. In 1986, the last year that E.D.S. was under Mr. Perot's control, only 1 percent of its managers and supervisors were from minority groups.
 
Beards and Facial Hair
 Jews may have thought they had reason to be uncomfortable as well. Records brought forth early in the campaign showed that Mr. Perot's company dismissed a computer programmer, Reginald Dallaire, in 1983 because he had grown a beard in defiance of company policy prohibiting facial hair.
Mr. Dallaire, who refused to shave his beard because he had converted to Judaism from Roman Catholicism after joining the company, was reinstated with back wages after Federal District Judge John C. Coughenour ruled that he had been discriminated against because of his religion. Mr. Dallaire later quit the company.
A flap over Mr. Perot's attitudes toward homosexuals also troubled the last days of his campaign. After stating in a May 29 interview with Barbara Walters on the ABC News program "20/20" that he would not consider appointing homosexuals to Cabinet-level posts and would not lift a ban against their serving in the military, Mr. Perot came in for sustained criticism from gay-rights groups. He reversed his position July 8, saying that he would not rule out such a Cabinet appointment. Mr. Perot's campaign chairman, Thomas W. Luce 3d, then indicated that a President Perot might relax restraints in the military as well.
That approach would be a departure for a company executive who has long emphasized traditional life styles and a complementary uniform of white shirts, dark suits and ties. Former employees say homosexuals were never warmly welcomed into E.D.S. In a June 29 issue of Time magazine, a former Perot employee described standing orders not to hire anyone with a "weak handshake" because the individual might be homosexual.
Mr. Perot has been blunt about the sort of employees he does like. He told U.S. News & World Report of his penchant for hiring Vietnam veterans who "could be on the wild side." He then described a series of conversations with one man, Don Drobny, whom he described as a talented 27-year-old who "loved to chase women."
Mr. Perot told the magazine's editors that he told Mr. Drobny: "You've got six months to get a wife." Mr. Perot said he forgot about the conversation but that Mr. Drobny returned five and a half months later with a fiancee.
Back in the spotlight this week, Mr. Perot angered female reporters with the comment that negative articles and television reports they produce are simply a result of their attempts to "prove their manhood."
 
Business Dealings
Money and Power Come in Handy
 More complicated questions about the candidate focus not on his personality but on his way of doing business. Though Mr. Perot has proved to be 1992's ultimate outsider in many ways, his business record is that of a longtime insider.
Republicans and Democrats have called Mr. Perot's quixotic run for the Presidency an attempt to buy the election. At a rally last May in Orlando, Fla., he told an adoring audience: "Just put it this way. I'm buying it for the American people." He has spent more than $12 million of his own money.
But Mr. Perot's political track record shows that he also sometimes spends money on others to get something for himself.
Since 1972, Mr. Perot and his business associates have helped to bankroll scores of politicians. In 1974, Mr. Perot gave more than $90,000 to Congressional candidates, making him the largest individual contributor in the United States that year. Twelve recipients of Mr. Perot's largess later voted for a $15 million tax break specifically written for Mr. Perot's corporations and passed in a late-night session of Congress.
Since 1980, according to reports by Knight-Ridder Newspapers, Mr. Perot and his family have given $175,000 to candidates for Federal offices. Some went to legislators who would later rule on the construction of one of the Perot family's pet projects, the construction of a modern airport in Fort Worth on land that lies in the center of a 17,000-acre tract owned by the Perots. Over the last five years, Federal, state and city governments have invested nearly $200 million in cash and tax breaks for that project.
The campaign for the airport began in 1987, when Mr. Perot and his son, Ross Perot Jr., asked the Federal Aviation Administration to finance a $25 million runway and control tower. The F.A.A. declined, saying the family should "compete fairly."
The Perots persisted. Turning to Representative Jim Wright of Fort Worth, who was Speaker of the House from 1987 to 1989, they convinced him that the project was critical to Fort Worth's growth. Three weeks later, Mr. Wright pushed a bill through Congress that dedicated money for the Alliance Airport.
Nothing about the project was illegal. Yet it did result in at least one clear benefit to the Perot family. a Perot company executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the value of tens of millions of dollars worth of real estate around the airport doubled after the project won approval.
Mr. Perot's efforts on the prisoner-of-war issue have been criticized as well. In 1987, working for the repatriation of American servicemen who he believed were held in Southeast Asia, Mr. Perot unsuccessfully sought to persuade the Reagan White House to begin limited economic relations with Vietnam.
Reagan Administration officials complained that he went to Vietnam for his own business ends. They also contend he was prepared to grant concessions in American foreign policy without first waiting for concrete signs that Vietnam would be more forthcoming about missing Americans.
 
Judgment
Use of Detectives Raises Doubts
 Mr. Perot's talent for making enemies, his tolerance for conspiracy theories and his frequent use of detectives has raised questions about his judgment.
A Perot campaign official said yesterday that Mr. Perot hired private investigators in the last two months to look into volunteers' use of money.
Some Government officials close to the prisoner-of-war issue said Mr. Perot became obsessed with the notion that a Government conspiracy was blocking efforts to free any prisoners left behind.
It was over the P.O.W. issue that Mr. Perot began a three-year feud with Richard Armitage, the senior Pentagon official in charge of P.O.W. and M.I.A. affairs. In 1986, Mr. Perot met with an undercover police officer who said he had information about a conspiracy involving the Pentagon and the prisoner issue. The undercover officer also raised questions about Mr. Armitage's relationship with a Vietnamese-American restaurant owner.
Mr. Perot met with the undercover officer, James L. Badey, then encouraged government investigations into the case. Mr. Armitage was never charged with wrongdoing.
Mr. Perot's harsh dealings with officials behind the construction of the Vietnam Memorial in Washington also won him enemies.
Though he gave generously to the project at the outset, once Mr. Perot turned against the design (saying it would look like a "trench"), he tried to get the committee to move in a more conventional direction. John Wheeler, the chairman of the fund that built the memorial, refused.
Mr. Perot hired Roy Cohn, the New York lawyer, to do whatever he could to stop construction. Mr. Cohn demanded the memorial fund's records and charged that the project's backers had misused money.
An audit showed nothing wrong. And the memorial was finally built. "He pushed me and pushed me to give up the wall," Mr. Wheeler said. "It was like being sliced with a knife."
Mr. Perot's aggressiveness in that instance was not without precedent.
When a rival computer company won a lucrative state contract in the 1980's, Mr. Perot hired a private detective to investigate the senior official in charge of that concern. The detective, a former F.B.I. agent named Joseph T. Wells, said he spent at least 18 months gathering information to use against the System Development Corporation and a top executive, Edward Doyle.
Mr. Wells also tried to get the F.B.I. to begin a criminal investigation into one of Mr. Doyle's top aides. Yet nothing was ever revealed to show that Mr. Doyle or anyone else associated with the company had done anything improper.
Examples of Mr. Perot's reliance upon detectives kept cropping up as his campaign progressed. Another highlighted case was that of his investigation into a land deal engineered by the Pennzoil Company and its head, J. Hugh Liedke, a close friend and former business partner of President Bush.
In that case, Mr. Perot hired a Washington law firm, Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPheron & Hand, to look into the sale of a 500,000-acre parcel of land in northern New Mexico. The land had been offered to Mr. Perot for $24 million in the early 1970's. It eventually was sold to Pennzoil. In 1986, Mr. Perot said, Pennzoil came to him with an offer to sell the same land -- minus 100,000 acres -- for twice the price. He said at the time he had learned that Pennzoil received a $48 million tax credit for donating the extra 100,000 acres to the Forest Service.
After reports surfaced that Mr. Perot had once investigated Mr. Bush's children, the President's campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, said Mr. Perot "doesn't have the judgment or temperament or respect for our laws to be President." Mr. Perot, who denied the reports, retaliated by producing a letter in which President Bush had praised him as a friend.

HEADLINE: One Group Saw Relief: The Very Wealthiest 1%

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Contrary to what many Americans believe, the way the Federal tax burden is shared among different income groups has not changed much since 1980. The only exception? The very richest 1 percent.
That group saw real tax relief. But for almost everyone else, effective tax rates are about what they used to be, according to findings presented at a recent conference of tax specialists at the University of Michigan. The Federal tax burden on families in the top 20 percent of earners, estimated at 27.5 percent now, is 3.2 times that of families in the bottom 20 percent, scarcely different from 3.4 times in 1980. 
 In essence, income taxes, which are the most progressive form of Federal tax, became a smaller share of the total Federal tax burden. At the same time, payroll taxes, which include Social Security and Medicare, and fall most heavily on middle- and lower-income families and more lightly on the rich, loomed larger.
The biggest surprise to many economists was that the burden on the working poor did not shrink. The effective tax on the bottom 20 percent actually rose sharply during the first half of the decade, but then fell again. The rise came as higher excise and payroll taxes pushed total Federal taxes to 10.3 percent of their income in 1985, from 8.1 percent at the beginning of the decade. At the same time, inflation was pushing more low-income people into the ranks of income tax payers. The 1986 Tax Reform Act, which removed millions of low-income families from the tax rolls, reversed most of the rise.
 
Theory at Issue
 As for the the top 1 percent, Federal taxes dropped to 24.9 percent of their pretax income in 1985, from 31.7 percent in 1980, as both personal and corporate tax rates were slashed. Now the figure stands at 28.8 percent.
The finding that there were not large shifts in the tax burden seems to refute the suggestion that tax changes are to blame for the big income gains by the richest Americans and the relative losses by those who make the least. "I've looked for evidence that lower rates caused the increase in inequality, but I couldn't find a smoking gun," said Joel Slemrod, a professor at the University of Michigan.
 
Tilting the Tax System?
 Lynn Karoly of Rand estimated that 85 percent of the rise in inequality was from shifts in pretax income.
Some economists at the conference argued for tilting the tax system more in favor of the working poor. "It's possible to find efficient ways that don't cost the rich $3 to give poor people an extra $1," said Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution.
But several economists at the University of Michigan meeting strongly questioned whether whether the tax system could play a dominant role -- as the current political debate seems to imply -- in redressing the squeeze on the middle class.
"The taxes required to offset inequality are far too large to undertake," said David Cutler, an economist from Harvard University.
To illustrate how large, the Congressional Budget Office economists calculated that raising the top income rate to 50 percent, taxing stock trades and scaling back Social Security taxes -- a package far more radical than anything proposed by anyone to date -- would roll back less than one-seventh of the increase in inequality during the 1980's.

HEADLINE: Niagara Crash Brings Cry for Rules on Helicopters

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Like many of the thousands of people who make their livings off Niagara Falls, Nick Ricci, who owns a hotel on a wooded ridge overlooking the falls, now wants the Canadian and American Governments to regulate the sightseeing helicopters that churn through the skies overhead at a rate of nearly one every five minutes.
Watching the thundering green-blue waters of the falls today, Mr. Ricci noted that the collision of two of the helicopters on Tuesday caused one to crash just 200 yards from his building. "If the wind had been blowing in toward the hotel instead of out, that copter could have hit us," he said. "It's pretty unsettling." 
 Three passengers -- two from Brooklyn and one from Queens -- and the pilot of one of the helicopters were killed. None of the five people on the other helicopter were seriously injured.
Long ignored as noisy nuisances or grudgingly accepted as necessary evils in the all-important tourist trade, the helicopters have suddenly become threatening and unwanted to many residents -- including many who know their economic value in a recession-strapped region.
 
Tourist Tapes Sought
 Moreover, the crash, the cause of which was still undetermined today, has raised questions about whether the aviation authorities on both sides of the border should start restricting when, where and how many helicopters can tour the falls.
At least three companies operate a total of 200 or more sightseeing flights daily during peak season. As many as five helicopters have been known to be airborne above the falls simultaneously.
"This is going to change everyone's thinking about the helicopters," said Mr. Ricci, 33, a former professional hockey player who now owns the Oakes Inn. "They fly overhead constantly and I never thought about them. Now, I realize it's just too dangerous."
In essence, anyone with a pilot's license can cruise the congested area along any route they choose, officials said. "All we do is recommend an altitude and flight pattern," said David Tomczak, an air traffic controller at Niagara Falls International Airport. "But there is nothing that says they have to do anything."
The crash victims were identified today as Ben Poprawski of North Tonawanda, N.Y., 42 years old, the pilot; Orna Levy, 19, of Queens; Esther Zarian, 23, of Brooklyn, and Amnon Sarfate, 26, of Brooklyn.
Investigators from the Canadian Transportation Safety Board continued inspecting pieces of the crumpled McDonnell Douglas 500E helicopter, which remained at the crash site. The Canadian authorities have asked tourists who might have videotaped the collision to submit their tapes to investigators. There were hundreds of sightseers in the area at the time.
"Because helicopters don't have flight data recorders, we don't know what actually happened," said Jim Harris, a spokesman for the Canadian Transportation Safety Board.
 
Flights Are Suspended
 Sightseeing flights have been suspended indefinitely while the investigation, which could take months, continues.
Though there has been no shortage of accounts from witnesses, many of them conflict. The survivors of the crash made no public statements yesterday.
But most accounts agree that the smaller helicopter, owned by Rainbow Helicopters of Niagara Falls, N.Y., lost control when one or both of its rotor blades were clipped by the other helicopter, owned by Niagara Helicopters Ltd. of Niagara Falls, Ontario.
After the collision, the American helicopter plummeted into the wooded ridge below Mr. Ricci's hotel. The second helicopter landed a mile away.
The question about regulating the helicopters has stirred debate. Scott B. Hughes, general manager of Rainbow Helicopters, said pilots could easily avoid each other if they maintained radio contact over the open frequency used by helicopter pilots.
"There's no doubt in my mind that our pilot was in continuous radio contact with the other pilot," he said today. "So what happened? Damned if I know."
 
Passengers Can Distract
 But Harold Bucholtz, who owns another American-based helicopter company, said pilots were often distracted by the excited chatter of their passengers. "For sure, the guy sitting next to you is going to be asking questions about you altitude, where you're going to turn and what's that thing on the left," he said. "You can lose 200 feet in altitude in a few seconds if you're not paying attention."
Mr. Bucholtz said the Federal Aviation Administration and its Canadian counterpart should begin setting mandatory flight patterns and altitudes for the helicopter flights.
In the wake of the crash in Niagara Falls, momentum has built on both sides of the border for banning or severely restricting helicopter flights. Two weeks ago, Rob Nicholson, the member of Parliament representing Niagara Falls, introduced legislation banning low-altitude flights over the falls.
And on the American side, Barbara A. Geracitano, a Niagara Falls city councilwoman, said she plans to reintroduce a bill to ban helicopters from taking off inside the city limits.
The bill was narrowly defeated two years ago amid fears it would hurt the local tourist trade. But now, Ms. Geracitano said, the tide of opinion has shifted. "People will still come; they'll just get a great view from the ground," she said.
 
Dependence on Tourism
 Along Main Street in Niagara Falls on the American side, where scores of vacant stores stand in bleak testimony to the bad economic times, the debate over helicopters was on many residents' minds yesterday.
"It's such a racket you can't talk over it," said Ruth Hooker, 59, whose apartment building overlooks the Niagara River Gorge. "The wind catches their blades and all you hear is bang, bang, bang, chop, chop, chop."
But in Norm's Bar across the street, the thought of banning a tourist attraction put a scare into Marla Fadel, who owns the tavern. "The industries are gone, we're really depressed here," she said. "The helicopters are good for business. They should stay."

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Panel Shows Consensus Is Easy If Ideas Are Vague

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
At a time when political consensus exists on precious little, few Americans would take issue with these propositions:
*The Federal budget deficit should be lowered. 
 *The nation's medical-care system should be reformed.
*Medicare and Medicaid costs need to be reined in.
*The tax system should encourage people to save more and consume less.
*Military spending should be reduced.
*Government spending should be adjusted so more goes to valuable programs and less or nothing to those without such merit.
So amid great fanfare, another commission with several prominent members, this one called The Strengthening of America Commission, issued a 180-page report today, the product of 16 months of work, urging that those steps be taken.
 
But How?
 What the commission did not address was how the medical system should be changed, which Medicare and Medicaid benefits should be reduced and by how much, who should pay higher taxes, which military programs should be cut and which Government programs are without merit.
It did not, in other words, address who would bear the pain, who would make the sacrifice for putting the country on a different course. That is the fundamental matter politicians have been unwilling or unable to address for a decade, a failure that caused the mess the commission now wants cleaned up.
Voter surveys show that Americans resent the way Presidential candidates and other politicians avoid confronting the crucial issues of the time. But this latest commission illustrates how it is not just politicians but leaders in all walks of life who decline to stand up and be counted on the side of making demands on the American people. John F. Kennedy's line about asking not what your country can do for you has become passe.
The 60 commission members included a few senators, representatives and other politicians but most were corporate executives, labor leaders and scholars working under the auspices of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington research institute.
When a reporter suggested at a news conference on Capitol Hill, where the report was released, that the group had ducked the essential issues, Senators Sam Nunn and Pete V. Domenici, the co-chairmen of the commission, took offense.
"You're fundamentally wrong," said Senator Nunn, Democrat of Georgia. He said that the panel had drawn a blueprint and that policy makers would fill in the details.
Senator Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said the question reflected "the sense of cynicism that's around."
He suggested, "Rather than say, We can't, I think we have to say, Why not?"
But a few of the commission members agreed that the panel had avoided the difficult calls.
"The problem with all of this," one member, Isabel V. Sawhill, wrote in her signed statement, "is that after aggressively calling for tough choices, the report is incredibly vague on what those choices are and, in the process, leaves the impression that they will be far more easily and less painfully achieved than is actually the case." Ms. Sawhill, a prominent student of the Government's social and economic policies, is a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, another research center.
Blue-ribbon commissions are as much a part of the Washington scene as campaign fund-raisers and the Lincoln Memorial. Sometimes they make history. That was the case with the Warren Commission on the Kennedy assassination and the Kerner Commission, which examined the causes of the urban riots in the 1960's.
But the work of commissions is generally hoisted to the top shelf in library stacks, where they gather cobwebs for the rest of their days.
Over the years, the Center for Strategic and International Studies has focused almost entirely on foreign affairs and military issues. But its president, David M. Abshire, said the center formed The Strengthening of America Commission because "we are most vulnerable not on the Russian steppes or in the Persian Gulf, but in our factories, our classrooms and our halls of government."
To get a copy of the report, send $14 to C.S.I.S., 1800 K Street N.W., Suite 400, Washington, D.C. 20006.
Some of the panel's recommendations are indeed ambitious. It would balance the Federal budget over 10 years by cutting spending by 8 percent from what it would otherwise be and raising taxes by 3 percent.
Following President Bush's lead, the commission endorsed a cap on mandatory spending programs other than Social Security, including Medicare, Medicaid, farm price supports, veterans benefits and student loans. These are programs that make payments to all eligible individuals. But like the President, the commission did not take the essential next step of saying how the cost of Medicare and Medicaid, which have been rising at the rate of 13 percent a year, should be controlled.
 
Overhaul of Taxes Urged
 The commission's most innovative recommendation was to abolish the existing income tax system and replace it with what the commission called a consumption-based income tax system. Taxpayers would pay taxes only on the portion of their income that they spent, not on the money they saved or invested. Since rich people are able to save more than the poor and the middle class, the only way to make such a tax as equitable as the current system would be to exempt the poor and have tax rates that would rise steeply as income and spending increased.
If overall taxes are increased by $376 billion over 10 years, as the commission proposed, rich people and the middle class would have to pay higher taxes than they do now, a point not addressed in the commission's report.
Like so much else in the document, the difficulty with the tax plan is in such details.
