HEADLINE: Brazil's New Chief Prepares for Monday Takeover

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Empowered by the impeachment of President Fernando Collor de Mello, Vice President Itamar Franco worked today to forge a parliamentary base to sustain him through the end of 1994 as the leader of Latin America's largest nation.
As the Vice President negotiated Cabinet choices with political supporters, the Senate completed steps that will allow a formal transfer of power on Monday, fulfilling the constitutional requirement that an impeached President be barred from exercising control while he is tried by the Senate. 
 The trial is supposed to be completed in 180 days. Mr. Collor said through a spokesman today that he would submit to the trial and would not resign. But an overwhelming majority of senators have already announced their intention to vote to convict Mr. Collor.
Today, the day after more than half a million people took to the streets to celebrate the impeachment, Brazilians started to take a closer look at the quiet 61-year-old career politician who is expected to be the country's leader for the next two years.
The styles and personal trajectories of Mr. Franco and Mr. Collor could hardly be more different.
The playboy scion of a political oligarchy, Mr. Collor was appointed by Brazil's ruling military to be Mayor of Maceio, a state capital, when he was 29 years old. When Mr. Franco was 29, he was a civil engineer working in his hometown, Juiz da Fora, as head of the city Department of Water and Sewers.
At age 36, he was elected Mayor of Juiz da Fora, the second largest city of Minas Gerais, an interior state known for austerity, a sober work ethic and nationalist politics.
"What most pleases him is his image of integrity, rectitude, honesty and public spirit," Valder de Goes, a Brasilia political consultant, wrote in a profile this month. "Itamar is a solitary, close, introspective man."
Mr. Franco was Mayor from 1967 to 1974, when he was elected Senator for Brazil's center-left Democratic Brazilian Movement. In his 26 years in public office, he has moved through four political parties and is currently politically unaffiliated.
In 15 years in the Senate, he gained a reputation as an economic nationalist hostile to foreign investment, to foreign imports and to cooperation with the International Monetary Fund -- concepts embraced by Mr. Collor.
Mr. Franco has made few public statements and has given few public interviews since assuming office on March 15, 1990, but several officials interviewed here this week said that his economic thinking had moved to the center in recent years.
"The world has changed, and Itamar has changed," said Antonio Delfim Netto, a member of the Chamber of Deputies who fueled Brazil's economic growth as Planning Minister in the 1970's and who is expected to be named Agriculture Minister.
Carlos Langoni, a former Central Bank president, predicted confidently, "There is no way that Itamar will change the fundamentals of the Collor modernization plan."
Senators close to Mr. Franco predicted that he would maintain Brazil's new debt accord, and, with minor changes, the privatization program and openings to foreign trade promoted by Mr. Collor. By the end of November, Brazil's Senate is expected to vote to approve an accord reached 10 days ago to reschedule Brazil's $44 billion private bank foreign debt.
The most pressing problem facing Mr. Franco will be the nation's 25 percent a month inflation rate. To beat inflation, Mr. Franco needs to pass tax increases through Congress, to speed the reduction of Brazil's federal bureaucracy and to cut tax evasion.
Today, Mr. Franco sought to translate into a formal political pact the political consensus registered in the Chamber of Deputies on Tuesday when 92 percent of members present voted for impeachment.
"The political parties have to be tied to a formal pact of national unity," said Senator Mauricio Correa, a Franco adviser who was chosen today to be Justice Minister. "It will not be enough for them to give support at first, and then to come out later with the machine guns."

HEADLINE: Detroit Journal;
Big Problems and an Image to Match

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Earlier this month, a Florida woman visited a downtown church where the Rev. Ervin A. Brown will marry the woman's daughter. The woman walked from Christ Church Detroit, where the wedding will take place, to a hotel at the Renaissance Center, where the reception will be held, two and a half blocks away.
"She asked if we needed an armed guard to walk the guests to the hotel," recalled Mr. Brown. "Talk about image problems." 
 Oh, Detroit, Detroit, Detroit. As hard as it tries to overcome its portrayal as an urban nightmare, stories like the one told by the Episcopal pastor, as well as a string of recent events, have repeatedly punctured this proud city's soul and bruised its pride. No other city, residents here lament, has to work so hard to overcome an image -- and sometimes the damage is self-inflicted.
Detroit's former police chief began a prison sentence earlier this month for embezzling police funds. A Cable News Network report a week ago portrayed the city as an impoverished shell. There was a bitter monthlong strike by 10,500 public school teachers.
All of these events have damaged an already fragile self-image. "If the city was a person, it would have a lot of defensive pride," said Larry Ledebur, director of the Center for Urban Studies at Wayne State University.
"When you mention you work in Detroit, the reactions you get from people make it very clear what their perception is," said Mr. Ledebur, who lives in the suburb of Southfield. "It's almost universally negative."
The city's beleaguered image masks the fact that its problems are generally no worse than those of other cities with populations of one million to two million. For example, Detroit's 615 killings in 1991 made the city's homicide rate comparable to those in Dallas, which had 500 homicides, and Houston, which had 608, according to statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Dallas, not Detroit, has the highest overall crime rate.
"As far as Detroiters go, we don't see our problems as any worse than other cities," said Paul Hubbard, president of New Detroit Inc., a public policy organization of civic leaders. "Detroiters are tired of it."
Yet the city continues to get grim reviews from around the nation. Urban specialists say this is partly because Detroit never recovered from the 1967 riots. The decline of its industrial economic base has led to a steady drain of residents, mostly whites who have fled to the suburbs. The city's 1990 population, according to the Census Bureau, declined to a little more than one million from 1.5 million in 1970. Nearly 76 percent of the city is black.
"Detroiters are very sensitive about these things," said Morris Thompson, an editorial writer for The Detroit Free Press. "Detroit has had a bad reputation in the country at least since the 1967 riots."
Residents fiercely defend their city, but even some of them admit that life is not easy, given the economy and chronic high unemployment, 15.5 percent in July as against the national rate of 7.6. "Sometimes life in the city is good and sometimes it's bad," said Owen Grant, who has lived in Detroit for 25 years. "Right now, it's very rough.'
Mr. Brown, the Episcopal minister, who has lived here for 11 years, concurs. "I kind of feel beleaguered and discouraged over unemployment, crime, blight, and the fact that the same things seem to be getting worse instead of better." Mr. Brown said he and his wife, a hospital chaplain, differ over the quality of the city. "She says Detroit has a spirit and the people are resilent," he said, "but I find it harder to find."
Urban experts say Detroit can rehabilitate itself. Mr. Ledebur of Wayne State points to Cleveland, which had image problems a decade ago but now, with a refurbished downtown, draws fewer knocks.
He concedes that it will not be easy but adds, "It's not impossible."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION PANEL SEES MODEST GAINS

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Only modest progress has been made toward the six national education goals that President Bush and governors agreed to in 1989, and the United States continues to lag behind other industrial nations in geography, mathematics and science, according to a report made public today.
"The rest of the world has been expecting more and getting more," from its students, said Education Secretary Lamar Alexander. 
 The report, released by the National Education Goals Panel, is the second in a series of 10 that will chart progress toward education goals that the nation is supposed to achieve by 2000. The panel is a bipartisan group made up of six governors, four members of the Bush Administration and four members of Congress.
American children at most age groups are achieving about the same scores they achieved for the last decade, although math and science scores improved slightly for children ages 9, 13 and 17, the report showed.
"We've got to have much more rigorous standards and raise expectations," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat who is a former chairman of the panel.
Today's report is likely to renew pressure for full financing of Head Start, since the panel's first goal is that all children should start school "ready to learn," which encompasses the need for early childhood nutrition, health and family programs.
 
6 Goals For the Year 2000
 The panel for the first goal has yet to define standards to assess progress, but its chairman, Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation on Teaching, said: "This report card is terribly flawed because it fails to take seriously the most important goal. Unless we get our policy toward mothers and babies straight, we're never going to have better schools."
The second goal calls for a 90 percent high school graduation rate. The report showed that although more high school students are entering college, the number of high school graduates has not increased. And a decline in the difference in high school completion rate between black and white students was countered by a rise in the number of Hispanic students without a high school diploma.
Goal three calls for American students to demonstrate competence in English, mathematics, science, history and geography, while the fourth goal calls for them to be first in the world in science and mathematics. The fifth calls for every American to be literate and possess the skills to compete in a global economy.
The final goal calls for every school to be free of drugs and violence and to offer a disciplined environment. The report showed that alcohol and cocaine use had declined among 12th graders, but that violence had increased in the same period.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Behind the Agency Review at Oldsmobile

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
OLDSMOBILE'S startling decision to consider changing agencies was not so much "a wake-up call" for the troubled car maker's longtime shop, says the vice president and general manager of the General Motors division, as it was a necessary response to Oldsmobile's poor showing in recent years.
"We shouldn't interpret the agency review as a lack of performance on the agency's part," John D. Rock, who became Oldsmobile's top executive in April, said in a frank telephone interview from Lansing, Mich., where the 95-year-old division is based. 
 "Oldsmobile had reached a point where the changes needed were of such a magnitude that everything got reviewed," he added.
Mr. Rock discussed Oldsmobile's plight, as well as his plans for the lagging division, in the wake of the unexpected disclosure on Sept. 18 that Oldsmobile would review its $110 million to $140 million account, which has been at Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago since 1967.
The last time a G.M. division dismissed an agency was in 1958, when competitors like Ford were still building Edsels and Chrysler was building DeSotos.
"Basically, when you try to do a repositioning, and do it correctly, you have to take a look at everything," he said. "We're reviewing ourselves."
That approach was applauded by Tom Dukes, director of competitive assessment at J. D. Power & Associates, the automotive consulting company in Agoura Hills, Calif.
Though the review is "precedent setting," he said, "it's not a simple matter of saying the fault lies with the agency or with the manufacturer."
"Is it the advertising?" he asked. "Or is it the product? Which came first, the chicken or the egg? It's a difficult call."
Oldsmobile's review follows a severe sales slump during which sales plunged 57.6 percent from 1985, their most recent peak year, through 1991.
Mr. Rock attributed that slide to "a lack of quality, reliability and durability in the mid-80's, when Oldsmobile was having those very successful years, selling 300,000-plus Cutlass Supremes to a very sophisticated group of buyers."
"I think we became probably the biggest owner group to build Honda," he said.
If anything, then, Burnett's advertising might have done its job too well, bringing customers into dealer showrooms to buy more than a million Oldsmobiles a year at precisely the time the products were inadequate and inferior.
"Your very success creates the difficulty," Mr. Rock said, likening the problem to that of a husband whose wife learns he had 25 affairs rather than a sole indiscretion: "Your chances are pretty slim of getting back in her good graces."
Mr. Rock, 56 years old, can afford to be forthcoming about Oldsmobile's mistakes -- he was elsewhere when they were being made. He joined Oldsmobile less than six months ago from a corporate G.M. position as vice president in charge of customer sales and service.
Still, the division has a special meaning to him; growing up, he worked at his father's Chevrolet-Oldsmobile dealership in South Dakota.
From 1987 to 1991, as general manager of the GMC Truck division, Mr. Rock demonstrated a proclivity for shaking up the status quo. Unhappy with GMC Truck's advertising, he encouraged his agency, McCann-Erickson Worldwide in Troy, Mich., to undertake a substantial reorganization, by acquiring a shop that handled the retail portion of the account and hiring Candace Robbins, GMC's truck advertising manager, to head the revamped operation.
Mr. Rock, who began working for G.M. in 1960, makes no secret of his admiration for Saturn, the auto giant's experiment in disrupting the status quo. Opened amid widespread doubts in 1988, Saturn now cannot build cars fast enough to meet demand.
He said he particularly admires Saturn's ability to "take the variance out of the retail environment," by offering friendly, no-haggling visits to dealerships.
"The early research data from consumers say they very much like that," he added. "If that's the case, and you're attempting to talk to nontraditional Oldsmobile owners, primarily import buyers, that atmosphere appeals even more to them."
"Can Oldsmobile become Saturn-esque?" he asked rhetorically, noting that "Saturn is America's newest car company; Oldsmobile is the oldest."
Mr. Rock said he "would envision Oldsmobile becoming more of a product line like Mazda," referring to the Japanese vehicle maker that specializes in niche models like the Miata convertible, but "with more plain, austere European styling."
His Oldsmobile of the future, he added, "is exemplified by Achieva," the division's recently introduced entry-level sedan and coupe, and by Aurora, a luxury model due in spring 1994.
"The natural question there is will the dogs eat the dog food," Mr. Rock said. "I wish I knew the answer to that.
"All I know is that business as usual is really not an option."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Merck Chairman Opposes 'Play or Pay' Health Plans

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
P. Roy Vagelos, head of the world's largest prescription drug maker, spoke yesterday against health care legislation that he said might endanger American leadership in medical research and innovative technology.
Dr. Vagelos, the chairman of Merck & Company, who presided at a campaign speech on health issues last week by Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, at Merck's headquarters in Rahway, N.J., criticized the financial implications of "play or pay" proposals. They would tax busineses that do not provide medical coverage to employees and use the money to finance coverage for those without insurance. 
 The play or pay approach has been endorsed by many Democrats in Congress, although it is not currently part of Mr. Clinton's program. Similar plans have been enacted, but not carried out, in Massachusetts and Oregon, and have been proposed in many other states. Dr. Vagelos contended that a national version could quickly lead to a Government-controlled system.
 
Fears Centralized System
 He said the initial tax increase would be about 9 percent of payrolls. Companies that already spend more than that would have an incentive to drop their coverage and pay the tax, adding to the public's share of health costs.
"We'd quickly slide into a centralized system," he said, involving the Government in approving investments in medical innovation. He said there had already been "a discouraging decrease" in research and development spending "by Government and most of the private sector."
"Innovation in biomedical research is every bit as crucial to achieving our health care goals as the investments that manufacturers make in research and development to increase their quality and productivity to stay competitive," Dr. Vagelos said. He made his remarks yesterday in a speech to business executives at the Detroit Economic Club.
Merck, which is spending more than $1 billion this year on research and development, has not endorsed a Presidential candidate. Dr. Vagelos, who has long been active in Democratic Party work, said the company would welcome a visit by President Bush.
Asserting that the inability of many Americans to get health care was "a national disgrace and a political time bomb," he said all poor unemployed people should be made eligible for Federal-state Medicaid assistance.
To help pay for the added coverage, he said, "it's also high time that we streamline our health-care system and bring it into the computer age." He said standardized insurance claim forms, electronic billing and data banks could save billions of the $800 billion a year in health spending.
Illnesses resulting from smoking add at least $65 billion a year to national health spending, he said. Preventive health measures, including auto seat belts, prenatal care and programs to slow the use of alcohol, tobacco and illegal drugs "could prevent two-thirds of all premature deaths," he added.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Hillary Clinton;
Hillary Clinton Fights Back With Punch Lines

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

 BODY:
Of all the unflattering things said about Hillary Clinton during the campaign season, she said yesterday, the cruelest blow was not criticism of her ambition or her headbands -- or even assertions that she is an enemy of the traditional family, insensitive to stay-at-home moms.
"The only one that really hurt, and one of the few that was really true, is that I'm middle-aged; I couldn't believe when I saw that in print," the 44-year-old wife of Gov. Bill Clinton said, drawing howls of laughter from the mostly female audience of 750 who paid $60 each to attend the Financial Women's Association of New York luncheon. "It was even meant to be a nice article" she said, "but gosh, I've got a few years left." 
 Mrs. Clinton, who has never been particularly well-known for her use of humor, on or off the stump, is still no Ann Richards. But at several junctures in an otherwise serious speech on children's issues, domestic violence and health care, she seemed to show a new jocularity.
 
An Early Celebration
 Asked how she would use her position as First Lady if her husband won the Presidency, she hoisted a bottle of mineral water and said, "Well, I'm going to have a drink here" before answering. Still laughing at her own joke, she went on to give her standard answer about working to be a voice for children in the White House.
Then, once again serious, she defended a decades-old paper on children's legal rights that Republican campaigners have interpreted as evidence that she would support the right of children to "divorce" their parents on a whim.
"Children are being exploited right now in the existing court system, whether they have any rights or not," she said, noting that welfare agencies were always able to sue parents on behalf of a child. And the whole issue of whether or not children can sue their parents would be moot, she said, if their problems were not ignored until court intervention became necessary.
On "family values," an early campaign issue that seems to have backfired on Republicans and even created a backlash against attacking Mrs. Clinton, she said, 'We have all this rhetoric at the national level about valuing children, yet we don't do very much to support children."
 
'A False Debate'
 "Family values begin with valuing families -- all kinds of families in all kinds of circumstances," she said, adding that finger-pointing about which families espouse true family values had been wholly counterproductive. "It's a false debate. There isn't anyone I know who doesn't believe families need strong values."
It was Mrs. Clinton's remarks about crime that drew the most enthusiastic response from the audience. In response to a question from a mother who said she worried about raising children in New York, Mrs. Clinton said many more police officers were needed on the street, and spoke of her own worry for her daughter Chelsea's safety, even during a short bicycle ride from the Governor's mansion to a Little Rock library.
She said Mr. Clinton's emphasis on increasing police protection was "one of the reasons why he's a different kind of Democrat."
After her speech Mrs. Clinton, who campaigned in Brooklyn earlier in the day, worked her way slowly through the crowd in the Grand Hyatt New York ballroom at Park Avenue and 42d Street, shaking hands with supporters. They included an older executive who said Mrs. Clinton had made her proud to be a woman, another who described herself as a "Wall Street economist" who would be forwarding her resume to the Clinton administration, and a young woman who whispered that she just wanted to touch Mrs. Clinton's green silk suit.
 
Reasons for Enthusiasm
 The enthusiasm was variously inspired. A fellow graduate of Wellesley College referred to the sisterhood, and a Republican who asked that her name not be used said she had been impressed by Mrs. Clinton's intelligence. Mary Robinson, of the Bank of New York, mentioned her impression that the speaker really cared about minority women.
Elsie Chan, the principal of Murry Bergtraum High School in Lower Manhattan, said Mrs. Clinton had won her over on many points. Among them: "I'm middle-aged, too."

HEADLINE: Further Prescriptions for the Convalescent Sears

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Sears, Roebuck & Company has tried to redirect its retail business, at times simply adding a brand name or two, at times mounting wholesale overhauls.
While Sears might receive an A+ for effort, however, many analysts would fail it for execution. Even though Sears on Tuesday announced plans to sell its securities business, Discover credit card and real estate operations, analysts say that a few additional basic, but sweeping, corrections are necessary for setting the $31.4 billion retail business back on its feet. 
 Following are questions about the company's situation, and the answers as seen by analysts:
Q. Sears stores generate enormous volume, but those sales dollars have not translated into profits. How can Sears force more of its sales dollars to the bottom line?
A. Sears has a higher expense structure than virtually any of its competitors. Last year it spent 29.2 percent of its revenues on salaries, light bills, advertising and other routine costs, while Kmart's expenses amounted to 19.6 percent of total sales and Wal-Mart's were an even leaner 15.3 percent.
Sears argues, with some justification, that as an older, more traditional retailer with more complex commitments to its employees, its cost structure cannot be compared with that of Wal-Mart, which evolved in a different era. But Kmart, which also has a long history, has done a better job of paring expenses.
Analysts praise Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman and chief executive, for making the tough decision to eliminate 48,000 jobs from the merchandising group by the end of this year, saving about $900 million annually. But so far, few of those savings have trickled down to the bottom line.
"The numbers aren't there yet because we're still in the process of seeing change occur," said Peter J. Siris, an analyst at UBS Securities. "But even if this recession persists, I think we'll see some marked improvement by the end of 1993."
Q. How can Sears rebuild its customer base?
A. While Americans of a certain age are still Sears devotees, baby boomers are less loyal. They may have worn Toughskins and Winnie the Pooh as children, but they are now sporting Gap and J. Crew. Some can even be found lurking about J. C. Penney, which has successfully managed to reshape itself.
Marketing consultants are puzzled as to why Sears has not capitalized on its legendary heritage. As the nation's first mail-order business and a general symbol of bedrock American values, Sears could use its advertising and marketing to play into the retro-1950's nostalgia that has swept the country.
"Sears has been such an integral part of the heartland and has always stood for value, and now we're back in a really value-oriented time," said Edwin D. Rice, executive marketing director at Landor Associates Inc., an image consulting firm based in San Francisco. "They need to tap into that."
Others suggest that Sears do more to build its market share among ethnic Americans.
Q. Why does Sears always seem to be a day late and a dollar short when it comes to innovation?
A. Edward A. Weller, a retail analyst at Montgomery Securities, likes to say that the main problem with Sears is that its managers and executives are "Sears-ized," -- so indoctrinated in the lore of past glories and so entrenched in an overwhelming bureaucracy that they cannot change easily. The result: Nothing happens quickly at Sears, which is why the company is continually playing catch-up with its competitors.
Mr. Weller and others believe that Sears's biggest challenge will be to radically alter its culture. And for the first time in many years, Sears is showing subtle signs of a personality change.
It has eliminated the elaborate structure that gave often-conflicting responsibilities to buyers, regional management and store managers, which stifled the flow of goods. Now responsibility is more linear, from buyers directly to the stores. Sears has also eliminated overlapping jobs by melding its corporate and merchandising staffs.
But its most visible change was the hiring last August of Arthur Martinez, formerly Saks Fifth Avenue vice chairman, as head of retail operations. While retail experts have debated the wisdom of selecting a financial man instead of an experienced merchant, they applaud the choice as a sign that Sears is willing to go outside for good ideas.
Q. How can Sears get away from its reliance on sales of washing machines, lawn mowers and power tools?
A. Sales of durable goods like major appliances, hardware, tires and electronics account for almost 70 percent of Sears' revenues from merchandise, which makes the company more vulnerable to troughs in the economy that most of its competitors.
Sears is notorious among retailing wags for displaying dresses next to lawn mowers or putting maternity clothes in the area next to petites. In a recent report about Sears, Mr. Siris at UBS Securities, said of Sears's women's department: "It has almost no major national brands, and it is not known as the place for fashion. Yet the women's business is the most profitable segment of Sears's merchandising."
Many consultants are convinced that Sears must find a way to make more of its money off sales of clothing and other "soft" goods, which generally earn a higher profit margin and are somewhat less subject to the vicissitudes of the economy.
"They have to supplement their hard lines with fashion -- fashion that's exciting, well-made, priced right," said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates Inc., a retail consultancy. "And they can't put it out three months after everyone else has marked it down for clearance."
Q. How did Sears lose its position as the largest retailer in America to Kmart and Wal-Mart?
A. When Sears made its initial attempts to correct its retail business in the mid-1970's, Kmart had always been the johnny-come-lately in the race for Middle America's shopping dollars, and Wal-Mmart had failed to attract much attention outside its home state of Arkansas.
Since then, Kmart has revamped its discount stores, giving them a sleeker, more contemporary look with bright lighting, bold signs and just enough trendy merchandise to make shoppers enjoy the experience. And it has bolstered the whole corporation by acquiring specialty-store chains like Waldenbooks, which it bought in 1984. Kmart even has a warehouse club, Pace, in its stable.
Meanwhile, Wal-Mart's conquest of legions of shoppers combined a commitment to consistent low prices, a down-home, service-oriented atmosphere and deft deployment of cutting-edge information systems that kept expenses to a minimum.
Sears was not as quick to adapt to the changing retail landscape. It dabbled in specialty-store formats starting in the early 1980's but did not commit itself to the concept until 1987.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate Race;
New Hampshire Governor Finds Himself the Issue

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H.

 BODY:
The discontent that chilled the Bush campaign in the New Hampshire primary has not abated, forcing another scion of New England Republicanism into a fight he didn't expect.
Gov. Judd Gregg, like his father before him, has won a string of easy election victories, for four terms in the House of Representatives and two more terms in the Statehouse. But now he is running for the Senate, at a time when his years of public service are shrouded by a sinking New Hampshire real estate market and a flurry of business failures that has cost 70,000 jobs in the last four years. 
 Local polls indicating that Mr. Gregg is running neck and neck with his Democratic opponent, John Rauh, show that voters thus far are treating the Senate race as a referendum on Mr. Gregg's performance as Governor. Mr. Rauh is a little-known retired corporate executive whose calls for price controls on health care and a 50 percent cut in the military budget have traditionally not been winning issues in this state of Yankee innkeepers and shipyard workers dependent on Pentagon largess.
No Democrat has won a senatorial election here since 1976, and few people here doubt that Senator Warren Rudman would have won re-election easily had he decided to run.
 
Voters Are Frustrated
 "The issue is Judd Gregg," said Tom Rath, a senior Concord Republican strategist. "As long as Rauh is not perceived as stunningly out of the mainstream, he can win it."
Mr. Rauh's surge relies on the frustrations of voters like Buck Howe, a 47-year-old Merrimack businessman whose printing concern has been forced to let go nine of its 12 employees. "The politicians are either in your body or in your wallet," he grumbled after meeting Mr. Rauh at a Hollis flea market. "I'm so fed up, Rauh looks pretty good."
The race is also a test for an electorate torn between anger and stoicism. Those who view New Hampshire's recession as one more natural blip in the business cycle are likely to vote for Mr. Gregg. Mr. Rauh's fortunes rest on the fear expressed by a growing number of people that New Hampshire is suffering a chronic downturn that will not bend unless government takes action.
No name is more identified with New Hampshire's steadfast commitment to low taxes and small government than Judd Gregg's.
 
'Change' Is No Mantra
 In a year when "change" has become a political mantra, Mr. Gregg steadfastly boosts President Bush and defends his record as governor, noting, "New Hampshire is doing better than our sister states."
"Since I've been in office," he said, "we're the slowest-growing state government in the region.
Mr. Gregg's charges that Mr. Rauh represents values outside the New Hampshire mainstream have been overshadowed recently by reports that the Governor avoided service in Vietnam because his father applied pressure to keep him out of the military. In response, Mr. Gregg said he deserved his deferments and ultimate exclusion from the draft because he suffered acne, sleepwalking and injured knees.
The Governor is a plodding campaigner, clearly uncomfortable with the retail style of campaigning that still characterizes New Hampshire politics in the television age. He dutifully shook hands up and down tables at a Manchester Greek-American festival recently but made little more than perfunctory chit-chat with voters. When confronted by a man who complained about mounting real estate taxes, he rolled his eyes dismissively, told him residents in Massachusetts pay more, and brusquely moved on.
 
Descendants of Poachers?
 But Mr. Gregg reminds voters that he is the torch carrier of the anti-government heritage that goes back to the days when outlaw poachers of the English kings' forests settled here.
Watching Mr. Gregg mount a 16-year-old Sellefrancis horse at the inauguration of a riding school for the disabled in Goffstown, Norm Chase, a 35-year-old engineer, said he would vote for the Governor because he is against government waste. "He's what New Hampshire tradition has been: conservatism," Mr. Chase said.
Mr. Rauh is a more engaging campaigner, but he spends so much time talking to each individual voter at campaign stops his aides fret that he is not shaking enough hands. Having come to New Hampshire from Cincinnati only six years ago, he still speaks with a Midwestern accent and may be vulnerable to the Republican charge that he is a carpetbagger.
While taking some unconventionally liberal positions, he has tried to tailor his campaign in a way that fits New Hampshire traditions. He tells voters he strongly backs a line-item veto and a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, and a capital gains cut for long-term business investments.
And while he wants the Federal Government to invest in more public works, like a high-speed rail between the New Hampshire coast and Boston, Mr. Gregg has embraced the message of the anti-politician.
"The public does not trust the President, the Congress, the two parties -- and I think they are right," he told a group of truckers at a recent forum. "Both parties have fallen in love with this miserable game of politics."

HEADLINE: Unusual Conditions Cloud Prospects for Rate Cut

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
With declines in retail sales, factory orders and consumer confidence expected to be capped later this week by a less-than-stellar unemployment report, conditions seem right for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again this Friday, after the jobless rate is released.
But don't bet on it. The Fed under Alan Greenspan has often cut rates as soon as poor jobless reports followed a wave of other bad economic news. But this time, a lively debate inside the central bank that has divided its governors and unusual outside pressures cloud the prospects for a rate cut. 
 In recent interviews, Fed officials indicated that there are definite tensions on the central bank's board, with some governors open to further rate cuts and others leaning against them. According to these officials, some Fed officials believe more easing may be needed to revive the torpid economy, while others assert that enough easing has been done already.
 
Dissatisfaction on Economy
 "We have put quite a bit of additional easing into the system over the past few months," said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Fed. Still, he acknowledged, Fed members remain dissatisfied with the anemic state of the economy. "Recent data have been a bit on the weak side," he said.
The Fed has rarely faced outside pressures like the recent turmoil on the world's currency markets. Europe's currency crisis has finally started to simmer down, and a Fed rate cut now could throw new fuel on that fire.
What is more, the dollar is at a record low against the Japanese yen and is approaching new lows against the German mark. Fed officials might be reluctant to cut rates further because that might help turn the dollar's slide into a nose dive.
Complicating matters is the November election. If the Fed cuts rates on Friday, it will no doubt be criticized for trying to help its friend in the White House.
Nonetheless, if the employment report is bad enough, economists say, Mr. Greenspan will have little problem lining up the Fed's seven governors to support a further rate cut.
"There's no question that payroll employment is the key factor in Fed thinking," said David M. Jones, chief economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities firm. "I think Greenspan will play it by ear depending on what happens with the job numbers."
The Fed cut rates on July 2 when the jobless rate jumped to 7.8 percent, its highest rate in eight years. It lowered the discount rate -- the rate at which it lends to banks -- by one-half point, to 3 percent, and it pushed down the Federal funds rate -- the rate commercial banks charge each other for overnight loans -- by one-half point, to 3.25 percent.
Two months later, when the Sept. 4 jobless report showed that private-sector employment had plunged by 167,000 jobs, the Fed pushed the Federal funds rate down further, to 3 percent. The discount rate and Federal funds rate are now at their lowest levels in almost three decades.
Most economists expect Friday's report on September employment to show a decline in overall payroll employment because of the end of a Government summer jobs program that employed 150,000 youths.
 
Assessing the Odds
 "We think that if the payroll numbers, after factoring out the summer jobs program, are up 50,000, then the Fed won't ease further," said Elliott Platt, chief economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. "But if the payroll numbers are flat or down, we think they will ease."
Mr. Platt suggested that the Fed's first worry was domestic. "If the job numbers are bad, we think the Fed will take the risk of a rate cut whatever the repercussions in foreign exchange markets," he said.
An American rate cut would aggravate European currency tensions by widening the gap between low American rates and high German rates. The higher yield available in Germany makes German investments attractive, causing investors to move money out of other currencies and into German marks. That puts pressure on some countries to raise their own rates to keep their currencies from sliding against the mark.
In an interview, the vice chairman, Mr. Mullins, said Fed members were "studying" the dollar's weakness "very carefully."
"One worries most when you see the weakness in the dollar reflected in the bond market and stock market," he said.
Some economists suggest that no matter how bad the job numbers are, the Fed might wait before acting until its open market committee meets on Tuesday. That committee, the Fed's main policy-setting group, includes the seven Fed governors and the presidents of five of the 12 Federal Reserve districts.
Mr. Mullins and other Fed officials expressed optimism that the economy was slowly picking up as consumers and businesses reduce debt burdens.
"We're making measurable progress in working our way through the deleveraging process," he said.
Mr. Greenspan has often described the debt burden as a head wind slowing the economy's progress.
Lawrence E. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, said in an interview, "The head wind is probably blowing fairly strongly, but our weather map suggests that the barometric pressure is going to improve, and the winds will diminish as we move forward."
Fed officials say there is some disagreement among governors about how to interpret money supply figures. Some governors are said to worry that a strong pickup in M-1 -- a narrow sector of the money supply that includes cash and checking deposits -- presages an economic rebound and high inflation, while others look far more to M-2, a broader sector of the money supply that is growing more slowly.
Fed officials said whatever differences existed on the board were in interpreting the data rather than in fundamental philosophy.
Economists suggested that the Fed officials leaning most against further easing were John P. LaWare, a governor, and Thomas C. Melzer, president of the St. Louis district. At the open market committee meeting last July 1, they were the only dissenters tofurther easing. They argued that this policy placed excessive emphasis on short-term concerns and might undermine the Fed's long-term inflation-fighting credibility.
But many economists and Government officials say lower rates are the best hope for the stalled economy.
"Some additional easing would be helpful," said Henry Kaufman, head of an economics consulting firm in New York. "It would reduce debt burdens. It would reduce the cost of financing. And I think the fears of spurring new inflation are overstated."
Many economists say the Fed, having cut rates on Sept. 4, just two months before the election, would probably feel little inhibition about cutting rates on Friday, just one month before Election Day.
Besides, the economists say, Fed officials can argue that there is no way any rate cuts this week would help the economy and President Bush before Election Day. Most economists say it takes at least three months for the stimulating effects of rate cuts to start coursing their way through the economy.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Candidate Bush Is Holding Back

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE economy is under water, and judging by the polls, so is the Bush re-election campaign. Is there no way for George Bush to regain the initiative?
Any President is obviously at a disadvantage running on his record in the midst of a recession. And this President is at particular risk because this recession threatens his natural constituency -- white-collar workers who never before imagined that the jobs lost could be their own. 
 But Mr. Bush's sometime allies on the economic right are still puzzled by his failure to fight with all the weapons at hand. The uncertain fate of two radical proposals, which have been bouncing from desk to desk in the White House for months, illustrate the grip of inertia on his Administration.
The capital gains coup. The President's apparent cure of choice for all that ails the economy, repeated so often that it has taken on the quality of a mantra, is a cut in the tax on capital gains. But Congress is not about to give him what he wants -- at least not unless it is attached to a tax increase on the ordinary income of the rich. And by most accounts, the contest is firmly stalemated.
Most accounts, but not all. Paul Craig Roberts, a Treasury official in the Reagan Administration who still carries the supply-side banner into political battle, suggested six months ago that the President could cut the effective tax rate on capital gains by executive order. And a high-powered Washington law firm hired by the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Taxpayers Union thinks he has a point.
The idea is to index capital gains to inflation, taxing only the portion of the gain in value that exceeds the change in the general price level. Thus a stock bought in the early 60's for $10 and sold today for $30 would not be taxed at all because the price level tripled in the interim.
Congress plainly never intended the tax code to be interpreted this way. But lawyers from the firm of Shaw, Pittman, Potts & Trowbridge concluded that ambiguities in the wording had left an opening for reinterpretation. Thus a Treasury decision to tax only indexed gains "should and would be upheld judicially."
In any case, there might never be a serious challenge. Congress would not be likely to muster a veto-proof majority to reverse the Administration's interpretation. And private citizens opposed to indexing would have great difficulty gaining the legal standing to force a decision by the courts.
Economists are of two minds on the policy issue. Isabel Sawhill of the Urban Institute points out that the "benefits would be heavily tilted toward the rich." But she acknowledges that indexing is "a sensible thing to do in principle," as part of a broader package of reforms to make the tax code inflation-neutral.
But the suburbanites in states from New Jersey to Texas who will determine Mr. Bush's fate would probably be delighted with the tax break. And even if the initiative went down in flames in court, it would help to recast the President as a mover and a shaker.
Why, then, has the White House chosen not to act? Jude Wanniski, the president of Polyconomics, dismisses the legalist arguments offered by the Treasury Department. The core opposition, he insists, is coming from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the budget director, Richard G. Darman, who are simply defending their turf against supply-side intruders.
Kill the lawyers. With the possible exceptions of "tax-and-spend liberals" and the Democratic platform writers who omitted the G-word, candidate Bush has reserved his harshest words for trial lawyers. That ought to make the auto insurance reform drafted by Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia and Michael Horowitz of the Manhattan Institute pure campaign gold.
The O'Connell-Horowitz plan offers an enticing solution to a problem that dogs virtually every American: the escalating cost of auto liability insurance. Instead of insuring themselves against negligence suits, drivers would, by Federal mandate, be given the option of insuring themselves against their own purely economic losses in auto accidents.
While those who took the option would give up the remote chance of a giant payoff from a lawsuit, compensation for injuries from one's own insurance company would be sure and swift. And the savings in legal fees and pain and suffering awards would cut overall auto insurance costs by an estimated 20 to 30 percent. "Can you imagine what people could do with the extra $30 billion?" Mr. Horowitz asked.
Unlike capital gains indexing, the auto insurance initiative is not dead in White House waters. Indeed, it is likely to show up one of these days in a Bush campaign speech. But one of these days is, by any reckoning, very late. If heaven helps only those who help themselves, the President is in deep trouble.

HEADLINE: Tax Burden Is No Lighter After Efforts of 80's

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
President Bush has recently been hammering his Democratic rival for harboring plans to raise taxes. Gov. Bill Clinton, in turn, says he is only aiming at the truly rich. He, like the President, has wrapped himself in the flag of middle-class tax relief.
But the latest research on the effects of the sweeping tax changes in the last decade -- from the 1981 tax cut through the 1990 budget deal -- illustrates how elusive the goal of easing middle-America's tax burden can be. New evidence shows that despite repeated efforts at lowering Federal taxes, the average American family's Federal tax burden -- including Social Security, corporate and excise taxes -- has failed to shrink at all. 
 The average effective Federal tax rate amounted to 23.3 percent in 1980, according to three economists from the Congressional Budget Office, Richard Kasten, Frank Sammartino and Eric Toder, who recently presented their findings at a conference of public finance specialists at the University of Michigan. That figure hovered within a narrow band, but never dropped below 21.7 percent. Today it is 23.2 percent, virtually where it was 12 years ago before a nationwide tax revolt helped sweep Ronald Reagan into the White House.
When people think about taxes, they tend to think of income taxes, because they are the biggest share of most people's tax payments as well as the most visible one, a beast to be battled every April. But as Federal income taxes have been trimmed and the Federal Government has raised the ante in other areas, economists have increasingly felt it useful to include the whole range of payments that Washington exacts to get a more realistic measure of the levy on the population.
So the new calculations include not only income taxes -- which have shrunk as a portion of the American family's income, but also Social Security, excise and corporate taxes. Although the latter three are paid all or in part by companies, economists point out that they are borne, ultimately, by individuals, as customers or shareholders.
These calculations also depart from earlier assessments of the changing tax burden because they focus on families and the burden borne by different groups of families. In measuring the effective tax rate, the economists consider a family's total Federal taxes divided by its pretax income -- which is the broadest measure of a person's tax burden.
What the figures showed, said William Gale, an economist at the Brookings Institution and one of the commentators at the Michigan conference, is that
"in some ways, nothing much changed."
That is not to say that there were no significant changes within the overall totals. Income taxes shrank as a portion of family income from 1980 to 1992, but that was offset by a sharp expansion in payroll taxes. The burden of corporate taxes on American families fell somewhat, while excise taxes edged up.
The fact that the total Federal tax burden has ended up where it started was caused by income, consumption and demographic trends as well as changes in the tax law. In particular, incomes grew too slowly to lighten the overall tax load. Pretax income rose 1.5 percent a year after inflation on average and less than half that pace for more than two-thirds of American families.
But mostly the problem was that for every tax cut, there was a tax increase. Washington, after all, was spending a growing share of national output. A Reagan tax increase in 1982, called the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, vies with the much-lamented Bush tax increase, the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990, as one of the country's biggest tax increases.
The conclusion that the more the tax code changed, the more the overall tax burden stayed the same reflects a broad consensus among dozens of the nation's top public finance experts on how the tax decade affected family tax burdens and aftertax incomes.
This view was reflected at the mid-September gathering of many of these experts, mostly middle of the roaders from government, academia and think tanks with no particular ideological ax to grind. They were meeting in Ann Arbor, Mich., to ponder the latest evidence -- much of it available for analysis only in the last year or so -- and to weigh the "fairness" issue, which has become a factor in the election.
"Reagan broke the 'no-new-taxes' pledge long before Bush," said C. Eugene Steuerle, a former Treasury official under President Reagan and author of a recent book, "The Tax Decade," chronicling the 1980's tax changes. "The Government promised to deliver higher benefits and lower taxes," Mr. Steuerle said. "If you promise too much, something has to give."
On the other hand, the experts agreed, Republican tax policies contributed only marginally to the income squeeze on poor and middle- class families. "The consensus is that growth in inequality was not due to changes in tax rates," said Joel Slemrod, director of the Office of Tax Policy Research at the University of Michigan's business school and the organizer of the conference. The trouble, he said, was declining wages at the bottom and stagnating pay in the middle.
Barring a new willingness to scale back Washington's obligations, the evidence suggests that promises of broad tax relief hold the same chance of payoff as circulars from groups like Publishers Clearinghouse announcing million-dollar prize winners. It also suggests that tinkering with the tax code would do little, if anything, to reverse the stagnation of middle class incomes, a prime cause of voter discontent and pessimism.
In fact, the last decade has been one that saw extensive remolding of tax policy, including five major Congressional tax bills, a basement-to-roofbeams Social Security overhaul and thousands of alterations too minor to attract much public notice. All this changed things less than people have thought.
The 1981 Economic Recovery and Tax Act slashed the top marginal income tax rate -- the rate paid on the last dollar of income -- from 70 percent to 50 percent and reduced all other brackets by nearly a quarter. The 1986 Tax Reform Act went even further, replacing numerous brackets with three -- 15 percent, 28 percent and 33 percent -- aiming benefits at low-income families and eliminating hundreds of tax loopholes.
In between, however, came three large consecutive tax increases -- in 1982, 1983 and 1984 -- aimed at reining in the runaway Federal deficit. More tax increases followed the 1987 stock market crash and the 1990 Saddam Hussein invasion of Kuwait.
Income taxes -- which helped touch off a taxpayer revolt that preceded Ronald Reagan's election -- did decline, from 12.3 percent of pretax income to 10.9 percent with the biggest breaks at the bottom of the income ladder.
 
Payroll Taxes Swell
 But other Federal taxes rose by exactly as much. "Highly visible taxes were cut, but less visible taxes went up," Mr. Steuerle said.
 In particular, payroll taxes swelled form 7.2 percent of income to 8.9 percent as the Social Security tax rates jumped to 15.3 percent of ages up to $55,000, counting both employee and employer contributions. And corporate and excise taxes, which are declined and then rose again.
 To be sure, the public finance experts are not saying that today's Federal tax system is not in many ways superior to the 1980 tax system. Ineffective and inefficient 70 percent top tax rates are no more. Ditto for much of the real estate tax shelter industry. And for millions of families, filing income taxes is a lot simpler. Indeed, some would argue, the stubbornly high tax burden was one of the few things that did not change for the better.

HEADLINE: Fall in New Home Sales Discounted by Analysts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell to an annual rate of 570,000 units in August, a steep drop despite soft prices and the lowest mortgage rates in nearly 20 years. But after close scrutiny, analysts found in the numbers scant evidence of further deterioration of the housing market, concluding that it was essentially flat.
"Although they appear to show a decline," said Mark H. Obrinsky, senior economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, "this has more to do with Commerce Department methodology than to the state of demand for homes." 
 The data on sales of new homes have become increasingly unreliable because of the Government's inability to adjust to changes in the market, specifically to the fact that builders are reluctant at a time of sluggish business to put up homes without a sales contract.
 
July Decline Reversed
 Skepticism about today's report arose on various counts, including a sizable upward revision that transformed the decline initially reported for July into an advance, and the fact that the Commerce Department deemed any change of less than 10 percent to be statistically insignificant.
The 570,000 sales rate in August compared with 607,000 in July, indicating a 6.1 percent drop. But when compared with the first reading for July of a 563,000 rate, the August pace was slightly higher.
The statistical surveys are based on samples of building permits, and in many cases sales have been made before the issuance of permits.
"We're seeing a lot more of that," said Audrey Harmon, a Census Bureau statistician. She said the agency tried to allow for this factor but had underestimated it. The sample, she added, was designed to pick up only one of each 40 permits issued, with none included for homes built on a consumer's own land.
The result has been upward revisions for every month during the last year, a phenomenon analysts said they expected to show up again in the September figures.
Some analysts combined the latest figures for July and August, which they found to be 3.7 percent higher than those for May and June. But Ms. Harmon, whose agency states that it takes four months to establish a trend for sales of new homes, was skeptical that this exercise was meaningful.
The Government's housing report showed sales rose in the Northeast to an annual rate of 72,000 from 67,000, and in the Midwest to 120,000 from 115,000. But these gains were offset by declines in the South, to 238,000 from 251,000, and in the West, to 140,000 from 174,000.
At the end of the month, there were 272,000 unsold new homes, or a 5.8-month supply at the latest sales pace. This compared with 273,000 in July, a 5.6-month supply. The 1992 peak was in April, when the inventory represented a 6.2-month supply.
Prices rose for those homes that sold in August but not enough to regain June levels. Both the median and average prices rose $3,000, to $121,000 and $140,200, respectively, compared with $122,900 and $146,000 in June, and $118,000 and $137,200 in July.
The actual number of sales in August, with no annualization or seasonal adjustment, was 50,000, down 1,000 from July and 3,000 from June, the report published jointly by the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development showed.
Through August, sales of new homes ran 18 percent ahead of the 1991 pace.
Upon revision, the annual sales rate is now 554,000 for May, 581,000 for June and 607,000 for July. The initial estimate was for a 2.6 percent decline for July, but the new figures showed a 4.5 percent increase.

HEADLINE: 6 Canadian Banks Post Big Rise in Prime Rate

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Canada's leading banks, reacting to volatility in financial markets caused by fears that voters would turn down a constitutional referendum in October, today announced the biggest single recorded jump in interest rates since the Depression.
The six banks, led by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and the Bank of Montreal, raised their benchmark prime rate by two percentage points, to 8.25 percent, in a move widely expected to hurt consumer and investor confidence here. 
 Joining the rate rise later in the day were the Toronto-Dominion Bank, the Bank of Nova Scotia, the Royal Bank of Canada and the National Bank of Canada.
As in the United States, where it stands around 6 percent, the prime rate here sets the trend for business and consumer borrowing costs throughout the economy.
 
An Emotional Debate
 "The reality here," said Warren Jestin, chief economist for the Bank of Nova Scotia, "is that the constitutional debate has become highly emotional, and its outcome is uncertain, making markets extraordinarily volatile. Once the referendum is over, conditions should be calmer and rates might fall again."
Canadians will vote Oct. 26 on an agreement reached by political leaders on Aug. 28 aimed at amending the constitution to keep Quebec from separating. Polls show that the referendum, which needs approval of all provinces, will be defeated in Quebec, British Columbia and Alberta.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has warned that a no vote would begin the process of dismantling the country. The Royal Bank of Canada calculated in a report published Friday that such a breakup would add 720,000 people to the 1.3 million already unemployed and that 1.25 million Canadians would emigrate to the United States.
 
Central Bank Actions
 The rate increase was also touched off by the actions Tuesday of Canada's central bank, the Bank of Canada, in tightening money to defend a plummeting Canadian dollar. During the day Tuesday, the dollar fell below 80 United States cents, to a four-year low of 79.50 cents. Over the last year, the Canadian dollar has fallen from a high of nearly 90 cents. It closed today at 80.24 cents, up 0.24 cent from Tuesday's close.
"There was a growing sense in the market that if rates didn't rise significantly, there would be an all-out repatriation of funds from Canada," noted Rob Palombi, an economist for MMS International, a financial information services concern in Toronto. "There was a need to stabilize the panic flows."
But the rate increase was about the last thing that Canada's weak economy needed. As in the United States, economic activity here has been lackluster and unemployment is running at 11.6 percent of the labor force.
 
Report of No Growth
 The dramatic rise in rates came as Statistics Canada, an economic agency similar to the Commerce Department, reported zero growth in July, following a slight rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in the value of goods and services produced in June.
Still, the financial news for Canadians was not universally bleak. A lower dollar helps big exporters, particularly the natural-resource companies in western Canada, and reduces incentives for those who have been crossing the border to shop for bargains in the United States.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed on Light Day; Report on U.S. Jobs Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday in light trading as the market awaited further indications on the direction of the American economy.
Gold prices fell a bit. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell 40 cents to $347.80. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price of $348.30 a troy ounce, down 20 cents. 
 Traders said there was little news to affect the currency market. Traders are awaiting tomorrow's scheduled release of September unemployment figures from the Government for more insight into the economy's health.
"That's a big number for the short-term direction of the market," said Peter Wild, a trader with the New York office of Bank Julius Baer & Company.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 119.25 yen, down 0.40 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 119.55 yen. In New York, the dollar traded at 119.85 yen in late afternoon, up from 119.31 late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7805, from $1.7705 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound traded at $1.7865, cheaper than $1.7895 the day before.
In Europe, the dollar fell to 1.4145 German marks, from 1.4220 the day before. In New York, one dollar bought 1.4100 German marks, down from 1.4110.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.2355 Swiss francs, up from 1.2278; 4.7695 French francs, up from 4.7665; 1,223 Italian lire, up from 1,199, and 1.24675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.25275.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $348.75 a troy ounce, from $347.45 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $348.70, from $348.50 bid late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.46 to close at a bid $349.09.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Washington State Refunding Issue

 BODY:
The Washington Public Power Supply System tentatively priced $637.6 million of tax-exempt refunding revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The financing, which is intended to refund various bonds sold when interest rates were higher, is broken down into three separate projects. 
 For Nuclear Project 1, the maximum yield is 6.518 percent for an issue due in 2015. Another long maturity due in 2017, which is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, is priced to yield 6.39 percent.
Serial bonds with shorter maturities are priced to yield from 3.20 percent in 1993 to 4.90 percent in 1997, 5.75 percent in 2002, 6.25 percent in 2007 and 6.40 percent in 2011 and 2012.
The bonds for Nuclear Project 2 are priced to yield a maximum 6.47 percent for an issue due in 2012, with serial bonds priced to yield from 3.90 percent in 1994 to 6.30 percent in 2010. Bonds due in 2009 and 2010 are insured by M.B.I.A.
Bonds for Nuclear Project 3 are priced to yield from 3.20 percent in 1993 to 5.20 percent in 1998.
Underwriters noted that the financing was rated AA by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, except for the insured securities, which were rated AAA.

HEADLINE: The Russian Art World Is Feeling The Troubles of Its Country

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Two weeks before the 800 artworks in the "Great Utopia" show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum were to be shipped from Moscow, the Government's Ministry of Culture was dissolved. Russian museum officials said that almost put an end to the show, which is composed of works of the Russian and Soviet avant-garde from 1915 to 1932 drawn from 72 institutions throughout the former Soviet Union.
Eventually, the museums delivered the works on their own, without the expected financial support from a central Government, and the show opened on schedule in Manhattan on Friday. But many of the regional museums participating in the show had received more lucrative offers from other nations for the loan of their holdings and threatened to pull out.
 
Where Chaos Prevails
 
 "I had to go to one museum and kidnap the paintings to get them here," said a Russian museum official who came to New York for the opening of the show. "I got three huge crates on the plane by stating that they were my hand luggage."
Getting art from Russia to New York is only a small part of the problems faced by museum officials in Russia these days. A number of them have been in town for the opening Guggenheim show, and most had stories of their own about the troubles, and occasionally the chaos, which now beset their world.
"We still have party functionaries who know nothing about art serving as the directors of some provincial museums," said one museum official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "In some cases, these museums have very valuable holdings, things that were sent to them from St. Petersburg and Moscow in the 1920's in order to hide them. The directors don't know what they have, and they don't know how to raise money to take care of what they have. In some instances, you could say there is chaos."
Anetta Bass, who served for 30 years as director of the State Art Museum, in Kuibyshev, on the left bank of the Volga, and is now the deputy director in charge of research, was defensive about this claim, as were several of her colleagues. "Our museum world is not chaotic," she said. "The chaos is elsewhere, in the economy. For 60 years when nobody was allowed to see these treasures, we kept them in good condition, and now, we are able to show them."
Miss Bass, who wears a look of perpetual defiance, said she had just been hired at the museum in Kuibyshev, a few months before Stalin's death in 1953 when she was ordered to destroy all avant-garde works in the the museum's collection. "I managed to preserve them," she said. "If I had been caught, it would have meant jail or worse."
Economic woes are worse than bureaucratic difficulties. As the chief of the All-Russian Artistic Production Association, which supervises all international exhibitions participated in by Russian museums, Zelfira Tregulova is among the most influential offials in the Russian art world. Yet until a few weeks ago, when she received a raise, Miss Tregulova said her monthly salary of 1,600 rubles, about a third of the average Russian wage, would last her only two weeks. Even at that, she said, she was doing much better than most of her colleagues because she holds a Ph.D. and has a relatively high administrative post. Asked how she made ends meet, she rolled her eyes and said: "Translations. Anything I can get."
Vladimir A. Gusev, the dour-faced director of the State Russian Museum of St. Petersburg, declared without amusement that "disasterous economic developments, especially inflation" are "forcing me to become a capitalist." Thus, his institution is the first of the major museums in Russia to have opened what is a fixture in virtually every American museum: a gift shop.
Furthermore, he said, an object of his visit to New York had been to meet with his counterparts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to arrange the production and sale of copies of old Russian porcelain. "This can provide us with tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars," he said.
Mr. Gusev also expressed concern that in the present economic turmoil, in which runaway inflation has hurt the well-to-do no less than wage-earners, privately held artworks are leaving the country at an uncontrollable rate.
"I don't mean the legitimate art market, which developed about four years ago when Sotheby's opened an office in Moscow," he said. "I mean that when the Iron Curtain fell, illegal exports increased greatly."
Although he said he was unable to cite specific examples, Mr. Gusev said that much of the Russian art now being sold abroad are masterworks that in normal times might be expected to be donated or bequeathed -- or sold -- to Russian museums.
Several of the Russian officials interviewed insisted their world was not without its lighter moments. Inna Balakhovskaya, who works in the All-Russian Artistic Production Association, said it took high-powered persuasion before she was permitted to include a huge birdlike construction by Vladimir Tatlin in the "Utopia" show.
Tatlin's visionary sculpture, created from 1928 to 1932, was being kept at in an aircraft museum about 80 miles outside Moscow. It took six visits, Miss Balakhovskaya said, to convince the authorities that the construction, now suspended from the Guggenheim's ceiling, was a visionary work of art rather than a highly classified space vehicle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Zelfira Tregulova in front of a group of paintings by Kasimir Malevich at the Guggenheim Museum. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Archbishop Asks for Film Guidelines

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 30

 BODY:
In an unusual 40-page pastoral letter, Roger Cardinal Mahony, the Archbishop of Los Angeles, challenged the entertainment industry today to adopt general guidelines for the depiction of violence, sex, family life and the treatment of women.
Implicitly criticizing the movie industry for an avalanche of films that "pander to baser instincts," Cardinal Mahony, who leads the largest archdiocese in the nation, with 3.5 million Catholics, went out of his way to insist that he rejected censorship or a return to the kind of production code, specifically governing how film makers deal with sex and other issues, that dominated the movie industry for decades. 
 Instead, the 56-year-old Hollywood-born cleric said the movie industry should voluntarily arrive at a way to assume its social and artistic responsibilities. In doing so, film executives should adhere to "general criteria" on such subjects as sex and violence, he said.
"The golden rule applies here," said Cardinal Mahony. "Responsible film makers will not do to their audiences what they would not want done to themselves -- or to their own teen-age sons or daughters."
There was no advance notice of the contents of Cardinal Mahony's message, but the reaction of a number of people in the film industry was one of relief that the message was not marked by more drastic proposals. Cardinal Mahony has a reputation for outspokenness, controversy and activism. And in the wake of recent comments about "family values" by Vice President Dan Quayle and other Republicans, the movie industry has been especially edgy.
By midday today, most studio chiefs had not yet received Cardinal Mahony's letter. But Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, the industry's lobbying group, received an early copy, and commented: "What the Cardinal said is wise, reasonable and thoughtful. He's not calling for a censorship board. What he wants to do is lift the level of quality in motion pictures. Who can argue with that?"
Other executives said privately, however, that while Cardinal Mahony's points might be instructive, they could not be expected to have a major impact on an industry driven by a need for blockbuster hits.
Specifically, Cardinal Mahony said that movie makers should adhere to "specific criteria" in certain subjects. In dealing with a movie's portrayal of women, for example, he asked: "How are the women in the story portrayed? Are they persons possessing the same intrinsic dignity as their male counterparts and, at the deepest level, facing the same soul wrenching challenges to grow and become aware. Is the unique vocation of motherhood given its proper due? Are the agonizing pressures and tensions of working mothers, especially those who must educate, nurture, and support their children, alone explored with sensitivity, candor and compassion?"
In dealing with sexuality, he asked the film industry to ask itself: "Does the picture convey the beauty of authentic sexuality, or does it demean this very important part of being human? Would you want your teen-age children to see this picture? How about their friends?"
On the issue of violence, Cardinal Mahony asks: "Is the violence demanded by the story? Is it presented as a desirable way to solve problems and resolve conflict? Is it presented honestly? Do we see the cowardice at the heart of it? Do we feel the pain and dehumanization it causes to the person on the receiving end, and to the person who engages in it?"
Although Cardinal Mahony said his message was also designed to cover the television industry, the bulk of his comments were directed at the movie business. The Cardinal said he would commit Catholic educational institutions in Los Angeles, the two Archdiocesan newspapers, the National Catholic News Service and the full resources of the Archdiocese to making the effort a priority.
 
A Papal Address
 Aides to Cardinal Mahony said that the pastoral letter was begun five months ago and was unrelated to the "family values" debate that has simmered in the Presidential campaign. The Cardinal issued the letter, they said, to observe the fifth anniversary of the address given by Pope John Paul II to leaders of the entertainment industry in Los Angeles. In that address, the Pope urged Hollywood to use its immense power to "enrich the whole of the human community."
During his seven years as archbishop of Los Angeles, Cardinal Mahony has been an outspoken, energetic and ideologically unpredictable figure. Bill Rivera, his spokesman at the Archdiocese, described him as a liberal on social activism issues and right of center on theological matters.
The leadership of the film community -- with whom he periodically meets -- was startled last February when Cardinal Mahony appeared to support a "decency code," proposed by a fundamentalist group, that would forbid such things as suggestive dancing and lustful kissing. But Cardinal Mahony's associates said his comments had been misinterpreted, and he later said that he opposed a code.
Cardinal Mahony insisted today that the "human values" he seeks in films were hardly controversial. "The criteria I articulate here, and the values that underlie them, are the exclusive property of no one religious community, ethnic grouping, educational level, economic class or political party," he said. "Certainly the Catholic Church has no monopoly on them."
