HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Woodpecker's Brain Survives, but Will Humans'?

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

The Diversity of Life
By Edward O. Wilson
Illustrated. 424 pages. Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $29.95.
In many respects, Edward O. Wilson's important new book, "The Diversity of Life," is a celebration of the miracle of evolution and the astonishing inventiveness of natural selection. You suspect that he's building a case to show how little we know of the environment's complexity and how recklessly we are spending the abundance of nature's storehouse. 
 Still, you want to concentrate on the wonders that Mr. Wilson unfolds. There is, for example, his account of why the acorn woodpecker of California keeps its brain intact despite hitting wood with its bill at 20 to 25 kilometers an hour (12 to 15 miles an hour), "whereupon it instantaneously decelerates at 1,000G, where 1G is the acceleration needed to counteract earth's gravity and 4G is what an astronaut experiences on liftoff." The woodpecker survives because its brain case acts as a shock absorber and because its body moves in a single plane like a metronome, avoiding rotational forces that would tear its brain loose from its moorings.
There's his description of how spiders travel through the air by spinning out web filaments long enough to be picked up and carried by the wind like a balloon. And there's his tribute to the evolutionary diversity of sharks, which range from the magnificent great white to the little cookie-cutter, which "thrusts its maw into the bodies of its victims and twists to slice out five-centimeter-wide conical plugs of skin and flesh." In other words, a two-inch cookie.
But then about halfway through "The Diversity of Life," you come to a chart that traces the full geological history of life from four billion years ago to the present. At intervals along a horizontal line there appear little lightning bolts to designate when "biodiversity was sharply reduced by the great extinction spasms." There are six of these in all. The first, for example, appears 450 million years ago at the dividing line between the Ordovician Period and the Silurian. The fifth marks the cataclysmic end of the Age of Reptiles, some 65 million years ago. But here's the shocker: The last lightning bolt appears just to the right of zero years ago, or a few decades from now. We are coming up on the sixth "major extinction spasm" in the history of life on earth.
This casts a considerable pall over the story Mr. Wilson is telling. The more you think about it, the more you realize that even the good news is bad. For instance, the good news is that the struggle to protect elephants or whales is not merely about saving these charismatic creatures but rather about preserving the infinitely complex habitats of which such animals are only the most manifest glories. Yet if commercial interests are reluctant to hold back for spotted owls, why should they worry about subterranean worms or microscopic ticks?
Moreover, the ethical dilemmas portended by this book are depressing. Where it comes to the conflicting needs of a starving Ecuadorean peasant and a rapidly diminishing rain forest, who in good conscience can ask the peasant to lie down and die for the sake of genetic diversity he can only be aware of in the abstract?
As it turns out, this book does deliver much grim information. A pioneer in the field of biodiversity studies and the author of such works as "Sociobiology," "On Human Nature," "The Insect Societies" and "Biophilia," Mr. Wilson celebrates the complexity of evolution precisely to emphasize the extent of the catastrophe we face. Symmetry is everywhere in "The Diversity of Life." He stresses the interdependency of species so that he can emphasize the great extent to which severe damage to environments can ramify. He amazes us with the enormous numbers of species we have not yet identified so that he can shock us with the unknown amounts of life that may be on the way to extinction.
His bottom line is that by the roughest estimate there may be tens of millions of species now alive on the earth, of which only about 1.4 million, at most 10 percent, are known. "A 20 percent extinction in total global diversity, with all habitats incorporated, is a strong possibility if the present rate of environmental destruction continues," he concludes.
Moreover, he drives home dramatically why people can't afford such a loss. To judge from experience, there are hidden riches in unknown species that could provide us with everything from miracle medicines to hardier food. It took 10 million to 100 million years to recover from previous natural devastations of the planet. Most important, perhaps, we don't really know enough about our nature as humans to judge what subtle but devastating effects such losses might have on our psyches. We are more deeply rooted in nature than we realize, and we break free at our peril.
Yet surprisingly, Mr. Wilson's book has cause for hope, too. There is evidence that ecosystems like the rain forests can be profitably used without harming them. As he concludes, "The race is on to develop methods, to draw more income from the wildlands without killing them, and so to give the invisible hand of free-market economics a green thumb."
He offers a point-by-point program for change and makes it sound as if the world were far more aware of what must be done to preserve biodiversity than headlines about elephants and wolves and spotted owls make it sound. He refers to the growing conflict between human population growth and the needs of the environment not as an apocalypse but as a "bottleneck." He writes as if we can pass through it.
So despite all the pessimism in "The Diversity of Life," its virtue is not that it frightens but that it educates. It broadens our understanding of what Darwin revealed. It hints that even if humans weren't created by the hand of God, they may yet prove to be a blessing upon the earth.

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
A Day at the Track With the Governor

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

 BODY:
Mario M. Cuomo sat high over the finish line at Belmont Park yesterday and said, yes, he knew that people portrayed him as a Governor who resented and maybe even suspected horse racing, and he peered back a half a century for reasons.
"My impressions of racing," he said, "were the same as anybody who was raised in a neighborhood like mine: very poor. My father owned a grocery store in Queens and he gave credit to people, and he resented it when people didn't pay him but they did go to the bookmaker and pay him. The best-dressed guy in the neighborhood was the bookmaker." 
 He paused, and concluded: "But everybody wants to get rich and I have no negative feelings or moral reservations about racing or gambling. People will be betting on racing forever."
The state, counting on it, tapped into the business of betting a long time ago. It authorized parimutuel betting at the race track half a century ago and nudged the well-dressed bookmaker off the street corner. And 20 years ago, it took over the street corner with the Offtrack Betting shop. So, betting now is not only legal but also patriotic.
Also, maddening. The bettor finds it maddening when he surrenders 17 cents of every dollar won -- it's called the takeout -- and 5 cents goes to the state, the rest to the tracks. But the tracks find it maddening, too, because people are also being induced to spend their money on casino gambling, lotteries, video poker and endless other games of chance. The state finds it maddening because it needs more money from racing than it's getting.
The situation grew even more maddening last spring when Cuomo got into a hassle with the New York Racing Association, the nonprofit agency that is enfranchised by the state to run Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga race tracks until the year 2,000. The Governor needed $50 million to fill holes in his state budget, and wanted to get it by inducing N.Y.R.A. to sell a parking lot at Aqueduct to the Port Authority for use by Kennedy Airport. The association would then be required to turn over the profit to the state.
The association resisted until the Governor went to the whip. He threatened to investigate N.Y.R.A. and the renewal of its charter and even to pack its board of trustees with his own appointees. He also named a nine-member board of inquiry with a far-reaching title: the Commission on Racing in the 21st Century. Peace promptly broke out.
Still, Cuomo did not visit a race track for nine years until last Aug. 22, when he unexpectedly arrived at Saratoga Race Course on the afternoon of the $1 million Travers Stakes. The race was obligingly won by the only New York-bred horse in the field, Thunder Rumble.
His second visit was made yesterday, when he appeared at Belmont Park in the morning a couple of hours before the first race and headed for the press box. He was flanked by two of his racing deputies: Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development and chairman of the new commission, and Steven Richman, a veteran of the state's Racing and Wagering Board, who will work as executive director of the commission.
"We want to make racing better," the Governor said, explaining his recent sorties to the tracks. "We're not going to change the face of racing overnight. We want to give people more joy."
"And," he added, without lingering on joy, "give the state more money."
"There's a tremendous potential in racing," he said, "if only because the problems are so obvious. Like OTB. Should we sell OTB? Generally speaking, I don't think it's being run very efficiently. What should we do about the takeout? When I was at Saratoga, I couldn't walk two steps without being swamped with questions and complaints. Mostly, what are you going to do about the takeout?
"It's like the takeout insults them. They don't understand the economics of racing, where the money comes from, where it goes. But they resent the takeout. That's one of the main things the commission will look into."
He was asked how his past confrontations with N.Y.R.A. had evolved into his swoops into racing in the new era of goodwill, and he sprang to answer.
"Of course, I was confrontational with the New York Racing Association," he said. "I had to tell them that you are here for the 18 million people of the state. You are not like Morgan Stanley or I.B.M. You are a public organization, and is that the way to do it? We put in a bill to change it, but dropped it after we began to work better with N.Y.R.A.
"I've had the same struggle with the Port Authority. They're a government itself. They have an air force. They get paid more than we do."
"But," he added, without breaking stride, "I would rather conciliate than confront. Don't forget, I also had a confrontation with Bill Clinton."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Little TLC for Mexico

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
Topic A here is the just-completed freer trade pact among Mexico, Canada and the U.S. Almost daily, newspapers splash the story on their front pages using the initials "TLC." This stands for "el Tratado de Libre Comercio." It does not stand for "Tender Loving Care," though Mexico needs a little of that from a U.S. that either ignores the treaty entirely or turns it into a campaign football.
Mexicans, it seems, follow every whiff of news about the issue with the attention Americans usually reserve for serial killers. "Perhaps it is because we take you more seriously than you take yourselves," said a senior government official. 
 Mexico, at least, deserves to be taken seriously. It is run, literally, by a powerhouse elite that has transformed the economy into the 13th-largest in the world, albeit only one-25th the size of America's. Mexico is America's third-biggest trading partner, ranking behind Canada and Japan and before Germany and Britain. The U.S. will export over $40 billion to Mexico this year, triple the exports in 1986. Much of this results from the ruling party's historic decision to abandon its insular past and take up free-marketeering.
President Bush has treated Mexico more seriously than perhaps any of his predecessors. Mexicans love him for this. They are worried about Bill Clinton.
The Democratic contender favors freer trade, but says he will withhold judgment on the treaty until he studies it. Democratic emissaries, authorized and otherwise, have come here to tell President Carlos Salinas and his aides not to worry. They have reassured Mexicans that the pact would sail through a potentially wary Congress even more quickly with Mr. Clinton than with Mr. Bush because Democratic legislators will better heed a Democratic President.
Mr. Salinas knows America well, so was not too reassured. He reportedly asked Mr. Bush not to keep making the treaty a Republican issue. But he agreed to a photo op next week with Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada. Mr. Clinton needed no convincing about cooling the issue; if he discusses it, he looks either protectionist or anti-labor.
But Mr. Salinas seems to be signaling another message to Mr. Clinton: Don't dig yourself into a deeper hole on the matter, so we can iron out problems later. A close aide to Mr. Salinas told me, "Notice Salinas himself never said publicly he would not renegotiate the text." The aide hastened to add that the sections on trade could not be touched, but that Mr. Salinas might be able to accommodate a President Clinton's political needs by modifying labor and environmental passages -- or by dealing with these controversial issues outside the treaty itself.
All this done, the Salinas propaganda machine -- as formidable and disciplined as China's -- put out a new line. The trade pact, it said, could and should be one of Mr. Clinton's first foreign policy initiatives. It is just sitting there, promising a net increase in U.S. jobs, ready to be set in motion with great fanfare. "A natural," one top economic aide called it.
These are clever, upbeat words that mask deep concern. Mexican leaders cannot afford doubt or delay on the treaty. Foreign investment in Mexico would trail off quickly. Mexico badly requires that money to finance social programs and economic growth, already slowing down.
The seldom-spoken truth here is that Mexico has much more at stake in this treaty than the U.S. For America, the pact would mildly accelerate present trends in trade growth and certain job losses in manufacturing. It would also help democratize and steady an increasingly important neighbor.
For Mr. Salinas and his ruling party, power and policy are at some risk. They stand to gain hundreds of thousands of jobs. But by opening up their country, they could also unleash American pressures -- for democratization, higher wages and more spending to clean up pollution -- beyond their capacity to manage.
Troubles with the treaty will not cause Mr. Salinas to turn back. He has already gone far to reverse Mexico's protectionist, state-run economy and historical antipathy toward the U.S., and to turn Mexico into a modern nation -- goals long desired by Washington. The U.S. elephant has no good reason to carelessly make his task harder.

HEADLINE: Clues to the Crash of the Job Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Almost 30 years ago a diverse group of concerned citizens sent a report to President Johnson titled "The Triple Revolution," predicting a cybernetic revolution in which computers would eliminate jobs and create a "human slag heap of tens of millions of Americans who do not have the skills to compete in a computerized society." 
 The age of the computer is indeed here and many workers now have been replaced by them, including well-paid middle managers whose jobs have disappeared for good. We have underestimated the impact of this revolution and apparently now are able to eliminate more jobs than we can create.
One of the remedies widely advocated is retraining of the unemployed, but almost nothing is said for what purpose. We need to know more precisely what products are to be made or services performed before we can provide useful training. Otherwise the prescription is without direction, leaving a still-unsolved problem.
Research and development is the key to meaningful job creation. As has been demonstrated many times in the past, research leads to new products, new companies, and new industries. Our spending on domestic research and development has been declining for many reasons -- certainly obsession with short-term results leads to a sacrifice of research expenditures. Changes in tax policies could provide added incentives to research and development.
Finally, the problem of capital formation needs to be addressed. We discourage savings as a source of capital and encourage debt as a tax-deductible item in cases where nothing is created except a transfer of ownership in corporate takeovers, leaving the surviving companies drowning in debt.
 
ROBERT J. DAVIS
New York, Sept. 19, 1992

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Companies' New Securities Balloon to Record Amount

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The rush by corporate America to raise money from the public continued at a breakneck pace in the third quarter, as companies issued a record amount of securities. For Wall Street, that translated into an unsurpassed payday as investment firms raked in record fees.
Corporations issued $224.7 billion in debt and equity securities in the three-month period ended yesterday, up 50.2 percent from the $149.7 billion in offerings that hit the market in the third quarter of 1991, according to the Securities Data Company. That amount also solidly broke the record of $212.9 billion in securities that were issued in the second quarter of this year. 
 With those results, 1992 will be without question the best year ever for underwritings. For the first nine months of 1992, corporations have issued $667 billion in securities, which is $77 billion more than was issued in all of the record year of 1991, according to Securities Data.
The flurry of financings has been generated by low interest rates and relatively strong equity markets. The low rates have pushed many corporations to refinance their debt in order to lower their costs, even as institutional and retail investors in search of yields have turned to the public marketplace in greater numbers to make investments.
"The demand has been pretty much across the board in terms of types of issuers," said Grant Kvalheim, head of the capital markets desk at Merrill Lynch & Company.
The heavy business has proved a boon for Wall Street. Firms earned an unprecedented $5.1 billion in the first nine months of the year, according to Securities Data, already surpassing the $5 billion in fees for all of 1991. Merrill Lynch alone has earned more than $1 billion in fees.
Underwriters said that the flurry of initial public offerings grew more tepid in the third quarter, as an increasing number of institutional investors became more price sensitive and selective. But, they said, investors have turned increasingly to yield-oriented products, such as convertible securities.
Merrill Lynch, the perennial leader in underwriting, again captured the top spot, with $37.8 billion in securities during the quarter for 16.8 percent of the market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Computervision Stock Plummets on Forecast

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
Just six weeks after making its initial public stock offering, the Computervision Corporation watched Wall Street hammer that stock yesterday, after the company announced that results for its third fiscal quarter would be "substantially below" expectations.
Computervision's shares lost more than 30 percent of their value yesterday, falling $3 each to close at $6.25 in New York Stock Exchange trading. 
 The company, formerly known as Prime Computer Inc., had already been predicting an unspecified loss for the quarter. It gave no details yesterday as to how much worse the final numbers might be.
"The decline was more than we expected," Harvey Wagner, Computervision's chief executive officer, said, adding that the company could not be more specific until it finished sifting through its data.
Mr. Wagner said the unexpectedly disappointing results for the quarter, which ended Sunday, were based on worldwide economic conditions in both Europe, where the company conducts 70 percent of its business, and the United States. He said recent turmoil in Europe over interest rates and currencies "tended to freeze customer spending."
Computervision is among the leading suppliers of computer-aided-design software, which manufacturing companies use in designing products. This past summer the company divested itself of its computer hardware business and changed its name from Prime Computer. On Aug. 14 it filed an initial public offering in a complicated financial deal intended to drastically reduce the company's huge debt.
Twenty-five million shares were sold at $12 a share, raising $300 million, along with another $300 million in debt issues. The $600 million was used to pay down long-term debt, and management hoped to set the new organization on a path to profitability.
Computervision's president and chief executive, John J. Shields, spoke to analysts today about the surprise announcement. Robert Herwick, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, said Mr. Shields attributed the unexpected revenue shortfall to the currency crisis in Europe and to the distractions of top executives in July and August as they prepared for the stock offering.
"The deviation in the plan occurred primarily in the last two weeks of September in Europe," Mr. Herwick said. "The recent confusion about currency translations and interest rates froze the buying process in the U.K. and Italy, where they had high hopes for orders.
"And the financing situation took senior management away from managing the sales and marketing process. Rather than holding weekly reviews of sales cycles, that fell to every other week. So in the month of July, management of sales and marketing was not all it should have been."
Mr. Wagner said Computervision would not know the official quarterly results for some time. But Mr. Herwick estimated that revenues would be down 20 percent from the comparable quarter a year earlier, when sales were $280 million. He added that operating income would probably be positive, although down from the $10 million in the corresponding quarter last year.
Mr. Wagner insisted that when Computervision made its stock offering the company had no indication of the depth of the sales downturn. "It was as much a surprise to us as to anyone," he said. He said Computervision was well positioned to move toward profitability, with "new state-of-the-art products, new distribution channels and a very respectable balance sheet."
Some analysts, however, believe Computervision's problems run deeper than current economic adversity.
Peter Schleider, a partner with Wessels, Arnold & Henderson in Minneapolis, said Computervision "has totally blown the pricing model," charging customers too much for its software.
He said a competitor, Parametric Technology Inc. of Waltham, Mass. "is eating their lunch" by offering better software for $15,000 to $22,000.

HEADLINE: Can This Guy Be Serious?

BYLINE: By Stefan Kanfer; Stefan Kanfer is drama critic of The New Leader and contributes to Time.

 BODY:
Hello, you people, this is Rush Limbaugh, the man George Bush came to visit last week. Why? Because I stand for what he stands for. Me. I. Rush Limbaugh, the talk show host who bills himself as "The Epitome of Morality and Virtue, With Talent on Loan From God." Rush Limbaugh, whose love affair with the mirror and the mike has attracted more than 500 radio stations.
And now there's even more of me, folks, available on shelves across the fruited plain. You know how I boast about taking on the liberals with half my brain tied behind my back? Well, that's the half responsible for the wit in my new book "The Way Things Ought To Be." This week it heads The New York Times best-seller list. 
 Some folks -- the jealous art and croissant crowd -- say it's because I tirelessly plug the thing on my radio show three hours a day, five days a week. But the President and I know it's because people want to read what I write. Well, not exactly write. I kind of talked it to a guy with a tape recorder. And he kind of stitched it together. Charles Dickens and Leo Tolstoy would have done the same thing if they were alive today.
The book is for people like you, folks who don't flip to another station when I go "dadalup, dadalup, dadalup" until I can think of something to say. Where was I? I. Myself. Mine. Dadalup, dadalup, dadalup. (In my tome this is defined as an "attempt to approximate the stirring sound of a trumpet fanfare and alert listeners that something important is coming.") Ah, yes, I remember what I was talking about. My book. By me. I.
It's neoconbabble, purist Limbaughlderdash, a fresh entry in the great tradition of nonsense literature. Not since Lewis Carroll and Edward Lear assumed room temperature (my way of saying they're deceased), etc. No wonder George Bush chose to air his views on my show. Dadalup, dadalup, dadalup. . .
Who could resist this sample from page 39: "The poor and the lower classes in this country have gotten a free ride since the Great Depression when it became noble to be poor. Look how we treat the homeless: We celebrate them, make romantic figures out of them. We make movies about them and teach them how to dine in dumpsters."
How about this on animal rights: "Our laws do not prevent us from killing for food and sport, so the right to life of an animal is nonexistent."
Here I am on ecology: "The earth is a remarkable creation and is capable of great rejuvenation. We can't destroy it. It can fix itself."
And how's this for keen political analysis: "The Republican Party should buy Buchanan two Cadillacs so that he can get rid of his Mercedes as thanks for dispatching Duke to the ash heap of irrelevance."
Can this guy be serious? America is asking. Indeed I am, my friends. But these sound bites -- as brilliant as they are -- don't even begin to tap my other side: I'm also a subtle and tasteful satirist. Take my commercial for Feminazi Trading Cards: "On the front, an action shot of a leading feminist burning a bra, dominating a TV show, picketing an all-men's club. On the back, all the vital statistics: waist, hips, the documented age, the number of abortions and, where applicable, the alimony payments and divorce settlements."
On Eastern Europe: "The Stone Age would be a giant leap forward for most Russians."
On liberals: "They are the past. We conservatives are the future." Dadalup, dadalup, dadalup. Folks, I could burble on like this forever. Maybe I will. After all, 12 million listeners can't be wrong, especially when two of them are William Buckley and Col. Oliver North. (Bill says my show is "like a jolt of champagne," and Ollie believes that "Rush has captured the sense of average Americans.") Besides, there's deeper purpose to all that we neocons do and say.
If I may quote myself -- and if I don't, who will? -- "The American economy cannot be revived without someone getting rich.
"Why not me?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
PEROT RE-ENTERS THE CAMPAIGN, SAYING BUSH AND CLINTON FAIL TO ADDRESS GOVERNMENT 'MESS'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Ross Perot jumped back into the race for the Presidency today, instantly creating new risks, opportunities and uncertainties for Gov. Bill Clinton and President Bush in the final 33 days before Election Day.
Mr. Perot, who bolted from the race in July, asserted he was reactivating his independent campaign at the plea of his supporters. "I thought that both political parties would address the problems that face the nation," he said. "We gave them a chance. They didn't do it." 
 Despite new polls showing his support vastly diminished, Mr. Perot dismissed the notion that he could function only as a spoiler or that he was motivated by animosity toward Mr. Bush.
 
Playing FamiliarThemes
 He presented his candidacy as a de facto nomination from the grass roots, declaring: "I would like to thank the American people. By choosing me as your candidate, you have given me the highest honor I could ever receive." [Excerpts from the news conference, page A20.]
With his running mate, retired Vice Adm. James B. Stockdale, at his side, Mr. Perot struck many of the same themes that he rode to sudden political prominence last spring, assailing a "Government in gridlock" that has let the deficit and other critical national needs go unresolved.
"The American people are good," he said, "but they have a Government that is a mess. Everybody in Washington makes excuses. Nobody takes responsibility even when they have direct responsibility."
 
Slapping at News Media
 The Perot camp declared that it expected Mr. Perot to be included in upcoming Presidential debates, and both Bush and Clinton campaigns said they were willing to do so. Negotiators said tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement on the debates. Officials close to the negotiations said there would be three debates, with the first one on Oct. 11. [Page A18.]
In a remarkably combative news conference for an announcement day, Mr. Perot, a Texas billionaire, also lambasted the news media for investigating his past and his political practices and asserted that he would keep his campaign focused solely on the issues he wanted to highlight.
"I don't care what you do," he told the reporters present. "Just have fun, get raises and bonuses, play gotcha. I don't care. I care about this country, I care about the American people, and I love them, and I will do whatever I can to serve them."
Strategists in the Bush and Clinton campaigns were quick to say that Mr. Perot would not be the formidable presence he was last spring, when he briefly shot to the head of the pack after a campaign waged largely on television talk shows. They predicted that Mr. Perot's candidacy would fare much as other recent third-party candidates have fared, pulling a vote percentage in the teens or single digits.
But they acknowledged that, in a close race, Mr. Perot would be an important variable in some of the most important states, like California and Texas, perhaps even tilting a state to one candidate or the other. Moreover, it was clear that Mr. Perot would affect the tone and the dynamic of the dialogue.
Mr. Perot, whose personal fortune has fueled the petition drive that has placed his name on the ballot in all 50 states, is expected to wage a campaign heavily oriented toward television. "I think you will see a heavy emphasis on the media, television," said Orson Swindle, head of United We Stand, America, the Perot organization. "You will see issues discussed in a way you have not seen in the past."
Unlike the campaigns of the two major party candidates, Mr. Perot's will not be publicly financed.
A new poll for CNN and USA Today suggested that Mr. Perot faced a skeptical and largely unfriendly public for his revived campaign. The poll, conducted Monday through Wednesday by The Gallup Organization, found that 60 percent of the 1,052 registered voters polled said Mr. Perot should not re-enter the race, while 33 percent said he should. In contrast, the Gallup Poll found in late June that 69 percent of those asked wanted Mr. Perot to be a Presidential candidate.
The CNN/USA Today poll also showed Mr. Clinton with a formidable lead, 52 percent, as against 35 percent for Mr. Bush and 7 percent for Mr. Perot. It had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
In his speech today, Mr. Perot apologized to his supporters for leaving the race this summer and hinted that after months of being portrayed as a temperamental quitter, he wanted to begin anew. "My decision in July hurt you," he said. "I apologize."
Then he added, "Looking back won't solve our problems. Looking forward, working together, we can fix anything."
Responding to Mr. Perot's re-entry, Mr. Clinton said in Wisconsin, "My fight is with George Bush, and I'm going to take it to him." The Governor said he still believed he had the best economic plan in the campaign and argued that Mr. Perot's re-entry would have little effect on the way he ran his race.
"The problem I have with the Perot plan," Mr. Clinton said in a interview with a television station in Cincinnati, "is that it puts deficit reduction ahead of generating jobs."
The Bush and Clinton campaigns today remained locked in negotiations over debates, with a main sticking point the Bush team's desire for a late debate, on the Sunday before Election Day, and the Clinton campaign's resistance to one. Should Mr. Bush succeed in tightening the race, a late debate would give the President a final chance to project a reassuring presence and make his case to the public..
Mr. Bush took a day off the campaign trail today but escalated his advertising offensive with a new attack on Mr. Clinton as a risky and dangerous taxer. "You can't trust Clinton economics," an announcer says in the new commercial, which focuses on five Americans and the additional taxes they would supposedly pay under a Clinton Administration. "It's wrong for you. It's wrong for America."
The Clinton campaign reacted to the commercial quickly and forcefully. "It is blatantly false, and nobody else in the world claims that," Mr. Clinton declared. "George Bush has said time and again that he would say whatever it takes to be elected President, and this is an example."
The Democrats, for their part, were broadcasting a new commercial that resurrects the broken campaign promise from 1988 that haunted Mr. Bush in the primaries this year: "Read my lips: no new taxes."
Both campaigns have treaded carefully around Mr. Perot in recent days, but Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, hinted at the contrast the Democrats would draw on economics. Campaigning in Wisconsin today, Mr. Gore said Democrats shared Mr. Perot's concern for the reducing the deficit, but the Tennessee Senator added: "He raises taxes on middle-income people in a way that we think is very unwise. We stimulate economic growth."
 
Reporting a Different Perot
 Stan Greenberg, the poll taker for Mr. Clinton, asserted today that the Clinton campaign's polls showed Mr. Perot slipping throughout the week. He also argued that Perot II was drawing a very different -- and more Republican -- constituency than Perot I was last spring.
"He was drawing the shake-up-politics voters last spring," Mr. Greenberg said. "Now he's drawing support from voters who want to get spending under control. And that's a very different share of the electorate."
But the Bush forces continued to hope that Mr. Perot succeeded in shaking up the race and perhaps opening up some states where Mr. Clinton has a formidable lead.
"We welcome him to the race," said Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign. "He says he wants to talk about the economy and the deficit, and we welcome that."
In general, Mr. Perot's entry is seen as a risk and an opportunity for both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. He poses a problem for Mr. Bush in Texas, a must-win state for the President, for example, but he could cut into Mr. Clinton's support in California and some Northern states like Michigan.
Perhaps foreshadowing an appeal to keep anti-Bush voters from straying, Mr. Clinton said in an interview with a Raleigh, N.C., television station: "I hope that it won't divide the vote of those who know that Mr. Bush should not be given another term."
In his announcement today, Mr. Perot did not go into the details of the economic plan he issued after he left the race on July 16, when he said he did not want to be a disruptive force.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis;
A Tremor Now, Not a Groundswell

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Ross Perot shook the scaffolding of American politics by re-entering the Presidential race today, but it was only an aftershock compared with the major earthquakes he caused earlier this year.
No one knows for sure from whom he is likely to take more votes, or how many, and the campaign staffs of President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton are both more apprehensive than they let on; their almost fawning eagerness to send delegations to appeal for his support early this week is proof of that. 
 In certain circumstances, Mr. Perot could alter the dynamics of the race, particularly if he takes part in television debates and manages to prevent Mr. Clinton or Mr. Bush or both from scoring with viewers. That could prompt many voters to ponder anew their views of all three candidates.
If the race between the two major-party nominees tightens, he could tip the balance by throwing large, vital states to one or the other.
 
Doubts About Credibility
 But Mr. Perot no longer commands anything approaching the support that he commanded early this summer, when for a time he led Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton alike in some polls. His abrupt and ill-explained departure from the contest in July, for which he apologized at his news conference here today, cost him not only volunteers but also a good deal of his credibility.
It is also much later in the game. Most voters have made up their minds, however tentatively, and Mr. Perot has only 33 days to persuade them to give him a second chance.
He spoke of a long, hard slog to restore a nation whose political process and government he described as messes. He said that it would take sacrifice on everyone's part to rebuild what he termed an educational system, an industrial base and a health-care network in disastrous decline. Some still see him as a potential savior, but many more, to judge from talks with voters around the country in recent weeks, doubt his staying power.
Perhaps, with the help of the sort of television blitz that his millions of dollars put easily within his reach, Mr. Perot can once again make himself seem an attractive alternative to a pair of major-party candidates with substantial, well-advertised electoral liabilities themselves.
He retains valuable political assets, notably the American fascination with billionaires who thrust themselves into the spotlight, especially self-made ones. Moreover, even though he has said little lately about how he would change things, he has unquestionably touched a nerve with his constant insistence that Washington has failed to come to grips with dire problems.
Yet serious questions remain about how the public will react to further exposure to Mr. Perot's prickly personality -- to his thin-skinned reaction to criticism of any kind, his resentment of any inquiry into his family or his past personal or business conduct, and his inexperience in the give-and-take of government, to say nothing of his innocence of the details of domestic and foreign policy.
Edward J. Rollins, the political consultant who managed the Perot candidacy for a time, has written that the candidate lacks the temperament needed in a President. He left the campaign early. But a similar judgment came today from John P. White, who stayed on to draft an economic plan and returned only yesterday to his job at the Eastman Kodak Company.
Mr. Perot's imperious instincts showed through when he announced this afternoon what kinds of questions he would answer and what kinds he would not, which is something corporate bosses can get away with but political candidates cannot. A man famous hereabouts for an ego as big as Lyndon B. Johnson's, he showed an unawareness of how many others view him when he asserted that the American public was tired of "ego-driven, power-hungry people."
Having renounced professional managers after an unhappy experience this summer, it remains to be seen whether Mr. Perot will have the tools -- polling services, television production skills, tactical counseling -- that any candidate, especially a neophyte, needs to make the most of his appeal.
The prevailing view in the political community, which has evident biases against someone so scornful of it, is that Mr. Perot will be lucky to finish with as much as 10 percent of the vote nationally and is highly unlikely to win a single state. That kind of percentage would be in line with those of the most effective third-force candidates of recent years, former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama in 1968 and former Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois in 1980.
A new poll for the Cable News Network by the Gallup Organization indicates some of the dimensions of the insurgent's problems, and indeed those of Mr. Bush. It gave Mr. Clinton 52 percent, Mr. Bush 35 and Mr. Perot 7. More important for the long run, it showed Mr. Perot with a 66 percent unfavorable rating, twice what it was when he pulled out in July, and it showed that only 14 percent thought his economic plan was the most promising among the three candidates.
On a state-by-state basis, it appears likely that Mr. Perot might help Mr. Clinton in Texas and Florida, two states that Mr. Bush needs to balance expected Clinton victories in California and New York, the other two Big Four electoral-college powerhouses. Mr. Bush might be helped in some close northern states, such as Ohio and Michigan, but the electoral arithmetic suggests strongly that without Florida and Texas, that would not be enough.
An exhaustive compilation of state polls by the Hotline, an electronic campaign news service, indicates that as things stand now, the Perot candidacy will have only a marginal effect and will not swing a single state.
But none of the polls yet reflects any campaigning by Mr. Perot. Nor do they take into account the President's success this week in putting Mr. Clinton on the defensive on the debate issue, at least for a day or so -- Mr. Bush's first successful strategic stroke since the Democratic convention.
The debates, whose frequency and format remain under negotiation, are almost certain to include Mr. Perot. He meets the criteria for participation set by the independent commission that has been trying to arrange the debates, and given that, any attempt to exclude him would risk making him look like a martyr, even though the commission may well not oversee the debates.
As the final phase of the campaign begins, each candidate can see different dangers looming.
For Mr. Perot, who was humiliated earlier by being branded a quitter, late reentry runs the risk of setting him down in history as an also-ran. For Mr. Clinton, the worst thing that could happen would be an interruption in his momentum, a restirring of the pot caused by the new debate about debates and the new three-way race. For Mr. Bush, the peril lies in the threat Mr. Perot could pose to the principal underpinnings of his already shaky base.

International
A scathing Senate report on B.C.C.I. says the bank derailed Congressional inquiries by using political influence and bribery. That, combined with Government incompetence and inaction, catalyzed the biggest financial fraud in history. It cited John Culver, a former Democratic Senator from Iowa, and Michael Pillsbury, a senior aide to Senator Orrin Hatch, Utah Republican. [Page A1.] 
 The Bundesbank said it spent more than $30 billion trying to prop up the value of the pound and the lira -- mostly the pound -- last month before Britain and Italy gave up defending their currencies and pulled out of Europe's monetary system. [D1.]
 
The Economy
Minority group members are rejected for mortgages far more frequently than whites of similar income, according to the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now. Studying 46 banks in 13 cities, it said 26.7 percent of black applications were turned down, compared with 10.5 percent of whites. [D1.]
Unemployment benefits claims jumped 15,000 to 429,000, in the week ended Sept. 19, the fifth consecutive increase, the Labor Department said, handing President Bush bad news. [D1.]
The manufacturing economy slumped in September to its lowest level of growth in seven months, according to a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers. [D2.]
White House officials are considering whether President Bush, to avoid a big defeat in Congress, should reverse himself and sign a bill regulating cable television prices. He has vowed to veto it. [D1.]
Electricity prices should be lowered but little would be done to decrease the nation's dependence on foreign oil under an energy bill negotiated by Senate and House conferees. [D2.]
Government officials in charge of the savings and loan bailout defended their efforts to recover damages from miscreants and disassociated themselves from White House efforts to draft guidelines that would make it more difficult for them to sue. [D2.]

A broadcast campaign against drugs began Wednesday. It is run by the Partnership for a Drug Free America. [D13.]
 
Markets
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 17.29 points at 3,254.37 in heavy trading, as investors reacted to gloomy economic news. [D4.]
Credit markets chalked up a strong advance on the dismal news. Some short-term Treasury yields fell to record lows. [D11.]
The dollar rose against major European currencies while falling against the Japanese yen. Gold prices fell slightly. [D12.]
Soybean futures prices tumbled to a 14-month low on favorable weather forecasts. Corn and oat futures also fell. [D12.]

HEADLINE: Hard Times Change Many Minds

SERIES: Closing Willow Run -- Third article of a series: Taking the Anger to the Polls

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich., Oct. 1

 BODY:
Union officials at General Motors' Willow Run assembly plant here have long complained about growing political apathy among the rank and file. But not this year. Their plant has been scheduled for closing, and the workers blame George Bush (along with the chairman of G.M., whose selection they don't get to vote on).
Bill Clinton wasn't the union local's first choice for President (Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa was) or even its second (Edmund G. Brown Jr. from California was). But workers have been registering to vote in record numbers just so they can back the Democrat in November. 
 One new voter, 35-year-old Fred Mosley, said he would have supported President Bush a year ago. "I believed in Bush," said Mr. Mosley, who installs the rear trim on cars. "He's strong, he's military; I was in the military."
 
John Wayne or 'a Wimp'?
 Then, last spring, the auto worker believed in Ross Perot. "I was hurting over the plant closing," he said. "Perot comes out, talking all this great stuff, and I was like, 'Yeah, yeah, that's what we want.' I was looking for somebody -- John Wayne, another John F. Kennedy."
Now, Mr. Mosley said, Mr. Perot was "a wimp" for getting out of the Presidential race in July and is still a wimp. "He's just making a last-ditch attempt to save Bush," Mr. Mosley said, dismissing Mr. Perot's declaration today that he is indeed a candidate for President.
While Governor Clinton of Arkansas isn't John Wayne or John Kennedy, Mr. Mosley added, he does have one overriding plus: "He's not Bush."
Indeed, the Bush backlash among auto workers here, as well as at other plants, seems to be behind what is thought to be the first voter registration drive inside the Willow Run plant that anyone can remember.
So far, local union officials estimate that more than 300 new voters have been signed up in the last six months, including 70 in just two days last week.
"I've never seen such anger or enthusiasm, and it's not so much for Clinton as it is against Bush," said Douglas A. Fraser, the former president of the United Automobile Workers and now a professor of labor relations at Wayne State University in Detroit. "No matter how much he says the economy is getting better, he can't convince them. They know it isn't true."
Back in Michigan last week, President Bush, who carried the state in the last election, was casting himself as the champion of the auto workers, in contrast to Governor Clinton whose fuel economy standards, the President contended, would cost the state 40,000 jobs.
With Michigan considered to be one of the pivotal industrial states this year, both candidates are chasing blue-collar voters like Mr. Mosley.
At 5:30 A.M. on Wednesday, one longtime auto worker, Tony Ochab, was at the gate of the Willow Run plant with 2,400 Clinton-Gore leaflets as the first of 2,400 workers were pulling into the parking lot.
"I've never been involved with politics before," he said. "I want to make sure George hits the unemployment line before I do. I might hit it in April. He can hit it in November."
Willow Run will shut down sometime in 1993. It has about 4,000 hourly workers, although half are already on layoff. Mr. Ochab has been plotting his revenge since Feb. 24, when General Motors announced that the Chevrolet Caprice and other large cars built at Willow Run would be produced instead in Arlington, Tex. The company has declined to specify why Arlington was chosen.
Without the facts, many workers are convinced that the President from Texas had something to do with it. The President has said that he was not involved.
Arlington aside, people in this town, 30 miles west of Detroit, where there are four auto plants in a five-mile radius, say Mr. Bush has stolen their American dreams. On Friday, Laraine Drew, who has raised three children by working on the assembly line, was at the union hall, registering to vote.
"When I was 21, I voted for Kennedy," she said. She has not been to the polls since.
Now, she is part of a dwindling group of die-hard Ross Perot supporters here. "He's a businessman," said Ms. Drew, who works for a company that lost a record $4.5 billion last year. "That's what we need."
Willow Run, one of 21 General Motors plants that will close by 1995, is only the latest disaster in a state with more than 9 percent unemployment. And U.A.W. leaders say the sentiments voiced by the Willow Run workers are being echoed loudly at plants everywhere.
At the Labor Day parade in Detroit, where Senator Al Gore of Tennessee was a keynote speaker, the marchers were estimated at more than 150,000. In contrast, only about 30,000 marched in the 1988 parade.
Mr. Fraser said the size of this year's crowd only confirmed the change of sentiment among auto workers. Union officials estimate that as many as 30 percent of auto workers voted for Mr. Bush last time.
 
'They're Coming Home'
 "The most disturbing thing about it, and I wish it weren't true, is that when people become affluent, their values change," Mr. Fraser said. "They don't think they should be paying taxes to support people who are less well off. Reagan made greed respectable, and it caught on with some of our people. Now, with the economy the way it is, it's turned around, and they're coming home."
Not surprisingly, Michigan's Republican Governor, John Engler, who is the President's state campaign chairman, takes another view. "They should vote for George Bush because we've got an American economy with five straight quarters of growth," he said. "Not robust growth the way it needs to be, but clearly headed in the right direction."
Five straight quarters of growth means nothing to many people here. They may be America's highest-paid industrial workers, but even if their jobs were not threatened, the auto workers say, they would still be worried about house payments and college tuition for their children.
 
Disappearing Overtime
 "Ten years ago, we were working 10-hour days, six days a week," said Ted Copeland, a 36-year-old assembler, Vietnam veteran and former Navy reservist who left last year to fight in the Persian Gulf war. "I was making a fantastic amount of overtime -- earning $42,000, $43,000 a year."
Now, with overtime a part of the past at the doomed auto plant, the figure is closer to $30,000.
General Motors has said that most Willow Run workers, with an average of 20 years seniority, will be transferred to other plants. But Mr. Copeland, with two young sons and only 12 years on the line, is preparing for the worst. He has taken a second job, installing energy-saving devices for an engineering firm. The twice-monthly family dinners at the Red Lobster restaurant are over. He has sold off the truck he bought last year and his prized 1929 Model A Ford.
And, for the first time in 12 years, he is backing the Democrat. "O.K., fine, the man went to Oxford," he said. "But I feel he's gotten a whole lot of exposure to what's going on in this country -- unemployment, homelessness, welfare, drug abuse, the whole spiel."
And, he added, "Clinton's a very personable guy." One thing that impressed Mr. Copeland: "I heard him talking about his 1966 Mustang."
 
Driving a Political Statement
 The kinds of car a person drives is a political statement here, where the bumper stickers say "Buy American." Bob Harlow, the president of the Willow Run local of the U.A.W., said any politician foolish enough to pull up at the union hall in a foreign model would probably not get an endorsement.
One auto worker, Dave Roberts, has been driving his Chevrolet Lumina between Arlington and Ypsilanti since last spring, 18 hours each way. His wife, Jacqueline, a salaried worker at Willow Run, was transferred to Texas. Mr. Roberts, with 22 years' seniority, hopes that by spring he will be transferred, too.
Just back from Arlington last week, Mr. Roberts said his road trips provided a chance to do some politicking. "Gas stations, restaurants, any store I stop in, I try to bring it up in some way," he said. "Like I'll say, 'Well, I hope it's Clinton we're all voting for.' "
Mr. Roberts noted that he had a "little confrontation" with another customer at a gas station in Hope, Ark., Governor Clinton's hometown:
"He said, 'We don't like him down here.' I said, 'Well, all I can see is the economy in a bad state. We need a change.' "
Mr. Roberts added, "This lady who was there came over and said, 'I think it's time for a change, too.' "

Bill Clinton has an overriding plus: "He's not Bush." (pg. D4) (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Catholic Archdiocese Weighs Closing Parishes

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
The Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that it was studying the possibility of closing a number of its 412 parishes because of shifts in Roman Catholic population, the declining number of priests and economic difficulties.
At the same time, the archdiocese said it might open new parishes in fast-growing areas such as Orange and Dutchess Counties. 
 The announcement was made in the weekly newspaper of the archdiocese, Catholic New York, which has been the forum the announcement of several recent economic developments -- including the disclosure last week of a salary freeze for 1,600 lay employees and 1,500 priests.
The newspaper quoted Auxiliary Bishop Patrick J. Sheridan, the second in command to John Cardinal O'Connor, as saying no specific areas or parishes were being considered for closing. "We're not nearly at that point yet, not at all," the Bishop said.
The Bishop could not be reached for further comment last night.
 
Task Force Study
 The article said no decisions on closings would be made until a study by an 18-member commission that Bishop Sheridan heads, the Archdiocesan Task Force for Parish Planning, is completed.
Over the last 20 year, only a handful of parishes have been closed or merged in the archdiocese, which is made up of Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and seven counties north of New York City. The archdiocese has been reluctant to close even those parishes in inner-city areas that have lost the bulk of their Catholic populations. The parishes are seen as anchors in the community, which can help to keep certain blocks from decay and provide vital social services like soup kitchens and schools.
The archdiocese has announced in recent years that it was examining the possibility of closing some of its roughly 300 Catholic schools. But only a few -- 10 in the last two years -- have been closed, and those only after long negotiations with the parents and teachers.
Whether or not parishes are ultimately closed, yesterday's announcement may be intended as a warning to parishes to shore up their finances and prepare for a leaner future.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Mixed Day for the Dollar Amid Uncertainty in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against major European currencies while falling against the Japanese yen amid uncertainty over Europe's political squabbling concerning its currency crisis.
Gold prices fell slightly. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell 30 cents, to $347.50. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price of $348.10, off $0.20. 
 Kevin Lawrie, vice president and chief dealer at the Bank of Boston, said the market had shown an "upward bias," but "essentially we didn't have anything very dramatic here."
 
'The Bleeding Has Stopped'
 In relative terms, the dollar is still weak, Mr. Lawrie said. "But it looks like the bleeding has stopped for the moment," he added.
He said traders were keeping an eye on Britain's handling of the currency crisis. On Sept. 16, Britain pulled out of a European Community program that sets exchange-rate limits to avoid sharp fluctuations.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, denied rumors that he was going to resign.
"That's added a little bit of support for the dollar," Mr. Lawrie said, adding that economic data on unemployment rates in September due today were not expected to be good.
By the end of the trading day in London, the pound dropped to $1.7325, from $1.7805 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound was quoted late yesterday at $1.7380, compared with $1.7865 Wednesday. It finished earlier in Tokyo at $1.7445.
The dollar fell to 119.80 yen, from 119.85 yen late Wednesday, in New York. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose, closing at 120.32 Japanese yen from a record low 119.25 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 119.90 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.4215 marks, up from 1.41; 1.2425 Swiss francs, up from 1.2355; 4.8040 French francs, up from 4.7695; 1,244.5 Italian lire, up from 1,223, and 1.24735 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24675.
Silver in late trading at the New York Commodity Exchange was quoted at $3.714 a troy ounce, down from $3.739 late Wednesday. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $3.75 a troy ounce, down from $3.76 bid late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Bush Offers Plan for Wider Use of Ethanol in Fuel

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
President Bush today proposed changes in the Clean Air Act that would encourage wider use of ethanol, a corn-based alcohol used in automobile fuel.
The proposal was welcomed by farmers in the hotly contested political battleground of the Middle West, but was criticized by some environmentalists and the energy industry, especially in oil-producing states that make competing additives for gasoline. 
 The Bush plan spells out a new formula for cleaner auto fuels that is intended to lower the emissions that cause smog. It would require refiners to devote most of their production to gasoline that evaporates much less readily than most fuel now on the market. As a result, more gasoline blended with ethanol -- a faster evaporating mixture -- could then be sold.
 
Credits for Farm Products
 Earlier today, Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said the Government would help 18 countries buy American grain and other farm products with $3.6 billion in credit guarantees. The credits represent two-thirds of the $5.7 billion that the Agriculture Department expects to guarantee this fiscal year, up from $5 billion last year.
The two actions today are the latest efforts to shore up Mr. Bush's standing in the Farm Belt. Last month the President authorized export subsidies for one billion bushels of wheat and released $755 million in disaster aid to farmers who lost crops to bad weather, although his Administration had resisted legislation dealing with disaster aid.
Mr. Bush, who made today's announcement in a ceremony in the White House Rose Garden, characterized the fuel proposal as a compromise involving farm groups, environmentalists, the oil industry and ethanol makers because it would speed the development of renewable fuels without sacrificing protection of the environment.
"The bottom line is this," he said. "Clean-burning ethanol fuel can help reduce pollution. This creative solution allows us to proceed in a way that is good for farmers, good for rural America, good for the environment in our cities and good for American consumers and motorists."
But the proposal might have produced as many political headaches as it was meant to solve. Oil refiners, natural-gas producers and the coal industry attacked it, saying it would necessitate costly changes to manufacturing plants, was expensive to taxpayers and harmed the market for compounds that compete with ethanol, particularly gasoline additives made from natural gas and coal.
"He's writing off the economic interests of those states that produce natural gas and coal, like Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Colorado, Wyoming, Pennsylvania and West Virginia," said Bill Orr, national representative of the $15 billion industry that processes methanol, an additive made from natural gas and coal that reduces harmful emissions from fuel. "There are thousands of jobs that will be lost in those states."
 
Criticism From a Democrat
 Environmentalists and a Democratic lawmaker who helped to write the Clean Air Act were also critical.
David Doniger, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental group, called the proposal an "unjustified giveaway to Archer Daniels Midland," the Illinois-based company that is the country's largest ethanol producer and that has given more than $1 million to the Republican Party so far this year, more than any other company.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, said he doubted the President's assertion that the proposal would clear the air.
"We have asked and asked," Mr. Waxman said, "but there is no detailed description of this proposal available. So we are expected to trust George Bush to protect the environment. Given his record, I do not think the American people can rest assured that this giveaway will not ultimately come at the expense of their health."
But Mr. Bush and his advisers were clearly pleased with the plan because of the effect they hope it will have in Indiana, Illinois, Missouri and Ohio, major corn-growing states. Illinois, Missouri and Ohio -- with 44 electoral votes in all -- are particularly crucial for Mr. Bush's re-election.
 
Quayle Announces First
 Hours before Mr. Bush's announcement, Vice President Dan Quayle told a group of farmers at an agricultural fair in Columbus, Ind., about the "good news."
"The President will announce a program that will further increase our consumption of ethanol," Mr. Quayle said. "Governor Clinton's response to ethanol has been rather simple. He has repealed the tax incentive for gasohol in the state of Arkansas. You've got a clear-cut choice of who's going to be on the side of farmers: the President or Governor Clinton."
Here in Washington, the National Corn Growers Association and representatives of the ethanol industry praised the President's plan. They said it would increase the amount of corn sold to ethanol makers by 100 million bushels annually by 1995.
This year, roughly 400 million bushels of corn are expected to be processed to produce 900 million gallons of ethanol. The widening use of ethanol as a fuel additive is largely due to a tax program that grants producers of fuels containing 10 percent ethanol a 5.4 cents-per-gallon exemption from gasoline taxes.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Reaction;
. . .As Clinton Refocuses Attack

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1

 BODY:
The Democrats today began planning a strategy to undermine Ross Perot's economic plan.
Mr. Clinton and his aides sketched a plan for the final weeks of the campaign that they hope will keep their team on track. They hope to capitalize on the weaknesses polls have identified in Mr. Perot's base of support while continuing the attack on President Bush. 
 Gov. Bill Clinton and his top aides appear to have been expecting today's announcement. In recent days, they have begun emphasizing the elements of Mr. Perot's plan that would call for higher taxes, like the gasoline tax, and cuts of entitlements in areas like Social Security. Confident that voters are not ready for such bold potions, they have begun to paint Mr. Perot as dangerously out of touch.
 
Deficit vs. Jobs
 "The problem I have with the Perot program is that it puts deficit reduction ahead of generating jobs," Mr. Clinton said in a radio interview in Cincinnati. Campaign aides said Mr. Clinton did not watch Mr. Perot's televised announcement and was informed of Mr. Perot's decision afterward.
But Mr. Clinton conceded in a television interview in Raleigh, N.C., that there could be a danger in the anti-Bush voters he has attracted being offered another alternative.
If there were any private concerns within the campaign about the new Perot campaign, it was not betrayed today in relaxed campaigning in Wisconsin, which included a visit to a small-town Dairy Queen.
Dee Dee Myers, the campaign's press secretary, said polls showed that Mr. Perot's strength was much less than what it was when he dropped out in July, an erosion that she said worked to Mr. Clinton's advantage.
"He doesn't change the outcome in any state," she said of Mr. Perot's presence on the ballot. "He kind of muddies it up in Texas, kind of muddies it up in Florida and North Carolina, states where Bush needs to win and where we're running pretty strong or very strong. In states like California, he takes probably a little more from us, but we're 20 points ahead."

HEADLINE: Congressional Panel Trims '93 Military Budget by 9%

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Voicing concerns about cutting military programs too deeply in a recessionary election year, House and Senate negotiators today approved a $274.3 billion military budget for the 1993 fiscal year that includes many weapons designed for the cold war era.
The compromise bill for the year that begins today represents a 9 percent decline, adjusted for inflation, from the $291 billion military budget for the previous year but cuts only $6.5 billion from President Bush's request. Lawmakers made no additional troop cuts beyond the Pentagon's recommendations and canceled few weapons programs. 
 In many ways, the bill marks a transition from lingering cold-war-era programs to what are likely to be several years of steep declines in military spending and a focus on regional military contingencies.
 
Saving Money, Saving Workers
 Lawmakers generally followed the Administration's proposed path toward a "base force" of 1.6 million in 1995 but signaled the first attempts to address new money-saving strategies, like buying more weapon prototypes before advancing to full production. They also plan to ease the transition for displaced workers in the weapons industry.
A 1990 agreement between Congress and the Administration that blocked the transfer of military spending to domestic programs expires this year, prompting many lawmakers and budget analysts to project deeper cuts next year in Pentagon spending.
"This year is the last year that the defense budget gets to tread water," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research organization here. "Next year the money disappears."
The measure adopted today supports development of the new Air Force F-22 fighter, a new aircraft carrier and the Army's light attack helicopter, the Comanche. It also provides $4.05 billion for the "Star Wars" anti-missile defense system -- about $100 million less than this year -- but sharply cuts spending for space-based weapons and delays the construction of a land-based anti-missile site to 2002, from 1996.
Even the main exception to this trend carries plenty of cold-war baggage: After some debate, Congress agreed with the Administration to end the B-2 Stealth bomber program after building 20 of the bat-winged, radar-evading aircraft. But the program's total cost, $44.4 billion, makes the B-2 the most expensive military aircraft ever.
The bill now advances to the full House and Senate, which are expected to approve it this weekend. Mr. Bush is expected to sign the measure.
"This bill begins to reinvest cold-war defense resources in American economic security," Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement.
Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said the Defense Department would reserve comment until the budget plan could be reviewed.
Lawmakers expressed concern about easing the pain for workers in the weapons industry and communities where bases will close by setting aside about $1.5 billion to help communities, displaced military personnel and factory workers.
 
Early Retirement
 One provision, originally offered by Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, allows military personnel with certain specialties to retire after 15 years, instead of 20. Personnel can receive credit for the five extra years by taking jobs in areas like education, law enforcement and health care.
The measure also supports the flagging weapons industry by approving $148 million to upgrade M1 tanks at the General Dynamics Corporation tank plant in Lima, Ohio.
In another program the Administration has not supported, lawmakers approved $755 million to develop and build the V-22 Osprey, which takes off like a helicopter and flies like a plane. In July, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney grudgingly agreed to spend the $1.5 billion that Congress had already authorized for the program.
The Pentagon's annual effort to reduce the number of reserve troops was again sharply curbed by lawmakers careful to protect one of their most sacred cows: The negotiators agreed to cut 39,000 reserve troops, instead of 116,000 as the Pentagon had requested. Lawmakers also approved $695.6 million for new night-vision equipment, trucks and C-130 transport planes for reserve units.
 
In Addition, . . .
 Also included in the legislation are these provisions:
*The Pentagon must conduct a thorough cost study of new combat aircraft, including the AX, the F-22 and the F/A-18.
*The Defense Department was ordered to review duplicative roles among the armed services.
*A 3.7 percent pay raise was granted to the 1.8 million active-duty forces, effective Jan. 1, 1993.
Both the House and Senate had included provisions that would repeal a Pentagon ban on virtually all abortions at American military hospitals overseas. But for the third consecutive year, President Bush's threat to veto the military budget bill if it included the abortion provision forced Congressional leaders to drop the language from the bill.
