HEADLINE: Increase in Jobless Claims Sours Outlook for Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
First-time claims for state unemployment benefits jumped 15,000, to 429,000, in the week ended Sept. 19, the fifth consecutive increase, the Labor Department reported today. From Arizona, meanwhile, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of manufacturing activity fell below 50, indicating contraction, for the first time since February.
The reports, both of which were weaker than expected, came as the economic and political worlds braced for publication Friday of monthly payroll and other labor-market data for September. This will be the final reading of this pre-eminent gauge of economic health before Election Day, with most analysts anticipating a further loss of jobs and perhaps an uptick in the jobless rate. 
 The bad news for President Bush and the Republicans, however, is that October is seen as producing a steady stream of figures reflecting a stagnant economy. Still worse, there is virtually nothing he or anybody else can do to redress matters for electoral advantage.
 "I think it's just going to be an accretion of weak economic statistics that show little or no economic growth," commented Lincoln F. Anderson, a senior economist for Fidelity Management and Research in Boston. "It's too late" for significant change, he added. "It's a done deal."
Even if Friday's report were to be mildly favorable, which a few analysts anticipate, it wouldn't have much effect on the Bush record. Joblessness, for example, has climbed about two percentage points, to the mid-7 percent range, since he came to office.
"The economy is a lost issue for Bush," said Kenneth T. Mayland, chief economist for Society National Bank in Cleveland, adding that "1992 is cooked, it's done." "Stick a fork in it," he said.
The broadest measure of the economy, the total output of goods and services within the nation's borders, is due to be published the Tuesday before Election Day. But while most analysts still believe gross domestic product will have expanded for the July-September period -- resulting in the sixth straight advance -- the gain is not expected to exceed the 1.5 percent annual rate posted during the spring.
In fact, Mr. Bush has yet to match the 3.2 percent advance in G.D.P. posted in the first quarter of 1989, during which he took office. And analysts believe third-quarter growth could be at a very skimpy rate of 1 percent or less.
 Voters looking at indicators with more immediate or clearer personal relevance will want to focus, after Friday's job report, on various sets of figures to be published at midmonth, particularly retail sales and consumer prices.
But analysts say there's little reason to expect significant improvement from August's five-tenths of 1 percent decline in retail sales -- worse when inflation is factored in -- though the numbers may benefit from a late Labor Day that no doubt deferred some back-to-school purchases that would normally have been made in August.
The price figures will very likely be a bright spot, analysts agree, with consumer inflation continuing to be held in check by economic malaise. But low inflation, as millions of voters have by now painfully learned, implies low interest rates and thus low returns on certificates of deposit and other fixed-income investments. Subdued inflation also means a relatively modest increase in cost-of-living allowances for more than 40 million people who receive Social Security and some other Federal benefits.
The 1993 cost-of-living allowance, based on the rise in prices for urban wage earners and clerical workers between the second quarter of 1991 and the second quarter of 1992, will be calculated when the Consumer Price Index is published Oct. 15. A cost-of-living allowance of about 3 percent is expected, the lowest since 1986.

HEADLINE: Big Shearson Charge Seen

 BODY:
The plunge in the Computervision Corporation's stock on Wednesday will probably result in a third-quarter pretax charge of between $100 million and $105 million for Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., which holds a 22 percent stake in Computervision.
That estimate, derived from company documents and confirmed yesterday by Shearson officials, represents more than a doubling of an earlier forecast by Shearson that it would take a pretax charge of between $40 million and $45 million because of Computervision. 
 The stock of Computervision took a beating this week in the wake of an announcement by its executives that third-quarter earnings would be "substantially below" expectations. They did not provide further details about the severity of the anticipated loss. The company blamed weak economic conditions in Europe and the United States for its woes.
Computervision's stock closed yesterday at $5.875, down 37.5 cents. On Wednesday, the last day of the Shearson's third quarter, its stock fell $3 to close at $6.25 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Computervision is a maker of software that helps companies design products. It also services computers, but no longer manufactures them.
John Keefe, an independent securities analyst, said this week's turmoil was far more disconcerting to Computervision and its shareholders than to investors in Shearson, for whom Computervision has become an old and familiar problem. Shearson was burdened in the second quarter by a $137 million pretax charge stemming from its investment in Computervision, whose name was recently changed from Prime Computer. Shearson has also lost $83 million in interest not collected on a loan it made to the company.
The two companies joined forces in 1989, when Shearson helped finance a leveraged buyout of Prime Computer. After the buyout, however, Shearson was unable to unload a $500 million loan because of a soft market for junk bonds.
Six weeks ago, Shearson helped Computervision conduct an initial public offering in which stock was sold at $12 a share.

HEADLINE: Two Top Posts Filled at American Ballet Theater

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON

 BODY:
Kevin McKenzie has been named the new artistic director of American Ballet Theater and Gary Dunning has been appointed the company's executive director. The announcement was made by Stephen J. Friedman, chairman of the governing trustees of Ballet Theater Foundation, after several months of uncertainty about the company's financial and artistic future.
Mr. McKenzie, who is 38 years old, was a principal dancer with Ballet Theater for 12 years. Mr. Dunning, also 38, joined the staff as assistant to the general manager in 1978 and was the general manager from 1984 to 1986, when he left to become executive director of the Houston Ballet. 
 A Ballet Theater spokesman said that the company's dancers burst into cheers when they were told of the appointments at a meeting yesterday morning.
The new directors will begin work immediately. Although neither has announced plans, it is expected that they will re-examine the company's budget and touring schedule.
 
Merger Plan Dismissed
 The troupe has a budget deficit that has been reported as $4 million to $5 million, and severe cash-flow problems that kept it from paying its dancers last month. A possible merger with the Joffrey Ballet, which is also financially strapped, was discussed by the boards of the two companies, but was dropped.
Mr. Dunning, a native of Bethesda, Md., and a graduate of Princeton University and the London School of Economics, said yesterday: "This is a time of great challenge for American Ballet Theater, and Stephen Friedman and the board of trustees deserve enormous credit for steering the company forward during the last few difficult months.
"We intend to meet these challenges head on, but it can only be with the generous support and active participation of all members of the A.B.T. family that our goals will be realized."
 
Silver Medalist at Varna
 Mr. McKenzie, whose appointment as artistic director had been widely rumored, was born in Burlington, Vt., and received his early training at the Washington School of Ballet. Before joining Ballet Theater as a soloist in 1979, he had been a leading dancer in the Joffrey Ballet and the now-defunct National Ballet of Washington; in 1972 he received a Silver Medal at the Sixth International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria. He was named a principal dancer of Ballet Theater in late 1979.
Acclaimed widely for his noble style in the 19th-century classics, Mr. McKenzie has also been praised in contemporary ballets by Antony Tudor, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins, Kenneth MacMillan and George Balanchine. He was appointed a permanent guest artist of the Washington Ballet in 1989; he became artistic associate of that company two years later and left Ballet Theater. He has also been associate artistic director of the New Amsterdam Ballet, a small touring group founded by Martine van Hamel.
"For many years, American Ballet Theater was my home as a dancer, and it is with great pride that I return in my new capacity," Mr. McKenzie said yesterday. "The dancers of American Ballet Theater are the finest in the world and represent the pinnacle of artistic achievement."
 
'Extraordinarily Fortunate'
 Mr. Friedman released a statement in which he said: "Kevin McKenzie has enjoyed a prestigious career as one of the leading dancers of his generation and possesses a rich and highly developed knowledge of both the contemporary and classical repertoire. Mr. Dunning has played a key role in the ongoing success of one of the leading regional companies in the United States, and is a highly respected figure on the international dance scene. We are extraordinarily fortunate to have a new generation of leadership by such talented and esteemed figures."
Interviewed after the announcement, Cynthia Harvey, a principal dancer with the company, said: "It was a joyous announcement. Being in limbo has been a scary prospect for the company's dancers. Gary has tremendous qualifications as a manager. And Kevin is a real gentleman, as a dancer, as a partner and as a human being. He's always been helpful and caring, and he told us that he wants to keep the lines of communication open."
Mr. Friedman said that Oliver Smith, the theatrical designer who was the company's co-director with Lucia Chase from 1945 to 1980 and with Jane Hermann from 1990 until the end of last season, would remain in an advisory capacity and hold the title of director emeritus.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Transition In Romania: An Instant History

BYLINE: By Frank Rich

 BODY:
"Mad Forest," first produced by the New York Theater Workshop, has reopened at the Manhattan Theater Club, City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Following are excerpts from Frank Rich's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Dec. 5, 1991.
Three months after the 1989 fall of the Ceausescus, the British playwright Caryl Churchill, a director named Mark Wing-Davey and 10 of Mr. Wing-Davey's acting students went to Romania on what promised to be a preposterous mission. Their aim was to become instant experts on a nation in postrevolutionary turmoil and to make a play about what they saw. Their visit was scarcely longer than a week. 
 Can you picture the results already? The acting students, being by definition romantics, would create a let-a-thousand-flowers-bloom pageant. Miss Churchill, being an archetypal Royal Court Theater ideologue of her day, would insist on equating Elena Ceausescu with Margaret Thatcher.
Or so one might reasonably imagine. But real artists are unpredictable. There is nothing knee-jerk about "Mad Forest," as Miss Churchill named her play, and it turns out to be just as surprising, inventive and disturbing as the author's "Top Girls" and "Fen." The piece has not dated the way newspaper accounts of the same history already have. If anything, this "play from Romania," as it is subtitled, seems to seep beyond its specific events and setting to illuminate a broader nightmare of social collapse, especially in the insinuating production Mr. Wing-Davey has fashioned with a crack American cast.
"Mad Forest" can penetrate beneath the surface of its well-chronicled story precisely because it is not journalism. Only in the second (and least successful) of the three acts, a Living Newspaper in which the company temporarily simulates Romanian accents to recite an anecdotal oral history of the tumultuous week after the massacre of demonstrators at Timisoara, does the play purport to traffic in documentary reality. The rest of "Mad Forest" forgets about the facts, which remain murky anyway in Romania, and exerts a theatrical imagination to capture the truth about people who remain in place no matter what regimes come and go.
Miss Churchill devotes her first and third acts to an examination of two Bucharest families, one of laborers and one of intellectuals, before and after the revolution. The author's technique is elliptical and atmospheric, often in the manner of Eastern European fiction of the Kundera and Havel era.
In Act I, the double lives of people trapped in a totalitarian state are dramatized by gesture and image rather than by the dialogue, which is oblique or insincere, lest the dread secret police, the Securitate, be eavesdropping. In Act III, the liberated Romanians do little but talk, but they often talk over one another, screaming and arguing in paroxysms of xenophobia and paranoia that sometimes seem even more frightening than the sullen episodes of repression that precede them.
As is the playwright's style, some vignettes are meanly funny. But such conventional political satire is eventually overwhelmed by a more surreal form of theater. Mythological figures enter the action, among them an archangel and an elegant Transylvanian vampire drawn by the smell of blood. As the phantasmagoric sequences grow more grotesque, Miss Churchill gives poetic voice to the new crisis of a society in which the old totalitarian order has splintered into a no less malignant disorder. Abruptly the new democrats look suspiciously like the old Fascists and a hunt for class and racial enemies becomes the pathological preoccupation of people who remain hungry and enraged.
By using a small cast to populate this large canvas, Miss Churchill once again provides exceptional opportunities for actors to play multiple roles. What Mr. Wing-Davey achieves with his familiar but often unsung New York ensemble evokes memories of Tommy Tune's achievement with the American cast of Miss Churchill's "Cloud 9" a decade ago.
As designed by Marina Draghici (sets) and Christopher Akerlind (lighting), the physical production conjures up shadowy tableaux as evocative as the play's title, which refers to the dense forest that once stood where Bucharest is now and was, as a program note says, "impenetrable for the foreigner who did not know the paths." Miss Churchill does not pretend to know those paths, either -- each scene is pointedly introduced by a banal sentence read from a tourist's Romanian phrasebook -- but she does see the forest, not the trees. Nowhere is this clearer than in the play's wedding finale, where every element of the production whirls together in an explosively choreographed panorama of drunken revelry and sadistic, retributive violence.
Few lines can be heard over the ensuing pandemonium -- "This country needs a strong man" is one -- and the chaos that engulfs the theater is terrifying. Surely I was not the only American in the audience who found the climax of "Mad Forest," with its vision of an economically and racially inflamed populace on a rampage for scapegoats, a little too close to home.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rocco Sisto, left, and Rob Campbell in Caryl Churchill's "Mad Forest." (Gerry Goodstein)

HEADLINE: Easy Diner's Road Map to the Hudson Valley

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
IN the 1954 film "The Wild One," Marlon Brando, the leader of a rowdy motorcycle gang, roars into a small town, takes a shine to a cafe waitress, eventually smashes up the place and terrorizes the citizens, then high-tails it out of town. In my less confrontational 1992 fantasy, I bomb into small towns in a gang of one, drop into restaurants with nerdy helmet-flattened hair and wind-blown clothes (no cafe Casanova, to be sure), eat as much as possible while surreptitiously scribbling notes, then careen down the road considerably heavier than I arrived.
Hardly movie fodder, but it's great fun. 
 Perhaps it was the storm clouds as I approached age 40 this year that prompted a burning need for reckless self-expression and put me on a motorcycle. More likely, it was the fact that my 5-foot-2, 106-pound wife, Mireille, kept a motorcycle at our Hudson River Valley home and I felt wimpy tooling around in a Subaru station wagon.
No sooner had I figured out which brake slowed the bike gradually and which could toss you over the handlebars like a well-kicked field goal than I was riding to restaurants. What a way to prepare for a fine meal! Pristine air, magnificent scenery, the exhilarating aromas of fall foliage.
Of course, there are complications in being a chopper gourmand.
Dressing is problematical, especially if you visit a jacket-and-tie establishment. Most of my motorcycle jackets are too tight to wear over a sport coat; I tied mine to bungee cords on the back of the bike, which left it looking as if it had been used as a beach towel all day. Moreover, light-colored pants invariably wind up with biker's lint -- grease spots -- around the ankles. Leather shoes are slippery on the gear pedal, and no matter how carefully you put on a helmet, you arrive at the restaurant with a deranged-looking Lon Chaney hairdo.
Upon buying a bike, I promised Mireille that I would never drink and ride a motorcycle, which should go without saying. So I am reduced to wistful swirling and sniffing at the table, sort of like a dog examining a giant steak bone on the kitchen counter.
Weather is a major issue on a motorcycle gastronomic tour: more than once I arrived at my destination soaked and shivering to meet my dining partners. Then there are the issues of gravel parking lots, a biker's nightmare; dealing with valet parking, doggie bags, and more. To a dedicated biker gourmand, however, these are mere bagatelles that could never deter us from our 500-cubic-centimeter mission.
O.K., gang, as Brando said, let's scramble.
 
Piermont
 The southernmost stop of this rolling gastronomic tour of the Hudson River Valley was Piermont, a little bird's beak of land in Rockland County that juts into the Hudson just south of the Tappan Zee Bridge. I approached via the Palisades Parkway (a relatively smooth ride), then spiraled down toward the waterfront on steep, winding residential streets lined with pastel two-story houses. Piermont Avenue is the busy main commercial thoroughfare with cafes, shops and galleries. It is also a riverside agora for motorcyclists.
The 40 seats at XAVIAR'S AT PIERMONT are hotter than Harley-Davidsons at a small-town parade. Locals reserve weeks in advance. The diminutive, elegant restaurant with waiters in black tie is owned by Peter Xaviar Kelly, the chef, while his brother, Ned, runs the front. Chef Kelly also runs a lavish operation across the river in Garrison, in a mansion bordering a golf course, that is called simply Xaviar's.
The Piermont restaurant is highly refined, essentially French and right on target more often than not. We started with a giveaway of lobster meat in dill sauce with caviar over sliced cucumber, then moved on to terribly salty shrimp with a clashing mango coulis. Much better are the lobster ravioli with a silken butter sauce and the woodsy pasta with morels. An au courant seared tuna with wasabi and soy sauce is perfectly executed, as is black bass gift-wrapped in thin potato slices with a butter-and-chive sauce. Duck breast fanned out over Oriental vegetables studded with confit of duck was a nice idea; however, the duck breast was gray and dryish.
Desserts are wonderful, especially the chocolate souffle cake and the raspberry souffle. Xaviar's also has a big-league French and American wine list with reasonable prices.
 
Brewster
 Brewster, on the east side of the Hudson, is near the intersection of Routes 684 and 22, not far from the Connecticut border. I took a quick detour through the pleasant though economically depressed business district, then headed up Route 22 to THE ARCH, which has been a special-occasion restaurant for Westchester and Connecticut residents for nearly 25 years.
The Arch is a welcoming, unpretentious restaurant, with a little bar near the entrance, a flagstone terrace for warm-weather dining, several small, simply appointed dining rooms, and servers in black tie. This is a pampering place where fine details do not go unnoticed. The cuisine is classical French, with rich, intense sauces and generous portions. The meal I shared with friends was not memorable, but the overall experience was enchanting.
We started with tasty lobster ravioli in a frothy, dill-flavored Champagne sauce, followed by a decent, though strong, commercial smoked duck breast with a warm potato-and-herb dressing. An unbalanced cold cucumber soup packed enough acid to burn a hole through my motorcycle's paint job. The traditional onion soup gratinee, made with a stout beef stock, was much better.
It was a challenge finding a reasonably priced wine on the upscale list, but my party finally went with a crisp and relatively light $29 Ferrari-Carano chardonnay. For a main course, I tried the baby chicken with a Bordelaise sauce to see how the chef could execute that benchmark dish. The kitchen did well on both counts, although the potato timbale and grilled tomato with it were bland. Duck with green peppercorns was pleasing, too, although the same dull vegetables reappeared. Roasted quail, superfluously paired with a grilled tournedo, was nonetheless well turned out. Same vegetables, though.
Pass on the inelegant creme brulee. Instead, try the elegant chocolate souffle or the very sweet (but well-textured) mocha meringue cake. Dinner is prix fixe at $45.
 
Stormville
 A short hop off the Taconic State Parkway just north of Interstate 84 is a don't-blink-you'll-miss-it town called Stormville, home of a most remarkable institution called HARRALDS . This 21-year-old restaurant is the embodiment of the courtly, effusive Harrald Boerger.
"Our trout are as fresh as they can possibly be because they come from a little pond right outside, which you may have noticed on your way in," Mr. Boerger says, adding that his bartender, Eugene, smokes them himself over the finest blend of fruit woods. The trout story goes on for several minutes until you know everything about the happy little flappers except their names.
The setting is romantic, sort of a Teutonic cabin with timbered ceiling, a big stone hearth and brass chandeliers.
As for the food, prepared by Mr. Boerger's wife, Ava Durrschmidt, it nearly lives up to her husband's billing. The trout, smoked with horseradish cream or sauteed, is terrific. Galantine of veal with pistachios is chunky and well seasoned. Main courses include a perfectly roasted duck with Calvados sauce and wild rice, and filet mignon with a well-balanced sauce choron (bearnaise sauce with tomato puree added). A cheese course follows, with port. Desserts are on the heavy side but good: linzer torte, chocolate mousse cake and a poppyseed-apple cake.
 
Millbrook
 The ride through Dutchess County's horse country to ALLYN'S near Millbrook is among the most spectacular in the valley. Well-tended Black Angus farms and magnificent stables for race horses alternate with multi-million-dollar estates. Allyn's, in a 200-year-old reconstructed farmhouse, is a well-meaning place that sometimes lacks the horsepower to meet its ambitious goals. Allyn Katz, the chef and owner, is a Culinary Institute of America graduate who has worked at the Hudson River Club in Manhattan.
I stopped at Allyn's for lunch and sat in the barn board-lined casual dining room with polo prints on the walls. A charming, more formal glassed-in room is open at night.
Gravlax is fine, served with bland yellow lentils. A white bean and escarole soup with chunks of ham is hearty and full flavored. Not so an insipid seafood salad. Best main courses are the simplest: hamburger, skirt steak with tapenade, and grilled chicken with mesclun, roasted peppers and sun-dried tomatoes. Servers have more personality than skill.
Allyn's has an exceptionally well-rounded wine list with a good selection of New York State labels.
 
Cold Spring
 Cold Spring is one of the most beautiful towns in the Hudson Valley, on a bend in the river where the highest mountains between New York City and Albany plunge down to the water. This 19th-century village, filled with antiques shops, inns and restaurants, is a tourist destination in the fall. Most visitors dine at one of the inns or restaurants near the waterfront, none of which have impressed me. Those in the know seek out a friendly publike spot, hidden behind a row of retail shops on Main Street, called VINTAGE CAFE .
One expects tavern grub in this all-wood setting replete with American artifacts. The soft-spoken owner and chef, Christopher Caul, offers a startlingly large selection of international fare, with an emphasis on Mexican. His wife, Cathy, runs the dining room. The salad of goat cheese and sun-dried tomatoes is a good way to start, as is the gutsy (and spicy) black bean soup. Chilies rellenos are exceptional, filled with a blend of goat cheese and cheddar and served over a tortilla.
Two of the best main courses sampled were blackened pork tenderloin with guacamole and a mild red salsa, and swordfish in a tomato cream sauce with capers. And if you have been on a motorcycle all day without eating, you might tackle the daunting but well-balanced fettuccine with scallops, lobster and tasso -- the spicy Louisiana sausage -- in a rich lobster cream sauce. On Monday nights the menu is all-Mexican.
I was disappointed to see the list at a Hudson Valley place called Vintage Cafe ignore most local wines. But there are some good buys among California labels.
 
Saugerties
 CAFE TAMAYO was the happiest surprise on this extended motorcycle tour. The trip over the Kingston-Rhinecliff Bridge at sunset, with the river valley stretching for miles in both directions, was dangerously distracting. Saugerties, about 10 miles north of the bridge along the west bank of the river, seems an odd place for an ambitious restaurant. But Rickie and James Tamayo, hostess and chef respectively, thought otherwise.
Their restaurant, in a brick building dating to 1864, has a magnificent old mahogany bar, a painted tin ceiling, and overhead fans that are powered by a series of belts connected to a motor in the basement.
Mr. Tamayo's essentially American cooking has no particular theme or statement: it's just good, flavorful food for a fair price. We started with fried goat cheese in a light breading with a lush sauce of red peppers and garlic, outstanding potato pancakes studded with smoked salmon, and excellent white bean soup garnished with basil. For main courses, there was succulent braised lamb with saffron rice, and grilled lamb -- overcooked, unfortunately -- with a potato gratin. Confit of duck was falling-off-the-bone tender and rich, with red onion marmalade and wild rice, and aged shell steak with gratineed potatoes was right on target, too.
Mr. Tamayo is serious about his wines, and there are plenty of interesting selections at good prices.
 
Catskill
 LA RIVE, well-hidden in the west bank town of Catskill, looks more like a motorcycle gang's clubhouse than a locally renowned French restaurant. The long, rut-scarred dirt road that winds down to a wooded creek gives first-timers second thoughts. At first glance, the restaurant looks like the porch of a charmless country bungalow, which is precisely what it is. But as soon as you meet Marseilles-born Paulette Macary, an earthy dynamo who founded the restaurant 23 years ago with her husband, Rene (who died in 1987), all doubts are dispelled.
Indeed, guests dine on the porch sitting on vinyl-and-wood chairs at closely assembled tables. Suspended from the ceiling are bird cages that serve as chandeliers. Matronly waitresses serve a big platter holding nine different appetizers, including chick pea salad, lentils in red wine, eggplant salad, cod mousse and pickled herring. A soup course follows: chunky fish chowder that needs salt, and a rather pallid leek-and-potato soup.
Main courses were the best: a special of roasted pork stuffed with brandy-soaked prunes and tasty gratineed potatoes, and rare-cooked lamb with Provencal herbs. Prices are all inclusive and vary according to the entree, in our case $26 and $28.75. Chocolate cake was sweet enough to make a teen-ager groan; peach cobbler looked as if my Honda had run over it, but the fresh peaches were delicious.
La Rive has a short but ingenious French wine list. Mrs. Macary's answer to the computer-generated documents that can be changed weekly is a sheet on which "19" is printed in ink and the last two digits are written in pencil. To change vintages, all she needs is an eraser.
 
Tivoli
 Route 9 along the east bank of the Hudson River, just north of Rhinebeck, is a pleasant blend of rolling farmland and villages dotted with antiques shops. About 10 miles north of Rhinebeck, I turned onto a roller-coaster country lane that leads to Tivoli, a riverside hamlet of one intersection and a smattering of four-story 19th-century brick buildings.
The only action in Tivoli is at a surprisingly good Mexican restaurant, SANTA FE , right in the center of town. On clement days, a wooden porch is filled with margarita-slurping students from nearby Bard College. A motorcycle or two can often be seen parked out front.
This funky, popular spot, with an old wood bar up front and an open kitchen nearby, serves both traditional and contemporary Mexican-style fare that is characterized by clean, distinctive flavors. Among my favorites are the enchilada stuffed with roasted chicken, sun-dried tomatoes, spinach and local goat cheese; tacos of chicken, cilantro, onion and mole poblano; grilled pork tenderloin with a roasted pepper salsa, and the lusty black bean stew.
 
Rhinebeck
 Rhinebeck, about 100 miles north of Manhattan on the east side of the Hudson River, offers the biker many attractions: handsome architecture, shopping, antiques, good food and a vintage airplane museum, the Aerodrome, which stages mock dogfights every Sunday. For some reason, scores of bikers show up every week.
Rhinebeck has two restaurants worth visiting. One is THE BEEKMAN 1766 TAVERN, in the Beekman Arms Hotel, purported to be the oldest continuously operated hostelry in the United States. I like the woody pub room with its low ceiling, stone hearth and long bar featuring a good selection of wines by the glass. Many visitors prefer the more formal glass-enclosed porch with a view of the town.
Until two years ago, the food at "the Beek" could have made Colonial soldiers groan. But then the restaurant was taken over by Larry Forgione, the owner of An American Place in Manhattan. Under his full-time chef, Melissa Kelly, quality improved dramatically, yet prices remained pegged to the local economy.
Try the winsome appetizer called house-smoked salmon and potato crisp napoleon, which is layers of salmon and crunchy potatoes with lemon cream and chive oil. Crab cakes are a winner, too, as is the charred carpaccio of beef with grilled wild mushrooms and fried onions.
Recommended main-course specialties include Atlantic salmon roasted on a cedar plank with a pudding of roasted garlic and corn; lamb shank in a lamb broth with barley, beets and tomatoes, and yellowfin tuna encrusted with black sesame seeds. In cool weather, there is a paragon of chicken pot pie.
Just across the street, in downtown Rhinebeck, is a beguiling place called LE PETIT BISTRO, operated by an affable French couple, Yvonne and Jean- Paul Croizer. It's a snug spot, all wood with a little crescent-shaped bar and high-backed banquettes. Mr. Croizer toils in a kitchen the size of a Chevy van, turning out a coarse, well-seasoned pork terrine; good onion soup; roast duck with a charred skin and an orange sauce cut with tart orange zest; tuna steak au poivre, and a beefy sirloin steak. Quality wines are available at affordable prices.
Some 900 miles and 9,000 calories later, my motorcycle fantasy has been fulfilled. This winter, it's back to the Subaru.

HEADLINE: Issues of Race, in Talk and Tragedy

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
None of the panelists on "The Issue Is Race: A Crisis in Black and White" are happy about the state of relations between white and black Americans, but they are not happy about one another either. Tonight's two-hour free-for-all, provoked by Phil Donahue, is marked by the differences in approach and style of the black participants, who, for once, are in the majority.
Starting with what might roughly be considered the left, they include: Sister Souljah, the rap performer who was taken to task by Gov. Bill Clinton for seeming to justify the black youths who helped burn and loot Los Angeles; Dhoruba Bin Wahad, a former Black Panther now described as an activist; Anna Deavere Smith, who wrote and performed a one-woman show about the 1991 race riots in Crown Heights, Brooklyn; Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly of Washington, and Alan Keyes, the Republican candidate for the Senate from Maryland. 
 There is no semblance of a meeting point between the condemnations of white America that dominate Sister Souljah's rap rant and Mr. Wahad's soapbox radicalism on one side, and, on the other, Mr. Keyes's exhortations to use the system to win political and economic power for minorities, even though that may mean an alliance with George Bush.
Sister Souljah's bored and baleful expression when Mr. Keyes makes his argument tells the story. But she does not often settle for silent comment; she outtalks everybody. She is, after all, in the rap game, and when things heat up, Mr. Donahue has difficulty keeping her and Mr. Wahad from taking over. The audience seems to be on their side.
The program is prevented from becoming a Sister Souljah special by a leavening of mini-documentaries. Sylvester Monroe of Time magazine makes a case for government assistance to the inner cities; Tony Brown, who has his own PBS program, "Tony Brown's Journal," argues for the virtues of black self-help, and Cornel West, the director of Afro-American Studies at Princeton University, reports on the success of a multi-racial alliance in a redevelopment plan for New Brunswick, N.J. It can only be taken as a fraternal rebuke to Sister Souljah and Mr. Wahad when Professor West says that "rage, as real and authentic as it is, cannot have the last word."
 
'Murder in Mississippi'
A&E Network
Tonight at 9
Race is also at the center of "Murder in Mississippi," an hourlong report on recent disclosures about the 1964 murder of three young civil rights workers by Ku Klux Klan members.
The main revelation in this account of how James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner were taken from their car and killed near Philadelphia, Miss., is that a black informant within the civil rights movement kept track of their whereabouts for state officials, who then passed the information along to the Klan. The alleged informant, who is now prominent in the state N.A.A.C.P., denies everything on camera, but the evidence presented here is at least compromising.
Bill Kurtis, who anchors this edition of "Investigative Reports," notes that in the weeks of searching for the bodies of Mr. Chaney, who was black, and Mr. Goodman and Mr. Schwerner, who were white, the F.B.I. found the bodies of nine black men whose disappearance had until then never been investigated. The most chilling thought left by this stark report is that if Mr. Chaney had not been in the company of two white men from out of state, his death, too, would probably have gone unnoticed by the nation. It's the sort of history that breeds Sister Souljahs and Dhoruba Bin Wahads.
 
The Issue Is Race
PBS, tonight at 9
(Channel 13 in New York)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Bush: Attacking Clinton's Tax Proposal

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The Bush campaign began broadcasting a new 30-second commercial yesterday. The campaign said it would get national exposure but would not be specific.
ON THE SCREEN -- Opens with a black screen that fades into the legend, "Here's what Clinton economics could mean to you." The announcer says Mr. Clinton has promised to raise taxes only on the rich but that the real story is different. In a departure for campaign ads, the announcer is a woman. The camera then cuts to quick shots of taxpayers, showing their name, occupation and the amount the Bush campaign says their taxes would go up under Mr. Clinton. The ad ends with the new Bush slogan about a Clinton Presidency: "It's wrong for America."
TELEVISION SCRIPT -- Announcer: "Bill Clinton says he'll only tax the rich to pay for his campaign promises. But here's what Clinton economics could mean to you. (John Canes, steam fitter) $1,088 more in taxes. (Lori Huntoon, scientist) $2,072 more in taxes.
"One-hundred leading economists say his plan means higher taxes . . . and bigger deficits. (Julie and Gary Schwartz, sales representatives) $1,191 more in taxes. (Wyman Winston, housing lender), $2,072 more in taxes.
"You can't trust Clinton economics. It's wrong for you. It's wrong for America."
ACCURACY -- Mr. Clinton's promise to tax only the rich is faithfully repeated.
But the estimated tax burdens for the five people mentioned in the commercial are based on economic proposals for which Mr. Clinton has not provided enough information for such detailed analysis or on figures that do not always follow Mr. Clinton's proposals.
The Bush team says Mr. Clinton's estimates of how much he would raise by taxing the richest Americans are wrong. They say that to pay for his programs, people earning somewhere between $20,000 and $30,000 a year will have to pay the higher rate.
 But the Bush campaign uses figures that cannot be reconciled with Mr. Clinton's figures. Bush aides acknowledged that they were making a leap of logic: that Mr. Clinton would not have enough money to keep his campaign promises and will therefore tax the middle class rather than revising his plans.
 The ad makes no mention of Mr. Clinton's proposal for a $60 billion tax cut for the middle class.
SCORECARD -- As it fine-tunes its attack on Mr. Clinton, the Bush campaign is trying to paint him as a tax-and-spend liberal. The spot also tries to portray Mr. Bush as the protector of the middle class, which the Democrats say has been badly burt by 12 years of Republican leadership in the White House. The use of the steam fitter seems intended to identify Mr. Bush with the concerns of blue-collar workers and the overall tone of the ad fits neatly into the appeal to suburban voters that is central to Mr. Bush's electoral strategy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
FIRST FIDELITY CUTS PRIME LENDING RATE TO 5 1/2%

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The First Fidelity Bancorp of New Jersey cut its prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point to 5 1/2 percent, the first bank in the country to reduce the rate in three months. First Fidelity, the nation's 23d-largest bank holding company, said the rate cut applied to all its 523 branches in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The prime rate is used by many banks as a benchmark for a wide range of loans. 
 Other banks did not immediately follow the move by First Fidelity, a banking company, based in Lawrenceville, N.J., that has historically not taken the lead in interest-rate adjustments. The last time the big banks reduced their prime rate was July 2, when they lowered it a quarter percentage point, to 6 percent. The drop yesterday, if it does spread, would put the prime at its lowest level since the summer of 1972, when it stood at 5 1/4 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: The Uses of Ross Perot

 BODY:
He's through with the teasing but not the trifling. At the "request" of what's left of his once-impressive volunteer army, Ross Perot has resumed his Presidential race. His chances of winning are much less than when he quit in July. His only dim practical hope is to confuse and destabilize the contest. But there is one important way in which Mr. Perot's quixotic candidacy can serve constructive purposes.
His economic program, published after his withdrawal, contains many bold and sensible ideas. If he's now willing to carry these ideas to the public and defend them in detail, he will sharpen the debate and do much to educate the country. But that will require a candor and courage he has so far failed to display. 
 Mr. Perot's announcement sounded all the standard chords of piety -- honesty, military valor, selfless service, competitiveness, fiscal responsibility. He produced a Purple Heart from a wounded Vietnam veteran and a touching letter from a child. It was part Sinclair Lewis, part Lee Iacocca, effective except for one creepy line: "I will not," he said, "spend one minute answering questions that are not directly relevant to the issues that concern the American people."
There he goes again: the old imperious Ross Perot. Taken at face value, that sentence would seem to rule out all questions about his arrogance, his occasionally cavalier attitude toward the Constitution, about his penchant for espionage and intimidation. Questions, in sum, about character and style wholly relevant to a candidate's fitness for office.
The good news is that Mr. Perot wants people to ask him about the economy -- how he would eliminate the crushing $4 trillion deficit, rebuild "the job base and the industrial base" and "make the words 'Made in the U.S.A. once again the world's standard for excellence." It will be interesting to see whether he's ready to fully share his answers.
Earlier, Mr. Perot bristled when anyone asked what his positions were. Then after he quit he published a program for deficit reduction and economic revival more detailed than that of Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton.
It contains a lot of pain -- higher taxes on many Americans, sharply higher gasoline taxes, limits on mortgage interest deductions, new taxes on wealthier recipients of sacred entitlement programs. It's not perfect but it warrants serious debate. The trouble is, the program remains within the covers of Ross Perot's book; the candidate himself has shown little appetite for articulating it.
There was a brief hint yesterday that he might now do so. Does he really mean to push up the cost of gasoline for "the average American"? Yes. Gasoline in the U.S. is far too cheap, he said, and a tax could help rebuild crumbling infrastructure.
It was probably the first time in the campaign that Ross Perot has carved beneath the surface of generality. Even if he has no chance to win the election, he could salvage a reputation now marked by caprice by doing more of the same.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Great Grovel

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The banker at the New York dinner party had made a huge loan to a speculator who used the money to take over a fine American business, swiftly spinning the company into bankruptcy.
I asked the banker how he could have made a loan that so quickly cost many workers their jobs. He said if he had passed it up some other bank would have made the loan, and the loan profit. I asked him if that was the way he wanted to go on living his one life; he said no. 
 In Dallas, Republicans and Democrats acted like that banker. They crawled to Ross Perot although most of them were deeply distrustful of him. They were afraid the other fellows would crawl there first and make the vote profit. At least that banker can say he did not know that the borrower was a cheapjack.
Republicans and Democrats knew that Ross Perot had brutally walked out on millions of Americans who trusted him. They knew that his new candidacy, which he announced yesterday, would be a piece of cut-rate trickery -- a way for him to push himself forward as a national leader, at no political cost and with not much out of pocket either.
They knew that the economic plan they were summoned to Dallas to discuss and revere was the Perot Plan Not. He had never endorsed it before he quit. He would have had to defend it in detail and pay in votes for demanding more taxes. Right?
They knew that even now he is not capable of more economic expertise on his own than waving his paperback around on TV, when he can find it.
When the going got tough, Mr. Perot got out. He dropped back in when it looked nice and easy. With only a few weeks left, he could not be pushed very hard on economics -- nor on other plans he promised but never delivered. He announces that personal matters are beneath him so he will discuss only Real Issues. Then he ducks issue-questions. I love it.
The Repubocrats -- in Dallas nobody could tell the pilgrims apart -- had come to know Mr. Perot, well. Before Dallas they asked, with that knowing nudge -- what's ticking away inside that man, anyway?
But when he crooked his finger, they ran to Dallas, pumping up his cruel farce to national drama. They did not speak what they knew about Mr. Perot, because the other party was fishing for his votes or blessing. So they all pretended he was still worthy of national trust.
One happy thought: Neither Republican nor Democrat will have the right to use the word "pander" again about a living soul.
I suppose that if Republican leaders could sit smirking at their convention while Patrick Buchanan, in his sour passions, called America to holy war against itself, why, bending to kiss whatever part of Ross Perot was available was no trick at all.
But haven't Democrats told us they are dying for the chance to change the old hypocrisies and govern America in a cleaner way? I recall that. But they sure did kiss him -- quick.
Even Al Gore, that good man we New Yorkers like to like, told David Frost that Mr. Perot was a team player and hinted he would be acceptable in a Clinton cabinet.
Ross Perot? Wasn't he the player who walked off the field after the press called a strike or two on him during the early innings, smartly giving the finger to his team, umpires and audience, all?
Cabinet? Al, say it isn't so.
The worst part about that Dallas show is this: Hypocrisy is poison ivy -- it rubs off on you.
I was surprised that so many fine people of both parties made themselves part of it. I winced when I saw them standing around looking embarrassed after the closed seances with the master and his disciples.
But when I ran into one of them later and asked him how come he went, and he said, well, the party asked him, what could he do, all I did was nod, and say sure.
The Dallas exhibition increases American political cynicism. And it makes both parties more vulnerable to that great team player when, soon enough, he sticks it to them again.
But in sweet hope eternal, let us dream that the major candidates will now stand straight about Mr. Perot, just because they do not want to live their one lives with dusty knees.
They may lose some votes. But they may pick up more from Americans who do not want to live that way either; never can tell.

HEADLINE: Senate Endorses Pact to Reduce Strategic Arms

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
With a decade of negotiations and an era of superpower rivalry gone by, the Senate endorsed an arms control treaty today that sharply reduces the numbers of long-range nuclear weapons held by the United States and four republics of the former Soviet Union.
Even greater cuts in nuclear arms are already planned under a later agreement reached last June by President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. That agreement, currently being translated into treaty language, would cut warheads to 3,000 in the Russian arsenal and 3,500 in the American one, less than a third of today's levels. 
 But the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which was signed in July 1991 and was voted on by the Senate today, carries importance beyond its numerical reductions in warheads. The treaty breaks new ground by actually reducing rather than merely limiting the growth in the most powerful weapons.
 
Reductions Already Under Way
 Some of those reductions are already under way, but the treaty makes them legally binding, and it dictates that the arms to be removed include some of the powerful land-based varieties that arms control experts consider the most destabilizing and dangerous.
At the same time, it prevents the breakup of the Soviet Union from scattering nuclear forces among several new republics, since only Russia would retain nuclear arms. Ukraine, Belarus and Khazakstan, three newly independent republics where Soviet missiles were based, will have to become non-nuclear states under the treaty's terms.
 
Vote Was 93-6
 That process could take years and may yet prove difficult, arms control experts said. In Ukraine's legislature, for example, there is large resistance to handing over weapons to Russia and embracing non-nuclear status.
If it happens, the disarmament of Ukraine, Belarus and Khazakstan would be the first time that any state with nuclear weapons has renounced them altogether.
The vote on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, which like all treaties must win the Senate's consent by a two-thirds majority, was 93-6, with only a few conservative members still opposing a pact whose momentum had gained steadily as the Soviet Union crumbled and the tensions between the two biggest nuclear powers relaxed.
The treaty will reduce the total number of long-range nuclear warheads in the United States arsenal to 8,556, compared with 12,646 in 1990. Russia will retain 6,163 warheads, compared with the 11,012 held by the former Soviet Union in 1990.
Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, noting the lingering uncertainties over carrying out the treaty, called it "a dream and a prayer to the tooth fairy."
But Acting Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, in a letter to Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, said approval of the treaty was needed to push the former Soviet republics forward.
"The history of the cold war will not be over until Start is ratified and has entered into force," Mr. Eagleburger said.
 
Soviet Aid Also Approved
 The Senate also passed a foreign aid bill that would provide $417 million to the former Soviet republics if they meet standards for human rights and carry out democratic and economic reforms. The measure would also provide $12 billion in new lending for the International Monetary Fund, some of which might flow to the republics. The House has approved a similar bill.
The treaty approved by the Senate today was negotiated with the Soviet Union, mostly during the Reagan Administration, and was signed at a Moscow summit meeting between President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in July 1991.
After the breakup of the Soviet Union, Russia assumed operational control over the Soviet nuclear weapons, and Mr. Yeltsin said at once that Moscow would respect the treaty as negotiated. Under a separate protocol, negotiated after the dissolution of Soviet Union, the republics of Kazakhstan, Belarus and Ukraine have become parties to the treaty as well.
Kazakhstan's legislature has already approved the treaty protocol, which was signed in Lisbon in May by the United States and all four republics in which the Soviet Union based nuclear weapons. None of the other former Soviet republics' legislatures have yet approved it, although they are expected to do so before the end of the year.
But even those votes will not put the treaty into effect. That only happens when all five parties exchange what diplomats call the "instruments of ratification." And neither Russia nor the United States is likely to do so until Ukraine and the other republics take further steps.
Under the protocols signed by all sides, Ukraine and the other republics must declare that they will join the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as non-nuclear states, meaning that they give up their nuclear weapons and forswear ever building any more.
The Ukrainian Government has said it hopes to do this, but it cannot guarantee that its legislature will go along, and nobody can say for sure whether the opposition to such a step can muster a parliamentary majority.

An article yesterday about Senate endorsement of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty referred incorrectly in some copies to the new lending approved by the Senate for the International Monetary Fund. It was $12 billion.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Hillary Clinton;
Talking Up To Children On Politics

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

 BODY:
Hillary Clinton fielded a few tough questions yesterday from some of the children she has said she will speak for if her husband is elected President.
After delivering a speech on education reform at the Bank Street College, Mrs. Clinton visited an eighth-grade government class in the adjoining Bank Street School for Children, where students asked whether the family-leave bill supported by her husband, Gov. Bill Clinton, would hurt businesses, whether children should be allowed to divorce their parents and what she would do to improve public education.
In detailed responses, Mrs. Clinton did not talk down to her audience. 
 "I do not believe it would cause an economic drain, especially since small business is exempt," she said in explaining her support of the family-leave bill. Her 13-year-old questioner nodded gravely throughout her answer, in a respectable imitation of a political reporter who knows he is on camera.
 
Some Friendly Questions
 Other questions were friendly, and some could have been written by the Clinton campaign staff: "How do you feel about being attacked by the Republican Party for being a working mother?" one girl asked. Another wondered, "Why do you think Bush and Quayle would support their own families having an abortion but not the rest of Americans?"
But no one could accuse Mrs. Clinton of pandering to her audience at the school on West 112th Street. In response to a question about battling the pernicious effect of television, she said, "I think schools have to give more homework."
During the school tour, Mrs. Clinton also sang, danced and clapped her hands during a short visit with a group of toddlers. She did her best to appear enthusiastic about participation in "The Jumping Song," hopping up and down in high heels, and joined in another tune that simulates proper tooth-brushing techniques.
Only moments earlier Mrs. Clinton had told educators, including Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, that public schools need a stronger emphasis on early childhood education and more resources.
On her way to expressing support for educators, she paused to take a swipe at Vice President Dan Quayle. "A headline in one of the newspapers today: 'Well, I can't be expected to spell. I only went to public school,' " she said. Mr. Quayle has said he was joking when he complained that the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, would have an unfair advantage in debates because he received a superior, private school education.
But Mrs. Clinton said teachers should also be challenged "to change the way they've always done things." And she said parents, who should work more closely with teachers, often need education in parenting skills and other services.
She recalled a recent conversation with a homeless woman: "I asked her if she was talking to her baby, and she looked at me and said, 'Why? He can't talk back.' "
Mrs. Clinton, whose own dedication as a mother has been questioned by her Republican detractors, allowed that all parents can be intimidated by the school system.
"For overeducated parents like me it's not so easy, either," she said. "I remember the first time Bill Clinton and I went to a teacher conference for our daughter, when she was in kindergarten, and you would have thought we were being hauled up before the Inquisition."

HEADLINE: A Two-Fisted Governor With a 'Foot in Mouth' Style

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss.

 BODY:
Barely a month into his first year in office, Gov. Kirk Fordice visited the annual meeting of the state Parent-Teacher Association and ended up in a shouting match over education financing. Within weeks the group, joined by the state teachers' association, was chanting "recall" outside the Governor's mansion.
 In the half-year since then Mr. Fordice, Mississippi's first Republican governor in 115 years, has frequently come close to choking on what both he and his critics call a brusque, "foot in the mouth" style. He suffered some embarrassing missteps with appointees and saw two of his vetoes overridden by the Democratic-controlled Legislature, a record for a first-year Mississippi governor. 
Democrats and some Republicans say Mr. Fordice, who vowed to bring a businessman's approach to government, is stuck in the strident and confrontational mode of his campaign.
 "Those were good qualities in a campaign, but they have to be moderated as Governor," said Jack Reed, a Republican businessman who was the party's 1987 candidate for governor. "It's early yet, but so far I would have to give him a grade of incomplete."
 
Inexperienced but Unafraid
 The Democratic state auditor, Steve Patterson, said, "He lacks the skills required to build a consensus on problems facing the state."
 But what opponents deride as inexperience and inflexibility, supporterssee as a willingness to skewer special interest groups and the courage to stick to a pledge of no new taxes.
 "Look at the way the special interests are screaming," said Gil Carmichael, a Republican candidate for governor in the 1970's, when the state party was hard pressed to win a race for dogcatcher. "If he were like the old politicians and lawyers who are trained to talk both ways, he would be smooth and slick. But he hasn't learned how to speak and not say anything."
 Mr. Fordice is not the first Mississippi governor to clash sharply with the state's historically strong Legislature. In fact, his Democratic predecessor, Ray Mabus, who styled himself the Harvard-educated face of Mississippi's future, had similar problems before he lost his office to Mr. Fordice.
 But where Mr. Mabus showed some finesse in a clinch, Mr. Fordice has so far been all sharp edges and flying elbows.
 The Governor, a 58-year-old engineer and former construction company president, admits that he can be too blunt for comfort but says he has few apologies for his first months in office.
 "I'm no politician, just an analytical businessman," he said in an interview. "I'm prickly sometimes, and I snap when the press gets negative. And I'm not going to get so guarded that I won't say anything."
 Much of the opposition to Mr. Fordice and his style grow from incidents like the P.T.A. meeting when he came off as insensitive and quick to anger. But he has also been dogged by charges of racism. During the campaign he strongly opposed affirmative action programs and even the Voting Rights Act of 1965, and many blacks and whites in the state said they saw similarities to David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi who last year made a losing bid for governor in neighboring Louisiana.
 Mr. Fordice denied charges of racism. But the issue arose again a month after his inauguration, when he responded to a question about a discrimination case that could have forced the state to raise taxes and spend more on historically black state colleges. Before a largely white Kiwanis group, Mr. Fordice vowed to call out the National Guard before he would comply with such an order.
For some, the symbolism was a disturbing echo of the days of "massive resistance" in the early 1960's, when Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and Gov. Ross Barnett of Mississippi vowed to call out the National Guard in their fight against court-ordered integration.
 After an outcry in the news media, Mr. Fordice said he regretted the comment. After meeting with a group of presidents of the state's black colleges, he said, "I ought to watch my mouth." But he continued to blame the news media for "a far, far reach" in seeing something sinister and racial in his comments.
 
'Pitiful Attempt at Humor'
 Race isn't the only issue on which he has tripped over his tongue. Two months ago, in a discussion with state officials on tourism, he recalled how his historic hometown of Vicksburg had "fleeced those Yankee tourists," treating them as "a renewable economic resource." It was, he said later, a "pitiful attempt at humor."
 Other criticisms revolve around substance rather than style. On the overrides of his veto of a sales tax increase that was intended to aid education, Representative Billy McCoy, the Democratic chairman of the Education Committee who helped draft the bill, said the Governor had shown an unwillingness to compromise and had suffered the setback largely because he presented no real alternative.
 Mr. Fordice also incurred some embarrassment over several appointees to part-time state boards. One businessman he chose for an environmental board had been cited by the board to which he was being appointed as a violator of many regulations that the board had established. Three Fordice appointees to a higher education commission foundered on accusations of improprieties, including conflicts of interest and Medicare abuse, and on questions about their qualifications.
 Democrats said these incidents bespoke "sloppiness" on the part of the Governor's staff, but Mr. Fordice asserted that the opposition to his nominees was purely political.
 As for the override of his veto of the sales-tax increase, he said: "Of course I wish I hadn't been overridden, but there are those people who say that I win either way for insisting on not raising taxes."
 As he moves into his second year, Mr. Fordice has mounted an effort that could give him leverage against his legislative opponents and the "special interests" he derides. The Governor's office has set up a toll-free telephone number that citizens can call to register complaints or concerns about state government. Callers will be directed to the appropriate state agency and enlisted in what the Governor calls Team Mississippi to lobby the Legislature with telephone calls and letters. Before contacting the legislators, callers will also be provided with the Governor's proposals on a host of issues, including tort reform, economic development and term limits.
 "In the past, governors here have gone directly to the people on specific issues such as education reforms, but this is the first time a governor has gone directly to the people on a variety of issues," said Johnna Plummer, the Governor's press secretary, who added that in less than a month since the toll-free line had operated there had been about 1,000 calls.
 But Mr. Patterson called Team Mississippi "a public relations gimmick" designed to arouse general opposition to government rather than any strategy for getting programs through the Legislature. He said the Governor's proposals were chestnuts from the conservative Republican agenda that spoke mostly of less government and did little to address the problems of poor Mississippians and average middle-class voters.
 At times such criticism and the unrelenting turmoil that has marked his Administration so far leave him wondering if politics is really his calling. Sitting at his desk in the Governor's mansion, surrounded by stuffed trophies and exotic pelts from his many big-game safaris, he said a bit wistfully that he now had little time for such trips or for indulging his passion for flying his plane.
 "Some of the requirements of the job cramp my style," he said, then added with a smile: "But you know I'm a type-A personality and I'm supposed to thrive on a challenge. So I must be having a ball."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Media;
Perot to Unveil A Big Ad Pitch, But Will It Sell?

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
One day after Ross Perot announced that he would be running for President after all, he committed to spending almost $1 million next week to buy three half-hour blocks of advertising on network television.
An advertising firm, called the 270 Group, has been formed to produce shorter television and radio commercials for him. And since the Texas billionaire is not accepting Federal election funds, he can spend as much money as he wants on advertising over the next four weeks. 
 But all this may not make much difference for a candidate whose support, according to recent polls, is in the single digits. As the Coca-Cola Company discovered when it tried to roll out New Coke, there are some products that even multimillion-dollar advertising campaigns cannot sell.
 
'At Best a Footnote'
 "No matter what he spends, he is at best a footnote," said Michael Robinson, a professor of government at Georgetown University who has studied the effect of paid advertising on Presidential elections.
Hal Katz, the chief executive officer of Katz Dochtermann & Epstein, a New York advertising firm, put it this way: "He'd have to have one sensational message. He can't do it."
Like most aspects of the revived Perot campaign, the candidate's advertising plans carry the hint of grandiosity. In fact, though, little is known about what these plans entail or to what extent they even exist.
So far, only two things can be said for certain about Mr. Perot's advertising campaign.
The first is that a group of advertising executives, headed by Dennis McLain of Dallas, have formed a quasi-independent firm along the lines of the Bush campaign's November Company to produce commercials for Mr. Perot. The members of the firm, named to reflect the number of electoral votes needed to win the Presidency, have declined to discuss their plans with the press.
The second is that representatives for the candidates have been negotiating with the three broadcast networks to buy a half hour of time on each network next week.
 
Firm Agreement at ABC
 Last night Stephen Battaglio, ABC's manager of media relations, said the network had reached a firm agreement to sell Mr. Perot a half hour starting at 9:30 P.M. next Friday for $620,000. The half hour will pre-empt "Camp Wilder" and lead into "20/20" with Barbara Walters, the show on which Mr. Perot appeared as a guest last night.
At CBS, a spokeswoman said the Perot campaign had contracted to buy a half-hour on Tuesday leading into the National League baseball playoffs, at a cost of $380,000, and pre-empting "Rescue 911." Representatives of NBC said they were still bargaining with the Perot campaign late yesterday.
Even as his campaign was contracting with the networks for time, though, it was unclear exactly what Mr. Perot planned to put on the air. Orson Swindle, the head of Mr. Perot's volunteer organization, told reporters in Dallas that two 30-minute commercials had been produced, one dealing with the economy and the other with Mr. Perot's biography.
But just a few days ago Murphy Martin, a former television reporter who took over the Perot campaign's media operation over the summer, said the Perot biography advertisement existed only in a five-minute form.
Mr. Martin did not return repeated calls to his office yesterday. And representatives of the television networks said they did not know what Mr. Perot planned to put on during his half-hour broadcasts, nor did they have any control over it.
"Political speech is protected by the First Amendment," ABC's Mr. Battaglio said. "He can really do whatever he wants."
It was over the cost of advertising, among other things, that caused Mr. Perot's campaign to fall apart in July.
In the spring the campaign hired Hal Riney, a highly respected San Francisco advertising executive, to produce a series of television commercials. At a meeting in early summer Mr. Perot asked the political consultants he had hired how much money it would take to pay for producing the ads and putting them on the air. One of these consultants, Charlie Leonard, who left the campaign early in July, recalled that Mr. Perot "flipped out" when he was told the cost.
"He said, 'Why would I spend that when I could go on the "Today" show for free?' " Mr. Leonard recalled. "It was at that meeting we learned this guy wasn't really willing to spend the money."
The ads produced by Mr. Riney never appeared, except on ABC's "Nightline." They showed Perot volunteers talking about what the candidate and the campaign meant to them and their children.
In the meantime, though, Mr. Perot continued to get plenty of free media exposure on shows like NBC's "Today," where he will be a guest again on Monday.
Just how much Mr. Perot will be willing to spend on advertising this time is unclear.
The half hours that he has purchased for next week will cost him more than $1 million. While this is certainly not an insignificant amount of money, even by television standards, if Mr. Perot continues to advertise at this rate, with only four weeks left before Election Day, he will spend only a fraction of the $35 million that President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton are each expected to spend on their general election advertising campaigns.
In theory, though, Mr. Perot could spend more than Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton combined between now and Nov. 3. The independent candidate is not receiving Federal matching funds, and thus is not required to abide by Federal spending limits. And since the economy is so slow, there is plenty of 30-second and 60-second spots left to buy both on the networks and on local television stations.
"There is probably an inexhaustible amount of time available," said Saul Cohen, a senior vice president at Slater Hanft Martin, a New York advertising firm. "There is really a glut of time that candidates would find appropriate."
Among the most popular advertising slots for candidates are what are known as "news adjacencies," slots that abut news programs. Other popular slots are during information-oriented shows like CBS's "60 Minutes" or ABC's "Prime Time Live."
 
High Cost of Advertising
 Even though the networks and the local stations are required by law to sell political candidates time at lower rates, it would not be difficult for a candidate to spend tens of millions of dollars on advertising in the next few weeks.
A single 30-second spot during a popular sports event or a top-rated sit-com can cost several hundred thousand dollars. During the season premiere of the CBS show "Murphy Brown," 30-second commercials were selling for about $300,000.
But no matter how much money Mr. Perot spends on advertising -- and some of his former aides, like Mr. Leonard, doubt that it will be that much -- advertising experts and political analysts say it is unlikely that it will make that much difference in the outcome of the election. Just as a big-budget ad campaign could not salvage New Coke, several million dollars of commercials are considered unlikely to sway enough voters to make Mr. Perot President.
Those who have studied the effects of advertising on Presidential campaigns say that the most effective commercials are those that shape the debate and resonate with a candidate's news coverage.
 
Negative News Coverage
 Before Mr. Perot dropped out of the race in July, much of his news coverage was distinctly negative, focusing on reports that he hired private detectives to investigate business rivals and influenced Federal policy for personal gain. This coverage resumed on the day he rejoined the race, with fresh reports that he had investigators check on some of his volunteers.
And a number of polls show that Mr. Perot comes to his revived campaign with such shaky credibility that it seems unlikely that paid advertising alone will restore the public's confidence in him.
Mr. Robinson, the Georgetown professor, recalled the case of another wealthy candidate, John B. Connally, the former Texas Governor, who tried to win the Republican nomination in 1980 by outspending his opponents. Mr. Connally spent some $13 million on advertising before he dropped out of the race. He had one delegate.
"Perot has demonstrated that going around the press doesn't help," Professor Robinson said. "Going through the press doesn't help. And paid advertising won't help. If you ask will any of this do anything, the answer is, 'No."'

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
In Depressed Middle West, Clinton Ridicules President on Economy

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., Oct. 2

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton traveled today to the economically depressed areas of the Midwest that President Bush bypassed on his train trip last weekend to talk about his favorite themes: why George Bush is killing the economy and why George Bush will not tell the truth.
And this evening, campaign officials said that Mr. Clinton, who had been criticized by Mr. Bush over his refusal to take a position on the North American Free Trade Agreement, had decided to support the accord. 
 Many of his supporters oppose the agreement and Mr. Clinton, while declaring that he favored the concept of free trade, has said that he found "glaring omissions" in the 2,000-page trade agreement that President Bush is scheduled to sign on Wednesday.
But a senior Clinton campaign official said tonight that Mr. Clinton would announce his support for the agreement in a speech on Sunday.
Asked about reports of his decision as he arrived in St. Louis tonight, Mr. Clinton refused to comment.
The Democratic Presidential nominee spent the bulk of his day today mounting an attack that was intended to put the President on the defensive about the economy and about new anti-Clinton commercials the Republicans began broadcasting Thursday.
"This is a campaign devoid of any conviction," Mr. Clinton said of the Bush effort. He ridiculed the President as playing down the jobless figures that were released today and said Mr. Bush has misrepresented the Governor's tax plans.
 
'Sucker-Punched Us'
 "Mr. Bush, you sucker-punched us once, and we are not falling for it again," he said to an invited crowd of Democrats at a rally in Toledo, Ohio. "Go away. Go away."
Mr. Clinton all but ignored the re-emergence of Ross Perot, and his aides seemed almost serene in their conviction that the Texas businessman's return to the political stage would not hurt the Arkansas Governor.
But his language about the President was as unstinting as it was harsh.
"Obviously, they've given up on winning on their record, and they don't have any plans for the future," he said. "So the only way they can win is to basically trash and convince people I'm for things I'm not."
The Clinton campaign released its own television commercial today in response to the President's attacks, asserting that Mr. Bush has mishandled the economy.
In Toledo today, Mr. Clinton used the new unemployment figures, which showed that the number of people out of work had decreased by one-tenth of a percent, to bolster his contention that the economy is not rebounding.
"Do you know what Mr. Bush said this morning?" Mr. Clinton said. "He said the unemployment rate had gone down one-tenth of a percent and we were moving in the right direction. Well, in a way we are. We're going to move him out of the White House."
While campaigning in Toledo and Flint today, Mr. Clinton emphasized his support for the concept of free trade, but also assailed the President as permitting the Agency for International Development to shut "plants down here and moving them overseas."
"That's their idea of a jobs program," Mr. Clinton said. "He promised us 15 million jobs. He just didn't tell us where they were going to be created."
Sounding protectionist and laissez faire themes at the same time, Mr. Clinton said: "I'm an expanded trade fellow. I believe in more trade. But I believe in more trade on fair terms."
In Toledo, his campaign invited several hundred Democrats, mainly union workers, to a rally on the parking lot of the Ohio Department of Employment Services. Mr. Clinton used the venue to point out that Mr. Bush's photogenic railroad train tour had bypassed Toledo.
"I'm the guy who came to Toledo," Mr. Clinton told the cheering partisan group. "Well, the train didn't stop here, and the buck doesn't stop there, but you can stop George Bush on Nov. 3."
