HEADLINE: Brazil's New Chief Ignites Uproar With Choice of Finance Minister

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Itamar Augusto Franco assumed presidential powers today and immediately created an uproar by appointing a little-known tax lawyer to Brazil's most powerful economic post, Finance Minister.
After the appointment of Gustavo Crause, a Congressman from a poor northeastern state, the key Sao Paulo stock market index dropped 3,711 points, or about 8 percent. And doubts spread about the new Government headed by Mr. Franco, the former Vice President and reclusive politician who today became Brazil's acting President. 
 After 48 hours of bargaining over Cabinet posts, two political parties that led the drive to impeach President Fernando Collor de Mello decided not to join the Franco Government. The leaders of both parties, the Workers Party and the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, are expected to be candidates in the 1994 presidential elections.
"People don't want to commit themselves to something that probably won't work," Alexandre Barros, a political analyst, said here today.
 
'Collor Out! Collor Out!'
 The morning began here with Mr. Collor formally surrendering his presidential powers in order to stand trial on corruption charges in the Senate. Dressed in a gray suit, Mr. Collor appeared dignified and composed if tense as ministers solemnly exchanged farewell handshakes.
"Collor out! Collor out!" jeered demonstrators as Mr. Collor and his wife, Rosane, strode briskly out of the marble and glass Palace of the High Plains to a waiting helicopter.
As the helicopter lifted off, Mr. Franco was exchanging hearty embraces with politicians in the cramped subterranean offices of Brazil's Vice President.
Breaking a three-day public silence, Brazil's new leader vowed in brief comments to reporters, "There will not be any corrupt people in my Government."
But behind the jollity, there was unease over what some described as a hesitant start to Brazil's new Government. Criticizing the "indecision" of Mr. Franco, the Senate went against his wishes by advancing the transfer of power from next Monday to today.
On Wednesday, a survey of Sao Paulo voters showed little confidence in a Franco Government. Of the respondents, 23 percent predicted that a Franco Government would be "good or great," 38 percent that it would be "O.K." and 19 percent that it would be "bad or terrible." Twenty percent did not want to hazard a guess.
 
Business Leaders Disappointed
 Today's appointment of the Finance Minister further eroded business confidence in Sao Paulo, Brazil's economic and financial heart. Business leaders had hoped that Mr. Franco would choose an economist with the experience needed to fight Brazil's inflation and with the polish needed to save an accord on foreign debt by renegotiating economic targets with the International Monetary Fund. Brazil has the developing world's largest foreign debt, about $120 billion, and Latin America's highest inflation rate, 25 percent a month.
Today's newspapers reported that Mr. Crause, a 46-year-old member of the Chamber of Deputies from Pernambuco State, would join the Cabinet as Interior Minister. Late on Thursday, however, Mr. Franco decided to switch him to Brazil's most important economic post.
"Nothing will happen when so much is needed," a mining company president in Rio de Janeiro predicted today. "Crause is not a bad guy, but he's a tax lawyer and knows nothing about the economy."
Alden Brewster, a New York trader in third world debt, said by telephone today, "The guy is completely unknown externally, and that is not good when you have to renegotiate targets with the I.M.F."
To calm worries and the markets, Mr. Crause and Brazil's new Planning Minister, Paulo Haddad, said at a news conference today that they would not unveil any radical economic packages. Mr. Crause warned against people believing in "magical ideas."
As the new minister spoke, Mr. Collor was preparing to move his office to Granjo do Torto, a rustic retreat near here that is Brasilia's version of Camp David. From there, he plans to prepare his legal defense for the Senate trial.
 
No 'Parallel Government'
 Through a spokesman, Mr. Collor has promised not to form "a parallel government." Although Mr. Collor can resign at any time to avoid a Senate trial, he appears to be gambling that Mr. Franco's stewardship will prove so disastrous that the Senate will fail to convict him within six months, allowing him to resume full powers automatically early in April.
"The speculation is that Collor will sit comfortably and wait for Itamar to go bananas," Mr. Barros said. "My fear is that if you have inflation at 45 percent in October, at 80 percent in November, by December people will say that between hyperinflation and a thief, they'd prefer the thief."
But Mr. Franco, who served in the Senate from 1974 to 1989, has many friends there. Several important Senators have predicted that Mr. Collor will be tried and convicted by the end of this year.
In a parallel process, Brazil's Attorney General plans to indict Mr. Collor on corruption charges early in November.
On Thursday, Ibsen Pinheiro, the president of the Chamber of Deputies, dismissed the possibility of a presidential pardon, saying, "An amnesty bill for Collor would not get through here in 300 sessions."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Perot Says It Will Take a Year to Enact 'Fair-Share Sacrifice' Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
One day after he jarred the Presidential campaign with his announcement that he was re-entering the race, Ross Perot said today that, if he is elected, his plan to balance the Federal budget would not get started until a year after his inauguration.
Interviewed by Barbara Walters for the ABC News program "20/20," Mr. Perot said it would take that long to secure Congressional approval of the legislation needed to implement his economic proposals. 
 "At the rate Congress moves, let's assume you go in the first of '93," Mr. Perot said. "You have everything; the plane's loaded and ready to go in '94. That's warp speed. But in terms of making the hard decisions, I'm saying within a year, with a mandate from the people, millions of Americans demanding that we get on with it, by the end of '93 we would have firm plans in place to restructure health care, rebuild the job base."
As he began his renewed campaign for the White House, Mr. Perot has had to face assertions that his economic plan places too much of a tax burden on the middle class and is such drastic medicine that it would throw the economy into a full-scale depression.
During this evening's interview, Mr. Perot said people are ready to make sacrifices to balance the budget. "We're talking about fair-share sacrifice," he said. "Everywhere I go, ordinary folks who work hard for a living pull me aside and say, 'Ross, I'm willing to do my share. Just make sure it's fair.' "
Mr. Perot's plan, as detailed in his book "United We Stand," calls for balancing the Federal budget in five years. This would be done through a mix of spending cuts and tax increases like a 50-cents-a-gallon increase on the gasoline tax over five years and raising the top marginal tax rates for people making more than $55,550 a year, to 33 percent from 31 percent.
The interview was the first time Mr. Perot had addressed the timing of his economic plans. John P. White, the Eastman Kodak executive who is the chief architect of the plan, has said it should not be begun until 1994 to make sure the economy is sufficiently on the road to recovery. Mr. White has defended the strong medicine and the relatively short timetable to eliminate the budget deficit as necessary to convince financial markets and the Federal Reserve that Federal fiscal policy is seriously addressing the problem so that long-term interest rates could be cut.
When Mr. Perot was asked if he though he could win, he answered that his victory would be less important than getting voters to focus on the need to confont the nation's economic challenges. "I am more than willing to go down in flames if the American people are too soft to face it," he said of his economic plan. "But nobody will ever be able to say that I didn't lay it out for them."
After his dramatic re-entry into the Presidential campaign, Mr. Perot plans to go underground this weekend, his advisers say. Instead of campaign appearances, he will meet with his staff to plot strategy, said Sharon Holman, Mr. Perot's press secretary.
The decision to spend the weekend on strategy reflects the fact that the Texan did not inform his advisers before he declared his re-entry into the race, Ms. Holman said.
"We were literally waiting to see what he would do," she said. "And now we're scrambling."
The staff, however, is much smaller than the group that worked for Mr. Perot before he withdrew from the race in July. Where the campaign had about 150 full-time paid staff members in July, it now has about one-third of that, none with any experience running a political campaign.
"This is the real Perot campaign," said a political consultant who worked for Mr. Perot during the first phase of his campaign and asked not to be identified. "This is the campaign he wanted to do -- no pollsters, no consultants, no internal pundits, no media. It's just him doing what he wants."

HEADLINE: Faulty Income Safety Net: Breaking Rules to Survive

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
After 37 years of marriage, Abelardo and Amanda M. have told the Government that they have separated. They are lying. But, after decades of hard work, it is the only way, they say, that they can survive retirement.
By filling in fake addresses on a couple of forms, they scrape by, guiltily, with an extra $294 monthly from a Federal program called Supplemental Security Income. Still, they run out of money at the end of each month, and search their cupboards for whatever food remains. 
 Created 20 years ago, S.S.I. was intended to guarantee a minimum income -- a safety net below all safety nets -- for those Americans considered most vulnerable: the elderly, the blind and the disabled. But the program, which serves 470,000 in New York State and 5.4 million people nationally, has come under fire recently.
 
'Make Difficult Choices'
 A group of experts hired by the Government to evaluate the program issued a report last month saying the program paid too little, discouraged relatives and friends from taking care of one another and had a bureaucratic backlog that prevented people from receiving help quickly.
"People are forced to make difficult choices whether to pay for food or shelter," said the experts' report, a result of a two-year study by what is called the S.S.I. Modernization Project. "Housing costs sometimes absorb most or all benefits, but the program penalizes people for trying to live together to make ends meet."
Abelardo, who is 66 years old, worked construction, repaired elevators, did just about anything he could get hired to do after coming here from Colombia almost 30 years ago. Amanda, who is 67, worked as a seamstress. They put their four children through Catholic schools. "We don't know English, but we got a good education for our kids," Abelardo said. But none of their children, with loans to pay and children of their own, have enough money to help them, he said. Indeed, they are putting up one of their sons while he goes to college.
Without their subterfuge, her union pension, his food stamps, and the small Social Security benefits each receives would leave them -- when they finish paying $600 a month rent for their shabby Harlem apartment -- with $273 a month to live on.
The advantage to their deception springs from an assumption, carried over from the Social Security system, that two people can live together more economically than they can separately. Hence the benefits available to a couple are 150 percent of those for an individual.
After much discussion, the experts rejected a suggestion that couples receive twice the benefits of singles. "It was more or less decided to keep the uniformity of the Social Security system," said Samuel Sadin, one of the experts, and the deputy director of Hunter College's Brookdale Center on Aging.
But the experts, he said, were more concerned about another disincentive to people living together -- the fact that if their children or friends help them, people like Abelardo and Amanda have to give up some of their S.S.I. benefits.
Recipients who move in with family or friends -- unless they pay rent or buy their own food and cook meals separately -- must give up one-third of their S.S.I. money. And any lesser help they receive from others results in an offsetting benefits cut. Roughly 10 percent of S.S.I. recipients forfeit some benefits because they receive outside help.
Increasing the benefits and changing the family-support provisions would require Congressional action, but Congressional leaders believe there is small chance of that. Representative Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk County, the acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's Subcommittee on Human Resources, is planning to hold hearings on the report's findings in the next Congress, but he is skeptical that Congress will act on them, given the size of the deficit.
In New York City single people receiving both state and Federal help through S.S.I. get a total of $6,096 a year -- below the Federal standard for poverty -- even though rents tend to run much higher than elsewhere in the country.
People who are on S.S.I. and also receive Social Security are permitted to keep an extra $20 a month, and some people on S.S.I., like Abelardo, also qualify for food stamps. In most states, they qualify for Medicaid. But even with that extra support they are unable to reach the poverty level, the experts said.
"We're content to let them live on an amount of money that isn't enough to let them get the essentials of life," said Arthur S. Flemming, a former United States Commissioner on Aging and Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare who was the chairman of the group.
Sia Arnason, co-director of the Institute on Law and Rights of Older Adults at the Brookdale Center on Aging, described one woman who went to be recertified for her S.S.I. benefits: "She said that she was doing fine, because her daughter was living in her neighborhood and she would occasionally bring by a bag of groceries.
"And their ears perked up and they said, 'How often does she do that?' And she proudly said, 'Once a week.' And before you know it her S.S.I. benefits are cut by $40 a week."
And so some people, like Abelardo and Amanda, break the rules. Both are American citizens, and, they say, always obeyed the law. Until now. And they don't feel good about the deception.
 
Navigating the System
 "No good," said Abelardo, for whom using his small amount of English seems like a matter of principle. "No good. No."
Some, however, are not able to work the system.
"Sometimes they aren't able to negotiate the system as well as other people, so they volunteer information," said Suleika Cabrera Drinane, executive director of the Institute for Puerto Rican and Hispanic Elderly. "You know, 'My children are helping me, with the rent, with this, with that.' They're proud. But sometimes it isn't even true."
S.S.I. serves a diverse group of Americans, ranging from children who cannot walk to schizophrenics sleeping on city streets to elderly people.
What the recipients share are extreme poverty and difficulty helping themselves -- the reason that, at a time when other welfare programs have drawn political fire for weakening people's will to work, the mission of S.S.I. has no such critics.
S.S.I. bolsters the incomes of its recipients in order to raise them to uniform levels: $422 a month for a single person, which is 74 percent of the poverty level, and $633 for a couple, which is 83 percent. Like Social Security benefits, S.S.I. benefits are raised each year to keep pace with inflation, but there has been no lump-sum increase since the program was started, according to the Social Security Administration.
Although most states tack on a contribution to the Federal money, in only two -- Alaska and California -- do the combined benefits for a single person exceed the poverty level.
New York State adds a maximum of $102.50 to the benefits for a couple, putting them at 96 percent of the poverty level. It adds $86 monthly to the benefits for a single person, bringing them up to about 89 percent of the poverty level.
"Every other country that I study has a much higher guaranteed income for the poor elderly," said Timothy M. Smeeding, one of the S.S.I. Modernization Project experts and a professor at the Maxwell School of Public Affairs at Syracuse University.
Lucille worked as a domestic from the age of 15, but never made enough money to save for her retirement or to qualify for much Social Security. Not that she ever thought about it -- between work and her six children, she was busy enough.
Now Lucille is 69 and living in the Bronx, and she can rattle off her benefits the way most people can recall their telephone numbers. She gets $217 from Social Security, $225 from the Federal Government for S.S.I., and another $86 from New York State.
She sleeps on the couch of one of her sons ("the only one I can depend on," she said) and pays him $234 in rent. That leaves her $294 each month. She would allow only her first name to be used out of fear she would jeopardize her benefits by talking to a reporter.
She said she wants to work, but asthma, high blood pressure, and arthritis have made that impossible. Each month, she runs out of money with two or three days to go.
As she described how she rations funds, she began, suddenly, to cry. "I get so confused sometimes," she said. "Sometimes I think it'd be better if I was dead."
Asked what she would spend a little more money on, if she had it, she didn't hesitate.
"A rib roast, I want," she said. "One more time."
The report by the S.S.I. Modernization Project called for an increase in benefits to raise recipients to about 120 percent of the poverty line, as has been done with some other poverty programs, and an end to the reduction in benefits for people sheltered or fed by their families or friends.
The report also called for allowing people who receive S.S.I. to have savings of $7,000, rather than the current limit of $2,000, and for the Social Security Administration to hire at least 6,000 staff members to reduce an average waiting period of four months for people who file disability claims. Making all the recommended changes would cost $38.8 billion annually by 1997, the report concluded.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The unemployment rate slipped a notch to 7.5 percent in September, the Labor Department said in its last pre-election report. Although it was markedly less negative than private economists and the White House had feared, the White House was hard put to find strong points in it, and Democrats were quick to attack. American businesses cut their payrolls by 57,000, also a less severe result than predicted. The Federal Reserve was not impelled to raise interest rates, as many had expected, although it could still do so. The figures, the first comprehensive measure of the economy's performance last month, were greeted with some relief by economic analysts. [Page 1.]
President Bush will veto a bill to regulate cable television prices on Saturday, Administration officials said. But highly placed Republicans said they did not know if they had the votes to sustain the President's veto. Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, said he did not expect a vote on overriding the veto until Monday. [35.]
 
Markets
The Dow industrials plunged 53.76 points, or 1.65 percent, to 3,200.61. Investors were disappointed at the Fed's reluctance to cut interest rates and fearful that earnings would slump. [35.] 
 A credit market selloff reversed itself, and bond prices eased only slightly, despite the better-than-expected jobless report. [38.]
The dollar fell against the yen, mark and Swiss franc but rose against the pound and the lira. Gold prices rose. [45.]
Corn futures prices fell to a four-year low ahead of a weekend that promised superb weather for harvesting a bumper crop. [45.]
The average stock mutual fund rose 2.77 percent in the last quarter, outpacing the 30 Dow industrials, which slipped 0.63 percent, but trailing the 3.15 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, Lipper Analytical Services reported. [35.]
 
Companies
An agreement between Eastern creditors and Continental Airlines was approved by Judge Burton R. Lifland. It will compensate Eastern creditors for being shortchanged when it was controlled by Frank Lorenzo and the Texas Air Corporation. [37.]
Two failed banks were closed and sold to other banks. First Fidelity of Newark is buying Howard Savings Bank, also of Newark, and Webster Financial of Waterbury, Conn., is buying First Constitution Bank, New Haven, Conn. Depositors, even those whose accounts exceed the $100,000 F.D.I.C. limit, will have no losses. [35.]
Clark M. Clifford would be at risk for a fatal heart attack, a court-appointed doctor has concluded, if he is forced to stand trial in New York in the B.C.C.I. case. [37.]
The Pittsburgh Press is being put up for sale by E. W. Scripps Company. The Cincinnati-based media conglomerate is exasperated by lack of progress in settling a 137-day teamsters' strike over a plan to eliminate jobs and improve distribution. [37.]
IBM Japan promoted Kakutaro Kitashiro to president, paving the way for Takeo Shiina, who will be chairman, to retire. [37.]
The American unit of Japan's NEC plans to enter the crowded market for low-priced PC's, with a line called Ready. [37.]
 
Today's Columns
The I.R.S. is trying to woo nonfilers back into the taxpaying fold to recover billions of back taxes and increase future collections. Interest and penalties will continue to accrue, but I.R.S. Commissioner Shirley D. Peterson said those who come forward voluntarily will be treated leniently. John H. Cushman Jr.: Your Taxes. [36.]
A compound that may reduce toxic side effects of some drugs used to fight AIDS and cancer was patented by a team of university scientists. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans;
Campaign Is a 'Fraud' to the Urban Underclass

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The burned- out buildings have mellowed in the generation since the riots. Like Yorick's skull, they lend an air of ghostly attentiveness as Kenneth Anderson talks about the far-off "perps," the Presidential candidates who have been skirting what he knows and cherishes and despairs of as America's underclass.
"You know, perps," he explained, "as in perpetrators of a fraud." 
 A ghetto etymologist of sorts and a benign ward-healer in the withered civics of the black inner city, Mr. Anderson isn't even angry in his street-shorthand characterization. He is only determined to be accurate, as he sees it, about the Presidential campaign's utter irrelevancy here in one of the original wastelands of modern American politics, the seared urban plains of the Detroit riots.
"Ain't no future with them fronters," he said, offering a further sample of the black English of the "hip-hop" culture.
 
Malcolm's Their Man
 "Fronters" refers to putting up a fake front, he says, smiling dismissively at all the distant hullabaloo over this week's monotonous question: Will the perps ever debate, perchance to grope for fresh sound bites and gaffes, to summon filler for the remaining campaign hours, to portray vivacity on the nation's electronic scrim.
"People here are talking Malcolm, not Clinton or Bush," he said, pointing to Malcolm X, the late black nationalist leader, as the only figure able to stir positive mass responses these days in the realpolitik of the ghetto underclass. "Bush and Clinton seem unscrupulous fellows around here -- 'politricians,' we say, as in 'trick.' "
Mr. Anderson is a 35-year-old inner-city social worker with a keen eye for "cross-over" -- the breaking through to the white world of the more commercially exploitable aspects of the black youth culture. There is hip-hop leaking into the white media and, soon, he predicts, there will be all-out commercialization of Malcolm X himself. Spike Lee's movie on Malcolm opens around election day and that, Mr. Anderson predicts, will prompt this year's one passing nod from the white world's campaign machinery to the urban black plight.
The Detroit man is cynical because he lost all hope of duplicating his father's blue-collar career 10 years ago when he lost his job on the General Motors assembly lines. Since then he has earned a master's degree in urban studies and communications, the better to know the younger black generation he ministers to now as a job locator with a locally respected anti-poverty program, the Lula Belle Stewart Center.
To an outsider, being a job locator for young black males of the inner city would seem to offer all the fulfillment of Charon's piloting souls across the river Styx. This depressed city's unemployment rate is double-digit, and in the local North High School neighborhood it's about 70 percent, by Mr. Anderson's estimate. Down from Webb Avenue, drivers whizzing along the Lodge Freeway can see able-bodied black men holding up cardboard pleas: "Will Work."
The commercial strips of inner Detroit's black neighborhoods are boarded-up mazes studded with lottery, alcohol and fast-food shops where bullet-proof glass muffles the clerk's 'Have-a-nice-day.' It is a pitiful backdrop as Mr. Anderson explains that with the auto factory economy collapsing around young urban blacks and the global economy rushing at them with even more problems of foreign low-wage competition, their despair is about to compound, even beyond the depths of the crack epidemic that ravaged the post-civil rights urban ghettoes.
"Young black people can only look to themselves for help, not to the politicians on the outside," said Mr. Anderson, banishing, as much as being banished by, the distant campaign. "We're on a battlefield here. Martin Luther King said he had a dream, but Malcolm X asked, 'What about the nightmare?' " Emily A. Palmer, the director of the Stewart Center and a canny black social activist of an older generation, listens politely as Mr. Anderson talks about the growing relevancy of Malcolm, not Clinton or Bush, and about the explosive possibilities of the young hip-hop culture, an amalgam of blues, gospel, R-and-B and rap plus the "hard life" influences of a new generation of urban blacks facing widespread unemployment and racial ostracism.
"I don't understand that hip-hop," said Mrs. Palmer, who has created one of the few new specks of hope here lately. She persuaded the Kellogg Foundation to underwrite a program to train young men in construction trades to rehabilitate buildings for stabilizing families and housing unwed teens and their babies.
Mr. Anderson, polite in turn as he runs the program, certifies this as the sort of self-help that Malcolm X would appreciate. But even more, he adds, Malcolm would have spoken out brilliantly for local control of the new Hip-Hop soft drink and the X basketball sneakers, two new white enterprises Mr. Anderson notices in his rounds.
See? The whites still pay some attention, he says, urging a visitor to watch what happens when Malcolm's movie opens. "Why, George Bush might even have to take note of Malcolm then," he said, laughing, as if at the sheerest political satire.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Young black people can only look to themselves for help, not to the politicians on the outside," said Kenneth Anderson, center, a job locator at the Lula Belle Stewart Center, an anti-poverty program in Detroit. He worked with Ronald Smith, left, and Reginald Smith to renovate an apartment complex. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N. Council Votes to Use Iraqi Assets Frozen Abroad

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council voted today to take control of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Iraqi assets frozen outside the country. The seized assets would be used to compensate victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and to pay United Nations expenses in Iraq.
The move means that Iraq will now begin using the proceeds of its huge oil reserves, believed to be the second largest in the world, to meet claims against it and to buy more foreign food and medicine for its people instead of relying on aid. 
 The resolution was adopted by a vote of 14 to 0, with China abstaining. The United States representative, Edward J. Perkins, called the resolution "a reasonable and proportionate response to problems Iraq itself has created."
But the roughly $800 million that the seizure of assets is expected to bring in will not go far toward meeting either the estimated $100 billion in compensation claims filed against Iraq so far or the country's peacetime bill for imported food and medicine of more than $2 billion a year.
 
An Alternative Plan
 And the seizure will not take place at all if Iraq agrees in the next few weeks to an alternative plan under which the Security Council would let it start selling oil again on a regular basis with the proceeds being used for the same purposes under United Nations supervision. This would mean a compensation program in which 30 percent of Iraq's oil revenues of some $17 billion a year would be regularly siphoned off over a couple of decades to meet claims.
When he addressed the General Assembly earlier this week, Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf, said Baghdad now wanted to reopen talks with the United Nations on such an oil-sale agreement after breaking them off last summer. He said Iraq would seek permission to sell $4 billion worth off oil and was ready to give 5 percent of the proceeds in aid to Somalia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Today the Foreign Minister estimated that this would leave Iraq $2.6 billion to spend on food and medicine after compensation payments and other deductions.
But in his General Assembly speech, the Foreign Minister made no reference to the United Nations' insistence on monitoring both the oil sales and the distribution of food and medicine inside the country, a demand that Baghdad rejected earlier this year as an insult to its sovereignty.
And today he and his aides ended separate talks with the United Nations about a new aid agreement for Iraq on an inconclusive note. Officials said Iraq still appeared reluctant to concede the degree of supervision that the United Nations wanted over distribution.
The resolution adopted today was drawn up when it appeared that President Saddam Hussein was determined to reject the Council's original oil-sale plan, despite the relief that it promised ordinary Iraqis, who were living in a world of serious shortages and soaring inflation after two years of sanctions.
 
Oil Barrels and Bank Accounts
 The assets to be seized under today's resolution include cargoes of unsold Iraqi crude oil stored in Turkey and Saudi Arabia as well as payments for oil deliveries that were blocked in banks when Iraq's foreign assets were frozen. The total value of these assets is still unclear but diplomats put it at $500 million to $1 billion.
If the resolution takes effect, a third of all the money will be put into a special United Nations compensation fund that will start reimbursing victims of the Kuwait invasion, giving priority to claims by foreign workers, mainly from poor Muslim countries, who lost their savings when they were expelled.
The rest of the money would be used to finance Iraqi imports of essential relief goods, and pay the cost of the United Nations arms inspectors hunting for President Hussein's weapons of mass destruction as well as the costs of the foreign relief workers in the country.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
Quiet Hecklers Receive Thanks From President

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
Thirty-two days and counting, and every expectation is that it's going to get nastier.
But take heart from this:
When President Bush was campaigning last week in Ohio, his appearances at Bowling Green and some other stops were marred by noisy supporters of Bill Clinton, some of them chanting, "Liar! Liar!" But at Columbus, a sizable pro-Clinton contingent was content to make its presence felt with only signs and stickers. The catcalls and harassment were kept to a minimum. 
 The President was moved. And as he left Columbus, he scratched out the following on his note pad and gave it to one of the Clinton people:
To the Clinton-Gore folks:
You guys did it right for your team -- but polite
and in the best tradition of U.S. politics.
Don't work too hard against me!
Thanks.
George Bush
 
Now, Let's Hear From a Democrat
 But don't take too much heart.
On Friday, the following note showed up on the bulletin board of the Democratic Party headquarters in Toledo, just north of Bowling Green:
"I want to thank you guys for all you did to make our counter-demonstration in Bowling Green as much fun as it turned out to be. I am encouraged that if Bush ever makes the erroneous decision to come to Toledo, you guys are primed and ready to go. Thanks again for all your help. I hope you had as much fun as I did."
It was signed by Tim Russo, the Clinton campaign coordinator in Ohio. It was headlined, "The Mugging of a President."
 
Some Debate Tips, From an Expert
 As Vice President Dan Quayle goes about preparing to debate Al Gore -- and maybe Ross Perot's running mate, James Stockdale -- he will first study tapes of Mr. Gore in public settings to get a feel for the man. Then, Warren B. Rudman, the retiring Republican Senator from New Hampshire, will come in and play the Tennessee Senator in mock debates.
Warren Rudman knows Al Gore. He is also regarded as one of the quickest minds on Capitol Hill, good on his feet and good on the issues, particularly economics.
 
Some Privacy Tips, From an Expert
 Bill Clinton was campaigning in Wisconsin, traveling from Milwaukee to Madison, and dropped in on a child-care center. He was chatting with an 8-year-old when the youngster asked if a candidate for the Presidency of the United States would like to see a fort. Sure, replied the candidate.
So the two made their way out to a wooded area, finally reaching a collection of sticks, whereupon they fell into a discussion of the merits of privacy.
"Thrill of the day," the Governor said as he came out of the woods.
 
Loose Ends And Double Takes
 *Bush campaign volunteers in the industrial Midwest are passing out "pink slips" to workers leaving auto plants. The partisan message is, if Bill Clinton becomes President, his plan to raise car mileage standards would depress the automobile industry even more.
It is a jungle out there.
*When Barbara Bush was in Cincinnati earlier this week to do a little campaigning, she made the obligatory stop at a local chili joint for some Cincinnati-style red, which, unlike Texas red, smacks of a mysterious pinch of cinnamon, or maybe cocoa, or maybe both. Actually, she ordered a "coney," which, Cincinnati-style, is a hot dog smothered in chili, cheese, mustard and onions.
But hold the onions, requested the First Lady.
"I can't do that to them in Kansas," she explained, referring to the Bush faithful waiting at the next stop.
*Headline of the Week, from The Washington (D.C.) Times:
"Perot Answers Own Call."

HEADLINE: Nuclear Plants Held Hostage to Old Fuel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The long delay in finding a place to dispose of nuclear wastes is about to collide with the accelerated pace at which the reactors are being retired.
Owners of several aging nuclear complexes are already keeping parts of their plants running for lack of a place to dump the highly radioactive spent fuel, and many more are likely to follow. The cost of doing so could go up to $20 million a year each if the Government cannot keep its promise to take old fuel by 1998. 
 The owners of the 31-year-old Yankee Rowe plant in western Massachusetts, which was shut down earlier this year, put the problem in stark relief this week, when they asked that their wastes be taken before that of other plants. "We're hoping to force the issue," William McGee, a spokesman at Yankee Rowe, said this week.
 
35 Years' Worth of Fuel
 When plants come to an end of their economically useful life, the owners want to seal or raze them. But if the fuel is still there, they must maintain the plants' miles of plumbing and wiring, valves and heat exchangers. Moreover, they must man the control rooms 24 hours a day simply to monitor the deep pools of water that hold the spent fuel. The old fuel contains most of the radioactivity that the plants produced in their lifetimes.
Nearly all the nuclear fuel consumed in the 35-year history of the civilian nuclear program is still stored next to the reactors that used it. The pools were not intended for long-term storage, but they can be adapted to hold the waste relatively easily while the plants are running.
At Yankee Rowe, for example, the Department of Energy is supposed to begin picking up spent fuel on Jan. 31, 1998, the date established by a 1982 law. But even if pickups start on time -- and Yankee Rowe officials and experts in the nuclear industry question whether that will happen -- they are not scheduled to finish until 2018.
"This is unacceptable to us," Mr. McGee said.
If the rest of the plant is shut down, then operating the spent fuel pool will cost $3 million a year, he added. So earlier this week the plant asked to be moved to the head of the line for pickup. The Government now plans to take the oldest fuel first. Some of Yankee Rowe's fuel is among the oldest in the country, but some was used as recently as 1991.
 
Expensive Alternatives
 The department, however, would face opposition from other utilities if it strayed from the current schedule and has given no indication that it will change it. Worse, it has hinted that it may not even be ready to help Yankee Row by 1998.
There are alternatives to store the fuel. If the fuel is old enough, it can be put in casks made of concrete and steel and cooled by natural air circulation, vastly reducing the level of attention and maintenance needed. But doing that at Yankee Rowe would cost $57 million, Mr. McGee said.
Under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, the utilities have been paying a tenth of a cent per kilowatt-hour produced by the reactors to finance a repository. In exchange, the Energy Department was to begin picking up waste on Jan. 31, 1998.
But the law envisioned the waste going straight to a permanent repository, and the Energy Department's efforts to establish one have been severely set back by technical problems and local political opposition. A 1987 amendment to the waste law designated Yucca Mountain, about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, Nev., on the edge of the department's nuclear bomb test range, as the site of the repository. But the department has made little progress in determining whether the site is suitable.
The law also allows for the establishment of a "monitored retrievable storage facility," essentially a fenced-in parking lot for casks. Presumably that could be built quickly, but so far no communities have volunteered to play host. Twenty towns, counties and Indian tribes applied for $100,000 grants from the department to study the feasibility of accepting an interim dump, but four later withdrew. One, Fremont County, Wyo., expressed some enthusiasm, but Gov. Mike Sullivan of Wyoming stepped in recently to block the process.
If the Energy Department misses the 1998 deadline, utilities may sue. "We believe the Department of energy has a financial obligation," Mr. McGee said. "We have already paid over $23 million into the fund."
Yankee Rowe, a small plant owned by a consortium of New England utilities, is an extreme case because it is a single-reactor plant. Southern California Edison plans to close its San Onofre 1 reactor soon, but the extra cost would be smaller because the company has two other reactors operating. But Yankee Rowe will not be alone in its problem, said Paul C. Parshley, senior vice president of Lehman Brothers, who has followed the nuclear industry for years.
 
Decisions Being Put Off
 "We have a number of plants that are going to shut down early," he said. "At the same time the decision to site and build a Federal repository is slipping further into the future." Some utilities, he said, are beginning to consider delaying decommissioning to wait for the Department of Energy to find a place to put the fuel.
Steven P. Kraft, director of nuclear waste and transportation at the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group based in Washington, said the costs could run to $20 million a year for each reactor. If a utility has to pay out money because of delays beyond 1998 by the Department of Energy, he said, "there's no question in my mind that they should seek recovery from the Department of Energy."
In Minnesota, where Northern States Power has run into difficulty trying to establish an alternative way to dispose of the fuel, the state's consumer advocate in utility matters, David Sampsel, said: "Northern States Power and the State of Minnesota were relying on the Department of Energy. We went into the nuclear power business relying on their assurances that the D.O.E. would have a repository for spent nuclear fuel."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Dueling Commercials;
Clinton Squad Snaps Back Quickly at a Bush Ad

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
On Thursday Gov. Bill Clinton saw a Bush campaign commercial on television that made him hopping mad. Today, less than 24 hours later, the Clinton campaign was on the air in 20 states with its own biting rebuttal, accusing Mr. Bush of having the "worst economic record of any President in 50 years."
It was the sort of hair-trigger counterpunch that is not uncommon in state and local politics but is almost unheard of in the layered, cautious bureaucracy of Presidential campaigning, and Mr. Clinton and his staff were crowing about it today. 
 On the campaign trail, Mr. Clinton said he had ordered his staff to prepare a rebuttal ad on Thursday after seeing the Bush commercial. It contends that Mr. Clinton's economic proposals "could" lead to large tax increases for middle-class workers.
"They just made it up and pulled it out of thin air," he told reporters traveling with him today. "It's absolutely false and it's the campaign and kind of Administration that George Bush has given America."
The Democratic media strategist who heads Mr. Clinton's advertising team, Frank Greer, said his staff worked much of the night to produce the 30-second advertisement. The Democratic ad included outside criticisms of Mr. Bush's commercial; the criticisms appeared in this morning's editions of The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal.
 
Searched for Quotations
 On Thursday night, Clinton campaign workers collected early copies of the Friday-morning editions of major newspapers to search for quotations to use in their commercial, Mr. Greer said. Finished copies of the commercial were delivered to television stations when they opened for business this morning, he said.
Mr. Greer said neither he nor Mr. Clinton are strangers to quick-response ads. Mr. Greer prepared several for Mr. Clinton's 1990 re-election campaign for Arkansas governor, a race in which his opponent, Sheffield Nelson, broadcast several attacks on Mr. Clinton's taxation record.
A Republican political strategist who recently left Washington, David Sparks, said today that such ads are rare in Presidential races, where most major decisions are made by committee and advertising staffs often include Madison Avenue professionals who work at a more measured pace.
But he also said that the ad should not surprise students of Mr. Clinton's election strategy. Mr. Clinton became well-known in his primary campaigns for quick, scorched-earth responses to unfavorable newspaper or television reports on his record or personal life.
And he dissipated the early advantage of a Democratic rival, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, in part with an advertising blitz that took quick, brutal exception to assertions that Mr. Clinton was making economic promises to voters that he could not fulfill.
"They've got a senior person full-time dealing with anti-Clinton stuff," Mr. Sparks said in a telephone interview from his office in Maine. "And a pledge not to let a day go by without rebutting a Bush charge. So while it might be unusual, it's certainly understandable given their tactics."

HEADLINE: Prague Journal;
A Flock of American 'Free Spirits' Nests in Czech Capital's Warm Heart

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Right off Narodni Street in the heart of Prague, around the corner from where the Cuban Cultural Center delivered fiery blasts against American imperialism not long ago, Ron Stillman from Forest Hills, Queens, is drawing customers in droves to taste the infinite varieties at his New York Pizza.
Kathleen R. Burke from Washington, operating from the top floor of an ancient house in the Old Town overlooking Prague's liveliest fruit and vegetable street market, puts out the twice-a-month, slick-paper Czechoslovak Financial Review, financed by high-powered European and American banks and businesses. 
 Matthew D. Morgan of La Jolla, Calif., has started a public-relations agency, and Melinda S. Ewing of Washington is doing public and guest relations and advertising for the city's most expensive hotel.
Steve Haas from Washington runs a busy copying shop. An American laundromat, the only one in the city, is thriving, and so is a gay bar opened by an American.
 
English Spoken Here
 Czech conversation rarely competes with the English of the mostly young customers at Ubiquity, a dark, ear-shattering disco the size of a football field or two, where dancers restore their vigor with Mexican food, brownies and chocolate-chip cookies, exotic delicacies for the Czechs.
From the up-market Lavka below historic Charles Bridge, similar sounds rise, but the largely American crowd is usually formed by M.B.A.'s or recent law school graduates sent here by consulting concerns to scout the business and investment opportunities in the formerly Communist country many view as most likely to succeed.
Americans publish two English-language weeklies. Two work as advisers at Prague Castle, the seat of the President.
The flow of Americans to Prague shows as much variety as Mr. Stillman's pizzas. One thing most do have in common is youth; they are largely in their 20's. There are those who, as Ms. Ewing puts it, are "just hanging out" for a while, as in Paris before it got too pricey. Some stay until their money is gone; others make it last longer by occasionally teaching in a city where studying English has become a passion from grade school through middle age.
"They don't last a long time," Richard Greene of Highland Park, Ill., said of most of the teachers. "I've been here for a year and I'm an old-timer." Mr. Greene, who is 22 years old and graduated from Carleton College in Minnesota last year, is more than a casual teacher. He says he loves the work and obtained a teaching job before coming. He will leave at the end of the year and is feeling nostalgic.
"Obviously it's gorgeous," he said, letting his glance roam over the cobblestoned expanse of Old Town Square, the Gothic Town Hall and the 17th- and 18th-century facades of the palaces, churches and burghers' houses that ring it.
 
1,000 Anmericans Register
 Americans appear to make up the largest group of expatriates. But the Czechoslovak authorities and the United States Embassy have no way of counting the number of Americans living here because no visas are required to enter and only those who wish to do so register with the embassy.
Rebecca Taggart of the embassy said more than 1,000 had so far registered to vote, and 1,200 have signed in as residents. The actual total is assumed to be several times higher. In 1989, the last year of Communist rule, 96 Americans were listed as residents.
The attraction of living in a beautiful city, which World War II spared and the lack of capital of the Communist Government protected against excessive "development," was cited by almost all of a score of American residents interviewed, including those whose primary motive is business opportunity. Neither the rest of the Czech Republic nor Slovakia seems to exert a similar appeal, and the impending breakup of the country into two nations does not affect the expatriates' lives.
"It has beauty, culture and history," Mr. Morgan, who is 26, said of Prague. Ms. Ewing said: "There is that Prague feeling. The architecture is so human. You know things have been happening here for hundreds and hundreds of years."
Many also cite the city's location, which makes trips all over Europe affordable.
Mr. Stillman, 38, saw Prague for the first time when he and 10 relatives took a bus tour to their family roots in Ukraine in 1990 and then crossed into Czechoslovakia.
"Prague was even more beautiful than the rest of the country," he recalled, sitting among the customers of his establishment, which is stark white and decorated with a New York subway map, a large photograph of the Manhattan skyline and the best of the drawings his customers are invited to make while they eat.
Large sheets of paper and boxes of crayons are on every table. Rock music fills the tomato-and-cheese-scented air. Mr. Stillman and his employees wear T-shirts with the shop's logo, recalling that of the New York Mets, and the slogan "Work Hard, Play Hard."
Mr. Stillman, whose partner is a cousin, Allen Wertheim, 34, typifies the qualities that impel Americans more than any others to plunge into what Mr. Morgan called "Dodge City, a really open place."
The stodginess of the anti-consumer attitude of the Communist era, which still characterizes much of this country, clearly brings out geysers of entrepreneurship among mobile young Americans used to a consumer-oriented economy.
 
Czechs 'Not Trying'
 They recognize and profit from the reluctance of Czechs to take the risks involved in filling the gaps in a service-starved city.
"Money is going to be made by people who take risks," Mr. Morgan said. "The Czechs don't know how to make money. They're not trying. They don't know that capitalism is based on hard work."
Mr. Stillman tries. He worked in the garment center, his cousin in the travel business. "Let's start a business here," he recalled he said to Mr. Wertheim shortly after their family bus got here. "He was all for it. We wrote out a business plan."
Mr. Stillman raised $120,000 of starting capital in New York; Mr. Wertheim apprenticed himself at no pay in a pizza place to learn the trade. They arrived here last January.
"We hit the ground running," Mr. Stillman said, describing what to Czechs seems a miracle of slashing through the bureaucracy. "No payments under the table," Mr. Stillman emphasized, just American persistence.
The partners see their present place as the "flagship for a chain," Mr. Stillman said. They plan to open two more outlets in December and January and a "sports bar" with video above the flagship. They are thinking also about producing frozen pizzas for export.
Many Americans cited two things that make Prague attractive: the low cost of living and friendly people. Prices are low only for Westerners used to much worse at home; for Czechs freedom has also meant rising costs.
But for Ms. Ewing to pay $200 a month for the top floor of a villa and a maid who does her laundry is a break from $1,000-a-month rent in Washington. Many of the young travelers -- "free spirits," Mr. Stillman calls the Americans who work behind his counter -- live with families at negligible cost.
"People really love Americans here," Ms. Burke said. Czechs describe this as a reaction to the repression of contact with foreigners in the Communist years. Nonetheless, Czechs and Americans agree that the expatriates keep largely to themselves. The Americans tend to overcome homesickness by spending as much time as possible among themselves. They make up half of his customers, Mr. Stillman said.
Americans and Czechs reported no open resentment of the expatriates. Indeed, David Krch, a psychologist, said: "It's the best thing that happened. It shows our isolation is finished. For the young generation, it's become natural to meet with foreigners."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
HOW SAFE A SAFETY NET?
Created 20 years ago, Supplemental Security Income was intended to guarantee a minimum income -- a safety net below all safety nets -- for those Americans considered most vulnerable: the elderly, blind and disabled. But the program, which serves 470,000 people in New York State and 5.4 million people nationally, has come under fire as paying too little and discouraging relatives and friends from taking care of one another. Page 1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
DINKINS TRIES TO MEND FENCES
Two weeks after a bitter police demonstration at City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins has begun an effort to repair relations with the Police Department and lower the oratory, including his own, over the racially charged issue of the Civilian Complaint Review Board. Page 1.
 

PUBLIC HEARING SHOWS DEEP DIVISIONS
While private negotiations continued on the shape of a new police review board, a public hearing on the proposal exposed deep racial and political divisions. Page 27.
 
WITNESS DESCRIBES CONFESSION
During questioning after his arrest on a Crown Heights street in August 1991, Lemerick Nelson Jr. admitted that he had joined a surging crowd of youths surrounding and hitting Yankel Rosenbaum and then stabbed him once in the left side, a detective testified. Page 27.
 
REGION
 
JUDGE PUTS OFF TRENTON LAYOFFS
A New Jersey Supreme Court judge provided a reprieve to hundreds of state employees who believed yesterday would be their last day at work. The judge's decision to block layoffs until Monday set the stage for a constitutional showdown between the executive and legislative branches of state government. Page 29.
 
LOANS FOR A HOCKEY TEAM
In their latest venture in investing in local companies to save jobs, Connecticut officials have made loans and loan guarantees to the state's sole major-league sports team, the Hartford Whalers, to keep it from leaving Hartford. The agreement gives the state the right to buy the team if its owner offers it for sale. Page 29.
 
YET ANOTHER POLICE CHIEF FOR SUFFOLK
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, reached into the troubled ranks of his Police Department to pick Peter F. Cosgrove, a 26-year veteran, as his third police commissioner in five months. Page 29.
 
STUDY FAULTS NEW YORK STATE
New York State agencies fail to correct their own violations of environmental laws in nearly 1 of every 10 cases, according to a state report. The findings support critics' claims that the Department of Environmental Conservation is more lenient in enforcing environmental laws against state agencies than it is against members of the public. Page 29.
 
THE PEROT FACTOR
Officials of Gov. Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign in New York and Connecticut are largely discounting the potential impact of Ross Perot's candidacy. But in New Jersey, Mr. Perot could salvage the state and its 15 electoral votes for President Bush. Page 9.

HEADLINE: Dow Loses 53.76, in Worst Day Since April

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Skittish investors, disappointed by the Federal Reserve's reluctance to cut interest rates and fearful that third-quarter earnings will be disappointing, poured sell orders into the stock market yesterday, fueling a broad retreat.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 53.76 points, or 1.65 percent, to 3,200.61. The decline was the biggest since April 7, when the Dow lost 61.94, or 1.9 percent. 
 Broader indexes also slumped, with the Standard & Poor's 500 falling 5.82, to 410.47, while the composite of over-the-counter stocks traded on Nasdaq fell 6.70, to 571.63. There were 13 declining stocks for about every 4 that gained on the Big Board. Volume declined to 188 million shares, from 203.8 million on Thursday.
 
'Investment by Default'
 "This market really needs some good news," said Melissa R. Brown, a quantative analyst at Prudential Securities Research. "Stocks have been an investment by default rather than choice because of the low yield on cash, and that's not enough to sustain any advance."
Analysts said yesterday's biggest disappointment was the lack of any move by the Bundesbank in Germany or the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to encourage economic expansion.
The Fed's inaction was widely attributed to the September unemployment figures, released before trading began, that showed a slight decline in the unemployment rate rather than the slight increase that had been expected on Wall Street. The unemployment figures touched off a small rise in interest rates, depressing bond prices, and that in turn led computerized stock trading programs to begin selling stocks.
"We estimate that 30 points of the Dow's decline came from program trading," said Philip H. Smith, an analyst at Birinyi Associates. The Big Board's limits on program trading were imposed late yesterday once the Dow's loss exceeded 50 points.
Mr. Smith noted that the blue-chip stocks like those in the Dow fell farther than those of midsized companies and that the smaller-capitalization stocks traded on Nasdaq fared best of all yesterday.
"The unemployment figures were strong enough to keep the Fed from acting and too weak to be a good sign for third-quarter profits," Mr. Smith said.
Analysts said fears about earnings disappointments hurt I.B.M., the most actively traded stock, which fell 1 5/8, to a 10-year low of 78 1/2. The company's latest restructuring announcement contained hints that business remained weak.
Similarly, United States Surgical fell 4 3/8, to 59 1/8, as investors reacted to the failure of Leon Hirsch, the company's chairman, to address Wall Street's doubts about the company's earnings outlook at an industry conference this week.
Stanley Works did not leave investors guessing. The manufacturer of hand tools and home-improvement products said it now expected a 10 percent to 15 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, rather than the flat showing it had estimated earlier. Its stock fell 6, to 34.
Retail stocks were also weak. Sears, Roebuck lost 1 1/2, to 43, as the impact of Tuesday's well-received plans to pull back from financial services continued to wane. Wal-Mart Stores fell 1, to 58..
The biggest loser was JWP, the troubled contracting and information-services company. It announced the resignation of David Sokol, its president, and projected losses for the third and fourth quarters. The company's shares fell 3 1/8, to 3 7/8, a drop of nearly 45 percent.

HEADLINE: Registration Of Voters Is Intensifying

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 2

 BODY:
George T. Younger Sr. figures he has registered about 50 people to vote in the last 10 days, all while selling his "soul dogs" from a street-corner stand here. He has nabbed customers, people waiting for the downtown bus near his cart, and those, like 21-year-old Al-Qumar Lindsay, just passing by.
"I ask everyone who goes by if they're registered," said the 24-year-old entrepreneur, as he guided Ms. Lindsay through the form. "A lot of them just walk by. Others say it won't make a difference. I tell them it will." 
 "I was going to do it," Ms. Lindsay said with a shrug. "I just haven't had the time to go to the school that's doing it and sign up."
As the deadline approaches for registering to vote in the Nov. 3 elections, registration drives have taken on a carnival-like frenzy. Mr. Younger's hot-dog stand is far from the only unlikely place where citizens are securing their right to choose the next President. Registration is going on in diners, at cosmetics counters and during rock concerts, in office lobbies, soup kitchens and, of course, on the streets.
Connecticut Votes, which focuses on registering voters in the work place, has also conducted registration drives at golf tournaments. Broadway stars are registering voters outside theaters. The Body Shop, a franchised cosmetics shop, has registered 25,000 voters in its 100 stores throughout the country, replacing displays of its all-natural eco-correct products with posters that proclaim: "Don't Say You Care if You Don't Care Enough to Vote."
In part, the mad pace comes because among election seasons, the Presidential election is obviously the big one. But many voting experts also believe that this year, hordes of prospective voters have been smacked out of apathy by the nation's bruising recession.
"Just in terms of numbers, we've never seen so many calls before," said Kay Maxwell, president of the Connecticut League of Women Voters. "People keep saying: 'Where can I register?' I really want to vote this year.' I think we're going to see an incredible increase."
At this point, the most current Connecticut tally, from March, reflects a downturn in the number of registered voters since 1988, from 1,784,383 to 1,672,944. But Barbara Steinberger, a spokeswoman for the Secretary of State, said that the reality is likely to be different on Nov. 3 because registration traditionally ebbs after one presidential election and picks up in the weeks before the next one. "We expect that the registration will be even higher than last time," she said.
In New Jersey, one of 15 states that allows citizens to register to vote when applying for a driver's license, registrations have jumped: In 1988, the State Department had registered 27,473 voters from February to September 29. That compares with 88,813 voters for the same period this year, an increase of 223 percent, said Lillian Midge Trainor, director of the state's election division.
 
'Trend Has Been a Decline'
 "About 58,000 of the new voters are these motor voters," Ms. Trainor said. She added that new registrants are not always new voters, but people who have moved from one town to another. She does expect that the state will have about 4 million voters going to the polls, at least as many as four years ago. "The trend has been a decline," she said. "So if the numbers go up or stay the same, that's a pretty good sign."
In New York State, with 8,121,359 registered voters as of July 1, 1992, voter rolls have dropped from 8,618,376 in 1988. But those numbers are expected to increase by several thousand over the next week before the Oct. 9 mail-in and Oct. 10 in-person registration deadlines.
Officials in all three states say that like the election itself, it is still too early too predict how many voters there will be by registration deadlines.
But whether all the registration will lead to a turnout larger than the 50.15 percent of eligible voters who participated in the 1988 election is a big question. Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a private, nonpartisan research group based in Washington, said that individuals who are "herded" into registering in 11th-hour drives tend to vote less than those who register on their own.
"The critical question in voting is motivation," he said. "That doesn't mean that those who were herded into registering won't vote. It's just a lower percentage than the self-motivated voters."
In downtown Newark, volunteers stand on street corners, spouting off reasons to vote ("It's Your Future! "It's Our Future!) with the hard sell of circus barkers. El-Majik Hassad, 23, said he has been trying to register voters for two weeks, with limited success. But he has had more and more comers in the last few days, after President Bush's visit to a labor group here on Tuesday.
"People are saying they're upset because Bush came and didn't even try to reach out to black folk," Mr. Hassad said. "They're saying 'sign me up and tell me where to pull the lever.' "
Last-minute registrants give various reasons. In Manhattan outside the Virginia Theater on 52d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, where the star of "Jelly's Last Jam," Gregory Hines, was registering voters Wednesday afternoon, those signing cards ranged from an advertising executive who recently moved to Greenwich Village from Texas, a Wall Street bond trader and former military officer who had always voted by absentee ballot and a restaurant manager from Rockaway whose original registration card got lost sometime ago.
Despite Mr. Hines's fame, only a few of the 53 people who registered in a two-hour drive were stargazers. Some stopped to register because it was convenient and others said they were drawn by the intensity of the 1992 political season.
"I want my vote to count this year because it's been a zoo with the election," said Elizabeth Shore, 34, a bookkeeper from Queens Village.
Volunteers registering voters say they cannot tell how many are doing so as Democrats or Republicans. Joe Lenihan, director of Connecticut Votes said, even with the 4,500 new voters the organization expects to register by the state's Oct. 20 deadline, two-thirds to three-quarters of the applicants are registering as independents. "We think there is a basic misunderstanding about registering with a party," he said. "People think that if they register with one or the other, they'll be pigeonholed into voting the party line. Or maybe they're just not sure."
To many civic-minded volunteers, the vote matters even more than the choice. Mr. Stronger, who plans to cut his workday at his hot-dog stand short on Monday, the deadline to register in New Jersey, so that he may devote more energy to registering voters, said he never preaches any candidate. "Some people just don't care," said Mr. Stronger. "But if one person I register votes, I still thinks it makes a difference."
 
Registration Information
 WHO IS ELIGIBLE: Any United States citizen who will be at least 18 years old and who has lived in their municipality for 30 days before the election may vote. Registered voters may request absentee ballots if they expect to be out of their area, if they are ill or if there is a conflict between work or school hours and voting hours.
IN NEW YORK: Deadline to register in person is Oct. 10; mail-in registrations must be postmarked by Oct. 9; absentee ballots must be requested by mail by Oct. 27 and in person by Nov. 2. To find out where to register, call your local county Board of Elections; in New York City call 212-VOTE-NYC.
IN CONNECTICUT: Deadline to register in person is Oct. 20; mail-in registrations must be received by that date; absentee ballots must be received by 8 P.M. on Election Day (there is no deadline to request ballots); Voters may register in person at any town hall (not necessarily their own); call your town clerk or registrar of voters in your local town for information on extended and weekend hours.
IN NEW JERSEY: Deadline to register in person or to mail in a registration form is Monday, Oct. 5; absentee ballots must be requested by Oct. 27 by mail or in person by Nov. 2; all requests for absentee ballots must be made through the local county clerk's office; call your county commissioner of registration in the county administration office for information, or the state board at 609-292-3760.

HEADLINE: Dr. David Caplovitz, an Authority On Spending Habits, Dies at 64

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Dr. David Caplovitz, a sociologist and an authority on American spending habits and misleading sales practices, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of cancer of the esophagus, his family said. 
 Dr. Caplovitz came to public notice in 1963 when he was 35 with the publication of what had been his doctoral dissertation at Columbia University two years earlier, "The Poor Pay More" (Free Press). Its contentions sound commonplace today, but did much to advance consumer-protection legislation.
 
'Buy Now, Pay Later'
 A "buy now, pay later" deal, he wrote, can ensnare the poor, uneducated or illiterate with high interest rates, hidden charges and shoddy goods.
Testifying in Washington in 1965, he described how some door-to-door salesmen and inexpensive furniture stores tricked unsuspecting -- mostly poor -- customers into signing "gimmick" contracts that required them to pay twice as much as they thought they would be paying.
At Columbia University's Bureau of Applied Social Research, Dr. Caplovitz directed a four-year study, "Consumers in Trouble: A Study of Debtors in Default." Released in 1971, it was later published (Free Press, 1974). A main conclusion was that courts often act "as collection agents of the creditors" rather than dealing out justice in default cases.
As a professor at City College of New York, he estimated in 1977 that the spreading habit of paying with "plastic" had put 10 million to 15 million Americans hopelessly over their heads in debt. He noticed that thousands of families were driven to credit counselors each year. "Debt entanglement is a major social problem," he said.
 
A Survey of Spending Habits
 A three-year survey completed in 1978, "Making Ends Meet," was based on interviews that delved into everything from people's spending habits to the impact of financial strain on marriages.
A native of New Haven, Dr. Caplovitz graduated from the University of Connecticut and, in addition to his Ph.D. from Columbia, held a law degree from City University of New York Law School at Queens College. He retired as a professor of sociology in February 1991 from City University of New York's Graduate School and University Center.
Since then and until his death, he did legal work for the Budget and Credit Counseling Service in Manhattan, representing indebted consumers. The organization's president, Luther R. Gatling, said yesterday that he was prompted by Dr. Caplovitz's writing to establish the service.
Dr. Caplovitz is survived by a daughter, Abigail of Groton, Conn.; a son, Gideon of Santa Cruz, Calif., and two brothers, Robert Caplow of New Haven, and Alvin Caplow of New York City.

HEADLINE: Few Bright Spots in Last Job Report Prior to Election

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
In the last chance for an improved job report that could help President Bush's re-election chances, the Government said today that the United States lost 57,000 more jobs in September and that the unemployment rate posted a statistically insignificant one-tenth point decline, to 7.5 percent.
The figures, the most comprehensive measure of the economy's performance last month, were greeted with some relief by economic analysts, most of whom had expected job losses twice as high along with a possible uptick in the unemployment rate. 
 But the Bush Administration strained to find a favorable light by which to portray a still essentially grim situation, one in which private-sector jobs have actually fallen by 25,000 since the President took office, far from the millions it had promised, while the unemployment rate has climbed two percentage points.
 
Dow Drops 53.76 Points
 The Federal Reserve was not compelled by the report to make any immediate cut in interest rates, though it could decide to do so at a long-scheduled policy-making session on Tuesday.
In part a result of the Fed's reluctance to act, the stock market retreated broadly yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 53.76 points, to 3,200.61, the biggest decline since April 7, when it lost 61.94. Investors were also disappointed by lowered expectations for fourth-quarter company earnings. [Page 35.]
Bright spots in the employment report, the final job tally before Election Day, were few. The drop in the unemployment rate came only because the labor force continued to shrink, as the economy's weakness was thought to have discouraged some people from looking for work.
 
'Pretty Weak Economy'
 The data "continue to show a pretty weak economy," said Darwin L. Beck, economist for the First Boston Corporation. "We've had really no gain in private employment for many many months."
Democrats seized on the report as a vehicle to attack Administration economic policy, particularly over the longer term. Campaigning outside an unemployment office in Toledo, Ohio, the Presidential nominee, Bill Clinton, complained of 1.3 million lost factory jobs over the last four years and of high overall unemployment "with no end in sight."
President Bush, interviewed on "Good Morning America," called the declines in the jobless rate in July, August and September an encouraging development, evidence, he said, of "slightly improving jobs markets."
Lynn Martin, the Labor Secretary, said a two-tenths of a point decline in the adult unemployment rate last month offered some encouragement as well as the fact that the ranks of the jobless shrank by 128,000, to 9,572,000.
In a separate report, today, new orders to the nation's factories fell 1.9 percent in August, the second straight decline and the biggest since December.
Among the 11 major states whose labor-market figures were individually published today, only Texas experienced a change of clear statistical significance. The jobless rate there spurted to 7.7 percent last month after having fallen to 6.9 percent in August.
The rates for New York, up five-tenths of a point, to 9 percent, and for Pennsylvania, down six-tenths of a point, to 7.6 percent, were regarded as having showed no meaningful change because the relatively small state samples make results volatile. The rate for Ohio, a major political battleground, eased five-tenths of a point, to 7.1 percent.
 
Matter-of-Fact Summation
 In sharp contrast to the eagerness with which today's report had been awaited was the matter-of-fact summation of lackluster results by William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"September labor market data show little change in both employment and unemployment," he told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. "Employment rose in the services industry and declined in the goods-producing industries and also in local government, where the special summer youth programs were being phased out. The unemployment rate was little changed from August but, at 7.5 percent, was down three-tenths of a percentage point from June's high of 7.8 percent."
Yet the results did mask some sizable subsidiary moves, like a sharp, 18-minute cut in the private-sector workweek that reversed an increase of that size in August. Sometimes an expanding workweek indicates overtime for existing workers that subsequently leads to new hiring.
Without the 88,000 decline in government jobs, resulting mainly from a winding down of special summer job programs and from the Detroit school strike, payroll employment would have posted a modest 31,000 increase. On the other hand, the August job loss was revised to show a 128,000 decline instead of the 83,000 initially reported.
American factories lost an additional 26,000 jobs in September, compared with a 92,000 loss in August, with weakness in aircraft, apparel and furniture as well as the erratic automotive and food-processing industries. Construction lost 21,000 jobs, resuming a downtrend that followed small spring gains.
 
More Service Jobs
 Services, however, added 72,000 jobs, including 18,000 in health, 9,000 in transportation and 7,000 in finance while retail trade was unchanged after skidding 79,000 in August.
The payroll survey also showed a 1.3-point drop, to 120.4, in the index of aggregate weekly production hours but a rise to 49 percent from 42.4 percent in the percentage of 356 industries raising September job levels.
According to the department's survey of households, employment fell 36,000 while the work force fell 164,000, reducing the number of number of jobless and the jobless rate.
The median duration of jobless spells jumped to 9.4 weeks from 8.9, the report showed, but the average spell edged up only to 18.3 weeks from 18.2. The number of people jobless for less than five weeks, the newly unemployed, fell by 13,000.
The department's quarterly survey of discouraged workers -- those who have given up looking for a job because they think it futile -- rose slightly over the summer but after rounding the figure remained at 1.1 million. Fewer blacks and men were discouraged but they were offset by more discouragement among whites and women.
Average weekly earnings of private-sector production workers dropped 1.1 percent last month, reflecting shorter hours, while average pay per hour eased two-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed.
