HEADLINE: Utilities Lead Stock Funds' Modest Gains

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Reflecting the performance of broad market averages, stock mutual funds registered unexciting gains during the third quarter.
Values of the average stock fund rose by 2.77 percent during the last three months, Lipper Analytical Services reported yesterday. The gain outpaced the 0.63 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average and the 2.27 percent rise in the Russell 2000 index but narrowly trailed the 3.15 percent gain in the Standard & Poors 500 index. 
 "It was a good quarter," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical. "But you had to be in the right stocks, like utilities and natural resources."
The last three months were not at all kind to investors in international stock funds. Currency crises hammered European equity markets, while continued poor economic performance in much of the rest of the world dragged down share prices from Asia to Canada.
All five of the worst-performing sectors tracked by Lipper Analytical were overseas funds. Latin American funds fared the worst, dropping by 11.14 percent after a 12.41 percent decline in the second quarter.
The two worst individual performers were Equi-Wright's Italian and Spanish funds, which fell by 26.70 percent and 24.65 percent, respectively. Financial markets in both countries were badly hurt by the failure of the European Community's Exchange Rate Mechanism to maintain stability between member countries.
"If you stayed home, you made money," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, a biweekly investment publication that tracks developments in the mutual fund industry.
 
Help From Hurricane Andrew
 Natural disasters, rather than man-made ones, helped to raise the performance of energy-related funds.
"Hurricane Andrew definitely helped in terms of focusing attention on natural gas prices," said Dan Rice, portfolio manager of the MetLife-State Street Energy fund, whose values rose by 13.80 percent in the summer quarter, the best among all funds. Three-quarters of the fund's portfolio is invested in natural gas stocks, Mr. Rice said.
Among sectors, according to Lipper, utility funds recorded the best gains, rising by nearly 5 percent. And small-company growth funds rebounded over the summer after a dismal performance in the second quarter. These funds rose by 3.23 percent after falling by 8.37 percent in the April-June period.
Science and technology funds, which were also pounded in the second quarter, rose by 3.67 percent over the last three months, recovering some of their declines. And the decline in interest rates and a slow but steady firming in building conditions helped to raise values of real estate funds by 3.32 percent.
Money continued to flow into stock mutual funds during the third quarter, but not at the accelerated rate seen during the first half of the year.
"Inflows over the last twelve weeks have been relatively flat, at about $1.3 billion a week, including reinvested dividends," said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services in Arcata, Calif., a firm that collects data on about 4,000 mutual funds.
Among fund sectors, Mr. Adler said that money had been flowing out of funds specializing in health care stocks since the start of September. By contrast, he said that utility funds have shown a steady increase in inflows since July.
Reflecting the decline in interest rates that has accelerated since the start of the year, only two groups of general equity funds tracked by Lipper Analytical have recorded gains for the first nine months. Returns in growth and income funds have risen by 4.97 percent since the start of the year. And during the same period, Lipper's equity income fund index has risen by 4.54 percent.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
For Greenpoint's Poles, an Uncertain Prosperity

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
AT Shanghai Lee's restaurant in Greenpoint, where the Chinese waiter took the orders in Polish, Andrzej Czeczot, an illustrator, was showing his latest satirical drawings to friends. As an artist and, what is more to the point, as a perfectly legal immigrant, Mr. Czeczot has no objection to seeing both his names in print, but at least two of the others were without green cards and so preferred to be called simply Jurek and Stas.
One of the drawings showed a street in the Brooklyn neighborhood with booths advertising different kinds of forged documents. "Social Security Cards," said one, "Green Cards," said another, and the third offered "Asbestos School Diplomas." This referred to state licenses issued to graduates of a course qualifying them for dangerous and relatively high-paying work in asbestos removal. A year ago the police broke a ring selling such counterfeit permits to Polish arrivals. 
 "You can't get the fake diplomas anymore," said Stas, who gained his own legitimately by completing the course offered by New York State and taught in Polish as well as in English and Spanish. "But you can still get any other kind of documents."
"Remember those war films showing roundups in Warsaw with Nazis looking for Jews and people without papers?" said Jurek, a freelance house painter. "Can you imagine what would happen if there was one here on Manhattan Avenue, God forbid? They would find half had no papers or bad papers."
No one is sure how many of Greenpoint's Poles are illegal residents, how many have come as tourists and overstayed their visas to work as cleaning women, restaurant workers, in construction or demolition or as factory hands. But as the conversation at the Chinese restaurant illustrated, the illegals, vulnerable to exploitation and forced to live lives of hustling and hassling, have had a big impact on the neighborhood.
"The big change came three years ago when the economy started to change in Poland," said Jurek. He explained that before then, as Communism was failing, $40 bought enough zlotys for a family in Poland to live reasonably for a month. Under those conditions people came here with the idea of working for a while, saving and going back. "Back then," he said, "if you could take back $5,000 you were set for life, you could set up a business."
"Now that Poland is an almost normal country, $5,000 is nothing," Stas said. "Even $20,000 won't change your life." As a result, people who may have come intent on going back are here to stay. "Look what happened to me," Stas said. "I came six years ago. I tried this. I tried that. The letters from my wife and daughter stopped. I met a woman here. I still say I am going to go back but I'm lying. My friends know it too."
"We are all here for good," said Jurek. He said that he and his friends pray that the lawyers they keep consulting will eventually find a way for them to become legal immigrants.
Meanwhile, living by their wits and coping with landlords and employers willing to exploit their uncertain status, they have brought energy and conspiratorial cunning to what had been a sleepy ethnic enclave little noticed by the rest of the city. "We may be in a recession but there is not an empty store on Manhattan Avenue," said Mr. Czeczot, the artist. "Legally or not people are working. New little restaurants are opening." Other old-timers agree that in the decade since young Poles like Stas and Jurek flocked to Greenpoint, the neighborhood has grown steadily richer.
One source of this prosperity has come from asbestos removal. This occupation, dominated by Polish and Irish workmen, is thought of as the best of jobs and Stas knows that many in Greenpoint envy him. He says the jealousy is misplaced, describing the work as exhausting, hazardous and not anywhere near as well paying as people think.
"When I was still in Poland I heard that Poles could make $45 an hour pulling away asbestos in New York," Stas said. "All I knew was that it was dangerous but I thought, 'How much more dangerous could it be than breathing the air around Katowice?' " he said, referring to the polluted industrial region where he grew up. "Anyway, for $45 an hour I was ready to bite frogs and jump from church steeples, but I have never seen $45 an hour."
"Look," he said, showing stubs from his pay slips. "I'm lucky if I get $10 an hour and sometimes I have to kick back money to the subcontractors who hire me. Often we don't stop for lunch. We don't get overtime. Sometimes important safety equipment is missing. Sooner or later some of us will get sick. But what can I do? Complain? To who? They'll just replace me with some other illegal Pole waiting for the opportunity."
"You mean like me," said Jurek, smiling and passing around a plate of sweet and sour shrimp.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Corn Prices Hit 4-Year Low; Huge Harvest Is Under Way

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Corn futures prices fell to their lowest point in more than four years yesterday ahead of a weekend that promised superb weather for harvesting what could be the biggest corn crop ever in the United States.
In other trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans dropped to a new 14-month low, and wheat and oat futures also slipped. 
 On other markets, copper futures prices were at their lowest since May amid pessimism about the economy; oil futures were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.
Corn for December delivery fell 2.5 cents, to $2.1125 a bushel, the lowest settlement for a near-term corn contract since May 18, 1988.
November soybeans dropped 5.25 cents, to $5.2725 a bushel, the lowest since July 19, 1991; December wheat fell 1.5 cents, to $3.48 a bushel, and December oats were unchanged at $1.335 a bushel.
The price of a bushel of corn fell 5 cents this week as frosty temperatures in the Corn Belt gave way to unseasonably warm weather that was expected to last through the weekend.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for October delivery plunged 1.95 cents, to $1.004 a pound, the lowest price since May 18.
"The poor economic numbers released this week continue to show that the economy is in a very slow growth pattern, and that weighs heavily on the copper market," said Peter Cardillo, research director with Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York. Copper is widely used in manufacturing and construction.
Energy futures turned in a mixed performance on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil ended slightly higher but below the day's high of $21.98 a barrel as border tensions between Saudi Arabia and Qatar appeared to ease.
Light crude oil for November delivery rose 9 cents, to $21.92 a barrel; November heating oil slipped 0.02 cent, to 63.85 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline rose 0.60 cent, to 58.50 cents a gallon, and November natural gas fell 0.13 cent, to $2.505 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Most livestock and meat futures advanced on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures prices were bolstered by expectations for stronger cash cattle prices next week. Speculative fund buying supported the pork complex.
Live cattle for October delivery rose 0.17 cent, to 75.92 cents a pound; October feeder cattle ended 0.30 cent higher at 83.70 cents a pound; October live hogs rose 0.28 cent, to 43.05 cents a pound, and February frozen pork bellies slipped 0.03 cent, to 39.87 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: N.H.L. Team in Hartford Receiving $4 Million Loan

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 2

 BODY:
In their latest venture in investing in local companies to save jobs in Connecticut, state economic officials have made loans and loan guarantees to Connecticut's sole major-league sports team, the Hartford Whalers, to keep it from leaving Hartford.
The loan agreement, announced Thursday by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., gives the state the right to buy the team if its owner, Richard H. Gordon, a Hartford developer, offers it for sale during the seven-year term of a $4 million loan from the state. In practice, Mr. Weicker said, the state would use that right to arrange another buyer within Connecticut. 
 The Connecticut Development Authority is also guaranteeing $10 million of $25 million in loans from Fleet Bank and Connecticut National Bank.
"The quid pro quo for us is that we have a right of first refusal," the Governor said of any sale of the team by Mr. Gordon. "I don't want to own it. He doesn't want to sell it. But I want to make damn sure it isn't going anywhere else."
 
A Struggling Franchise
 The Whalers, which were brought to Hartford in 1974 by Aetna Life & Casualty and other Hartford-based corporations, have suffered as a hockey team and as a franchise in recent years while the city and state around it were being battered by recession.
Attendance has declined steadily since the 1986-87 season, when the Whalers won the Adams Division in the National Hockey League and averaged 14,574 people a game. This year, with the third-worst record in the league, the Whalers averaged 10,896 fans a game.
Mr. Gordon said the team lost $4.5 million last season, and the sale of season tickets and the arena's 45 luxury boxes for the next season are down.
In addition, the Whalers were caught up in the bankruptcy of the Colonial Realty Company, the state's largest realty company, when its pyramid of limited partnerships began collapsing two years ago. Colonial's partners owned 37.5 percent of the Whalers through a limited partnership.
 
'This Is Not a Bailout'
 Mr. Gordon said the $4 million loan from the state would be used to acquire the Colonial interest and restructure his 75 percent ownership. The remainder of the franchise is held by the corporate consortium from which he bought the team in 1988.
"This is not a bailout for the Whalers," he said.
Mr. Gordon first approached state officials early this year, after United Technologies announced it would eliminate 6,400 jobs in Connecticut in the next three years, but months before two Hartford mainstays, Aetna and the Travelers Companies, announced they would be eliminating 2,500 jobs in the state.
Just last month the state's capital city suffered another blow, the news that May Department Stores was closing the flagship G. Fox & Company department store on Main Street.
The company's announcement that it was merging its Hartford-based G. Fox chain into its Filene's chain means that Hartford is losing its last department store and the 695 jobs at G. Fox's corporate headquarters.
Keeping the Whalers in Hartford is essential for preserving what is left of Hartford's retail businesses, including the Hartford Civic Center, the team's home, said Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for the State Department of Economic Development.
"The Connecticut Development Authority is convinced that the Hartford Whalers are critical at this time to the viability of the Hartford Civic Center, which is critical to the survival of downtown Hartford," he said.
Mr. Gordon received the state loan and loan guarantees under an aggressive program Mr. Weicker's administration is operating to preserve jobs and create new ones by providing credit to companies that banks are reluctant to lend to.
Mr. Cohen said the state has made $150 million in loans and loan guarantees in the last 18 months, helping to save or create as many as 25,000 jobs.
 
Not Pursuing Buyers
 "Richard Gordon's made it clear," Mr. Cohen said, "that when you've got a team that's not doing well, poor ticket sales, a dropoff in skybox ownership, in a tough economy, banks are not interested in making loans to a business that is continuing to bleed money."
Mr. Gordon said he had not pursued any offers to buy the team, but estimated he could earn a profit of $25 million to $30 million by selling it for $50 million to $55 million.
Under the terms of the loan agreement, if another buyer appeared during its seven-year term, the state could buy the team, or arrange a buyer for it, at 85 percent of the offered price. In addition, the agreement bars the team from moving for five years after being sold.
One other National Hockey League team, the Winnipeg Jets, has received government aid in return for staying put. That team's operating losses are covered by Winnipeg and the province of Manitoba. Many professional teams have received state and municipal aid in building or renovating their stadiums.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed as Job Report Is Not as Bad as Expected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in currency trading eysterday as Government unemployment figures turned out to be not as bad as expected.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery gained 60 cents, to $348.10. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price of $348.25, up 15 cents. 
 The Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate edged down slightly to 7.5 percent in September even though employers laid off 57,000 more workers.
The slight improvement from August's 7.6 percent rate marked the third straight month that the jobless rate edged down by a tenth of a percentage point after hitting an eight-year high of 7.8 percent in June.
However, most economists were unimpressed because the decline resulted from shrinkage in the number of people looking for work, not becuse more people found jobs.
Kevin Weir, a vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company, said there was an initial rally because traders had been prepared for the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates in the wake of poor numbers.
"I think people took a second look at the number" and coupled that with the Fed taking no action, thus trading wound up "kind of all over the map today," Mr. Weir said.
Trading was also affected by the German central bank's silence on the interest rate front yesterday.
If Germany had revised its interest rates, that would have affected the currency markets also.
"The bottom line is you still may get a cut from the Fed and no overt action from the Bundesbank," Mr. Weir said.
The dollar fell to 119.35 Japanese yen in New York, down from 119.80 late Thursday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 119.40 Japanese yen from 120.32 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it was quoted at the same 119.40 yen.
In New York, the pound fell to $1.7285, from $1.7380 late Thursday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.7265, from $1.7325 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.4095 marks, down from 1.4215; 1.2320 Swiss francs, down from 1.2425; 4.7700 French francs, down from 4.8040; 1,250.0 Italian lire, up from 1,244.5, and 1.25065 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24735.
Silver rose on the New York Commodity Exchange to $3.734 a troy ounce, from $3.714 a troy ounce late Thursday. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $3.74 a troy ounce, from $3.75 bid late Thursday.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The New York Region;
Perot's Return May Hurt Clinton in New Jersey

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Officials of Gov. Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign in New York and Connecticut are largely discounting the impact of Ross Perot's return to the race. But in New Jersey, Mr. Perot's return offers at least an opportunity for President Bush's flagging campaign to salvage the state and its 15 electoral votes, political analysts say.
New Jersey, which has voted Republican in recent Presidential races, is considered a must-win for Mr. Bush. But before Mr. Perot's re-entry, Mr. Clinton was running slightly ahead in public opinion polls. The thin margin raises at least the possibility, say politicians and pollsters, that Mr. Perot could lure away enough Clinton supporters to let Mr. Bush squeak through. 
 "The people voting for Bush are voting for Bush," said Janice Ballou, director of the Center for Public Interest Polling at the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University. "Clinton voters are the not-Bush people. That's why Clinton becomes more vulnerable."
 
Sharing the Protest Vote
 The argument for this view is that Mr. Perot may draw some share of the protest vote on which Mr. Clinton is counting and that New Jerseyans are accustomed to registering protest votes. Since Mr. Clinton appears to have inherited more of Mr. Perot's supporters over the summer, he might have more of them to lose now that Mr. Perot has officially returned to the race, analysts say.
But politicians and pollsters acknowledge that their theories are just that. The candidate has only been back in the race for two days, and the race and the candidate have been redefined since Mr. Perot dropped out in July.
Richard Gannon, the Clinton campaign director in New Jersey, said most Perot voters would probably come from economically depressed conservative areas in South Jersey that would otherwise have supported Mr. Bush. Still, Mr. Gannon added, "Anyone willing to spend $100 million gives me cause for concern."
New Jersey has a higher proportion of residents enrolled as independents than as either Democrats or Republicans, underscoring that party affiliations are not likely to have that strong an influence on the outcome.
In New York, Republicans have not publicly given up on the state's lode of 33 electoral votes. But many acknowledge privately that President Bush appears to be trailing irretrievably.
 
Quick Campaign Swing
 William D. Powers, the Republican state chairman, said yesterday that he hoped that the race would become competitive enough to lure Mr. Bush to New York for a quick campaign swing later this month. Mr. Powers discounted a poll released yesterday by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion because it was conducted just before Mr. Perot formally rejoined the race.
When those questioned who said they were undecided were asked which candidate they were leaning toward, the totals were 52 percent for Mr. Clinton, 35 percent for Mr. Bush, 10 percent for Mr. Perot and 3 percent still uncertain.
The telephone survey of 821 voters has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points among likely voters.
"Half the voters in the Democratic primary rejected Bill Clinton," Mr. Powers said. "They would not support President Bush, but probably would support Ross Perot."
The Marist poll appears to contradict Mr. Powers's prediction that Mr. Perot's re-entry would substantially benefit Mr. Bush. In a two-way contest, Mr. Clinton's margin was larger, nearly 25 percentage points. But when people were asked whether they were firmly committed to their candidate, 71 percent of Mr. Clinton's supporters said they were, compared with 57 percent of Mr. Bush's and 43 percent of Mr. Perot's.
 
Support for Perot
 Among people who identified themselves as Republicans, 13 percent said they were supporting Mr. Perot, compared with about 5 percent of the Democrats.
"Where we have to go to get the big turnout -- from labor, African-Americans Latinos -- he does not hurt us," said Bill Lynch, the deputy Clinton campaign director in New York, referring to Mr. Perot. "If we don't do that, then whatever he gets here could be a problem."
John A. Marino, the Democratic state chairman, agreed that the outcome would be closer than the poll suggested and that some anti-Bush voters might shift to Mr. Perot. "But even if you give him another 5 percent and it all comes from Clinton, it shouldn't matter," Mr. Marino said.
Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute, concurred that Mr. Perot was unlikely to affect the outcome in New York. "The race Perot left is a very different race than the one he re-entered," Dr. Miringoff said.
Whatever impact Mr. Perot has in New York is likely to be limited to the Presidential race. The Perot campaign organization told state election officials last month that no local candidate has permission to run with Mr. Perot on his independent ballot line.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: TH AD CAMPAIGN;
Clinton: The Swift Counterattack

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

 BODY:
Yesterday, one day after the Bush campaign began broadcasting an advertisement charging that Gov. Bill Clinton would raise taxes for an array of average Americans, the Clinton campaign released its own commercial in response. The 30-second ad will run in about 20 battleground states.
 
ON THE SCREEN Opens with a picture of four television screens, each featuring a clip from the Bush commercial. At the top in a red band are the words "George Bush attack ad." The words " 'Misleading' -- The Washington Post, 10/2/92," appear superimposed over the screens. Cut to quotation from The Wall Street Journal. Cut to another red band reading "The Bush record," and a statement beneath: "The worst economic record of any president in 50 years." Cut to a photograph of Mr. Bush. Ends with black-on-white message: "Nothing could be more frightening than four more years."
 

PRODUCER Clinton/Gore Creative Team
 
TELEVISION SCRIPT Announcer: "George Bush is running attack ads. He says all these people would have their taxes raised by Bill Clinton. Scary, huh? 'Misleading,' says The Washington Post. And The Wall Street Journal says, 'Clinton has proposed to cut taxes for the sort of people featured in Bush's ad.' "So why's he doing it? Because George Bush had the worst economic record of any President in 50 years. George Bush is trying to scare you about Bill Clinton. But nothing could be more frightening than four more years."
 
ACCURACY By most measures, economic growth under Mr. Bush is in fact the slowest since Franklin D. Roosevelt ratcheted up the industrial machine for World War II half a century ago. The newspaper quotations come from a Wall Street Journal article about the Bush commercial and a Washington Post critique, similar to this one, of the same ad.
 
SCORECARD At political war once more, Clinton strategists are hewing to the basics that saw them through the firefight of the Democratic primaries: never let an accusation go unanswered for more than one news cycle; hit back harder than your opponent hits you.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congressional Roundup;
Democrats Work On a Tax Bill

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Democratic chairmen of the House and Senate tax committees, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, met today to work out a compromise tax bill that would satisfy both houses without provoking a Presidential veto.
Both houses have passed legislation that would, among other things, spur business investment in economically distressed neighborhoods, extend a number of expiring tax breaks, and pay for the expenditures with several tax increases. 
 The Senate bill includes two provisions that the White House has threatened to veto because they would raise taxes on upper-income taxpayers. The two provisions would raise about $7 billion over the next five years, so if they are removed from the bill some cuts or other revenues would be needed, perhaps removal of costly provisions sponsored by Senator Bentsen expanding the availability of Individual Retirement Accounts.
Mr. Rostenkowski, emerging at one point during the meetings, said he hoped to make use of various revenue-raising proposals included in the budget plan President Bush submitted to Congress earlier this year. Some of those are already in the Senate or House versions of the tax bills, but others could be added.

HEADLINE: Clinton: The Teflon Candidate

BYLINE: By Haley Barbour; Haley Barbour was political director for the Reagan White House.

DATELINE: YAZOO CITY, Miss.

 BODY:
Long before the official Presidential campaign began, before the first candidate kissed the first baby in New Hampshire, an echo of elections past began to fill the air. This sound, which gained strength and power over the months, was the sound of Democrats crying "foul!"
While every recent Democratic Presidential hopeful has made liberal use of the charge that Republicans rely on dirty tricks during campaigns, none mastered it as early or as well as Bill Clinton. At the first whiff of criticism or even a recitation of facts from his record, the Clinton camp immediately went on the attack, accusing the Republicans of dirty tricks. 
 If unflattering stories cropped up in the press, the Democrats decried the low road taken by Bush-Quayle "operatives." Day after day, they sounded the refrain. The Clinton people have crowed about the effectiveness of this strategy, and it has worked.
It has become virtually impossible for the President to discuss any issue -- from Mr. Clinton's economic proposals to his draft record -- without being tarred as mean-spirited or, in one account, accused of McCarthyism. When a recent Bush campaign ad estimated the costs of Mr. Clinton's economic plan, the press complained that the numbers didn't come from the Governor's camp. That's because the Clinton campaign never calculated the most important number of all -- what tax rate you must charge to generate $154 billion in revenue.
It's important to recall that the big early scandals involving Mr. Clinton's character were not generated by Republicans, but by the press and his Democratic primary rivals. But that didn't stop him from blaming these stories -- the Gennifer Flowers "expose" and his draft record -- on Republican dirty tricks. And when his 1969 letter about avoiding the draft was published, he lambasted "a pattern by people desperate to stay in power and willing to impugn the motives, the patriotism and the lives of anyone who stands in their way."
After his claim that the Pentagon had leaked the letter was proved wrong, Mr. Clinton continued to blame "the Republican attack machine" and "search and destroy politics that have taken the heart out of the political system in this country." For the most part, the press did not hold him accountable for such unsubstantiated or demonstrably false charges.
So he has stuck with his tactic: never defend. This attack campaign has two major goals: to mask their own assaults on the President and to inoculate Mr. Clinton from Republican charges.
No campaign in recent history has been as aggressively personal as Mr. Clinton's assault on George Bush. A national co-chairman of the Clinton campaign called the President "a racist." Ron Brown, the national Democratic chairman, likened the President's racial policies to massive resistance to civil rights in the South in the 1960's South. Al Gore has insinuated that George Bush lied about the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue and called the President a hypocrite.
During the Clinton-Gore bus-capade in July, Albert Gore and other speakers would rise to rip into George Bush and Dan Quayle, then Mr. Clinton would take the stage and sanctimoniously warn the crowd not to fall for the Republicans' tactics. He told one audience, "Everywhere I go, people say, 'Are you ready for one more Republican negative campaign?' "
This is character assassination, plain and simple, disguised as a plea for civility. Bill Clinton knew that long after the public lost interest in the facts of any particular controversy, his insinuations about Republicans would linger on.
And so they have. This weird spectacle reminds me of the "bad guy" in the wrestling match who gouges eyes and pulls hair while whining to the referee about his opponent's cheating. It succeeds because no referee intervenes.
Despite the polls, I don't think the Clinton scheme -- cynical, clever, well-orchestrated -- will succeed through Nov. 3. As in the wrestling match, I believe people will cheer as the guy on the mat rises and flattens the bad guy. Americans just don't like unfair tactics -- especially unfair tactics masquerading as fair play.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: How to Disarm Iraq

 BODY:
In an effort to step up pressure on Iraq, the United Nations Security Council has now voted to tap Baghdad's overseas assets to pay war compensation and U.N. administrative costs. That's sound strategy: clearly defined pressure to achieve a clearly defined goal.
The same can no longer be said of the 26-month-long economic embargo against Iraq. The embargo has been an impressive exercise in international solidarity, confounding skeptics who once predicted the effort would break down after just a few months. Yet the strategy has begun to suffer from Washington's inflexibility. 
 The purpose of keeping sanctions in place after Baghdad's expulsion from Kuwait was to force the destruction of Iraq's remaining arsenal of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons and Scud missiles and to nail down guarantees against future arms buildups.
Thanks to the bravery and persistence of U.N. arms inspectors, the first part of that goal looks attainable. Yet President Bush's firm refusal to contemplate any easing of sanctions while Saddam Hussein remains in power weakens the U.N.'s ability to finish the job. If Iraq can expect the same treatment whether or not it cooperates, what reason does it have to cooperate?
There's a more promising alternative: Without in any way rewarding Iraqi intransigence, give Baghdad a positive incentive to cooperate with the U.N. by reaffirming the explicit link between sanctions and arms control progress.
Working in the teeth of Iraqi resistance, U.N. inspectors are well into the process of destroying most of the nuclear materiel, missiles, biological and chemical weapons they have been able to find. But given Baghdad's past deceptions, the inspectors can't be confident that additional items aren't buried at some secret site. And their job won't be complete until they negotiate reliable inspection provisions for the future.
Completing their work largely depends on Iraq's cooperating. Iraq might be more inclined to do so if Council members recalled the bargain embodied in Resolution 687, which formally codified the Persian Gulf war cease-fire. The resolution declares that once the Security Council finds that Iraq has complied with its requirements concerning weapons, the main international economic sanctions automatically end.
The Council later imposed additional requirements on Iraq, like protecting the Kurds, paying for humanitarian relief and accepting a newly delineated border with Kuwait. These too need to be enforced, but not necessarily with sanctions on Iraqi exports. Tangible relief ought to be granted in exchange for full compliance on arms control alone.
Instead, the Bush Administration insists that all sanctions stay in force as long as Saddam Hussein remains in power. That's politically satisfying. But it's also counterproductive, since it effectively tells Baghdad that it has nothing to gain from cooperating.
As long as Mr. Hussein's departure remains unlikely, the most important goal is to deny him any access to mass destruction weapons. The world's persistence has brought that goal within sight. Completing the effort now requires a judicious use of carrots as well as sticks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Improving African Farming Is a Two-Part Job

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Richard Critchfield's Sept. 14 Op-Ed article, "Bring the Green Revolution to Africa," is a misleading and ultimately mischievous characterization of a very difficult situation. By singling out the World Bank to bear the responsibility for the problems of African agriculture, he fails to recognize the complexity of modernizing agriculture on that continent, and chastises an organization that strives mightily to work with African nations to improve the well-being of their people. 
 Raising the productivity of agriculture requires a combination of new production technology and getting the prices right for the farmers. The new technology is the potential source of increased output; the "right" prices provide the incentives for farmers to adopt the technology. Nobel Laureate Norman Borlaug and his colleagues are working on one component of this combination; the World Bank and other bilateral and multilateral development agencies are working on the second part.
Most governments in the region have seriously discriminated against their farmers by using trade and exchange rate policies to lower prices of farm commodities while providing high levels of protection for their nascent manufacturing sectors. Thus the World Bank and other international development agencies have faced serious difficulties in addressing their part of the solution to the pervasive problems of African agriculture.
 
G. EDWARD SCHUH
Dean, Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs, U. of Minnesota
Minneapolis, Sept. 23, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For Cities: Some Christmas Tree

 BODY:
Want a challenge? Try finding the urban aid in the urban aid bills just passed by the House and Senate. The bills have little to do with cities and almost everything to do with rewarding powerful constituents. Unless radically altered, the bills aren't worth passing.
After the Los Angeles riots in April, Congress pledged a swift response. But then it dithered for months -- and finally proposed showering tens of billions on real estate investors, yacht buyers, oil and gas producers, even rural development. Only a fraction is left for ghettos. Of the $30 billion the Senate would spend over five years, only about $6 billion would go to blighted cities. 
 There's still a slim chance that the conference committee will produce a bill worth having. The first task is to prune the giveaways that make this a Christmas tree bill for almost every sector except cities.
The Senate version would create new subsidies for retirement savings of high-income families. Although it appears harmless for the five-year period that Congress is required to examine, it would create a huge budget hemorrhage in future years. Ultimately the tax giveaway would raise the deficit and thereby drive down national saving, the opposite of what proponents claim.
The conference committee could eliminate this irresponsible measure, and also lop off proposed tax breaks for real estate investors, first-time home buyers and other special interests. The next task is to salvage three modestly worthwhile provisions:
Enterprise Zones. The centerpiece of the Administration's response to Los Angeles was enterprise zones -- blighted areas in inner cities to which employers would be drawn by tax breaks and regulatory relief. State experience with such zones isn't encouraging, but Federal zones, potentially more powerful, are worth trying.
Unfortunately, Congress wants to create between 50 and 125 zones, spreading the money so thinly that no zone would feel much impact. If Congress would limit the program to a dozen or so zones, it might provide enough tax cuts and support services to make the idea work.
Low-Income Housing Tax Credit. The tax credit currently attracts private investors to low-income housing projects and accounts for most low-income housing construction. Community development corporations rely on the credit to finance residential housing projects. It is scheduled to expire and merits permanent passage.
Children's Assistance. Two programs warrant passage. One would provide additional food stamps to families saddled with high housing costs. The other would provide money to assist families threatening to break up.
Stripped down to these provisions, Congress would have an urban aid package costing only about $10 billion. That could be paid for without raising income taxes. These three provisions wouldn't end inner-city blight, or even make a major dent in it. But they would provide honest relief for distressed people in distressed cities -- a big improvement over the mislabeled giveaways that Congress has so far passed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
SHOW BUSINESS, by Shashi Tharoor. (Arcade, $19.95.) An impressive novel about the rise, fall and rise again of a matinee idol in Bombay captures the crazy razzle-dazzle of the world's biggest and gaudiest film industry.
KATERINA, by Aharon Appelfeld. (Random House, $18.) In a narrative of tribal hatred overcome, the eminent Israeli novelist reimagines the Holocaust through the eyes of a gentile peasant woman, a runaway who has been taken in by a Jewish family.
VANISHING POINTS, by Thea Astley. (Putnam, $21.95.) Two intricately linked novellas -- "The Genteel Poverty Bus Company" and "Inventing the Weather" -- about disaffected Australians seeking escape from the monster called progress.
HANNAH ARENDT -- KARL JASPERS: CORRESPONDENCE, 1926-1969, edited by Lotte Kohler and Hans Saner. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $49.95.) Forty-three years of discussion between two world-class intellectuals whose lives were defined by the great ideas and events of the 20th century.
FACES AT THE BOTTOM OF THE WELL: The Permanence of Racism, by Derrick Bell. (Basic Books, $20.) A prominent scholar of race and the law argues, with allegory, fables and dialogues, that our progress against racism so far has been illusory.
YOUR BLUES AIN'T LIKE MINE, by Bebe Moore Campbell. (Putnam, $22.95.) An eloquent first novel that shows the lives and hearts of poor black and white people, with malice toward none.
THE OXFORD COMPANION TO THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE, edited by Tom McArthur; managing editor, Feri McArthur. (Oxford University, $45.) This perfect browser's manual contains an abundance of neat things to know about what we say and why.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Mel Gibson Shoots (a Movie)

BYLINE: By ALLEN BARRA; Allen Barra, a contributing editor at The Village Voice and Entertainment Weekly, has written about film for Premiere and American Film.

DATELINE: BAYSIDE, Me.

 BODY:
This tiny resort community, on the Maine coast not far from Camden, is a cluster of summer houses so quaint that in the words of one Southern Californian, "you almost expect a little train to drive down the lane with Mickey Mouse in the engine." The houses, with their picket fences and bay windows, look as if they were built for the movies. And in fact, as local residents with binoculars and cameras wait outside in a drizzle, a movie is being shot inside one of them.
The film is "The Man Without a Face," a modestly budgeted drama that is Mel Gibson's directorial debut. As the camera rolls, Margaret Whitton, looking like the quintessential all-American mom, is serving her family lunch from a steaming pot of SpaghettiOs. Suddenly, the screech of an alarm rips through the house. Mel Gibson, every bit the lean, mean, fighting machine that has made him an international star, leaps from behind the camera and into the dining room, index fingers pointed like automatic pistols. 
 "Everyone duck!" he yells. "Don't move! Wait for the bomb squad!"
"What is this?" asks Faye Masterson, who plays the oldest daughter. " 'Lethal Weapon 4'?"
A quick check reveals that the vat of hot SpaghettiOs has set off a smoke detector. "That's the SpaghettiOs alarm," Mr. Gibson observes. "More SpaghettiOs for my actors."
With feigned exasperation, the 12-year-old Gaby Hoffman says, "Oh, Mel, you're so silly."
Mr. Gibson's behavior does seem pretty silly by the standards of most directors. During rehearsals he gives his actors bits of advice in the voices of Sammy Davis Jr., Charles Bronson and -- in the words of Bruce Davies, the film's producer -- "absolutely, hands down, the best Ben Gazzara impression I've ever heard."
Sometimes, during a lull, Mr. Gibson will begin a story to one of his actors with the words "Did I ever tell you about the time . . . ," and a chorus of "DEE-DEE dee-dee DEE-DEE dee-dee," the theme from "The Twilight Zone," will break out. "Demento Boy is back," Ms. Whitton cautions her movie children, and they nod knowingly.
"Demento Boy" is the cast's nickname for their director when, in Gaby Hoffman's words, "he acts really nutty." But Mr. Gibson, like the Hamlet he played in Franco Zeffirelli's 1990 film, has a motive for his madness. Gaby Hoffman and the 13-year-old Nick Stahl, another member of the movie family, are professionals; but they are also young, and "The Man Without a Face," in which a boy struggles to find his identity in a family of women, involves profound emotional issues. Mr. Gibson's playfulness helps to ease the tension.
"Sometimes I feel the pressure of keeping the cast and crew waiting when I flub a scene," Nick says, "but Mel jokes a lot and makes me feel that that I'm not messing up. He takes all the pressure off me."
"The Man Without a Face" is based on a 1972 novel by Isabelle Holland about the relationship between a disfigured former prep school teacher (played by Mr. Gibson) and a 13-year-old boy. Budgeted at between $10 million and $12 million and scheduled for release next fall, it is a small film by Hollywood standards. But that pleases the 41-year-old Mr. Gibson as he joins the ranks of actors who, whether out of desire for creative control or simply curiosity, have gone behind the camera.
"I was drawn to the material because of the relationship between this older man who's terribly disfigured and this young boy who's struggling to find a way to manhood," Mr. Gibson says. "A big budget would only get in the way; there aren't any car crashes or special effects."
Still, in some ways the pressure on Mr. Gibson is greater than if he had the budget of "Batman" to play with. As Richard Masur, who plays Ms. Whitton's husband, puts it: "It takes guts to put yourself on the line like Mel does. A lot of people are laying for you when you play Hamlet or decide to direct a film." 
During a coffee break on the set, Mr. Gibson admits: "The truth is that I'm not entirely sure what I'm doing. The kids are more veteran than me. They've acted before, but I've never directed a film. I'm winging it."
And he is. For various reasons, Mr. Gibson couldn't get the actors he wanted for the title role. And so he ended up directing one of the biggest stars in movies -- himself -- in his feature-film directing debut. (His only other directing credits are for films about the making of "Hamlet" and of two "Lethal Weapon" films.)
According to his colleagues, Mr. Gibson was lucky in his choice of star. Piper Laurie, who starred with Mr. Gibson in a little-seen 1979 Australian movie called "Tim," said she believes that "the only people who were surprised by how good Mel was as Hamlet were people who don't know about his extensive stage training or who haven't seen his early film work. He should do very well behind the camera."
Mr. Gibson's friend Richard Donner, the director of the "Lethal Weapon" movies, calls the star "a director's dream," but he adds: "Mel has a lot of anger and hostility in him. He bottles it up well, but there have been times when I've seen the pot start to boil over, and I know enough to back off and get others to back off."
In any case, Mr. Gibson seems to be in a good mood three weeks into filming in Bayside, where he has been joined by his wife and six children. On location he has been directing, acting and watching his budget. Each night, after shooting is finished, he goes from the movie set to a cold pizza and screening room to watch the daily rushes before checking in with his family.
Seated beneath a canvas tent that gives the set an air of a traveling circus -- Mr. Gibson himself likens his role to that of "head clown" and "ringmaster" -- he answers questions between bites of chicken. He responds warily, sometimes backtracking on statements, often glancing at the interviewer's tape recorder as if afraid that it might pull a fast one. He seems to enjoy being Mel Gibson while he is working but is downright uncomfortable about having to play Mel Gibson in situations that aren't spontaneous. Still, as a director, he appears receptive to suggestions.
"Mel is remarkably open to the ideas of other people involved," says Ms. Whitton. "He's not a theorist or an ideologue; he sees film as a collaborative process. He's going to be a very good director, and that shouldn't surprise anyone. He's a very good actor, and good actors know how to direct themselves."
Mr. Gibson agrees, adding: "That side of the camera I feel I know something about, so that's what I'm sticking to, the acting. I feel safer with that than trying to be Orson Welles my first time out. I can't really say I started out watching directors and thinking, 'So that's how it's done.' It's more like I saw the finished product and became increasingly interested in retracing the steps and seeing how it was done."
Mr. Gibson has had a lot of time to observe the techniques of respected directors, including Peter Weir, with whom he worked on "Gallipoli" and "The Year of Living Dangerously," and George Miller, whose "Mad Max" and "Road Warrior" made Mr. Gibson an international star before he was 25.
"I've been lucky that way," the actor acknowledged. "George Miller, for instance -- I learned a lot about economy from him. 'The Road Warrior' was shot for a fraction of what they do big Hollywood action films for. He also taught me to use economy of effort to obtain maximum effect. The famous chase scene at the end of the movie? Half the time the truck wasn't even moving."
Economy is clearly on Mr. Gibson's mind as "The Man Without a Face" nears completion; it's as much a matter of pride as finance to bring it in on schedule and on budget. "There's so much waste in films these days," he says. "It's really getting appalling. I mean, the whole budget for this film . . . ." He trails off. The entire budget for this film probably wouldn't be far from what Mr. Gibson was paid for "Lethal Weapon 3."
"Anyway," he says, "it restores your sanity to make movies this way. Or in my case," he continues in his best Three Stooges voice, "my insanity."
He is told about a comment that Nick Stahl made when asked how he copes with the tedium of movie making: "I figure they pay me to put up with that. The acting I do for free." Mr. Gibson grins. "Did Nick say that? What a wonderful thing to say."
At that moment, Nick walks by.
"Nick," says Mr. Gibson, "my old pal. Nick, did I ever tell you about how I met my wife? It was in a burning wasteland . . . ." The boy looks at Mr. Gibson, then glances at other cast members nearby. A chorus of "DEE-DEE dee-dee DEE-DEE dee-dee" breaks out in the yard.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
Celebrating 20 Years Of Elitism

BYLINE: By John J. O'Connor

 BODY:
Politicians who issue ominous warnings about a "cultural elite" turn curiously coy when asked to name names, but the arts, of course, merit conspicuous attention in their pantheon of villains. And so does public television with its persistent habit of providing a showcase for the best and, on occasion, the most provocative of the arts, at home and abroad.
Wearing its "cultural elite" badge proudly though hardly defiantly, one public-television institution, the "Great Performances" series, is this Friday, at 9 P.M. on Channel 13/ WNET, throwing a 20th birthday party for itself, pointedly subtitled "Celebrating Creativity, American Style." 
 The special offers an assortment of pieces commissioned for the occasion, many featuring series alumni. One, Meryl Streep, introduces the program, recalling her own television debut, in "Secret Service," a Civil War melodrama that was part of the 1976-77 season. For Ms. Streep, the magic of the series is that "it's a record of all those 'great performances' that would have just floated off into air, a record of artists doing what they do best."
Friday's assortment, aimed in various ways at showing how the arts enrich us all, is generally ingratiating and inevitably uneven as it tries to encompass something for everyone. Included are short plays by Terrence McNally, Wendy Wasserstein and Alan Zweibel; dances choreographed by Peter Martins and urban hip-hoppers; an Annie Leibovitz movement study with Mikhail Baryshnikov and Twyla Tharp; a tribute to Leonard Bernstein, and a rousing soul version of Handel's "Hallelujah Chorus."
There's little here to upset the anti-elitist brigades, although Mr. McNally's sympathetic treatment of a gay man dead of AIDS could activate their hostility. But this is, after all, not an occasion for inviting confrontations. There have been enough of those over the years, as Jac Venza, the executive producer of the series, recalled one recent evening in an Upper East Side restaurant.
Money problems, endemic to public television, have always existed. And even 20 years ago, politicians were going after what they considered an overly independent and liberal system catering to, in the immortal words of a Spiro T. Agnew writer, "the nattering nabobs of negativism."
Actually, "Great Performances" won't be 20 years old until next year, but the series can trace its roots to "Theater in America" of 1972, another Venza project, which began its distinguished tour of regional theater with Lanford Wilson's "Rimers of Eldritch." The following year, that series and others, including "Dance in America," were brought under the umbrella title of "Great Performances," produced by WNET and underwritten by Exxon on a 39-week basis, an enlightened corporate-identity relationship that would last for 15 years. The current underwriter is Duracell.
Mr. Venza remembers the earlier years as a "purer experience," nearer to the original structuring of public television as an alternative service. And, he notes, everything cost less. As production expenses began soaring, however, he refused to cut what he considered essential corners. "If you ask someone to perform for very little money, usually scale, you cannot economize on the hair, the makeup, the lighting," he says. "The performers have to be presented as professionals and given first-class production values. Otherwise we're treating the arts as a kind of poor cousin."
The "Great Performances" season gradually evolved into a combination of European acquisitions and original domestic productions. The relatively inexpensive imports, ranging from a wealth of classical music concerts and operas to mini-series on the magnificent level of "Brideshead Revisited" enabled the series, Mr. Venza says, to "put most of our money into American productions." Those include works by just about every major choreographer, the broadcast of four new American operas and adaptations of short stories by John Cheever.
Most music is easy. Even the anti-elitists can appreciate Bernstein conducting Beethoven or Stephen Sondheim's "Follies in Concert." But Mr. Venza has made a point of highlighting productions outside the mainstream: "Einstein on the Beach" by Philip Glass and Robert Wilson; the controversial Peter Sellars stagings of three Mozart operas; the equally controversial Boulez-Chereau interpretation of Wagner's "Ring" at Bayreuth (presented as an eight-part series). The list is long and staggeringly impressive.
The future? Noting that "we have already covered a lot of the classics," Mr. Venza speaks about finding "better ways to communicate with larger audiences." As costs continue to soar and budgets are increasingly scrutinized, he says that "even within public television, there are people who'd like to see less arts programming." New directions in the series are already apparent. More is being done with jazz and popular music. "Swinging Out With Harry" (Harry Connick Jr.) or "The Fred Astaire Songbook" can be tucked between "The Mahabharata" and "The Search for Nijinsky." Dance can be packaged imaginatively with biography, and the result can be as illuminating and moving as "Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane and Co."
There are still, of course, certain cultural gatekeepers who reject the very idea of the arts being associated with a medium ostensibly as vulgar as television. But there's no going back. Mr. Venza does indeed talk of a time when "many of the celebrated artists with whom we were eager to work had little enthusiasm for television because of their minimal presence in commercial television." Whatever its weaknesses, public television has changed all that.
"My job," Mr. Venza says simply, "is to protect the turf of artists and creativity." Don't underestimate the toughness and durability of elitists.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
In Philadelphia, a Showcase of Abandoned Hopes

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
It was the largest building in America, and reputedly the most expensive. Its bold, original design influenced architecture internationally. Tocqueville came from France to study it; Dickens declared it (along with Niagara Falls) one of the two sights he hoped to see on his 1842 American tour. Today, the Eastern State Penitentiary is something of an embarrassment, an abandoned ruin overgrown with weeds. But this gloomy landmark is still worthy of wide public attention. Few buildings shed a more penetrating light on modern democracy and its discontents.
Located just a few blocks from the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Eastern State is also a museum, a showcase of lost hopes. Empty since the last prisoners departed in 1970, the prison's stone-walled cells are haunting tableaux of a failed experiment in utopian social planning. Designed in 1821 by the Philadelphia architect John Haviland, Eastern State was born from the fusion of Quaker social conscience with the Enlightenment's faith in reason. Its innovative form arose from humanitarian concern for the treatment of prisoners and from philosophical speculation about the cause and cure of crime. 
 Few visitors today, however, will find this place either humane or reasonable. For it was here, in the city of the Liberty Bell, that the concept of solitary confinement was put to its first major test. This was the dubious achievement of the place known around the world as "the Prison at Philadelphia."
Today, a preservation task force, financed by the Pew Charitable Trusts, is studying ways to re-use Eastern State and educate the public about its history. In the mid-1980's the prison, now owned by the city of Philadelphia, was the target of several redevelopment proposals, including plans for luxury housing and an urban shopping mall. All the proposals called for substantial demolition of Haviland's architecture, however, and in 1988, in response to a petition from the task force, Mayor W. Wilson Goode turned them all down pending further study.
But the popularity of Alcatraz notwithstanding, prisons make awkward landmarks. Compared to, say, a courthouse, a prison lacks the luster of civic pride. The classical form of a courthouse extols a supreme democratic virtue: the law and its impartiality, the consent of the governed to the rules that make their liberty possible. A prison speaks of the loss of freedom. Its message is not the law but the consequences of transgressing it: guilt, disgrace, the stigma of the outlaw state.
These qualities are not easily rendered into architecture, though Piranesi, memorably, transformed Baroque court design into "imaginary prisons" of nightmarish power. Still, for a young democratic nation, dedicated to reforming society and its institutions, the prison was an irresistible challenge. What could be more idealistic than to reform a brutal institution into an enlightened system for reforming individuals?
Viewed from outside, Eastern State resembles a Gothic fortress. Square in plan, the crenelated granite walls enclose a 10-acre site. A stone tower marks the entrance; from the corners, turrets rise. The design turns the form of a medieval city inside out. No hordes clamored to enter Eastern State, though the forbidding walls were designed to deter people from acts that might land them there. The massive ramparts also gave reassurance that those confined within would remain outside the city of the law abiding.
But it is inside the walls that the prison's experimental plan unfolded. Traditionally, prisons were squalid places, where people were thrown together in common rooms, often regardless of sex, age or the severity of their offenses. They were places of disorder and social neglect. By contrast, "penitentiaries" like Eastern State were places of discipline. They were built on the theory that criminals are psychological slobs, people who failed to acquire discipline early in life. Within the penitentiary's controlled environment, criminals would reform themselves through penance -- hence the name. The Pennsylvania Plan, as solitary (or "separate") confinement was called, took the theory a step further. Criminals would acquire discipline more readily if they were isolated from other undisciplined souls.
Philadelphia's prison officials considered several options before choosing Haviland's plan. They deliberated over a panopticon, a circular building with an observation tower in the middle, similar to one Benjamin Latrobe had designed for Richmond Prison in 1795. Though an observation tower rises from the center of Haviland's building, this is not the true panopticon form conceived by the British political economist Jeremy Bentham. Instead of forming a circle, Eastern State's seven cellblocks -- containing 250 cells altogether -- radiate from the central observation tower like spokes. (Four additional blocks and other outbuildings were added later.) This plan allowed surveillance of the open yards but, unlike a panopticon, it did not permit guards to look into the cells.
Instead of "the eye of power," to use Michel Foucault's term for the technique of constant prisoner surveillance, Eastern State relied on the power of the invisible. On arriving at the prison, prisoners were hooded before being led to their cells, to prevent them from seeing where they were going. Each cell measured 8 by 12 feet and was equipped with a flush toilet and running water. A walled yard outside the cell permitted solitary exercise. An 1831 report explained: "No prisoner is seen by another, after he enters the wall. When the years of his confinement have passed, his old associates in crime will be scattered over the earth, or in the grave . . . and the prisoner can go forth into a new and industrious life, where his previous deeds are unknown."
It sounds a bit like heaven, and indeed the roots of the Pennsylvania Plan lay in monastic architecture and in the solitary life of Carthusian monks. Inmates at Eastern State were provided with Bibles and expected to work at weaving and other crafts. They received regular visits from members of the Philadelphia Prison Society, the Quaker organization that had championed the creation of Eastern State. It is as if, by emulating a monastic structure, the prison could convert a criminal calling into a religious one, sinners into saints. "The Pennsylvania System is a Divine System," hailed one contemporary advocate.
But to Dickens, who visited the prison 150 years ago, the system was infernal, precisely because of its reliance on the unseen. Prisoners were invisible to the world as well as to one another, and their punishment left no visible scars. Society did not have to witness the consequences of confining people here. Dickens thought public flogging preferable to this "slow and daily tampering with the mysteries of the brain."
But the governing concept of reform hinged on that tampering: on the prison's capacity to turn the private recesses of the mind into a matter of public interest. What stands out most vividly in Dickens's account of his visit (in his "American Notes") is the eagerness of prison officials to secure the prisoners' assent to the system that held them. One inspector asks a prisoner, Are you resigned now? Are you a better man? A female prisoner is asked, Are you happy here?
Such questioning was critical to the experiment's success. By a circular logic, only the prisoners could say if the system worked. Only they could provide the evidence that, yes, they had reformed. They had acquired discipline. They had mended their ways.
If Dickens paused to visit Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, he did not record it. From Philadelphia he traveled south to Washington, where he spent several days attending Congressional sessions at the Capitol, "a fine building of the Corinthian order, placed upon a noble and commanding eminence."
THERE'S A LOGIC TO DICKENS'S itinerary that is conceptual as well as geographic, for Latrobe's 1811 design is the complement of Haviland's: both buildings are concerned with the process of self-government. Gleaming, proud, the Capitol lifts its dome high over the landscape, the public symbol of the Republic's collective mind. From the Capitol, government power radiates outward into the city along the avenues of L'Enfant's Baroque plan. Inside the building, Latrobe's interiors (inspired, in part, by Piranesi) lay out the structure of reason within which the contentious process of self-government will unfold.
At Eastern State, the capitol's dark twin, abusers of liberty were compelled to bring themselves back into line. The sphere of this building is the private, psychological life of we, the people. Instead of radiating outward, the building presses in. It expresses its power in physical confinement, in the constant pressure it applied to the cells and their inhabitants, to the inner lives of individuals where democratic authority resides.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Study Planned Of Ecotourism

 BODY:
The Ecotourism Society, a consortium of conservation and travel professionals, is developing a program to evaluate the conservation practices of tour companies operating in fragile natural areas. The society is surveying consumers and tour operators to help prepare the final questionnaire it will send to organizers of tours. Questions will touch on an operator's recycling efforts, predeparture procedures, policies on energy consumption, a trip's impact on the local environment and economic practices in the communities visited. Questionnaires will be sent out next fall; first results are expected in the fall of 1994.
The two-year-old Ecotourism Society's membership includes tour operators, conservation professionals, academics, individuals and the tourism boards of several countries. The society focuses on travel to natural areas, the Amazon and Alaska, for example, and the impact of tourism 's impact on them. The society conducts workshops and seminars for developing countries and for universities. 
 Further information is available by sending a self-addressed stamped envelope to the Ecotourism Society, 801 Devon Place, Alexandria, Va. 22314.
