HEADLINE: Mitchell-Lamas Going on Sale

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
FOR King and Nadine Lenoir one of the pleasures of living in Fairfield Towers in Brooklyn is the afternoons spent relaxing on the balcony reading or dining at the umbrella table.
"We feel secure here," said Mrs. Lenoir, as she and her husband, a retired chauffeur, sat in the living room of their two-bedroom apartment. "The place is safe and clean and many of the people here are old friends. This is our home now." 
 The couple hope to own it soon. The Lenoirs, who sold a home in another part of Brooklyn, moved back to Fairfield Towers earlier this year. They have signed a contract to buy their apartment when the former Mitchell-Lama complex converts to a condominium later this year.
The Lenoirs and the 300 or so other residents who have also signed contracts to buy apartments in the complex see the conversion as an opportunity for their part of the American Dream -- owning their own home. But others, including some state housing officials and legislators as well as some Mitchell-Lama tenants, see the conversion of Fairfield Towers and other buildings in the system as an erosion of the city's dwindling supply of moderately priced rental housing.
Rents for Mitchell-Lama apartments are usually well below the cost of similar housing in neighborhoods where they have been built. Within the last few years, a total of 8,500 units have passed out of the Mitchell-Lama system as their landlords exercised their rights to pay off the subsidized mortgages used to build them and accept full property taxation. While some 160,000 Mitchell-Lama units in 400 projects remain in the system, the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal says 134 projects with 82,000 units are eligible for the buy-out by the end of this year. Currently, 15 state- and 4 city-sponsored Mitchell Lama complexes with more than 5,000 units are leaving the system. The agency estimates it would cost a minimum of $100,000 a unit to replace this housing at today's construction costs.
"The housing is important and was designed with a particular population in mind," said Angelo J. Aponte, the Commissioner of the D.H.C.R. and one of the state officials who has waged an unsuccessful campaign to change the laws that let Mitchell-Lama projects become private housing once they reach their 20th anniversary.
"THE government is not in the business to provide windfalls for people in Mitchell-Lama housing when they are converted to co-ops or condominiums," Commissioner Aponte said. "Government subsidies have allowed people to remain in their apartments paying affordable rents. When these units leave the system, there are no replacements."
Stuart Berelson, a principal in the company that owns Fairfield Towers and Mark Terrace, a former Mitchell-Lama complex in the Bronx now being converted, says he does not understand the opposition to the conversions or the reluctance of lenders to extend mortgages to potential buyers in converted buildings.
"Everyone from Jack Kemp, the Housing Secretary, on down," said Mr. Berelson, "says what we need is more opportunities for working-class people to own their own homes. These kinds of conversions provide just that. We are selling homes for an average of $55,000 in Fairfield Towers. Why should people who live in Mitchell-Lama be renters all their lives?"
For the last six years some state officials and housing advocates have lobbied the Legislature in support of measures that would extend the obligation of owners of Mitchell-Lama housing to remain in the system. Bills that would stretch the period for buy-outs from 20 to 35 years have been defeated in the last six legislative sessions.
The Mitchell-Lama housing program, created in 1955, owes its name to former State Senator MacNeil Mitchell, a Manhattan Republican, and former Assemblyman Alfred Lama, a Brooklyn Democrat, who sponsored the legislation that established it. Known officially as the Private Housing Finance Law, it offered private developers tax breaks and low-interest mortgage money as incentives to build housing for middle-income people. In exchange, they would limit profits to 6 percent and keep rents down. But the agreement also said that these constraints could be lifted after 20 years.
Under the program, the subsidies given developers were passed along to tenants in the form of moderate rents. To be admitted to a Mitchell-Lama building, the applicant's income cannot be higher than what has been established for the apartment. Rents and income limits, set by the D.H.C.R. for state-supervised buildings and by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development for city-supervised Mitchell-Lama housing, varry from building to building.
For a typical two-bedroom apartment, for example, with a monthly rent of $450, the maximum household income could probably be no higher than $43,000. If a tenant's income rises above the ceiling for his apartment, a surcharge, no higher than 50 percent of the base rent, is added to the rent.
The property tax benefit granted owners of Mitchell-Lama housing is calculated according to a complex formula, based on rental income and utility expenses, and varries widely from building to building, depending on individual financial factors.
Myron Holtz, deputy commissioner for Housing Management with D.H.C.R., said it would not be possible to put a figure on how much the typical Mitchell-Lama owner pays in property tax.
The Mitchell-Lama program has resulted in the construction of 139,000 units in 270 projects in New York City and 28,500 apartments in 152 developments in other parts of the state. Many complexes built in the state under the program in the 1960's and early 70's, when most went up, are now reaching their 20-year anniversaries.
Despite the dire predictions from critics, so far only six of the 22 Mitchell-Lama complexes that have been eligible have converted to owner-occupied residences. The rest have remained as rental buildings but subject to the restrictions of rent-stabilization rules. But Mr. Aponte and others say it is only the poor real estate market that has kept more owners from converting their buildings.
"These things are dictated by economic conditions," said Mr. Aponte. "When the market comes back, I think you can count on seeing more projects go to owner-occupied housing. This will be particularly true of Mitchell-Lama housing in areas where property values have gone up."
There is a benefit to leaving the system after 20 years, Mr. Aponte said, even for owners with no plans to covert to co-op or condominiums. "If a building is in an area that has appreciated," he said, "the equity over time has been building up. The owner can refinance the mortgage and pay back the Mitchell-Lama debt. With today's interest rates nearly as low as they were when some of these projects were built, the owner can take the cash out and then convert sometime in the future."
Rueben Glick, a principal of the Glick Organization, a leading development company that has participated in the Mitchell-Lama program, rejects the notion that there is any windfall for buyers or landlords in the conversions of these properties.
"In the plan," said Mr. Glick, whose Brightwater Towers complex was recently converted to a condominium, "the advantage to builders was that there would be limited profit of 6 percent returned on our equity. But that usually did not happen because rents were kept so low and expenses were high so that profits did not have to be limited because they did not reach 6 percent in most cases."
Mr. Glick said that the original expectation was that after 20 years in the program the owners would be able to take their buildings private and charge market-rate rents.
"But rent stabilization was introduced," he said, adding that converting the buildings to co-ops or condominiums gives owners a way to get a return on their investments. When former Mitchell-Lama rental buildings are converted to co-ops or condominiums, owners are free to ask whatever tenants will agree to and what the market allows.
There have been some small victories for D.H.C.R. in the effort to stem the flow of projects from the system. In July the New York Court of Appeals upheld the agency's efforts to delay a buy-out petition from two Bronx Mitchell-Lama complexes, Bronx Park East and Columbus Park. The court said that the owners were bound by a clause in their deeds from New York City restricting the use of the land they occupied for 40 years, which took precedence over the 20-year Mitchell-Lama restriction.
Housing officials say they do not beleive that these sorts of deed restrictions, which were individually negotiated between the city and the developers, apply to many Mitchell-Lama projects. The restrictions came to light as part of the routine review of documents and deeds in the privatization process.
Most of the housing built with Mitchell-Lama subsidies was rental buildings, but the program sponsored a handful of limited- equity co-ops as well. These also have the right to convert to completely private co-ops after 20 years. The first to do so was Contello I in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Three years ago the owners took their complex private.
The move to convert had nearly unanimous support among the residents. Out of 325 apartment owners in the two-building complex, 315 opted to buy. Five residents were given lifetime tenancy arrangements and the other five immediately sold their apartments to outside buyers. The initial investment for most residents in 1968, when the complex opened, was between $1,500 and $2,000.
MARTIN MARKMAN, an original buyer and president of the co-op board, said support for the privatization of the complex had always been fairly strong but had risen significantly a few years ago after residents heard that some housing officials were suggesting that homeless families be placed in the Mitchell-Lama buildings with room for them.
"It was an easy transition," said Mr. Markman. "We were self-managed for 25 years so we knew the building inside and out. There was a lot of support."
The owners refinanced the building's mortgage for $370,000 to pay off the underlying loan and start a co-op reserve fund. When the complex was converted to full-equity co-op the buyers did not have to make any more contributions because of the refinanced loan. With the impact of full taxation factored in, the charges went from $275 to $400 a month on average. Since the owners had already purchased their apartments, there was no additional cost to them. The 30 or so residents who moved out of their apartments soon after the conversion, Mr. Markman said, sold them for between $50,000 and $125,000.
Mr. Markman rejects the position that owners in Contello I voted themselves what amounted to an easy financial gain by taking their building private.
"This is not a place where rich people live," he said of the waterfront complex, which in its transition changed its name to The Waterview. "Many of the people who were among the first to move in are still here. We are working people who helped the city and state in that the housing created under Mitchell-Lama kept middle-income people from leaving the city."
Not all transitions have been as smooth. The conversion of Brightwater Towers has taken nearly six years. The condominium plan for the 734-apartment complex in Coney Island was declared effective in July. Part of the delay was due to several legal challenges by tenants to such things as the new rent increase schedule and surcharges when the complex became subject to the rules of rent stabilization before converting to a noneviction condominium.
And Mr. Berelson said that the conversion that he and his partner were trying to do in their buildings, Fairfield Towers in Brooklyn and Mark Terrace in the Bronx, had been hobbled by the reluctance of lenders to write mortgages for buyers in buildings where less than 50 to 60 percent of the units will be owner-occupied. In each project about 20 percent of the apartments have been sold. The owners, as a term of the conversion plan, agreed to arrange for bank financing for resident buyers.
"We had a commitment from a bank to do end loans for our tenant buyers when we started in 1989," said Mr. Berelson, "but the bank backed out when the market started to go down."
Brightwaters reached its 20th anniversary in 1985. The owner, the Glick Organization, paid off the mortgage the next year and undertook a conversion plan.
Paul Podhaizer, a longtime Brightwater Towers resident, is one tenant who will not join those insiders paying $33,000 to $75,000 for condominium apartments.
"I did not support the move out of Mitchell-Lama," said Mr. Podhaizer, a retired post office employee who for several years has served as chairman of the Brightwater tenants' association. "But I believe we were able to get in the end a pretty good deal for those who are buying."
The nonpurchasing tenants there are rent stabilized, as required by law, but Mr. Podhaizer does not feel this is enough protection for all tenants.
When buildings pass from Mitchell-Lama to rent stabilization, the base rents in the apartments are frozen at the last Michell-Lama rent, including any surcharge.
"The problem is that some of the residents had their rents set at a time when their incomes were higher than they are now," Mr. Podhaizer said. "Some people have been hurt by the loss of Mitchell-Lama status. It has been a hardship for people who have retired since the building left the system. If we had remained, some of them would have seen their rents drop to reflect their after-retirement incomes. The rent rules were fair up until that time."
ABOUT 100 tenants bought their apartments and the sponsors have made sales to about 130 outside buyers.
Mr. Podhaizer said the tenant negotiators were able to push the price of apartments to insiders from the original asking price of $30,000 a room down to about $10,800. A result was that apartments sold for $33,000 to $40,000 for one-bedroom units to $75,000 for three-bedroom apartments in the complex, which has water views, terraces and a swimming pool. Outside purchasers, Mr. Glick said, paid on average $110,000 for two-bedroom apartments.
With the prospects of convincing the Legislature to rewrite the Mitchell-Lama rules not promising, Mr. Aponte has taken another approach.
"We are examining other ways to keep owners in the system," he said, "by providing incentives."
As the buildings in Mitchell-Lama reach their 20th anniversary, many will be at the age where they will be due for extensive upgrading and repair work.
"One approach we are contemplating," Mr. Aponte said, "is the use of home-improvement repair loans or tax credits that will allow buildings to be upgraded and give the owners the tax break in exchange for a commitment to stay in the program for a certain period of time. It would probably be at least for the duration of the tax credit or loan."
"The best part," he continued, "is that the plan does not require legislative approval."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Brightwater Towers in Coney Island is becoming a condominium; Paul and Ruth Podhaizer are tenants who will remain renters. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Illegal Occupancy;
Lessons From a Campaign for 'Possession'

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
OVER 10 years the issues have changed, says Arthur Zabarkes, full-time pursuer of illegal occupants in the Manhattan apartments of Peter Sharp & Company. In the 80's it was nonprimary occupancy. People tried to cling to their occupancy rights to a regulated apartment, often in hope of cash from a co-op conversion sponsor eager to sell it vacant.
Now the main question is succession, or who has the right to inherit lease renewal rights when the tenant named on the lease moves out or dies. 
 "At 440 East 79th Street we've got 13 cases going and eight are on succession," Mr. Zabarkes said. "It's not the first generation of illegals but apartments inherited by sublessees."
Most owners might be prepared to make a deal with sublessees, offering them a primary lease. Not Peter Sharp & Company or its residential arm, Church Management.
Mr. Sharp, who died in April at the age of 61, was a major Manhattan real-estate investor who started buying well-located rentals in the late 60's specifically for the purpose of converting them to co-ops. His policy was to achieve conversion with a modest percentage of buyers and wait patiently for turnover to sell the inventory at vacancy values.
Under this noneviction approach, renters are entitled to lease renewals indefinitely after conversion. Most sponsors in the early days of conversion used eviction plans, which left nonbuyers with no lease-renewal rights. To convert, sponsors had to achieve purchase agreements from at least 35 percent of the tenants. Later the percentage became 50 percent and nearly all sponsors switched to noneviction plans.
But Mr. Sharp was adamant about gaining possession of an apartment -- the ability to control its use -- once he was legally entitled to it. He hired Mr. Zabarkes to see to that.
Beyond the legal precedents of lawsuits he set in motion, Mr. Zabarkes's 10-year experience is instructive on the behavior of many upper-middle-income renters. A significant minority of them apparently tried hard to exploit their advantageous position under rent regulation. Legal action was required to gain possession in 28 percent of the apartments that had a tenancy turnover. The lawsuits led to possession, or a sale to the tenant, in almost every case.
The 13 midtown buildings, with 1,684 apartments, were converted from 1972 to 1982. There were 1,218 renter-occupied apartments when Mr. Zabarkes was hired in 1982. One year later the decision was made to stop offering cash payments to tenants to leave.
Currently 528 apartments are still rent-regulated and 690 have been vacated by regulated tenants. In the 199 lawsuits that were filed to gain possession, 145 tenants dropped their occupancy claim before the case was adjudicated. Twenty-four of these tenants bought their apartments.
THERE were trials in 58 cases. Peter Sharp won 54 -- a dozen in Civil Court and the rest in reversals on appeal. Four cases were lost at both levels.
"People were either trying to capitalize on the subsidy of rent regulation by not giving up their apartment, or they were looking to extract some part of the value of the sale of a vacant apartment," Mr. Zabarkes said. "I looked at it as extortion."
Tenant lawyers have a different perspective. Kent Karlsson , of the Manhattan firm of Karlsson & Ng, said that when the market was strong, some owners would bring nonprimary-occupancy cases based on almost any evidence, hoping to make tenants spend money or confront sponsors to make a deal. In more than half the cases he took, tenant claims to primary residence were legitimate, he said.
"The state of regulation forces the tenant to make choices that put them on the edge of what's legal and what's illegal," said Samuel Himmelstein, whose firm, Himmelstein, McConnell & Gribben of Manhattan, represents tenants. In a large minority of cases brought to him the tenant's case was not strong and he advised them not to proceed, he said. Legal costs are a minimum of $1,500 and typically end up ranging from $3,000 to $8,000.
But in other cases, he said, the tenant had a just claim to primary occupancy and the owner had merely used evidence of the existence of another residence to bring a case. And some tenants leave their residence for what in their own minds is a temporary if indefinite period, and have been vulnerable to the powerful hand of a pursuing landlord, he said.
Under the law, renters have a right to a regulated apartment only if they use it as their primary residence, as verified, if challenged, by public documents and testimony on the frequency of their use.
Possession cases also arise over subleases. The tenant's right to sublease a regulated apartment is limited to two out of every four years and requires the owner's consent, which cannot be unreasonably withheld. In the current market, many owners are said to be taking a more relaxed view of subleasing.
A THIRD law involves roommates. Rent-regulated tenants are allowed to bring in an unrelated individual and dependent children of that individual, as long as the tenant remains in occupancy. If the tenant moves out, under state rules based on a Court of Appeal decision, the roommate can succeed to the apartment when the roommate and the tenant have had "an emotional and financially interdependent relationship" for at least two years. The regulations are under court challenge.
A common situation in Manhattan, said Robert M. Olshever, a lawyer in Manhasset, L.I., is that a tenant will have two apartments, live mainly in one but show up in the other as well. If challenged, the tenant can sometimes succeed in claiming either or both apartments as a prime residence, Mr. Olshever said.
The Peter Sharp cases have established two main legal principles, according to Sherwin Belkin, of Belkin Burden Wenig & Goldman, who represented the company. One is that the burden of proof in a right-to-succession case lies with the claimant. The other is that in nonprimary occupancy cases, documents alone -- showing where the tenant remains in occupancy. If the tenant moves out, under state rules based on a Court of Appeal decision, the roommate can succeed to the apartment when the roommate and the tenant have had "an emotional and financially interdependent relationship" for at least two years. The regulations are under court challenge.
A common situation in Manhattan, said Robert M. Olshever, a lawyer in Manhasset, L.I., is that a tenant will have two apartments, live mainly in one but show up in the other. If challenged, the tenant can sometimes succeed in claiming either or both as a prime residence, Mr. Olshever said.
The Peter Sharp cases have established two main legal principles, according to Sherwin Belkin, of Belkin Burden Wenig & Goldman, who represented the company. One is that the burden of proof in a right-to-succession case lies with the claimant; the other is that in nonprimary occupancy cases, documents alone -- voter registration, for example -- are not enough to assure the right to occupy. Tenants must be able to show they actually use the apartment.
ON the tenant side, cases have established that for sufficient cause, a tenant can sometimes keep an apartment he doesn't frequently occupy. But most of the key decision favorable to tenants involve procedural issues. If landlords are not careful to notify tenants at the right time that their lease won't be renewed and why, for example, they can lose their right to gain possession of an apartment for years.
Mr. Zabarkes, 49 years old, has practiced architecture, obtained a master's degree in urban planning from Columbia, worked toward a doctorate in economics specializing in property rights, and served as executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council and the Rent Stabilization Association. "I'm a market-oriented economist," he said.
He says his experience shows that in almost one of three turnovers in upper-middle-income rent-regulated apartments in Manhattan, the tenant tries to cling to his possession rights. Privately arranged sublets, without notification of the landlord, are the most prevalent current method of accomplishing this, he says.
The apartments owned by Peter Sharp or investors for whom he manages are in the following co-ops or condominiums: 270 West End Avenue; 35 East 38th Street; 44 Gramercy Park North; 75 East End Avenue; 80 Park Avenue; 15 West 72d Street; 141 East 55th Street; 203 East 72d Street; 325 East 79th Street; 325 West End Avenue; 440 East 79th Street; 444 East 52d Street, and 520 East 81st Street.
A snapshot of the rental situation in one building, the co-op at 15 West 72d Street, suggests why many rental tenants won't buy their own apartments.
The 37-story building is a neighbor to the Dakota, on Central Park West, and its higher floors have excellent views. It became a co-op in 1980. Of its 497 apartments, 140 are occupied by preconversion renters. Their income is estimated at above $100,000 an apartment, based on occupations and the number of income-earners per unit, but not on financial data.
There are 18 apartments on the floors 24 to 26. Seven are still occupied by regulated renters. Their rents are $830 a month for the sole one-bedroom, on the 25th floor, and $900 to $1,300 a month for six two-bedrooms, which have 1,000 to 1,300 square feet and in two cases a terrace.
The apartments in the current market have a vacancy rental value of $1,800 to $2,200 for the one-bedroom and $3,300 to $3,500 for the two-bedrooms, Mr. Zabarkes said.
A two-bedroom co-op on a high floor recently sold for $430,000. At that price monthly costs for a buyer who pays 25 percent in cash would be about $3,200 before tax deductions. That includes debt service on the loan and a monthly maintenance payment of $1,300 to the co-op. It looks steep to a renter paying $900 to $1,300 a month.
"Tenants don't want to double or triple their carry," Mr. Zabarkes said, "and they don't expect the appreciation in value that people did in the 80's. Also, they don't want to start assuming ownership responsibilities they're not used to."
Before he died, Mr. Sharp advised patience, since there is an overall turnover rate of 5 percent a year in the rentals. His successors are following that policy.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Oct. 14 Auction;
For Sale: Pieces of the City

 BODY:
While the region's economic woes have been a drag on property values here, land in New York City still comes pretty dear. But later this month the city will be selling pieces of New York for just a few thousand dollars.
On Oct. 14, 130 city-owned buildings and parcels will be put up for sale at a public auction where bidding for a few parcels will start as low as $1,000. The cheapest lots are not, mind you, building sites, just slivers of land. One parcel, for example, is a 10-by-96-foot Staten Island lot on South Railroad Avenue between Bache and Jacques Avenues. But officials with the Department of General Services, the agency holding the auction, say these slivers often are bought for their value as parking spaces or private gardens. 
 G.S.A. is to conduct a pre-auction seminar tomorrow at 6 P.M. in the auditorium of 125 Worth Street. The auction itself is to be held in the auditorium of One Police Plaza at Chambers and Centre Streets behind the Municipal Building. Bidding is to start at 9 A.M. For more information call 212 566-8914.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Renaissance Revival on West 79th;
School Buildings for Sale

 BODY:
For nearly a century, the 1895 Renaissance Revival buildings at 168-170 West 79th Street in Manhattan filled roles that emphasized the teaching of religion and languages, first as the Notre Dame School, then as the Fleming School. The final lessons, however, have been in economics.
The Fleming School, which for two decades had been at 10 and 35 East 62d Street, bought the buildings from the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for $5.8 million in 1989 at the beginning of the real estate recession and then spent more than $4 million on renovations and construction of a new gymnasium linking the buildings. Last November, though, the school filed for bankruptcy. 
 Now, the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan-based real estate brokerage firm retained by the United States Bankruptcy Court, is orchestrating a sealed-bid sale of the 36,000-square-foot property.
The deadline for bids is Oct. 16, with a minimum bid of $4.5 million. For additional information, call (212) 355-3550. "It's most suitable for use as a school or nonprofit institution and is also prime for residential development," said George van der Ploeg, vice president of the Corcoran Group.

HEADLINE: A Second-Hand Store Upgrades to First Class

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
PAUL H. CRANFORD browsed through a few of the dozens of men's suits on a rack and liked what he saw. "Here's an Yves Saint Laurent," he said. "And a Faberge, hand-tailored in Paris. And a Hickey-Freeman! All very vogue."
He also liked the prices because they should appeal to shoppers. One suit was marked $15, another $20; the highest priced, $30. "We try to get 10 percent of the original prices," he said. 
 Mr. Cranford could be a retailer trying desperately to survive during a deep and long recession but the uniform gives him away. He is a Salvation Army captain and the store he is visiting is the latest of 11 under his jurisdiction. It opened this summer in West Hartford and, at 30,000 square feet, is said to be the biggest thrift store in New England.
It is an establishment of soft lighting and wide aisles, with clothing in neat racks and coordinated by color and size, a plethora of changing rooms and well-trained and polite salespeople.
 
A New Retailing Approach
 Anyone who has ever wandered into a Salvation Army thift store in the past, perhaps looking around to see if any acquaintances were in the vicinity, knows that the stores featured second-hand clothing hanging indiscriminately on plain pipe racks or tossed into giant bins. If there was any motif, it was casual disarray. Most of the stores were found in the poorer sections of cities, sometimes tucked away in dreary brick buildings with Dumpsters on the side.
Now, an oversize thrift has shown up in suburban West Hartford, renowned for its high per capita income and excellent school system. Granted, the site of the thrift, in the Shield Street Plaza off New Britain Avenue, is in a less affluent part of town near the Hartford line but it is still West Hartford.
What's going on here? Is the Salvation Army moving into mainstream retailing? Is the old dreary image of urban thrift stores giving way to a new, brighter one in suburia? The answers to both, Captain Cranford said, is yes.
The reason for the new approach, he said, is simple: the Salvation Army needs more money to carry out increasingly more expensive programs that range from housing the homeless to rehabilitating drug and alcohol abusers.
Because the Salvation Army is a religious organization, it is cut off from funds available to many other social service organizations, Captain Crawford said. In Hartford, for example, he and his wife, Deborah, supervise the Salvation Army Adult Rehabilitation Center for drug addicts and alcoholics. It can handle 112 people on a long-term basis and accepts people of any or no religious affiliation as well as atheists.
The annual budget for the rehabilitation center has escalated to $5.2 million a year but the center receives no money from the United Way, Captain Cranford said, and only $173,000 from the state. Faced with raising nearly all of the money himself, he is creating new and bigger thrift stores for the revenue they can generate. Of the 11 stores he supervises, he personally started four -- in Mansfield, Bristol, Newington and the giant in West Hartford -- in the two years he has been in Connecticut. He expects to open another in a Windsor shopping center this month.
The reason for moving into suburbia is a simple one: the money is there.
"It's a good market," Captain Cranford said."I need people with money to shop at our stores, and they live there." But he believes the move to bigger and better stores in suburbia also benefits the poorer people of the cities that the Salvation Army has traditionally served since the movement was started in the East End of London in 1865 as a Christian organization with a semi-military structure.
"People from the cities can shop with dignity in these stores," Captain Cranford said. "They can find what they want easily, the right size, the right color. And no one knows that some of them are assisted by Salvation Army vouchers for their purchases. This is meeting their needs with dignity."
 
Business Is Booming
 It is also evidently meeting the needs of many suburbanites. Business is booming at the newer and bigger thrifts, according to Captain Cranford, dramatically answering the question of whether people who live in big homes with manicured lawns and follow the stock market will shop in a store that carries a big THRIFT sign.
"Just check our parking lot on a weekend," Captain Cranford invited. "You'll see cars that barely make it to the lot but you'll also see Beamers and Saabs and Mercedes. People in West Hartford are smart shoppers."
In many cases, Captain Cranford believes that residents of wealthier communities do not have as much money to spare as is generally believed. "Their costs are up, the cost of educating their kids is up, and they're worried about jobs, too. I think they appreciate us."
The trend to larger stores, patterned after chain discount stores, is not confined to Connecticut or New England. It is a national pattern. Before Captain Cranford came to Connecticut, he opened new stores in the Jersey City, N.J., and Columbus, Ohio, metropolitan areas.
 
Stigma Fades
 Sometimes he is amused at the reaction of some people who do not quite know what to expect when they enter the West Hartford store. "They go 'Wow, this is O.K. I can deal with this.' The stigma of shopping at a thrift store is gone."
All the second-hand clothing is donated, which means those stores start off with a definite advantage over regular merchandisers. Do they resent the Army's intrusion on their turf?
Captain Cranford says no. "They like us as neighbors; we bring people in," he said. The Shield Street Plaza in West Hartford also contains such stores as Caldor and Radio Shack, a Waldbaum supermarket and a McDonald's. The large building the thrift store occupies had been vacant for months after a large lumber store fell prey to the recession and moved out. But the shopping center's look of abandonment turned to one of prosperity again, thanks to the addition of a store that deals in recycled clothing.
 
'The Original Recyclers'
 "We're the original recyclers," said Captain Cranford of his organization. "Without us, a lot of clothing would wind up in landfills. We don't waste anything. Clothes we get that are too worn or torn we bale up and send to third world countries."
He paused for a moment. "We also recycle people," he said. "All this goes for giving people a new chance at life at our rehabilitation center.
"And we add to the economy. The workers in our stores mostly come off welfare. We train them and they work hard. They want to work. This year, we've added 25 new jobs. That means 25 people are not dependent on welfare. And the state gets revenue from the sales tax."
The Salvation Army officer, a youthful, muscular man of 42, brings a personal expertise to the new business of retailing. He was involved in business, including retailing, before he joined the Army in 1981.
Although his parents and a grandmother were Salvation Army officers, he said he had no plans to join when he was growing up. After graduation from a small college in Maine, he said he first went to work for a clothing chain, then sold insurance and prospered in that, and finally became an executive for a major company.
In 1981, at age 31, he had a wife, three young children, the luxuries money could buy and a big house in Woodbury. He had attained the life style he thought he wanted.
But he was unhappy, he said, and it was reflected in a growing addiction to alcohol. "I'd get out of work and go to a bar and drink," he said. Something was missing. That year, he and Deborah enrolled at the Salvation Army seminary in Suffern, N.Y., to become ministers. There have been no regrets. "I love this job," Paul Cranford said.

HEADLINE: Assembly to Examine Youth Agency

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AN investigation by the State Division of Youth and Family Services into the events surrounding the injury of a 2-year-old Edison boy has triggered a wide-ranging legislative examination of the division itself.
Assemblyman Jeff Warsh, Republican of Edison, said the case in his district had been the final straw that led him to call for hearings to look into the division's investigation procedures and the training of caseworkers. He had already been concerned, he said, over "serious problems with the division in communities throughout the state." 
 The first of three scheduled hearings before the Senior Citizens and Social Services Committee has been set for Wednesday, he said.
The Division of Youth and Family Services is responsible for investigating allegations of child abuse and neglect and for the monitoring of families or placement of children in foster homes when such allegations are substantiated. The division has 46,000 active cases, handled by 1,065 caseworkers.
The division has been the object of mounting criticism from some medical professionals, lawyers, parents and child-advocacy groups. They charge that the division and its caseworkers are too often arrogant and relentless in their efforts to obtain evidence of abuse. Critics also say that division caseworkers are often poorly trained, using coercion and other improper techniques during interviews. The division's practice of acting on anonymous accusations is also widely criticized.
Officials and supporters of the agency, however, say it functions well, particularly in light of its limited resources and recent cuts in staff.
"D.Y.F.S. performs tasks that are very difficult and extremely sensitive," said Nicholas R. Scalera, director of the division. He said the agency's responsibilities often "require us to invade the privacy of the family, and when you do that you are going to run into opposition, anger, and a great number of accusations."
Assemblyman Warsh, formerly a lawyer with the State Department of Human Services, called for "ongoing and continuous" legislative oversight of the division. Though the Legislature has looked at criticisms of the agency in the past, he said, "officials in the division knew the legislators would go away, and they did."
The case that led Mr. Warsh to seek the hearings concerned Rabbi Bernhard Rosenberg; his wife, Charlene, and their son, Ari. Last July, Ari was injured when he fell off a trundel bed while playing at home. Eventually, after X-rays were taken, his injury was diagnosed as a spiral fracture of the femur, and he underwent an operation at a local hospital.
The injury is often associated with cases of child abuse, and apparently, Rabbi Rosenberg said, one of the hospital's doctors called the state agency.
"One hour after the operation," the rabbi said, "D.Y.F.S. is in there interrogating me and my wife." In addition to a representative of the division, he said, an investigator from the Monmouth County Prosecutor's office appeared in his son's hospital room, "flashing his badge."
Though the couple agreed to answer the investigators' questions, Rabbi Rosenberg said, they balked when the division investigator demanded that additional X-rays be taken to determine if the boy had sustained any other fractures. The rabbi said he did not want the child subjected to the additional radiation. The investigators persisted.
"The end result was that they said they could keep the baby in the hospital as long as they wanted," Rabbi Rosenberg said. The investigators finally relented when the couple's lawyer insisted that they produce a court order for the additional X-rays.
In addition to being arrogant and insensitive, Rabbi Rosenberg said, the division investigator refused to call the family's pediatrician to obtain Ari's medical history, refused to answer any questions regarding the grounds for the suspicion of abuse, and subjected the couple's 8-year old daughter to a telephone interrogation that left her crying.
In the end, the division closed the case after finding that Ari's injury was accidental.
"With D.Y.F.S., you're guilty until proven innocent," Rabbi Rosenberg said.
Division officials say that confidentiality requirements prohibit them from commenting on the Rosenberg case or any other specific case. But speaking in general terms, Mr. Scalera said that division practices and procedures "are not grounded in some willy-nilly list that we just come up with." They are based, he said, "on statutory authority, which is the fundamental building block of everything we do."
Under state law, he said, any person who has reasonable cause to believe that a child has been abused is required to report that to the authorities. And the division is required by law to investigate every incident of suspected abuse that is reported to it.
 
Anonymous Accusations
 Under current division procedures, anonymous accusations of abuse are pursued by the division. Some experts have criticized the policy.
"If somebody makes a false accusation, they should be open to having legal action taken against them," said Bruce Eden, vice president of the New Jersey Council for Children's Rights, a Wayne-based advocacy group for divorced parents who do not have custody of their children. Anonymous reporting, Mr. Eden said, makes it impossible to track down a false accuser.
In 1991, the division logged 53,750 reports of suspected abuse, Mr. Scalera said, and about 9,400 were anonymous. But about 1,800 of the anonymous reports were ultimately substantiated, he said.
"A one-out-of-five hit rate is a very high risk," he said. "You can't look the other way with that kind of number."
Over all, Mr. Scalera said, 19,489 of the original 53,750 reports of abuse in 1991 were substantiated.
 
'One of the Greatest Abominations'
 But Dr. Richard A. Gardner, a Cresskill psychiatrist and a clinical professor of child psychiatry at the Columbia University Medical School, said the "substantiated" label was sometimes wrong, the result of improper techniques used by division investigators.
"We're living through one of the greatest abominations in the history of this country," Dr. Gardner said, alluding to the way sexual abuse allegations are typically investigated.
In many division investigations, he said, the investigators are "coercive, they're overzealous, and they start off with the assumption that sex abuse took place." Investigators typically ask children leading questions that taint their recollection of events, he said, and in some cases even create false memories of events that may have never occurred.
"The vast majority of people working for D.Y.F.S. are untrained, many are incompetent, many are zealots, and the vast majority of them are doing incompetent evaluations," Dr. Gardner said.
 
Caseworkers Supported
 But Dr. Martin A. Finkel, a medical consultant to the division and a faculty member of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Camden, said the agency's caseworkers were doing a good job, given their heavy workloads. The average caseworker handles about 42 open cases, the division says.
"It's easy to be critical of D.Y.F.S.," Dr. Finkel said. "But it's a difficult job being a caseworker and making these decisions. I would say that most of the caseworkers I've come in contact with are very skilled."
Alisha A. Griffin, an assistant administrator for the division, said that in addition to having a bachelor's degree and one year's experience in social work, every field worker must complete a 15-day orientation program that includes training in investigation, cultural sensitivity and family sensitivity.
In addition, she said, during the first year on the job, workers must take a set of courses geared to specific areas of their assignment. For example, a caseworker would have to take a four-day course in child sex abuse investigation before being allowed to handle a sex abuse case. Moreover, caseworkers are assigned a "buddy" during the first month they handle cases, and are given only a few cases each week as they build their caseload.
 
'Law Needs to Be Changed'
 Too often, some critics charge, the training does not work. Herb Klitzner, a North Bergen lawyer who represented a couple anonymously accused of drug abuse, a charge that was never substantiated, called the division "the Spanish Inquisition of child welfare."
He said that a division investigator began an interview with the couple's 9-year-old son by telling him that his father was suspected of having a drug problem.
"The law needs to be changed to require any interview with a child to be taped from beginning to end," Mr. Klitzner said.
Division officials said that while they were open to suggestions that would improve the investigatory process, audio taping might not be the answer. "It has a chilling effect," said Raymond Wolfinger, supervisor of the division's office of legal and regulatory liaisons. "People would not be as forthcoming in interviews if there was a tape running."
Some experts say that division policies encourage investigators to engage in relentless searches for instances of abuse to the point of intentionally excluding witnesses who may provide contrary evidence.
 
Battle for Girl's Custody
 "In New Jersey we have an agency that is unbridled and out of control," said Dr. Lawrence D. Spiegel, a Morristown psychologist who was himself the target of a division investigation in 1983. "In many instances they are doing more damage to children and families than they are doing good."
During a bitter battle for custody of his 2 1/2-year-old daughter, Dr. Spiegel's wife filed an accusation with the division that he had sexually abused the child.
Without interviewing him, and without having the child examined by a doctor to determine if there was evidence of abuse, Dr. Spiegel said, the division notified the Morris County Prosecutor's office of the accusation.
"I was arrested and charged with first-degree aggravated sexual assault the next day," said Dr. Spiegel, who said he felt compelled to resign his position as chairman of the psychology department at Morris County Community College. It was three years before he was allowed to see his daughter again -- after a jury trial in which he was acquitted of all charges.
"In the course of three years D.Y.F.S. never, ever requested to talk to me," he said.
Gary M. Burrus, a social work supervisor with the division, said that many of the criticisms leveled against the division were warranted.
Field workers, he said, "make very bad mistakes all the time." He added: "These folks are guided by a philosophy that is so paranoic, that is so completely driven by fear of making a mistake, that consequently, a lot of people are getting labeled as child abusers who are not child abusers at all."
 
Set of Checks and Balances
 Mr. Scalera, however, said such charges "couldn't be further from the truth." He said that an intricate set of checks and balances -- from an independent oversight committee that monitors the division's actions to the state court system -- insures the fairness of the agency's investigations.
"We are trying to fulfill our mission under very difficult economic conditions," Mr. Scalera said. For the third year in a row, the division is losing employees as a result of layoffs caused by budget cuts. And while nearly all those layoffs have been among management personnel, he said, the reduced staffing inevitably puts greater pressure on the district offices.
Caseworkers have a reputation for being villains, said Dr. Richard Klein, a forensic psychologist from Caldwell who is a consultant to the division, but the reputation is false. "As a matter of fact," he said, "they save lives on a routine basis and the public has no idea."

HEADLINE: Service Clubs Rallying To Reverse Their Slide

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
ONCE upon a time, in municipalities all over New Jersey, clubs made up of doctors, lawyers, bankers and other community leaders met once a week for lunch. The groups, each a small local branch of a large national organization, offered members a chance to socialize, conduct a little private business and organize community service projects. They called themselves Rotarians, Kiwanis or Lions, and they proudly erected signs at city or town limits proclaiming their existence.
The signs still greet newcomers to New Jersey communities, but the letters are often faded. The clubs behind the signs now find themselves fighting against the tide of social change; their most crucial project is survival. 
 The nation's five largest service clubs, Rotary, Lions, Kiwanis, Jaycees and Optimists, still claim thousands of New Jersey members. The state groups range in size from the Rotary Club (9,579 members and 249 clubs) to the Optimists (1,600 members and 45 clubs). But leaders of all five clubs say membership has declined over the last five years.
The clubs are not taking this sitting down. They are recruiting at public events, revising their social projects and volunteer work to keep up with the times and replacing the traditional lunch with morning and evening sessions. Membership restrictions as to race, religion, sex or ethnic background have been dropped, and only the Jaycees restrict membership by age. (Members must be between 25 and 40.)
The most frequently cited reason for the service clubs' decline is that familiar specter, the economy. The recession in white-collar jobs is so deep that it has touched even middle-age service-club stalwarts.
"When people are unemployed or worried about their jobs, they don't worry about club meetings," said Austin Johnson, a district governor of the Kiwanis Club, who also noted that two of this year's Kiwanis district governors had suddenly found themselves unemployed. For some people in actual or anticipated financial jeopardy, the cost of dues plus once-a-week meals has seemed too high.
Service club officers offer other reasons for the membership decline. In families where both parents work outside the home, family time may take precedence over community service. Many small towns have become bedroom communities, and the commuters who inhabit them sometimes have less of an interest in a local service club than do longtime residents. Even commuters who want to join the Rotary Club or the Jaycees have trouble attending regular meetings, particularly luncheons.
Another factor that works against club membership is what Dr. Lionel Tiger, a Rutgers anthropology professor, called "a lack of residential stability." A person joining the Kiwanis or Optimists in 1955, Dr. Tiger said, could count on being socially and professionally involved with the same people in 1965. Increased mobility has changed that assumption, reducing the value of club membership. Dr. Tiger said that young professionals might also feel that old-line clubs were "out of synch with the times."
Robert Wagner, a 52-year-old executive in Marlton who is district governor of the Lions Club, sees another, less tangible reason for the club's decline. Describing the 1980's as "the yuppie period," he said the prevailing hedonism of that decade affected the willingness of young professionals to become involved in community activities.
The traditional, nonfraternal service organizations are determined, however, not to go dinosaur-like down the road to extinction. The change in the times of club meetings, for example, has been dramatic. Only 6 of the 300 New Jersey Lions Clubs still hold noon meetings.
Honey Morganstern, who like her father, Jack Rosen, is a Rotarian from Fair Lawn, founded a "spinoff" Rotary Club in that borough. It meets for breakfast, which ends on time so commuters can catch their trains. Ms. Morganstern says her group has attracted new, younger members, at least partly because of the morning meetings.
Breakfast meetings, said Austin Johnson of the Kiwanis Club, benefit both time- and cost-conscious members by keeping meal prices down. Some retired Kiwanians even meet for coffee and doughnuts to lower expenses further.
The major service clubs were founded in the Middle West in the first two decades of the 20th century. Because membership was restricted to community leaders, local Rotarians or Lions also had local clout, Dr. Tiger said. Established service clubs, he added, had a role in the social structuring of small communities.
In some cities and towns, service club membership still carries a certain amount of prestige, Mr. Johnson said. "It depends on the community and the size of the club," said the 36-year veteran Kiwanian, a lawyer from Caldwell.
 
Admission of Women
 In the last five years, women have made the biggest change in the service club scene. The Jaycees changed their national bylaws to allow women after a 1984 United States Supreme Court ruling requiring them to do so. In 1987 a similar decision against Rotary International forced the opening of that club's ranks to women.
A fraternal ripple effect followed, and later that same year the Lions, Kiwanis and Optimists eliminated their rules barring female members.
In New Jersey, the Jaycees (formerly known as the Junior Chambers of Commerce) lead other clubs in the percentage of women admitted to their ranks. Alisa Hodawanec, president of the New Jersey Jaycees, estimates that her organization is 20 to 30 percent female, with 500 to 700 women. The Lions, Rotary, Kiwanis and Optimists range from 8 to 10 percent female members statewide.
In many clubs, women have moved into leadership roles. Phyllis Dejesse of Freehold, who owns a health-care advertising company, is about to become state governor of the Optimist Club; she will be the first woman to hold such a post in the United States. About 13 percent of the Rotary Clubs in the state have female presidents.
 
Making Connections
 Women have joined for the same reason that men traditionally do: business and social connections. Ms. Morganstern, who owns a travel agency with her father, said she had no desire to join Rotary when women were first admitted. But she booked Rotary conventions through her travel agency and eventually found that "I really had to be a Rotarian for business reasons."
Service club leaders say that minority membership is also increasing. Mr. Wagner, the Lions Club district governor, said members of various minorities made up about 20 percent of the New Jersey Lions, with a large number of Hispanic members in northern areas of the state.
Leo Chernev of Newark, state governor of the Optimist Club, noted that a new club in Paterson was largely composed of Jamaican immigrants. Mr. Johnson said that minority membership had risen in the Kiwanis Club, which had a black district governor in 1987-1988.
The clubs are making a special effort to recruit new members. Mr. Wagner said the Lions Club used the networking skills of its members to seek out potential Lions where they work: in banks, insurance offices and other businesses. These recruiters arrange to make presentations at businesses, or sit down with individuals to discuss the organization and invite the person to a meeting.
 
'Get Out the Vote' Effort
 The Jaycees hope to attract new members by increasing their visibility. Ms. Hodawanec said local Jaycees clubs had sponsored "get out the vote" efforts before elections as well as candidates' debates. The Jaycees are also setting up booths at community events.
Locally and nationally, all five clubs have made efforts to update their service projects. In the last few years, Rotary, Lions and Optimists have joined the antidrug crusade, underwriting the costs of established school-based drug education programs like "Just Say No," Dare and Quest. Local schools are provided with antidrug curriculums, sometimes augmented by outside speakers. (In the case of Dare, the speakers are local police officers.)
A new variation on the antidrug theme is the Optimists' "Get Real" program against steroid abuse. Ms. Dejesse is responsible for the initiative, which is providing schools with literature and speakers.
While New Jersey service clubs still concentrate on traditional children's charities, supporting essay contests, summer camps and projects for the handicapped, some have turned in new directions.
Mr. Chernev said one Optimist Club in southern New Jersey ran its own soccer league, with members providing coaching as well as financial support to 500 to 600 children. The Kiwanis Clubs' two-year-old "Young Children Priority One" program encourages prenatal care and maternal education, sometimes working through hospitals.
 
Focus on Children
 Both Mr. Chernev and Mr. Johnson of the Kiwanis Club say they think that their clubs' focus on children will attract parents of young families to their ranks.
Some clubs have increased their involvement in "hands on" projects. Some members of the Secaucus Rotary Club, for example, are in training to become literacy volunteers. Ms. Morganstern's Fair Lawn Rotary Club helped build a park this summer, and this month will "adopt" another, taking responsibility for painting, cleaning and some maintenance. The Eatontown Lions Club built a home ramp for a handicapped local resident and rebuilt a halfway house for women.
Though networking is traditional in the service clubs, some groups are exploring new ways of doing it. The Jaycees publish Biznet, a statewide list of Jaycees members cross-referenced by address and occupation.
The Secaucus Rotary Club will meet with neighboring Rotary Clubs to hold a "business card exchange" this month. As part of this exchange, businesses in the area will be charged a nominal fee to send representatives who will, it is hoped, mingle with the participating Rotarians, making contacts and exchanging business cards.
In the long run, Mr. Wagner of the Lions said, he expects that membership will increase as New Jersey and the rest of the country become further removed from the attitudes of the 80's. He is convinced that refugees from 80's-style selfishness will eventually find that the route to altruism runs straight to the time-honored service organizations.

HEADLINE: 2 Old Foes Square Off Again in Bid for Congress

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
THE battlefield is new -- a Congressional district once contained entirely within Westchester, which now, after redistricting, also includes a thin strip of the Bronx as well as most of central Queens -- but the contestants are familiar, certainly to each other, and so are most of the issues. 
 The 18th Congressional District, as it is now designated, was the 20th Congressional District when Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican-Conservative, won it in 1986 with a narrow, 51 percent majority over Oren J. Teicher, a top aide to Richard L. Ottinger, who was retiring. Mr. DioGuardi, claiming to be the first certified public accountant ever elected to Congress, captured a seat long considered safe for Democrats.
 
Defeated by Nita Lowey in 1988
 It was his first bid for elected office and he won re-election in 1986, beating Bella S. Abzug, a transplanted Manhattan resident seeking a return to Congress. But in 1988, in a stunning upset, he lost the seat to another novice, Nita Lowey, who was making her first bid for elected office.
Mr. DioGuardi sat out the 1990 campaign, when Ms. Lowey won re-election easily over Glenn Bellippo with a 63 percent margin, but now the New Rochelle resident has decided to challenge Ms. Lowey in what appears to be a grudge match. He says the new district favors him and could reverse the 1988 results, when he lost by fewer than 6,000 votes.
Their earlier face-off was bitterly contested, and among the nation's most expensive Congressional races, with each candidate spending more than $1 million. The rematch has the earmarks of another costly race. Mr. DioGuardi, who spent $1.6 million in 1988, said last week that "it will cost us another $1 million dollars; we've already raised $350,000."
The race, he says, is among the most closely watched Congressional contests in the country and a "top target" in New York State for the National Republican Congressional Committee. "I expect to get the maximum assistance, $60,000, from the N.R.C.C. -- $10,000 in cash and $50,000 in services." He said he has "probably the best opportunity of anybody to take out an incumbent."
 
Pinning His Hopes on Redistricting
 One reason for Mr. DioGuardi's confidence, he said, is that redistricting removed 83,000 voters from the new district, reducing the percentage of voters representing minority groups. In 1988 Ms. Lowey beat Mr. DioGuardi by 56 percent to 44 percent in that part of the old 20th Congressional District that is no longer in the new 18th Congressional District, but in the part of the old 20th remaining in the new 18th, Mr. DioGuardi got 51 percent.
He says the top issue is economics, jobs and taxes. Ms. Lowey "is the quintessential tax and spend liberal, even more so than Barney Sanders from Vermont, the only Socialist elected to Congress. He has a 95 percent favorable rating with the Americans for Democratic Action, while they give Nita Lowey 100 percent.
"She's walking around describing herself as a moderate. That's what this election is all about -- to expose who she is and to alert the people to who I am. I'm the only practicing certified public accountant elected in 215 years who understands the process of capital formation.
"I wrote a book, 'Unaccountable Congress: It Doesn't Add Up,' that's been out only three months," Mr. DioGuardi said, "and I've been on 76 radio talk shows." He speaks of the national debt as being tallied on a "Mickey Mouse cash basis of accounting" and says "the Congressional voting card is the most expensive credit card in the world; they just put off payment until the next generation."
If this sounds familiar, it is. Mr. DioGuardi made much of his accounting skills in earlier campaigns, but this time he is also emphasizing his criticism of Ms. Lowey for voting against the death penalty "for drug kingpins and warlords if they commit murder."
He said that on the death penalty issue, "she is just like Governor Cuomo, who trained her. He's her mentor; she worked for him." Ms. Lowey was employed in the New York Department of State for 12 years, the last two as Assistant Secretary of State.
Mr. DioGuardi has also criticized Ms. Lowey's position on "obscenity and pornography," saying she supports controversial programs financed by the National Endowment for the Arts, and he has rebuked her for voting against sending troops to the Persian Gulf.
Ms. Lowey said Mr. DioGuardi is "good on rhetoric but is a failed former Congressman who cannot talk about his accomplishments because he has none."
She said she has voted for economic-growth incentives, has helped bring jobs to Mount Vernon (a proposed transportation hub), Yonkers (manufacturing subway cars), New Rochelle (relocating the Navy Motion Picture Service there) and White Plains (a new Federal courthouse). She said she helped prepare a report that calls for cutting $60 billion to $85 billion in wasteful Government spending.
 
Anti-Crime Bill Supported
 She said she has been active in improving educational assistance, especially in Head Start, child care and other early-childhood areas. She supports a comprehensive anti-crime bill designated to put more police officers on the streets, establish boot camps for first-time youthful offenders and help keep drugs out of schools.
Mr. DioGuardi takes credit for helping to establish a chief financial officer in the Federal Government and for "setting up the Long Island Sound Caucus and the Hudson River Caucus, which made my opponent's role easy; she uses those platforms well, as she should, but they were my ideas."
These and other issues may dominate a series of debates between the candidates scheduled to begin in mid-October. So far, the prospective debates have been overshadowed by accusations from both sides about illegal campaign tactics in the 1988 race and by a dispute over responsibility for the cost to the town of Harrison of a site for a new regional post office.
Mr. DioGuardi, who was campaigning against Ms. Lowey two months before he officially entered the race last January, included her use of "illegally unreported campaign funds" in radio ads at that time. She has, in turn, recalled similar accusations against the former Congressman, in his case probably instrumental in his losing the election.
 
Committee Paid $3,500 Penalty
 In July 1991, the Lowey campaign committee agreed to pay a $3,500 civil penalty for failing to disclose that Ms. Lowey lent the campaign $250,000 during her 1988 race. The loan, which came in four installments, was made during the final days of the race.
Federal election law requires that during the last days of a campaign, committees must disclose contributions of more than $1,000 within 48 hours of the contribution. Mr. DioGuardi has often stated that "the Congresswoman bought her seat by hiding the last-minute loans from the voters."
The other incident exploded on the election scene two weeks before polling day with a report that Joseph Crabtree, a New Rochelle auto dealer and member of the DioGuardi campaign finance committee, had apparently violated Federal laws by reimbursing employees with "bonuses" equal to contributions they had made to the DioGuardi campaign.
The candidate denied any involvement, but Mr. Crabtree told a Federal judge in May 1989 that Mr. DioGuardi had masterminded the scheme. Mr. DioGuardi has since repeated his denials. He said in a recent interview that he has a completely new campaign staff for this year's race.
Last Thursday, Dennis Mehiel, the County Democratic chairman, said that the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee was writing that day to the Federal Election Commission demanding that its investigation of Mr. DioGuardi's alleged involvement in the Crabtree incident "be brought to a conclusion."
Mr. Mehiel, at a news conference, said the commission "may have held its investigation in abeyance pending the outcome" of the Justice Department inquiry that resulted in Mr. Crabtree's conviction. United States Attorney Otto Obermaier on Aug. 26 said Mr. DioGuardi was "neither a subject nor a target of an investigation" by his office.
 
Agreement Negotiated
 In the post office dispute, Mr. DioGuardi has accused Ms. Lowey of accepting $1,000 in campaign contributions from Lowell Schulman, a developer whose company sold land in Harrison to the Postal Service for $21 million. The land is for a regional postal plant.
Mr. Schulman was one of 29 members on a committee named by Ms. Lowey in 1989 to find an alternative location to the Postal Service's preferred site at the County Airport in Purchase. The committee recommended a site in Yonkers, which postal authorities rejected, picking the Schulman property instead.
Ms. Lowey negotiated an agreement last winter with the former Postmaster General, Anthony M. Frank, in which the Postal Service was to pay the town $400,000 in partial compensation for the estimated $1.7 million in taxes it would no longer receive from the Schulman property once it became tax exempt as Government property.
Mr. DioGuardi said Ms. Lowey had made a bad deal -- a one-time payment of $400,000 for the loss "in perpetuity" of the much larger tax payments -- and failed to monitor the agreement properly. The Postal Service recently decided to retract its offer to pay the $400,000 because the town had "rejected" the amount and because the Postal Service could not afford it.
Delays by Harrison officials in acknowledging the deal evidently was taken by postal authorities as rejection of it. Meanwhile, Ms. Lowey and Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, a member of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Treasury, Postal Service and General Government, joined in getting approval for an amendment to an appropriations bill "directing" the post office to pay Harrison the promised $400,000.

HEADLINE: 'Who Prospers?'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In its preoccupation with the chapter on blacks, Jason DeParle's review of my book "Who Prospers? How Cultural Values Shape Economic and Political Success" (Aug. 16) misses the basic point not only of the book but also of the chapter on blacks. 
 "Who Prospers?" seeks to demonstrate (1) that, among the numerous factors that influence why some nations and ethnic groups do better than others, culture is, in the long run, the most important, indeed influencing some of the other factors (for example, politics and policies); and (2) that culture changes, often as a consequence of politics.
The point of the chapter on blacks is not to do a comprehensive analysis of the ghetto problem, which Mr. DeParle correctly implies would itself require a book, but to examine culture as an alternative to the other broad explanation -- racism and discrimination -- of the ghetto tragedy. This is why the chapter focuses on the two-thirds of America's blacks who have made it into the middle class; black immigrants from the Caribbean (for example, Colin Powell's parents), who do better than white Americans; and the relevance of the tragic histories of Haiti and Liberia.
The force and persistence of culture are underscored by the poverty of Appalachia, which Mr. DeParle attributes to "the conquering coal industry, not the laboring miners trapped in company towns."
As the historian David Hackett Fischer has documented in "Albion's Seed," the roots of Appalachian poverty trace back to precolonial north Britain, whence came most of the "backcountry" settlers. They brought with them traditions of highly inequitable income distribution, little concern with education and suppression of entrepreneurial activity, which, coupled with the isolation that so often accompanies poverty, lie behind Appalachia's distress.
 
LAWRENCE E. HARRISON
Vineyard Haven, Mass.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Has the Dollar, At Long Last, Hit Bottom?

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse

 BODY:
Since 1985, the dollar has gone from Schwarzenegger-like to 98-pound weakling. Last week it slid to record lows against the Japanese yen and flirted with new lows against the German mark.
The question now is whether the once-almighty dollar will become a slightly heftier 108-pound weakling or an 88-pound pipsqueak.
The dollar could continue its slide if the Federal Reserve cuts rates further to pep up the torpid economy, as many economists predict. A rate cut would hurt the dollar by encouraging money managers to buy marks or yen as they seek higher-yielding investments abroad. 
 Administration officials insist that the dollar is so weak because Germany's interest rates are so high, not because American economic growth is so anemic. This assertion seems to ring a tad hollow, because when the dollar rose during Europe's currency crisis, White House officials said this was a sign of America's economic strength.
David D. Hale, chief economist for the Kemper Financial Companies, said the dollar "has finally scraped bottom" against the mark because of the belief that German interest rates have peaked. He added that the dollar "will get weaker against the yen" because Japan's trade surplus continues to burgeon.
Paul Chertkow, director of global currency research for UBS Phillips & Drew in London, was not as optimistic. "The dollar is still very vulnerable on the downside against the German mark," he said. "There is a good chance the dollar will test new lows, primarily because of continued German intransigence toward cutting rates."
He said the dollar, which closed at 1.409 marks on Friday, would soon test the 1.40 barrier, and if it fell through that, it could sink past the record low of 1.386 and reach 1.35.
Most economists forecast that the dollar will rebound against the mark next year. "I think the dollar could close the year at 1.50, and in the first half of next year it could go up rapidly to 1.70," Mr. Chertkow said. "Next year we will see the Germans cut their rates," and "that will occur when, we believe, the U.S. economy will be recovering more solidly."
John P. Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said that as a result of a lackluster American economy and the likelihood of further rate cuts, "the upward move of the dollar against the mark should be relatively modest." He sees the dollar clawing back to 1.60 marks, at most, next year.
But Mr. Lipsky sees the yen continuing its rise against the dollar as the yen remains the preferred haven during Europe's currency crisis. The yen looks so attractive because Japan's economy should soon pick up steam thanks to an immense public works program.
"The yen should be aided by the upturn in Japanese economic growth and the prospect that Japan has finished easing its monetary policy," Mr. Lipsky said. He predicted that the dollar, which closed Friday at 119.35 yen, would drop "to 115 yen certainly or perhaps even less."

And the German mark," the number of marks one dollar will buy, Sept. 21-Oct. 2, 1992.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
For Novice Shareholders 'Adam Smith' in Russian

BYLINE: By F. DUAYNE DRAFFEN

 BODY:
Goodness knows, the Russians need all the help they can get as they ease into the fast lane of free enterprise. And who better to lend a hand than Adam Smith? Of course, this "Adam Smith" is the nom de television of George J. W. Goodman, the host of the Public Broadcasting Service business program.
"In one big leap, the Russians have passed the United States in terms of individual shareholders," Mr. Goodman said. "Think about that." He was referring to the state vouchers that can be used to buy stock that every Russian citizen started receiving on Thursday. 
 "Adam Smith," which has been seen in Russia since 1990, started its ninth season in this country on Thursday with a segment videotaped in Moscow. The segment dealt with the continuing, and in some cases deepening, problems that President Boris Yeltsin faces as he makes radical economic reforms.
Mr. Goodman, 62 years old, is also author and has written several books about economics and finance, including "The Roaring 80's" and "The Money Game."
He said the Russians' favorite program topics were American inventors and patents and "anything about women starting up a business."
He said the program was shown with a translator doing a voice-over narration of the topic being discussed. While this works fine in most cases, Mr. Goodman said, a show on the economics of baseball apparently proved a bit too much.
"Now I am of course speaking perfect English," Mr. Goodman recalled the translator telling him when they later met. "But you must realize that in Russia serfdom ended in 1863. After 1917, the Communists said you could not even employ someone as a chauffeur, maid or other servant. Yet in your show you said Boston sold two men as outfielders to Chicago. How can this be?"
In Russia, the program can be seen on Channel 1 of the All Union network, with a potential viewership of 100 million. Imagine the fund-raising possibilities.
