HEADLINE: All About/Franchising;
Hamburgers or Home Decorating? Businesses That Sell

BYLINE: By VERONICA BYRD

 BODY:
Though the harsh economic climate has battered many major corporations, franchisors, the companies that license their names and expertise to entrepreneurs eager for a lucrative piece of the American Dream, have as a group seen increasing gains in both ownership and sales.
In fact, part of that lift has come because of the recession, as companies cut back by dismissing workers with severance pay and offering sometimes-generous buyout plans. Many former executives, managers and employees have turned to buying franchises. 
 For an initial investment and yearly royalty payments, franchise buyers can often get training, business name recognition, start-up financing and even advertising help.
This weekend, more than 25,000 people curious about joining those ranks are expected at the American Franchise Association show at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. There, some 120 companies have set up booths to display their versions of how easy it can be to prosper as a franchisee.
But a darker side of the industry is emerging. Saying that they were misled by slick or unscrupulous companies, franchisees are increasingly calling for new Federal regulations. Many of these business owners say franchisors hype the potential for profits, pressure them to sign one-sided "take it or leave it" 50-page contracts and provide little help afterward if their operations run into trouble.
The International Franchise Association, a Washington-based trade group that represents more than 800 franchisors, dismisses such charges as the complaints of a small number of people who probably do not have what it takes to run a business.
 
Starting Up
The Industry Gains During Hard Times
 The total number of franchises in the United States grew 4 percent, to 542,496 in 1991, from 521,215 in 1990, according to Francorp Inc., a franchise development and consulting firm. That is expected to rise nearly 15 percent in 1992, based on the rosy projections of a study this year by the I.F.A. John Reynolds, executive vice president of the association, acknowledged that in light of last year's meager rise, the expected increase "is very optimistic." He added, that "it doesn't mean that every single franchise will do this well."
Continued growth is expected in print shops, restaurants, retail shops and car servicing outlets. New kinds of franchises expected to surge include Kitchen Tune Up, a remodeling business, and United Coupon, a small-business coupon service. And businesses targeting the booming children's market, like USA Baby, a furniture store, and those aimed at older people, like Reading Glasses to Go, should also do well, consultants say.
"The franchise industry thrives during tough economic times," said Michael H. Baum, executive vice president of Francorp, which is based in Olympia Fields, Ill., outside Chicago. "When recessions hit, a lot of people who are out of work start their own businesses. They often don't have a lot of capital, and franchising is the best way to go into business without a lot of capital."
Some franchises, like a simple home decorating or commercial-cleaning operation, can be started for as little as $5,000, but the average investment, including equipment and other initial costs, is about $140,000. And the privilege of owning a top established restaurant or hotel can cost $1 million or more.
In addition to a one-time franchise fees, franchisees are required to pay yearly royalty costs, typically 2 percent to 8 percent of gross sales.
Franchises "come with a lot of the same risks as any small business," said William B. Cherkasky, president of the International Franchise Association. "But because of the many support services provided there is a far greater chance of success than starting a small business on your own."
 
The Competition
Sometimes, Dreams End Up Going Sour
 Even franchise buyers who thought they had done careful research have ended up losing their homes and cars when their business soured.
Especially vulnerable are franchises built on an idea that is easily duplicated. Owners of The Country's Best Yogurt, also called TCBY, found themselves in fierce competition for customers as the franchisor, based in Little Rock, allowed too many shops to be established near one other. At the same time, two or three other yogurt franchises were vying for the same spaces in shopping malls and business districts around the nation.
"Frozen yogurt is a seasonal product with not a lot of upscale potential," said Mr. Baum of Francorp. "Other more diversified snack food companies began offering the same product and taking their business away."
Consultants advise obtaining a copy of the franchise disclosure circular, one of the few documents the Federal Trade Commission requires of all franchisors. The circulars include a detailed description of the business, start-up costs and applicable fees.
But when it comes to dealing with a franchisor, it is wise to remember that "franchising is simply a relationship, a method of distribution," said Edward Kushell, president of the Franchise Consulting Group. "One of the most important things to learn is how to manage that relationship."
Some chains seem to have as many stores close each year as they have new ones opening. But figures from an I.F.A. study found more than 95 percent of companies opened in the last five years were still operating.
Mr. Reynolds of the I.F.A. did note that 15 percent of the franchises that opened in the last five years no longer had the original owner.
"That means that something happened to those people," he said.
 
Making the Choice
Shopping Around For a Business
 Many of the newest franchise owners are former corporate executives who were laid off or became disgruntled with corporate life.
Donald Boyle opened his Alphagraphics Printshops of the Future store in March 1991 in Stamford, Conn., with a $340,000 start-up investment. He decided he could use his managerial and sales skills -- gained from more than 25 years in retailing -- to break the company's record for first-year sales.
Mr. Boyle, a former executive vice president with Lord & Taylor, and former chairman of Hahnes, a department store, accomplished that and more. His store had almost $500,000 in sales the first year, he said.
Begun in 1970 in Tucson, Ariz., the Alphagraphics chain now has 325 stores in 14 countries.
Wayne Hale and his wife, Carolyn, of Crossville, Tenn., spent more than a year extensively researching restaurant franchises before buying a Krystal Kwik hamburger outlet. The fast-food restaurants have dual drive-through lanes and outside seating only.
In addition to researching food costs, employee training and legal fees, Mr. Hale parked near restaurants and counted the cars in their lots. "That gave me a pretty good idea of the kind of traffic the restaurants were getting on an average day," he said.
The Hales opened their first Krystal Kwik in Crossville, about 80 miles west of Knoxville, in September 1990, becoming the first Krystal Company franchisee. They have just opened a second one in Cookeville, about 40 miles east of the first restaurant.
Mr. Hale, who had owned a medical equipment company, said 18-hour days, seven days a week were typical for the first six months. But he is optimistic that his Krystal Kwiks, where a hamburger costs 43 cents, will be a big draw for families. "People are very conscious of their spending," he said. But at Krystal, you can feed an entire family with $10 and have change left over."
 
 
OPEN-DOOR RECRUITING
 When Renee C. Greenleaf and her family began the search for a franchise, their biggest concern was finding one "that would provide a needed service to the community, rather than one that was a luxury," she said.
Ms. Greenleaf, the owner and operator of a Mail Boxes Etc., which provides postal and business services in downtown Newark, said she; her mother, Marguerita Calloway, the company's vice president, and her brother, Albert Calloway, who is president, were attracted to franchising because of the training and skills they could take advantage of.
"An independent person would have to stumble over and take the hard knocks for themselves," Ms. Greenleaf said. "But the franchisors are there to provide the necessary training and ongoing support."
The Calloways, who are black, are among a small, but growing, percentage of minorities in franchising.
Franchisors say they are increasing their efforts to recruit more women and minorities into the industry by aggressive recruiting, advertising and special programs.
In April, the International Franchise Association created the Alliance for Minority Opportunities in Franchising with the goal of increasing the number of opportunities for women and minorities to own franchises and to expand the use of minority vendor and supplier companies.
About 14,000 -- or 2.5 percent -- of the 550,000 United States franchises are minority-owned, according to the Department of Commerce's Minority Business Development Agency in Washington. In a study of 366 franchise companies, the International Franchise Association reported 9.5 percent were owned by minorites.
Reaching out to women and minorites "is not a social responsiblity but a business imperative," said Ron Harrison, the chairman of the I.F.A.'s Minorities and Women in Franchising Committee.
The committee is encouraging major franchisors like McDonald's, Baskin-Robbins and 7-Eleven to develop programs and become more involved in their local communities.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1705 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 27 - October 2

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Standing on a Platform of 'Fair-Share Sacrifices'
 

In a voting system reminiscent of the one that elected Nikita Khrushchev -- all votes were counted as "yes" -- Ross Perot's volunteers (and others who happened to call his 800 line) overwhelmingly urged him to run. Mr. Perot accepted their draft in a no-nonsense speech. Building on his first foray into Presidential politics, when he was criticized for being long on color ("I'll clean out the barn") but short on specifics, Mr. Perot re-emerged with a credible economic platform filled with statistics. But unlike the economic plans of President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, Mr. Perot's platform puts shrinking the Federal deficit ahead of economic growth. His plan requires no lip-reading, either. He would raise taxes on the wealthy (to 33 percent, from 31 percent), raise taxes on gasoline and tax the Social Security benefits of well-heeled retirees. The plan also calls for spending cuts of 15 percent for programs other than debt costs and entitlement programs like Medicare. Mr. Perot said implementing the plan would require "fair-share sacrifices." He will begin getting his message out this week with $1 million worth of network air time.

More Jobs, or Fewer Seekers?
 
When the Labor Department reported that unemployment fell in September to 7.5 percent from 7.6 percent in August, President Bush said it was "very good news" and meant a full recovery was under way. But Gov. Bill Clinton had a different take on the last unemployment report before the election. It showed Mr. Bush's policies would keep unemployment high "with no end in sight," he said. To economists, the report was inconclusive. Unemployment did go down, but only because "fewer people were out there looking for jobs," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities Inc. With job creation sluggish, they had few reasons to pound the pavement.

A Slip in the Leading Indicators
 
The Government divines the nation's economic future with the aid of the index of leading economic indicators. The index, which consists of 11 components including stock market prices and the length of the work week, forecasts economic growth three to nine months hence. Right now it's saying the end of the year will be anything but rosy. The index slipped 0.2 percent in August, the Commerce Department said, the second decline in the last three months. "The economy is really showing very few signs of life," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.

Consumers' Dampened Spirits
 
American consumers, peering out at the world, seem to be losing their nerve. The Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell to 56.4 in September from 59 the month before. It was the third decline in a row for the index, which registered a chipper 72.6 in June and a positively buoyant 100 in 1985. Most troubling for the economy is that consumers, who account for two thirds of all economic activity, don't spend when they feel pessimistic. What's troubling them? Jobs. A "sluggish economy and weak job market are continuing to dampen consumer spirits," said Fabian Linden, who directs the survey.

Manufacturing Takes a Hit
 
It was some of the worst economic news for the manufacturing sector this year. The index of the National Association of Purchasing Managers slipped to 49 percent last month, from 53.7 percent in August. A reading below 50 indicates economic contraction, above 50 indicates expansion. The index is considered a reliable gauge of growth in manufacturing. "Although the overall economy continued to expand in September, the manufacturing sector ground to a halt," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee.

The Senate's New Tax Package
 
After four days of raucous debate, the Senate finally came up with a new tax package. Trouble is, it still must be harmonized with a House measure that is very different. And because the Senate bill makes permanent a phase out of exemptions for Americans wealthy enough to be profiled by Robin Leach, it has caught the ire of the White House. The bill also increases tax incentives to businesses that invest in impoverished city neighborhoods, gives a tax credit to first-time home buyers (the House version does not) and expands the use of individual retirement accounts to nearly all taxpayers, allowing them to deduct up to $2,000 annually. And it includes a capital gains write-off on long-term investments made by start-up companies. Is the measure dead in the water? "We'll have to get closer to the provisions of the House bill before there's enactment," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Stretch of Bad Road
 
Germany's Porsche A.G. makes sports cars that are pretty, pricey and fast. That's a tough market to be in right now. Thanks to the weak global economy, Porsche's sales fell 15 percent in the year ended July 31, to $1.9 billion. Last week, Porsche said it would eliminate 1,000 jobs and restructure itself. With these and other cuts, Porsche will have eliminated 20 percent of its work force, bringing it to 6,200 by mid-1993. Though Porsche has a deal with Daimler Benz to assemble the ultra-luxurious Mercedes 500E, that car's sales are also falling. Analysts wonder if Porsche can continue to exist on its own. "Maybe Daimler or some other auto maker will take a stake in Porsche," said Peter Fliegel, who follows the company for Berwein Wertpapierhandels-und Boersenmakler, a brokerage in Munich.

An International Food Fight

Forget trade frictions over cars. A war now seems to be heating up between Japan and the United States over sushi. To get around Japan's ban on importing American rice, Sushi Boy, an Osaka restaurant chain, opened a sushi plant in Escondido, Calif. The sushi was placed on a ball of rice, frozen and flown to Japan. Sushi Boy wanted to import two million pieces of the sushi a year. It reasoned that Tokyo customs officials would treat the sushi as processed fish -- not rice. Wrong! The first shipment was impounded last week by Japanese customs police and remains in an airport freezer until the Government can decide what to do with it.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Back to Basics for Sears
 
Last week Edward A. Brennan, chairman of Sears Roebuck & Company, announced that Sears would sell its securities business, the Discover credit card, its real estate operations and up to 20 percent of its Allstate insurance subsidiary. "We are responsive to our shareholders," Mr. Brennan said, indicating that some of the proceeds of the sale would be disbursed among owners of Sears stock. Selling off a slice of Allstate is expected to bring in $1 billion to $2 billion alone. Mr. Brennan also indicated that Sears would go back to basics and focus on its retailing operations. When Mr. Brennan took over in 1985, Sears was the nation's No. 1 retailer; since then it has slipped to No. 3, behind Wal-Mart and Kmart. But while Wall Street appreciated Sears's new direction -- its stock rose $3.375 on the news to $44.75 and finished the week at $43 -- retailing specialists think Sears will really have to struggle to regain market share. "They've got to perform now," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail analyst. "There can be no more excuses."

Big Blue's Blues
 
Not so long ago, the International Business Machines Corporation was corporate America's equivalent of a cover girl. Big Blue seemed to do everything right. But more recently, the world's No. 1 computer company hasn't been looking so good. Its core business, mainframe computers, is depressed; Big Blue is taking a $415 million charge on those operations this year. And while I.B.M. is still the world's largest PC manufacturer, that business has been hammered, while its bid to grab control of the market for PC operating-system software has fizzled out. Last week, I.B.M. said a total of 40,000 jobs would be eliminated this year through buyouts. The cutbacks would reduce earnings in 1992 by $2.1 billion, offset in large measure by $1.9 billion from accounting changes. Since 1985, I.B.M. has reduced its work force by 25 percent. With the cuts, Big Blue "will achieve an improved balance between assets and current business needs," said John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman. Investors were not convinced. I.B.M.'s stock fell $1.75 on the news, to $81, and finished the week at $78.50.

Magic Is Back
 
Magic Johnson may have the virus that causes AIDS, but that hasn't slowed him down: His ball-handling wizardry led the American Olympic team to victory last summer in Barcelona. Last week, Magic -- who dazzled the fans and filled the stadium when he played -- rejoined the Los Angeles Lakers, part time. He will play 50 to 60 games next season. To bring him back, the Lakers gave their star a raise. While his old contract was worth $2.5 million a year, plus a $600,000 bonus, the new one will be worth $14.6 million -- about $240,000 a game, if he plays all 60. But does he still have the stuff? "I have more muscles than I ever dreamed of," he said.

Planes From the Great Satan?
 
Remember when Iranian officials called America the Great Satan? Last week, state-owned Iran Air placed an order with the Boeing Company -- the Great Satan's leading exporter -- for 16 737 jetliners worth $900 million. But there is little chance the sale will go through: The State Department bans aircraft sales to Iran (the Iran-Contra scandal notwithstanding). If the sale is stopped, "Iran Air is going to look elsewhere," said Thomas J. Whalen of Condon & Forsyth, a Washington law firm that represents Iran Air. Elsewhere probably means Europe's Airbus Industrie consortium -- Boeing's chief rival.

The heads of Delta, American Airlines, United Airlines and Federal Express wrote to Transportation Secretary Andrew H. Card Jr. asking him to stop British Airways from investing in USAir Group Inc. The carriers said the arrangement violates laws limiting foreign ownership of American carriers and that an existing agreement grants American carriers limited access to the British market.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3110 words

HEADLINE: An Oasis Rich in Shady Operators

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, Fla.

 BODY:
Joseph Del Raso leads the way through a gleaming marble lobby into the spanking new suite that housed College Bound, a chain of scholastic-test coaching centers that was a stock market favorite before collapsing this year.
Now the suite is deserted, half the furniture gone to satisfy debts, with dollies and packing crates ready to carry out the rest. Peach-colored afternoon sunlight slants through the dust as Mr. Del Raso walks to a pile of company documents. 
 "Here," he says, stooping to retrieve one of the brochures. "Have a piece of total fiction." The document is College Bound's last annual report and audit. It depicts a healthy and expanding company, a far cry from the insolvent business Mr. Del Raso found when he was named bankruptcy trustee in April. In June, the company agreed to settle the Securities and Exchange Commission's civil charges that it had inflated its revenues and profits. Its founders, George and Janet Ronkin, remain under investigation; they insist they have done nothing wrong.
College Bound is not unique in Boca Raton. Indeed, in the past year, this expensive enclave has experienced the financial equivalent of a cancer cluster. Six local corporations, including College Bound, have fallen under S.E.C. investigation; a seventh has been shut down and its chairman arrested and accused of running a Ponzi scheme. Dozens of other companies based here are little more than corporate shells created by boiler-room brokers, or financially flimsy companies whose chief products seem to be their own stock and news releases boasting of their prospects.
Regulators policing the penny stock market refer to the area's unsavory brokers as the Boca Bunch, and state investigators have dubbed the area "the Maggot Mile." The United States Attorney's satellite office next door in West Palm Beach, once a three-person operation, now keeps 14 attorneys busy.
 
'Very Appealing Location'
 "Once it was North Miami that had become notorious, then Fort Lauderdale," said Caroline Heck, executive assistant United States Attorney in Miami. "Now, Boca is a very appealing location."
Charles A. Harper, the regional administrator for the Miami office of the S.E.C., agrees. "We've definitely seen problems moving up the coast."
To be sure, some nationally known companies are based here. W. R. Grace moved its headquarters here last year. Most major Wall Street firms have large offices here, and many local investment managers, newsletter publishers and institutional brokerage firms have solid reputations.
"We don't have the luxury of picking and choosing our residents, but these scandals certainly haven't hurt us," said M. J. Arts, president of the Greater Boca Raton Chamber of Commerce. "Our unemployment rate is consistently under 5 percent. We've announced more new companies locating here in the past year than some entire states. Boca Raton, in the corporate world, is a very attractive address."
But there is another aspect to Boca Raton's business life. A computer-assisted search of S.E.C. filings by The New York Times found that besides College Bound, a number of local corporations are being investigated by the S.E.C.:
* Cascade International, a retailing chain that owned the Diana Shops and Allison's Place stores and was forced into bankruptcy last year. The collapse came after its chairman and chief executive, Victor Incendy, vanished in November, just before he was to answer accusations, later found true, that Cascade's financial statements were wildly exaggerated.
* Great Oaks Financial, an insolvent if once impressive insurance company, and its related finance company, the FHC Acceptance Corporation. The S.E.C. is examining the company's books for inadequate disclosures or fraudulent statements about its financial strength.
* Ringside International, an inactive boxing promotion company revived over the summer by stock promoters from Texas. The S.E.C. has been asked by a Congressional committee to examine why trading in Ringside resumed when the company had not filed financial statements for nearly two years.
* Dycom Industries, which supplies equipment to power utilities and is being examined for "possible financial misstatements," according to company documents.
* A.B.E. Industrial Holdings, a flimsy financial holding company that said it is cooperating with an S.E.C. examination of how it came to acquire an apparently fraudulent mortgage on a French vineyard.
Other members of the local financial community, while not under a regulatory microscope, clearly have blindsided their investors. For example, the Met Capital Corporation, a furniture holding company, released an overdue 1991 audit in July. The audit, besides revising the 1990 figures, disclosed two bankruptcies the officers had left off their corporate resumes and revealed that insiders had been selling the company's stock for three years without disclosing the sales as required by law. Company executives attributed the belated disclosures to bad legal advice.
According to court records in Miami, the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which has since emerged as one of the largest bank frauds in history, opened a branch here just to cater to Munther Ismael Bilbeisi, a Jordanian businessman and Boca Raton resident indicted in August 1991 on tax evasion charges stemming from a coffee-smuggling scheme financed by B.C.C.I. Mr. Bilbeisi left Boca a fugitive.
Cary Maultasch, who testified under a grant of immunity against Michael R. Milken in 1990, still lives here, as do other former Wall Street lions from the scandals of the 1980's, including Martin A. Siegel, who pleaded guilty to insider trading charges involving Ivan F. Boesky.
Flim-flam has long been a problem in Florida, of course. Its well-to-do but often nave elderly residents are a magnet for the fast-buck crowd. Drug money courses through hidden channels in the economy, and a transient population has learned not to look too closely at the people across the street -- or across the bargaining table, for that matter.
But why has Boca Raton become home to so many dubious companies and habitual swindlers?
It is unarguably a beautiful town -- a low, lush beachfront community where candy-pink Mediterranean shops and homes mix with glittery Miami-modern office buildings on spacious shaded grounds. Fountains splash in plazas, decorator-perfect cafes attract tanned and unhurried visitors, and a car with more than a few years on its paint job is a rare sight. About 65,000 people -- one quarter of them 65 or older -- live within Boca's 27 square miles of beach, fairways and Bermuda grass.
Conventional explanations for Boca Raton's problems -- lax enforcement and lazy media watchdogs -- do not seem to apply. Florida's securities regulators at both the state and Federal levels get high marks from their peers. And the area's newspapers and business magazines are tireless in their exposure of local con artists.
 
Historical Roots
 A more likely contributing factor, said Mr. Harper, is rooted deep in Boca's own history, from the land-boom swindles of the 1920's to the boiler-room operations of the 1980's. Whenever regulators have shut down an illegal operation, its employees and the professional advisers typically have remained in the community, available to unsavory entrepreneurs.
And while Boca has all the glitz of the wealthy communities to the north -- Palm Beach and West Palm Beach -- those communities are more established and perhaps less open to a newcomer on the make, Ms. Heck said. Lawyers also note that Florida's laws permit bankrupt ex-millionaires to protect a handsome amount of assets from creditors.
Moreover, a construction boom in the past decade produced a glut of beautiful office buildings. A suite sure to impress visitors can be leased for a song -- or, for a while at least, for nothing. College Bound's lease on its palatial space in the Crocker Center included an 18-month "rent holiday," Mr. Del Raso said. And the region's wealthy population is migrating from the crowded communities to the south into the newer, more secure communities along the Broward-Palm Beach County line. "Crime tends to follow that population," Ms. Heck said.
But the most common explanations echo the view of Mr. Del Raso. "Boca is different," he said. "If you have money here, you can be 'in' real fast, no questions asked. It's like 'The Great Gatsby' in modern times."
 
A Popular Figure
 Jay Gatsby, meet Thomas R. Mullens.
Mr. Mullens, 47 years old, was until recently chairman of Omni Capital Group Ltd., a private financial firm (unrelated to any of 17 publicly traded companies using the "Omni" name) that occupied an expensive building on Glades Road. An avid golfer, he was a popular figure on Boca's several courses and a member of the Chamber of Commerce. At 7:30 every Friday morning, he steered his Rolls Royce to Bruno's Hair Salon for a trim and a manicure. A $50 tip was routine, said Bruno Dominijanni, the owner.
Mr. Dominijanni was sufficiently impressed to invest $45,000 with Mr. Mullens. So were other wealthy members of the Boca golf crowd. So were more than 100 retired couples on Florida's west coast.
On the morning of April 24, agents of the S.E.C. and the Federal Bureau of Investigation shut down Omni's headquarters. Mr. Mullens was subsequently arrested and, on June 26, was indicted on charges of operating a Ponzi scheme that may cost investors at least $10 million.
Mr. Mullens's criminal history includes a 1976 conviction for mail fraud arising from an earlier Ponzi scheme and a 1983 conviction for customs fraud. He is in jail near Tallahassee, awaiting trial on the new fraud charges. His lawyer, Van Stillman of Boca Raton, refused to permit Mr. Mullens to comment on the case, noting only that a plea of "not guilty" had been entered.
"One of my customers called me at home that Monday," said Mr. Dominijanni in his salon. "He said: 'Bruno, we've lost all our money. The guy is all phony. It's not real.' "
Nor is Mr. Mullens an isolated case. Other members of the community include Lionel Reifler and Leonard Tucker, confessed swindlers who have begun new careers as Government witnesses against former associates. Both are awaiting sentencing on their most recent convictions.
Mr. Reifler's criminal record began in 1970, when he pleaded guilty of mail fraud and conspiracy. He subsequently pleaded guilty to other finance-related fraud charges (in 1975, 1989 and 1990) in a flim-flam career that stretched from New York to Louisiana, and from the stock market to the savings and loan industry. In 1985, according to S.E.C. court filings, he and two associates met at St. Andrews Country Club here and hatched the Hughes Capital Corporation, a fraud the S.E.C. shut down in 1987.
Lenny Tucker, in his heyday, headed the Boca Raton operation of F. D. Roberts & Company, a penny-stock brokerage that promoted a host of other dubious companies, including Goldcor, a phony enterprise that boasted of being able to extract gold from Costa Rican beach sand. Investors, hooked by hyperbole and high-pressure telephone sales tactics typical of boiler-room operations, lost at least $50 million when Goldcor collapsed in 1988. F. D. Roberts shut its doors in 1989, amid a Federal criminal fraud investigation that has produced guilty pleas from Mr. Tucker and nearly three dozen others, many of them Boca residents. Mr. Tucker, who also agreed to give the Government his stake in his mansion here and his Rolls Royce, is cooperating with the investigation.
"He was the driving force behind the firm's Boca office," said Alain Leibman, an assistant United States attorney in Newark, where the case is being handled. The firm's headquarters was in Paramus, N.J., but most of its brokers were in Boca Raton, Mr. Leibman said. "They were mostly waiters and waitresses, kids just out of college looking for jobs."
Mr. Tucker's lawyer in New York, Barry Slotnick, declined to permit his client to be interviewed.
 
An Embarrassing Gift?
 Other traces of Boca Raton's dark side appear around town. The school of business at Florida Atlantic University is the home of the Stuart-James Research Center -- named for, and partly financed by, the Stuart-James Company, a penny-stock brokerage that closed its doors in 1990 after paying $1.9 million to settle civil charges of price gouging.
The center, set up five years ago, is a worthy program that provides computer laboratories to students and Census data to local businesses. Has the Stuart-James name become an embarrassment? "I've never been asked that before," said Professor Paul Guglielmino, the center's director. "I don't think it is an issue at all. From my perspective, we accepted the gift in good faith and did very positive things with it."
A local legend in Boca is Joel S. Nadel, whose troubles with securities regulators date back more than 20 years. Mr. Nadel, who lives in a house the size of a small office building in the St. Andrews Country Club development, is best-known among regulators as the publisher of more than a dozen market newsletters, including one that claimed to be the product of a secret investing society in Liechtenstein. Investors who followed his newsletters' tips frequently found themselves holding worthless shares. Postal authorities know him as the former operator of direct-mail "sweepstakes" programs that allegedly promised far more than they delivered.
In April 1991, the Postal Service obtained an unusual magistrate's order freezing nearly $7 million of Mr. Nadel's assets, based on an affidavit by postal authorities charging that the sweepstakes violated Federal mail-fraud and money-laundering statutes. No charges have been filed, and lawyers for Mr. Nadel have filed motions to have the order lifted.
Ira L. Sorkin, the New York lawyer representing Mr. Nadel, confirmed that settlement talks have been held but said he could not predict when the matter would be resolved. He said neither he nor his client would comment further about any aspect of Mr. Nadel's business life. In June, without denying or admitting guilt, Mr. Nadel paid $100,000 to settle a two-year-old S.E.C. complaint. The agency had charged that he violated securities laws by failing to tell his newsletter subscribers that several penny-stock promoters, since convicted of fraud, had paid him to tout their dubious companies. One of the stocks that figured in the complaint was Goldcor, the gold-extraction company that collapsed.
 
'We Don't See Them'
 "You have to understand," said Mr. Arts at the chamber, "that these people just don't surface here: We don't see them, we don't deal with them, they're not involved in the community, they don't contribute. We don't even know they're here. It just doesn't affect us."
But some members of the financial community here are growing quietly worried about the recent scandals. Local newspapers have run articles analyzing the impact of the cases on Boca Raton's image. "Everyone I know talks about it, and it's a real concern," said Mr. Del Raso, the court-appointed trustee for College Bound. Several other local financial executives said privately that they too were worried. One willing to say so publicly was Robert A. Anderson, first vice president of Southeast Research Partners, an institutional brokerage and research firm.
"Our own credibility is harder to defend every day because of this," Mr. Anderson said. "We're about at the point where you'd feel better with another address." He turned to a colleague. "What do you say -- West Palm Beach?"
 
 
INVESTIGATIONS AND THE BOTTOM LINE
 His investment newsletters attracted complaints from the Securities and Exchange Commission. His direct-mail "sweepstakes" was investigated by the Postal Service. What's next for Joel S. Nadel, a well-known entrepreneur in Boca Raton?
Well, the roster of Boca-based companies includes Quantum Ventures Group, a Nasdaq-listed corporation that has lost money for four of five years and trades for about $1 a share. Quantum controls certain rights to the Bernard Haldane employment counseling system. Mr. Nadel is chairman of Quantum's three-man board.
The address Quantum lists with the S.E.C. is a handsome North Military Trail complex where nothing called Quantum Ventures was listed on the building directory. The caretaker had no idea where it was, nor had the Federal Express driver who regularly makes deliveries there.
A secretary at the telephone number listed with the S.E.C. explained that the address is the law office of a Quantum director, Jeffrey G. Klein. Mr. Klein previously served as president of an investment newsletter company named by the S.E.C. in a complaint it filed against Mr. Nadel in 1990. That complaint, which charged that Mr. Nadel failed to disclose payments he received for touting specific stocks, was settled last June with a payment of $100,000 by Mr. Nadel, but without an admission or denial of guilt by anyone.
Jerold P. Weinger, the third Quantum director and its president, later called to explain that the company "splits its time" between the Boca Raton office and one on Park Avenue in New York. Mr. Weinger, a former broker, settled civil S.E.C. fraud charges in 1987, without admitting or denying guilt, and was disciplined by the National Association of Securities Dealers in 1989 for violating industry registration rules.
Mr. Weinger acknowledged in a recent interview that Mr. Nadel's history is "something of a negative" for Quantum shareholders -- in a very tangible way, because $145,000 of Quantum's money has been tied up in an asset freeze imposed on Mr. Nadel by a Federal magistrate last year at the request of postal inspectors. "But his business attributes make up far more than that," he added. "So the bottom line would be positive."
 
SEARCHING THE RECORDS
 The New York Times pursued its investigation of Boca Raton businesses under regulatory scrutiny by purchasing data tapes from the National Archives that contained names and addresses of companies that had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell securities to the public.
A computer was used to search the tapes for zip codes in the Boca Raton area. The result was a list of 145 companies. Current S.E.C. filings, news releases, articles and court documents relating to 82 companies were examined in detail.
Of the remaining 63 companies, no information beyond outdated S.E.C. entries could be found for 30. The rest were either limited partnerships, whose local sponsors were examined, or subsidiaries of companies based elsewhere.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 18; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 778 words

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Financial-Services Funds Rebound

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The stock market continued its indecisive course in the third quarter of 1992, as the average equity mutual fund rose 1.4 percent. For the year as a whole, stock funds have been almost motionless, dropping five-tenths of 1 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.
While the average has been steady, the losers have outnumbered the gainers 14 to 9. The worst performers include funds that invest in Japanese equities (down 18.5 percent), health and biotechnology funds (down 17.5 percent) and environmental funds (down 14.5 percent). 
 The group that has performed best in 1992 encompasses the 14 funds that invest in financial services companies. This sector has gained 16.7 percent. The $1.3 billion financial services group consists mainly of funds that invest in bank stocks but also includes funds that specialize in brokerages or insurers.
The group's excellent performance can be attributed mainly to the surge by the stocks of banks and savings and loan institutions, some which have registered phenomenal gains after having hit bottom in late 1990. Since then, problems with loans on real estate and overseas loans have abated somewhat. These trends and low interest rates have helped increase banks' profitability.
"But over a longer period they're not up as much as you would think," said James K. Schmidt, manager of the $80 million Freedom Regional Bank Fund in Boston. Now the bank stocks sell at roughly 11 times earnings, a big discount to the overall stock market, which is trading about 18 times 1992 earnings. But some managers say the easy money has already been made.
Mr. Schmidt said lower interest margins next year would be balanced by lower costs of credit for banks, yielding projected returns from bank stocks of 15 to 20 percent in 1993. His biggest holdings are Seacoast Banking in Stuart, Fla.; the Hawkeye Bancorporation in Des Moines, and the First Commercial Corporation in Little Rock, Ark.
Returns in the 15-to-20 percent range are also the goal of Stephen Binder, who manages the $135 million Fidelity Select Regional Bank Fund. The fund's biggest holdings are Comerica Inc., based in Detroit; Nationsbank, created by the merger of NCNB and C&S/Sovran, and the Bank of New York.
Bank stocks also seem to have been helped by institutions and others who have invested in them as other growth stocks have performed unimpressively, said Bruce T. Herring, who manages the $100 million Fidelity Select Financial Services Fund.
In July bank stocks dropped about 10 percent because of profit taking and a feeling that the banks' earnings had peaked. But after the dip, the stocks became attractive to investors looking for bargains, and this -- along with a slowly improving economy -- should propel the group upward. His fund's largest holdings are the Midlantic Corporation, Citicorp and the Bank of New York.
Karen L. Finkel, manager of the $50 million Paine Webber Regional Financial Growth Fund, which is about 65 percent invested in banks, believes the bank stocks still have a long way to grow. "I would expect to see continued response by the stocks, albeit more gradually, as earnings kick in as problem assets continue to abate," she said. The fund's biggest positions are in the Mercantile Bancorporation in St. Louis; First Empire State in Buffalo; and the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, which buys home mortgages and sells them to investors.
The year's biggest winner among the financial services funds is the Fidelity Select Savings and Loan Fund, which has risen 30.3 percent. David H. Ellison, who runs the $95 million fund, says the year's sizzling returns stemmed mostly from economic improvements in the Northeast.
He says there is still money to be made when California, whose economy is still worsening, begins to turn around. But he cautions that rebuilding the banking industry "doesn't take six months -- it takes years." His favorite holdings now are Albank Financial in Albany and Excel Bancorp in Quincy, Mass.
The biggest loser in the group is also a Fidelity fund: the Select Brokerage and Investment Management Fund (down 10.2 percent), which buys stock brokerages and mutual fund companies, among others. Last year, when most fund companies had their best year ever, the fund returned 82.3 percent; even with 1992's slippage, it earned 63.6 percent from Jan. 1, 1991 through Sept. 30.
The stocks with the heaviest weighting in its portfolio are Paine Webber, which he says is trading at 85 percent of its book value, and Franklin Resources, which stands to benefit from its recent acquisition of John Templeton's mutual fund empire.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Nowhere to Go But Higher?

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
And now, a nice word for silver.
Paul Macrae Montgomery, an economist at Legg Mason Wood Walker, does not have anything against gold, but he says silver looks even better. Better, that is, if you're a fearless bargain hunter. 
 Silver has suffered the third-worst bear market of any commodity ever, he said, citing statistics from The Investors' Edge, a California newsletter. "Virtually anything can be a bargain at some price," he said.
Big risk takers "might begin to investigate the equities of silver-related companies," he said. Silver moves by greater percentages in both bull and bear markets than gold does, Mr. Montgomery warns. Which means winners win big. And losers are happy to have canned food in the basement.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Celebrating Success by Giving

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
When Lynn Bignell and Janet Tweed, co-principals of an executive search firm, decided they wanted to celebrate their 20th anniversary in business by making a contribution to society, they did not reach for a batch of Rainforest Crunch. Instead, they gathered several of the people who work for them at GilbertTweed Associates in Manhattan and started brainstorming. How could the firm best use its resources to give something back to the people and organizations that helped it grow?
What Gilbert Tweed decided to do -- in late October or early November it will hold a lottery to give away more than $100,000 worth of search, consulting and training services to 20 nonprofit organizations -- represents what one expert has dubbed "philanthropic economics." 
 Corporate philanthropy is nothing new, of course, said the expert, L. Lawrence Embley, author of "Doing Well While Doing Good," a survey of 1990's-style corporate good deeds to be published shortly by Simon & Schuster. "Large corporations have always done it," he said. "The significant change is that businesses of all sizes are beginning to see the connection between the bottom line and social responsibility."
Mr. Embley attributes rising social awareness to greed fatigue from the 80's and to the ascension of a growing number of survivors from the rebellious 60's to positions of power in companies. "It's the second coming of the flower-power generation," he said.
While there may be people at Gilbert Tweed who brake for macrame, the decision to give away services seems to have stemmed from a broader source than radicalism redux. Ms. Bignell initiated the conversation on "giving something back," and the rest of the firm took the thread and ran with it. Discussions turned immediately to the nonprofit sector, in part, because the spirit of volunteerism, in churches, on boards and so on, lives large at Gilbert Tweed. "All of the partners personally do a great deal of volunteer work," Ms. Bignell said.
Of course, it is no coincidence that two of Gilbert Tweed's search specialties are in prime nonprofit territory -- health care and education -- or that those are the two areas designated for awards. In that respect, the firm's initiative provides evidence for Mr. Embley's contention that more businesses are realizing a connection between bottom-line and social concerns -- a connection Ms. Bignell acknowledges. "It provided us with a win-win scenario," she said. Nonprofits are "a practice area where we realize revenue. It would make us more noticeable to that community."
It took Gilbert Tweed two months to figure out what sort of outreach to do. A close second to the lottery was a plan that would have matched, with time off, the time employees spent volunteering, up to 40 hours a year. That suggestion was rejected because of the bookkeeping it would have entailed and because, as Ms. Bignell said, "we felt our impact would be splintered."
The firm could hardly have chosen a sector riper for impact. Nonprofits, always forced to look for ways to slenderize, have been hit especially hard by the lingering recession. Otis A. Jackson, planning and development executive vice president at Inroads Inc., a St. Louis-based organization that matches talented minority college students with corporate internships and jobs, said one of his affiliates applied for the Gilbert Tweed lottery to increase its competitiveness. "The labor market is very difficult now," he said. "We are competing with people who have been 'downsized' and who have much more experience."
If Inroads comes up in the lottery, it could win an executive search, worth $30,000, or expertise in recruiting or a seminar on hiring . The opportunity would come at a propitious moment for Inroads. The human resources department of the 22-year-old organization is beginning to focus more on staff development. "We could really use the services, especially interview training for staff," Mr. Jackson said. Managerial proficiency is becoming more important. "We work with senior-level officers and managers," he added. "Our organization emulates the business community as much as possible."
Lynn Bignell said Gilbert Tweed had been flying by the seat of its pants on this project, streamlining and improvising as it goes. It chose a lottery format because, she said, the firm does not want to be in the business of making judgments about programs. "We don't think we're qualified to rank people's needs," she said.
Gilbert Tweed is in the middle of what Ms. Bignell calls the "administrivia," decisions on such weighty matters as how the lottery will work. Six envelopes? Six fishbowls? By its nature, the administrivia is taking more time than she would like.
But she is convinced Gilbert Tweed's impulse is meeting a widespread need. One inquiry came from the Environmental Protection Agency. At least officially, the Federal Government is not a nonprofit.
 
 
 
AN AWARDS LOTTERY FOR NONPROFITS
 Gilbert Tweed Associates' "Serving America" awards program is open to nonprofit organizations in health care or education. Awards -- one to an applicant -- will be made in each area of Gilbert Tweed's expertise: 2 in executive search, 8 in consulting and 10 in training, and they will be split evenly between health care and education.
The one qualitative requirement Gilbert Tweed imposes is a commitment to diversity. "Diversity is a big issue today," Ms. Bignell said. "If it's not in a nonprofit, it should be. Hiring practices should reflect the populations they serve."
In addition to a two-page application, applicants are asked to submit their most recent annual reports or brochures; lists of board members; financial statements, and material supporting the commitment to diversity. The deadline for applications is Oct. 15. For information, contact Bettina Nelson at Gilbert Tweed Associates, 630 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-697-4260.

HEADLINE: Arms Makers' Latest Tune: 'Over There, Over There'

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Hurt by dwindling Pentagon orders, United States military contractors are relying more heavily than ever on foreign sales.
The value of agreements to sell arms to foreign countries has nearly quadrupled in five years to $24.1 billion already this year, from $6.5 billion in all of 1987, according to the Pentagon. Foreign orders should account for at least 25 percent of American arms production in the next few years, up from about 15 percent now, industry officials say. 
 To some extent, the overseas orders this year are wrapped up in Presidential politics: Most sales of American-made arms must be approved by Washington, and the President's authorization of such sales can translate into votes in communities where factory jobs were saved. In the last month, President Bush rejected protests from Israel and its supporters by approving the sale of 72 McDonnell-Douglas F-15 fighters to Saudi Arabia, saving some 7,000 aerospace jobs in St. Louis. He also reversed a 10-year-old limit on sales of advanced weaponry to Taiwan by clearing the sale of 150 General Dynamics F-16 fighters, saving 3,000 jobs in Fort Worth.
Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, also supported the Saudi and Taiwan sales, largely because of the economic benefits.
Industry officials say that with no rebound in sight for shrinking American military budgets, overseas orders will help pick up the slack for companies converting to commercial work or repositioning themselves in the leaner military arena. They also argue that the increased volume that results from sales to foreign customers allows weapons makers to charge the Pentagon less for each unit.
But arms-control groups and several members of Congress decry this trend, contending that arms proliferation, particularly in the Middle East, will escalate political tensions. There has recently been a stampede of Western arms merchants seeking to sate the growing appetite of Persian Gulf countries for arms.
A study issued last week by the Congressional Budget Office argued that limiting arms sales to the Middle East might permit reductions in American military spending. The office reasoned that if Middle East countries were less armed, the United States would not have to involve as many Americans in a Middle East war. "It is shortsighted to stimulate the arms race for the purpose of redressing economic problems in the United States," said Representative Dante B. Fascell, a Florida Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
But Jeffrey E. Garten, an investment banker and author of "A Cold Peace: America, Japan, Germany and the Struggle for Supremacy," thinks that "we're unlikely to sacrifice economic interests to take the moral high ground on curbing arms sales."
Why military contractors are looking overseas comes down to simple math:
* Saudi Arabia will buy seven times as many General Dynamics M1-A2 battle tanks as the United States Army in the next five years. The United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and Sweden are also shopping for tanks.
* After 1993, McDonnell-Douglas will sell two of its top three combat aircraft -- the F-15 and the AV-8B Harrier -- only to foreign customers, as United States Air Force and Navy orders wind down. Foreign orders to the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation's aircraft division will probably rise to about 33 percent of sales in the next few years from 20 percent now, said George Hibbard, director of international business development.
* More than 20 percent of Raytheon's sales this year are expected to come from Patriot missiles, mainly to countries like Saudi Arabia, Turkey, South Korea and Israel.
"In the short run, exports are going to be imperative to keep defense lines open and keep a warm industrial base in place," said Joel L. Johnson, international vice president of the Aerospace Industries Association in Washington. Mr. Johnson said that as Pentagon orders wane, American contractors will have to be more sensitive to foreign customers' needs, "even at the design phase and when putting together contractor teams."
Foreign sales stave off work-force cuts in the short run, but some economists argue that companies may use overseas orders as a crutch, to avoid the painful conversion to commercial production.
American companies cite strong demand not only in the Middle East but also in Southeast Asia, including Taiwan and Singapore,as United States military forces reduce their presence in East Asia. International competition in the global arms bazaar is already heating up among Washington's historical allies, including France, Britain and Germany, as well as Russia and China. For example, the Saudis were weighing British-made Tornado aircraft before Washington approved the F-15 sale. The American M1-A2 and the British-made Challenger are vying for a Kuwait order of about 250 battle tanks.
Industry officials say that international sales will help domestic production by keeping down unit costs for Pentagon purchases. For example, Mr. Hibbard said that the 325 F/A-18's that McDonnell-Douglas is selling over the next several years to foreign customers, including Finland and Switzerland, shaved $2 million off the cost of each of the 871 F/A-18's the United States Navy has bought for $24 million each.
As overseas orders become more important to military contractors, the Government has been under increasing pressure to facilitate such sales. Even before the Bush Administration exercised what critics call a jets-for-votes strategy, it was for the first time paying for United States warplanes and other arms to be flown to the big air shows in Singapore and Paris. The Europeans have done this for years to help their industries.
In addition, the Administration recently announced that it would end its policy of charging a fee on sales abroad of military equipment or commercial derivatives that were developed with Government research money. It also agreed to seek to repeal legislation that requires such fees on sales of major military equipment by the United States Government to other nations.
There is also greater support in the Administration for an industry-backed proposal under which the Government would guarantee private credits for foreign purchases of American military products.
"We've had more of a proactive and cooperative role from our Government than in past," said Toby G. Warson, chief executive of Alliant Techsystems Inc., a large munitions supplier based in Edina, Minn.
Companies are not relying solely on Goverment help. They are also experimenting with new strategies. Raytheon last year opened offices in Dubai and Jidda, Saudi Arabia.
Other companies that had not been big players overseas are jumping in. Martin Marietta, which assembles missiles and launchers for the Patriot missile and builds the Lantirn night-navigation and target system for F-15's and F-16's, expects foreign orders to climb to about 20 percent of total sales by 1994 from 5 percent in 1989.
Meanwhile, the politics of lobbying for foreign sales is shifting. In the F-15 sales, McDonnell-Douglas mustered a coalition of industry chief executives as well as labor union leaders to lobby the White House.
"The big difference is that manufacturers have tried to translate the impact sales are having on their bottom lines into domestic political leverage," said one Defense Department official involved with arms sales. "They've done it more effectively in the last two years than ever before."

HEADLINE: The Stepford Channel

BYLINE: By RICK MARIN

 BODY:
THIS is some kind of weird nightmare. Watching commercials that are half an hour long. Epic pitches for makeup, shampoo, hair conditioners, juicers, steamers, fitness machines, rhinestone setters and stain removers. Or for Jessica Hahn's 900 number, "Love Phone."
Watching them not just between television shows but as television shows. Lulled by their monotone, the spiritual opposite of MTV, and feeling powerless to turn off the smiling famous faces and euphoric, satisfied customers who promise a better, younger, prettier, richer, happier, more personally empowered you. 
 "What people seem to want from the infomercial is an experience that is wholly and brainlessly affirmative," said Mark Crispin Miller, professor of media studies at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. "It may be commercial television in its purest state."
Or self-help in its purest state. In a decade with much talk about dysfunction, the world of the infomercial is mesmerizingly functional, even multifunctional. Everything works, or seems to. And if it doesn't? There's always the money-back guarantee.
BLURRING the ever-blurrier line between television programming and advertising, infomercials generated $750 million in product sales last year. Two weeks ago, they even had their own awards ceremony, the first Play awards (Play is an acronym for program-length advertisements of the year) in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
No longer lurking on cable television's late-night fringe and no longer a demimonde of Hollywood has-beens, these mock-talk, mock-news, mock-cooking shows increasingly feature celebrities like Cher, Ted Danson and Jane Fonda. Dionne Warwick's "Psychic Friends Network," which invites viewers to call psychics via a 900 number, is the mostly frequently broadcast infomercial, according to Jordan Whitney, an industry analyst. In Denver, Playboy's "Secrets of Making Love" infomercial gets higher ratings than "Late Night With David Letterman."
And on Thursday, ABC is to introduce "Nitecap," a late-night half-hour starring Robin Leach that will feature famous guests and offer products for sale by 800 number. As of last week, though, the producers did not know which famous guests and what products.
Thirty-two ABC stations will carry the show; New York's WABC-TV will not. Disdaining terms like "home shopping show" or "infomercial," the network has even devised a new name for the hybrid format of "Nitecap": transactional talk.
The transactional genre has already made rich men of Jay (the Juiceman) Kordich and Joe Sugarman, the bearded guy who sells Blublocker sunglasses. Richard Simmons grossed $40 million last year from the "Deal-a-Meal" diet plan sold via his teary, hand-holding half-hours. Tony Robbins's "Personal Power" series, featuring his celebrity friends Fran Tarkenton and Martin Sheen, has sold $100 million worth of motivational videos.
And Victoria Jackson, queen of the mail-order make-over, has sold $150 million worth of makeup during the last three years exclusively through "Beauty Breakthroughs," her girl-talk sessions with Ali MacGraw, Meredith Baxter and Lisa Hartman.
Victoria's secret? Step into her living room. Grand yet intimate, the setting is a rented Beverly Hills mansion, a sedative venue. Two large columns frame a picture window, and light floods into a room meticulously accessorized with plants and cut flowers.
Meredith and Ali -- first names only -- sit on a pillowy ivory sofa. Victoria, a soft-eyed brunette with a slight lisp and perfect nails, is in a matching chair on the other side of a glass coffee table arrayed with her monogrammed makeup and skin-care line.
They talk quietly, earnestly.
Meredith: "I wanted to tell you that I read in The Los Angeles Times that you have had an absolutely phenomenal response to the commercials that you guys have done."
Victoria: "It's been incredible! I mean, it's just overwhelming. From the first week we were on TV, we were selling 10,000 kits a week. It's been incredible."
Ali shares next. How she is stopped in supermarkets and airports by women who tell her, "I've been using Victoria Jackson, and it's great, just like you said it was!"
Occasionally, the three pause to "watch" testimonials gathered from places like Waukesha, Wis., or Champaign, Ill. Before-and-after split screens transform wan, depressed-looking women into smiling, radiant beauties.
Lisa Hartman comes on, in a different living room, to give her own endorsement for the makeup and an 800 number. The full Victoria Jackson line is "available," she says, for just three easy payments of $39.95, the mail-order trade's magic price tag.
The infomercial cost $750,000 to produce, as much as Madison Avenue's slickest 30-second spots. The direction (three-camera video, soft-focus glow) is seamlessly conversational. The artful imagery -- the columns, mirrored table, Victoria's red dress -- is meant to register on some deeper level than the disclaimer racing across the bottom of the screen. It reads: "All claims and representations made in this program-length advertisement are the sole responsibility of the sponsor."
Caveat emptor. In 1984, the Reagan Administration erased the Federal Communications Commission's limit of 12 commercial minutes per hour of programming. Last seen in the 1950's, the 30-minute commercial, now with the dubious prefix "info," was back. Soon the President's own son, Michael Reagan, was extolling the Euro Trym Diet Patch, whose manufacturer was later sued by the Federal Trade Commission for false advertising. The F.T.C. caught the same company peddling a bogus impotence cure on a "talk show" with the television personality Lyle Waggoner as host.
"It was like a frontier town," said Jeffrey Knowles, counsel for the National Infomercial Marketing Association in Washington. When Congressional hearings threatened to shut down infomercials for two years because of rampant charlatanism, the trade and lobbying group was formed to police its own members.
Slouching towards legitimacy, infomercialists now talk sensitively of their "craft" and decry the "fringe element," the snake-oil salesmen and carnival barkers who give the business a bad name.
"I, from a creative perspective, hate most of the infomercials that are on the air," Tim O'Leary, marketing director of Tyee Productions, an infomercial company, told an audience of 350 colleagues and potential clients last month. They had paid $395 each for a daylong conference at the Waldorf-Astoria that promised to reveal the "secrets" of the infomercial trade. (Mr. O'Leary disclosed that he always shoots on film, never video, for his Nordictrack account.)
Rick Bradley, an agent of the William Morris agency who represents Victoria Jackson and Richard Simmons, estimates that Cher was paid $1 million, plus a percentage of the gross, for her role in selling "Aquasentials," a line of hair-care products. "Celebrities feel more comfortable now about doing them because more of them have jumped in and seen the potential to make a lot of money," he said.
A mid-range celebrity can make $25,000 an infomercial, plus up to 5 percent of gross sales. Bigger stars can get $250,000 and 7 percent of sales.
A handful of companies rule the industry, with some cross-pollination. Victoria Jackson is engaged to Bill Guthy, whose Guthy-Renker Corporation does the Tony Robbins series. Mr. Robbins's producer, Lenny Lieberman, is producing Georgette Mosbacher's new infomercial for her beauty line.
The dominant presence is American Telecast (15 Play award nominations), a highly secretive family business that has made millions off Richard Simmons, Victoria Jackson and others, but shuns media coverage. "The spouting whale gets harpooned," a company spokeswoman said.
Stations charge companies like American Telecast anywhere from $500 a half-hour in a small market to $50,000 for a slot in New York or Los Angeles, though many are embarrassed to admit it.
"What do you want me to say?" said Martin Blair, a spokesman for New York's WCBS. "Yeah, we run them. So what?" Substituting commercials for programming is a recession neccessity, said WNBC's president and general manager, Bill Bolster, predicting that "as the economy improves, they'll be the first thing to go."
At the conference, Phil Beuth, ABC's vice president of late-night programming, was hailed as a "visionary" for resisting network snobbery and pushing "Nitecap" onto the schedule. After Mr. Beuth's speech, a fan approached to shake his hand and said, "It's nice to meet someone at the network level who understands the American dream!"
Marvin S. Traub, former president of Bloomingdale's, said infomercials drove the store's juicer sales up "geometrically," from 5 to 10 sales a week to hundreds a week. Similarly, he said, when Bloomingdale's Labor Day catalogue featured Toastmaster's $90 Grillerie, a product introduced by Ricardo Montalban on an infomercial, the housewares department sold more than 100 of them in the first week.
DOES Bloomies' good housewares seal of approval herald a new era of respectability for informercials and their wares? Possibly not. Consider the bizarre Flowbee "vacuum haircutting system," parodied in the opening scene of "Wayne's World." Or the "chef" touting the joys of the Jet-Stream Oven, who notes that his chicken breast is golden brown while the one cooked in a microwave oven resembles "cadaver meat." Or the anti-baldness cures or the real estate "seminars" invariably conducted from a beach in Hawaii.
Lawsuits brought by consumers abound. Consumer groups like the Center for the Study of Commercialism are lobbying Congress to mandate branding any infomercial as paid advertising with a continuous symbol in the corner of the television screen.
"I bought three mixers and all of them burned out in a week," said Rader Hayes, an assistant professor of consumer science at Marquette University in Milwaukee. Her Juice Tiger died after three days.
And yet people buy and buy. "I can't explain that behavior," Professor Hayes said. "There is a percentage of people who respond to these things, and we don't know why."
Prof. Todd Gitlin, director of the mass communications program at the University of California at Berkeley, has his own theory. "They let your eyes do the walking," he said. "The same people who would otherwise be out at the mall are getting the mall experience at home. Shopping is pleasure for a lot of people, and with infomercials they can fool themselves into thinking they're learning something at the same time."
The pitch is delivered in the guise of a talk show or news report, Professor Gitlin said, because "after all these years, these forms of television have become the forms of thought."
It was an awards ceremony like any other: lights, cameras, a host in a dinner jacket and a hostess in sequins. Elation and envy in the air. A funny-looking statuette.
The first Play awards honored the industry's best director, best performance, most innovative product.
"And the winner is . . . Miiike Leveeeey."
Mike Levey is host of "Amazing Discoveries," an informercial that sells car wax by setting the hood of a Rolls-Royce on fire. He was also the host of the awards ceremony.
"I never anticipated this," Mr. Levey said, choking back emotion. "You all have helped me realize a dream. A vision can become reality. Thank you very much!"
This was the fifth little glass globe Mr. Levey had accepted since the evening began, including one on behalf of the late Michael Landon for best celebrity performance. Accepting, Mr. Levey let out a little "Yay!" -- the same noise he makes when the car is set on fire -- and hurried to the next category: most innovative product.
"And the winner is . . .tThe Jet Stream Oven!"
Call now.

HEADLINE: The Reckoning;
No Painless Way Out for the Next President

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHOEVER is elected President 30 days from now, the next few years will be rough.
Ross Perot touched on this last week when he got into the race for the final lap and called for "fair-shared sacrifice." But Mr. Perot did not tell the full story, and George Bush and Bill Clinton have ducked it during their campaigns. 
 Over the long haul, the only way out of the country's budgetary and economic mess is for most people to pay higher taxes, for popular Government programs to be cut and for medical care to be rationed. Economists differ on the means and the timing; few disagree on the point.
The prevailing view among politicians and political scientists is that the new President needs to tackle this right away when he is strongest politically. "There's a golden window that opens in the first six months or so of a new Presidency that allows grand and bold accomplishments," said Donald F. Kettl, political scientist at the University of Wisconsin.
Franklin D. Roosevelt pushed the main elements of the New Deal through Congress in his first 100 days as President. Lyndon B. Johnson had two honeymoons: The first, in 1964 shortly after the Kennedy assassination, he used to get a tax cut and a civil rights bill. The second, in 1965 after his election, led to the Great Society. Ronald Reagan completely overhauled the economy with supply-side tax cuts his first year in the White House.
Mr. Bush, on the other hand, skipped the chance to make his mark at the outset. When he took office in 1989 the economy was strong, and the deficit could have been addressed with a tax increase and a spending cut. But Mr. Bush was stymied by his no-new-taxes pledge and the overwhelming Democratic majority in Congress. As a consequence, the deficit now, about $330 billion, is more than twice what it was four years ago and dealing with it will be many times more severe.
The country's economic problems are no secret, but the huge Federal debt -- now $4 trillion, four times what it was a decade ago -- has severely limited the Government's options for solving them. Personal incomes have been stagnant for years. Businesses have failed in record numbers. Medical care swallows up 15 percent of the nation's economic output, far more than in any other country, yet millions of Americans still have no health insurance. One American in 10 is on food stamps. Assembly-line jobs, a mainstay of the American middle class, are going abroad or being replaced by machines. Hundreds of thousands of defense industry workers fear layoffs, their highly honed skills no longer applicable. Bridges, highways and airports are rotting. Americans consume too much and save and invest too little.
"These weaknesses will continue to erode our economic strength and further burden future generations," a bipartisan commission under the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington research institute, said last week. "Addressing these vulnerabilities will require reforms that will be painful at first."
 
Synthesizing a Solution
 The problems are even more intractable because the solutions are so contradictory. Today's bad times probably require a fiscal stimulus -- a tax cut, more spending or both -- but that would increase the budget deficit, which is gradually corroding the economy. Reduced military spending is the centerpiece of a lower deficit, but it means more people in the unemployment lines. Cuts in Medicare and Medicaid, the fastest growing part of the Federal budget, would force individuals, companies and communities to pay more themselves for medical care, leaving them less to spend on productive enterprises that would fuel economic growth. Lifting trade restrictions would expand exports and improve the overall economy, but many jobs would also be lost. Low interest rates, which encourage investment by Americans, discourage the kind of investment here by foreigners that has propped up the economy for years.
The political situation is worsened by the fact that Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton have offered only painless, inadequate ways to resolve these conflicts. As for Mr. Perot, he has put forth a detailed, generally plausible plan for balancing the budget by raising the top income tax rate, by imposing a 50-cents-a-gallon tax on gasoline and by cutting Government programs across the board. But Mr. Perot rarely talks about the unpleasant aspects of his program. And while he may play spoiler, he cannot be elected President.
So the next President's job will be harder because he will not have a mandate from the voters to call for sacrifice. Some Presidents -- Jimmy Carter, for example -- have failed because they did not have clear mandates for their policies. But Woodrow Wilson had no mandate to enter World War I. And Roosevelt said nothing about the New Deal during his first campaign.
"You don't need a mandate for this," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. "There is a general understanding in America that the chickens have come home to roost and that we are going to have to tighten our belts. If a leader comes forward with a balanced and gradual package to do this, there will be reluctant acquiescence in Congress and among the American people."
Neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Clinton has articulated such a package. But in political and academic circles as well as on Wall Street a consensus is slowly developing on what the main elements should be.
To get the stalled economy moving again, a temporary economic stimulus of $50 billion or so should be approved in the form of tax credits to encourage business investment and public works projects that would improve the national economy in the long run. At the same time, in the same legislation, the President and Congress must enact specific tax increases and spending reductions, not just general principles, to be put into place gradually over the rest of the decade. The deal would have to be reinforced with rigid rules allowing the tax and spending measures to be rescinded only in extraordinary circumstances.
Whether that is practicable is another matter. "Multi-year programs have proved not to be credible," said Robert D. Hormats, who has advised several Presidents on economics and international affairs and is now an investment banker in New York. "The public and the markets are going to be skeptical."
One person who thinks it can be done is Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the chairman of the Budget Committee. Mr. Sasser, a Democrat, says he favors such an approach but fears it could cost him re-election in 1994.
"Our problems," he said, "are so serious and the only solutions are so unpleasant that I wonder whether any of us can come out of this with our popularity intact."
