HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUE;
Where They Stand on the Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
The annual Federal budget deficit, the difference between what the Government spends and the tax revenue it receives, is now about $330 billion and is projected to rise to $500 billion by the turn of the century. The deficit began mushrooming in the 1980's because income taxes were cut deeply under Ronald Reagan, while spending increased substantially, especially for Medicare and Medicaid. 
 Some economists on both the left and right ends of the political spectrum play down the importance of the deficit. But most economists in the mainstream hold that the deficit is gradually crippling the country by forcing the taxpayers of the future to pay for today's consumption.
 
THE RECORDS
 BUSH: As Vice President, Mr. Bush was in the Administration under which the deficit growth began, and in his own Presidency it has more than doubled. The increase under Mr. Bush was not all his fault. Some was caused by the savings-and-loan bailout. Some was a result of the lower tax revenues and higher spending that grew out of the recession.
The budget agreement Mr. Bush and Congress negotiated in 1990 kept matters from getting even worse. Congress rejected some of the spending cuts Mr. Bush proposed, but over all, Congress appropriated less money than Mr. Bush requested.
The main reason the deficit has risen so much is that although Government spending increased during the Bush Presidency by an average of 7.5 percent a year, after adjusting for inflation (as against 1 percent under Ronald Reagan), Mr. Bush refused to support offsetting tax increases.
 CLINTON: Bill Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas is not directly comparable to that of the President. The Arkansas constitution requires a balanced budget, and to comply with that Mr. Clinton has backed increases in the sales tax and taxes on cigarettes, insurance premiums and gasoline.
He tried to raise the state income tax but was blocked by the legislature. Thousands of the poorest Arkansas residents were given exemptions from state income taxes. Only eight states have lower taxes.
The state's budget under Mr. Clinton more or less doubled in size, partly because of inflation and partly because of increased spending for education and other programs.
PEROT: Mr. Perot has never held public office.
 
THE PHILOSOPHIES
 BUSH: Controlling the deficit is important but not so important as keeping taxes low as a way of generating economic growth and jobs.
 CLINTON: Controlling the deficit is important but not so important as "investing" money to improve highways, communications networks and other installations, as a way of generating economic growth and jobs.
 PEROT: The Federal deficit must be eliminated, not just lowered, before the nation's other problems can be dealt with.
 
THE PROPOSALS
 BUSH: In July, Mr. Bush offered a program that he said would reduce the deficit to $118 billion by 1997, but since then, he has proposed more than $140 billion in additional tax cuts. He insists he will not raise taxes in any circumstances.
His deficit-cutting measures are grounded in his plan to limit the growth in mandatory programs like Medicare, Medicaid, food stamps and veterans benefits, excluding Social Security. Mr. Bush has never said how the limits would be imposed. He has also proposed freezes on other domestic spending programs, a reduction in Federal subsidies to some affluent Americans like wealthy farmers and a lowering of the military budget.
Mr. Bush favors a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, but he has never offered a balanced budget himself nor explained what specific steps he favors to reach such a goal.
 CLINTON: Clinton promises to cut the deficit to about $140 billion by 1996. That is based in part on the assumption that the economy will grow somewhat faster than most economists believe is likely. The main deficit-reduction elements are tax increases of about $150 billion and cuts in military spending about $40 billion deeper than those proposed by President Bush.
About two-thirds of the increased tax revenue would come from higher income taxes on the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans (joint annual incomes over $200,000), a surtax on incomes over $1 million and a higher minimum tax on wealthy taxpayers with large deductions. Taxes would be cut for families with annual incomes below about $90,000 and for some businesses.
Mr. Clinton also proposes better collection of taxes from foreign companies, a 3 percent reduction in administrative costs and more efficiency in the savings-and-loan bailout. With a goal of generating economic growth and jobs, Mr. Clinton would increase spending by about $220 billion over four years. This "investment" would go to things like education, job training and public works.
PEROT: Mr. Perot promises to balance the budget after five years. The gasoline tax would be raised 10 cents a gallon each year for five years. The top tax rate would be raised to 33 percent from 31 percent for couples making more than about $90,000. Taxes would be raised on the Social Security benefits received by upper-income taxpayers, and benefits from other Government programs would be taxed. Employers would be taxed on health-insurance premiums worth more than $335 a month.
Deductions of mortgage interest would be limited to mortgage amounts of $250,000 or less. Federal spending on programs other than the military, mandatory programs and interest on the debt would be cut by 15 percent by eliminating "unnecessary and outdated" Government programs. Military spending would be reduced by $40 billion below the level proposed by Mr. Bush. The capital-gains tax would be eliminated for small businesses, and businesses would get other tax breaks for investment and research. An additional $70 billion would be spent over five years for public works.
 
SCORECARD
 The deficit will be a major problem facing the next President. But neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Clinton has made it a central campaign issue, and neither has a credible plan for dealing with it. Both candidates have promised to revamp the health-care system. But neither has explained how he would meet the increased cost to the Government, which could run to tens of billions of dollars a year. The only way to reduce the budget deficit is to raise taxes on most Americans, cut popular spending programs or both, and neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Clinton has proposed doing so. Mr. Perot's proposed tax increases would raise hundreds of billions of dollars over five years, but the spending cuts he offers are less precise and less realistic. He has not developed a plan for limiting medical costs, identified the unnecessary programs he would abolish or explained how some programs like, say, the air-traffic-control system, could be cut by 15 percent without doing grave damage.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Suddenly, 148 Million Capitalists

 BODY:
Last week, Russia began issuing every adult and child a voucher worth 10,000 rubles, or about $50. Next year, they'll have to decide whether to sell the vouchers for cash, invest them in a mutual fund or use them to buy shares in the thousands of factories being put up for sale.
In other words, every Russian will become a capitalist. 
 That's an astonishing change from the cradle-to-grave security blanket that enclosed Communist Russia little more than a year ago. More than astonishing: audacious. President Boris Yeltsin's shrewd plan forces Russians to engage in capitalist calculations, leading to decisions that will dictate personal fortunes.
It's the largest, most fateful variation on the social and economic transformation of this generation. Privatization is sweeping across Eastern Europe. Czechoslovakia began a voucher program last spring; Poland is poised to begin and Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania are speeding along. All paths point in the same direction: capitalism.
Americans will desperately want, and no doubt help, the Russians to complete the perilous journey. At risk are the democratic and market reforms that have turned archenemy into budding ally.
Fast-track privatization is shrewdly designed to solve a formidable economic problem. The Yeltsin Government dismantled Communist controls; market controls haven't yet taken their place. That has left factory managers in charge but accountable to no one -- an invitation to mismanage and steal. By creating instant owners, the plan would force managers to take proper care.
But Mr. Yeltsin has political concerns too. The plan is designed to give beleaguered Russians a stake in his market reforms. It's also designed to buy the allegiance of industrial managers, whose privileged status is threatened by market reform. Under the plan, they would get an inside track to owning and controlling the factories they manage. Not wholly fair, but it is a clever way to dissipate opposition.
Indeed, putting existing factory managers in charge helps solve another problem. After ownership rights are distributed, the factories must be governed. And a factory owned by everyone is a factory controlled by no one. Giving savvy insiders the upper hand concentrates control.
Will the plan work? There are reasons to worry. Billions of illegally earned rubles would be used to buy up vouchers, a slick way to launder ill-gotten gains. Uniquely, the plan would allow investors to use a combination of vouchers and cash to buy factories. That favors well-informed, well-financed domestic and foreign investors. Again, that's unfair, but it may get firms running under wise management.
The Russians haven't figured out critical details, like how investors will actually bid for shares. Nor have they controlled inflation, closed huge budget deficits or clarified bankruptcy rules. These daunting challenges will have to be met before privatization has a chance.
But given the political peril, Mr. Yeltsin judged, perhaps wisely, that speed should win out over caution. Factories are preparing privatization plans; Russians are picking up their vouchers. Once the bidding begins, it might well be impossible to turn back the tidal wave to markets.

Rise, Sir Rebuttal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
Moderator: Good evening and welcome to lap one of the American Debatathon, or "Honey, I Shrunk the Candidates."
Listen closely because I won't explain this again. Our format tonight is to have one panelist direct a question to one of the three candidates. After a two-minute reply, each of the other candidates will have a one-minute rebuttal, followed by a surrebuttal by the original questionee. 
 Panelist: Do you think, Mr. President, that after watching six hours of debating in one week, the American people are likely to adopt these debate formats as a means of intra-family communication? And if they do, part two of my question is: What sort of interpersonal issues would lend themselves to this debate format for a family sitting around the kitchen table?
Bush: Family values -- or traditional values, as we now call them, because some people treat "family" like a dirty word . . . uh, I kinda like the idea of a family sitting around the kitchen table, Mom and Dad and the kids, chewing things over -- nothing wrong with a family without kids, or a single-parent type of situation -- though not in the military, and make no mistake, General Powell is right with me on that -- but sure, I think that debates, especially the tightly organized kind, like the one tonight, help people decide who they can really trust because that's what it all comes down to, not how many points you can memorize, or dreary statistics about the past, but character, no waffling, but who you can trust in the middle of the night when the phone rings and it's the man with the football, the nuclear codes, who sleeps right outside my door next to Millie . . . yes, that's the sort of disciplined debate I think is healthy for American families. Wholesome --
Moderator: Your rebuttal, Governor Clinton?
Clinton: Can we trust a man who claims to be "out of the loop" on Iran-contra, when everybody else says he was profoundly looped? Can we trust a politician who said "read my lips, no new taxes" and then raised taxes? Can we trust rosy promises about pulling out of hard times from a man whose economic record is the worst since Jimmy -- since Herbert Hoover?
Back in April, I issued a five-point paper on ways the debate idea can bring American families -- just like Hillary, Chelsea and I, or me -- together again. One, pick a relevant topic, like bedtimes. Two, get your neighbors to form a joint commission to sponsor your kitchen-table debates. Three, each one of us has to accept responsibility for making sure there are plenty of cookies and milk handy, or a six-pack of beer, for the time-outs that resolve the tension, especially in broken homes caused by Bush-Quayle socio-economic hardship, and four -- actually, it was a three-point program for change in our debating system. We've had enough of the same old debating, the divisiveness, the polarization by the current Administration, and now I remember the fourth point, we must --
Moderator: Time.
Clinton: Change!
Moderator: Mr. Perot, your rebuttal.
Perot: Did you just hear what I heard? You ever hear such unadulterated poppycock in your life? They don't have the solution; they're the problem. Peas in a pod, the both of 'em, spoutin' off about some idiot question from the gotcha media while the deficit is down there in the basement and they're treating it like a crazy aunt, pretending she ain't there. Folks, the lady down in my basement is my aunt, and she's crazy as a coot, and I have her chained to the wall for her own good, but I can tell the difference between Aunt Sadie and the red-ink budget, which neither of these birds here could do in a lifetime in politics. That's all I have to say; you can take the rest of my time, Mr. Moderator, and stick it in your ear.
Moderator: A 30-second surrebuttal, Mr. President.
Bush: Ross, I hear you, and while we may differ about some of the details about the treatment of the mental illness of your Aunt Sadie -- a wonderful family woman, I'm sure, whose Medicare is safe with me -- I think it's wrong for you and Governor Clinton to want to slam her with a 50-cent-a-gallon gas tax, so that when you let her out of the dungeon she couldn't afford to drive away. In the few seconds I have left, I just want to say trust, trust, trust, trust --
Moderator: Time, gentlemen, please.

HEADLINE: Tribal Colleges Helping Renew Indians' Spirit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While your report on poverty at the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation is largely accurate ("Sad Distinction for the Sioux: Homeland Is No. 1 in Poverty," Sept. 20), I believe there is a major element missing in the picture you presented of life there. 
 Having lived on the Pine Ridge Reservation for 16 years, first as a youngster from grade school through high school and later as an adult from 1976 to 1984, I will tell you that our people do suffer many hardships there, as they do on most Indian reservations. Yet in spite of the desperate physical poverty and deprivation, there is still humor, camaraderie and a strength of spirit. These resources are nurtured by a rich cultural heritage and values that, despite organized efforts to destroy our culture and force assimilation, have survived and are upheld in the reservation setting.
This strength of spirit has carried us through the last 150 years, the lowest point in the history of the Indian people, during which we have fought for our physical and cultural survival. I believe we are now at a most hopeful turning point in our history. As one Pine Ridge resident was quoted in your article, after years of government interference, we Indians are taking our affairs back into our own hands and finding our own solutions to our problems.
Arguably, the most successful effort so far in the Indian movement toward greater self-determination is the establishment of tribal colleges over the last 25 years. There are now 26 Indian colleges found on and near reservations in 12 Midwestern and Western states -- including Oglala Lakota College on Pine Ridge.
These colleges are bringing new opportunities to our people in the way of academic degree programs and vocational training. We have seen great achievements in our students, attributable in large part to the importance given by the colleges to traditional cultural values and identity. These institutions are responding to community needs by providing such services as literacy and health education and economic development initiatives. Through them we are developing tools to rebuild our communities.
 
DAVID L. ARCHAMBAULT
 President
 American Indian College Fund
 New York, Sept. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
With Reservations, Clinton Endorses Free-Trade Pact

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 4

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton said today that he endorsed the North American Free Trade Agreement, but also said that as President he would not sign it in its current form.
The Democratic Presidential nominee said an acceptable trade agreement should include provisions that would toughen environmental and worker-safety standards in Mexico and allow the President to establish a commission to monitor the agreement's impact. 
 "I believe we can address these concerns without renegotiating the basic agreement," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Backers Could Be Upset
 On Wednesday, President Bush is scheduled to travel to San Antonio, where trade ministers from the United States, Canada and Mexico are scheduled to initial the agreement to eliminate most customs duties and other trade barriers among the United States, Mexico and Canada over the next 10 years. American law allows Mr. Bush to sign the agreement as early as Dec. 17, although he could choose not to do so if he loses the election.
Though expected, Mr. Clinton's endorsement of the agreement runs the risk of alienating some supporters in organized labor and Congress.
His speech today drew immediate criticism from Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, who said the "omissions" that Mr. Clinton identified had already been alleviated by the agreement, which is the product of more than a year of negotiation by Bush Administration officials.
Mr. Clinton said the agreement should be part of a "larger economic strategy" designed to raise the incomes of American workers. "If it is not done right, however, the benefits of the agreement are far less clear," he said in a speech at North Carolina State University here. "And the burdens will be significant. I'm convinced that I will do it right. I am equally convinced that Mr. Bush won't."
Mr. Clinton had been leaning toward endorsing the agreement for some weeks, his advisers said, even as he reviewed the 2,000-word pact to make his final assessment. But today for the first time, he formally outlined his objections to the North American Free Trade Agreement, saying that the United States must be forced to develop a more integrated economy with expanded trade as part of the formula.
He also chose a university campus to make his announcement rather than the towns of the industrial Midwest where he had frequently been greeted by union members with signs with slogans like "Fair Trade, not Free Trade."
"On balance, I believe N.A.F.T.A. can contribute to this effort, not undermine it, as long as we move aggressively to address the serious omissions from the agreement," he said. "I believe we have to do more for our own workers to protect the environment on both sides of the border both because it's good for the environment and because if they don't do it, it will further lower the costs of production."
Mr. Clinton said the criticism he had received for the delay in taking a stand on the trade agreement was symptomatic of the shallowness of American politics.
 
Eliminating Trade Barriers
 "One of the most difficult problems in modern politics and therefore in this Presidential election is the simplistic and superficial labeling of complex issues," he said.
The agreement, which was completed in August, is scheduled to take effect on Jan. 1, 1994, and would establish the largest trading bloc in the world with $6 trillion in output.
The effects of the agreement will be most pronounced on Mexico's trade with the United States and Canada because trade barriers between the United States and Canada are already being pulled down by a 1988 free-trade agreement between them.
Mr. Clinton said he would work to maintain a strong American manufacturing base that would prevent harm to American workers by the strong economies of competitors.
"I remain convinced that the North American Free Trade Agreement will generate jobs and growth on both sides of the border if, and only if, it's part of a broad-based strategy," he said.
"If we don't do those things, we can kill N.A.F.T.A.," he said. "But we'll still lose jobs."
 
Republican Rejoinders
 Ms. Hills objected to Mr. Clinton's description of the trade agreement. "I think that anyone who studies what we have accomplished has got to give it very high marks," she said. "And we would not have been able to achieve our agreements without support from Democrats. The qualifiers sound to me like he is being held back by the labor unions who are opposed to the agreement."
Mary Matalin, the President's deputy campaign manager, said: "Either Clinton supports this treaty or he does not. He can't be on both sides of the issue."
Clinton advisers said the protections the Administration had called for were weak and would not have the force of law. By contrast, they said, the commission they proposed would be headed by the Vice President and would have the power to assess damages for violations.
Mr. Clinton, however, said that the best way to insure fair trade would be to use the agreement as the basis for a global agreement with other nations.
"It will provide more jobs from exports," he said. "It will challenge us to become more competitive. It will certainly help Mexico to develop. But still, that is also in our interests. A wealthier Mexico will buy more American products. As incomes rise there that will reduce pressure for emigration across the border into the United States which depresses wages here."
Leaders of labor unions supporting Mr. Clinton have remained opposed to the trade agreement, but they have withheld criticism of Mr. Clinton's sympathy for it in favor of working for the election of a Democratic President.
But it remains unclear whether these leaders speak for their members, many of whom are suffering from job losses brought on by the closing or relocation of plants. Many of these men and women are also the traditional Democrats who strayed from the fold during the last decade to support Ronald Reagan and Mr. Bush.
"Although it is unpopular with some people and organizations I admire and represent, the very Americans I am fighting so hard for in this election," Mr. Clinton said, "I think we should go forward with it because it advances our interests, the interests of ordinary Americans, more than it undermines it."
Democratic members of Congress from two important states have expressed reservations about the agreement. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who is the House majority leader, says it should be renegotiated, and Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio has said the pact could cost 550,000 jobs over the next decade in this country.
Representative Don J. Pease, an Ohio Democrat who is a member of the Ways and Means subcommittee on trade, said Mr. Clinton, "probably didn't have much choice but to endorse the N.A.F.T.A. in general, otherwise he'd have been savaged by the press, among others."
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat on the same subcommittee, said that by endorsing the pact, although with some qualifications, Mr. Clinton had prevented it from becoming controversial over the next month. "It really neutralizes it completely as an issue in the campaign.
Mr. Matsui and Mr. Pease both said that the endorsement improved the odds that some version of the pact would eventually be cleared by the Democratically controlled Congress. Mr. Matsui, for example, said he would not vote for legislation putting the agreement into law if Mr. Bush was re-elected because he did not believe that the current Administration would carry out pledges to protect workers and the environment.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 6, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Gov. Bill Clinton's endorsement of the North American Free Trade Agreement misstated its length in some copies. The treaty is some 2,000 pages long, not 2,000 words. The article also misstated the combined economic output of the trading partners in some copies. The output of the three nations, the United States, Mexico and Canada, would be $6 trillion.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
DIAL 'M' FOR MOVIES
The nation's first video dialtone system, which will transmit cable television programming over telephone lines, is expected to go into service in three large apartment buildings in Manhattan early next year. The companies planning the yearlong test of the new system -- New York Telephone and Liberty Cable Television -- say it will let subscribers choose what they want to watch when they want to watch, rather than subjecting them to the rigid schedules of traditional broadcast channels, cable systems and pay-per-view movies. The companies say this would be possible with a device they call a "video jukebox," which will let viewers use a telephone line to dial an on-screen menu from which they can select programs. B3.
 
ACCOUNTS OF CROWN HEIGHTS
In two weeks of sometimes chilling testimony in Supreme Court in Brooklyn, seven police officers, one sergeant and two detectives have each described a slightly different moment during the chaotic night in Crown Heights when Yankel Rosenbaum, a visiting rabbinical scholar, was stabbed to death. But almost all of the witnesses said they heard Mr. Rosenbaum, who was lying bleeding on a car, identify the defendant, Lemrick Nelson Jr., as his assailant. Page B3.
 

SCHOOL OFFICIALS FAIL TO HALT BOYCOTT
Top school officials failed to persuade the leaders of a local P.T.A. to call off their plans for a boycott of Eastern District High School in Brooklyn to protest what parents say are overcrowded and dangerous conditions. Leaders of the Parent-Teacher Association emerged from a three-hour meeting with Deputy Chancellor Stanley Litow saying that the school board had not addressed their concerns and that they were making arrangements for a boycott. B3.
 
UP FROM THE WELFARE HOTEL
Yvonne McCain spent four years in welfare hotel hell, but the years were not spent in vain. By the time she was able to move out of the Martinique on Herald Square in Manhattan five years ago, she remembers: "People would say they had brand new mattresses, they put on window guards. I did see some changes. If it did help just one person not to feel the desperation I did, then it was worth it." Since that time, Ms. McCain's life, too, has been evolving into a success story. Metro Matters, B3.
 
REGION
 
TEEN-AGER DIES IN STOLEN CAR
A 14-year-old boy was killed when a stolen car he was driving veered off a sharply curved street in Newark, plowed through a chain link fence and slammed airborne into a steel sign girder. The police called it a speeding accident, but the victim's family said he had been killed by police officers who chased and rammed him with a patrol car. The police said the victim, Rasheed Ali Sharif, riding alone in a stolen 1992 Buick Century, was killed instantly when the vehicle, traveling at what witnesses estimated was 75 miles an hour, missed the curve on Quitman Street near Clinton Avenue and crashed. The authorities said no other car was involved and they denied any involvement by the police. B5.
 
IT'S BOB AND AL, TIT FOR TAT
Forget recession, health care and the environment. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and State Attorney General Robert Abrams have managed to make the New York campaign for the Senate a contest of "Really, Bob!" vs. "Come on, Al!" -- a tit-for-tat war of television commercial tag lines, listing each other's supposed sins. That is just how Mr. D'Amato wants it, since he has been under fire for years over his personal ethics and now faces a tough fight for a third term. Mr. Abrams, adopting the prevailing political wisdom that an attack left unrebutted is an attack that might ring true, has responded in kind. Political Memo, B5.
 
HOUSANDS AT ANTI-KLAN RALLY
Religious and civic leaders and thousands of residents demonstrated in the heart of the old riverfront city of Newburgh, N.Y., to protest a nearby gathering of neo-Nazis and members and sympathizers of the Ku Klux Klan three weeks ago. "Hate and racism won't survive -- can't survive in a community that has finally come alive," the city's Mayor, Audrey Carey, a black woman, told a crowd the police estimated at 3,000 after a mile-long march up Broadway. "Let us make a definitive and strong statement to those hate mongers -- they will not, will not, will not be tolerated in this community." B5.

HEADLINE: 1,500 ARE LAID OFF IN JERSEY AGENCIES

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The New Jersey Supreme Court opened the way today for the immediate layoff of about 1,500 unionized state workers and the transfer of as many as 5,000 others to new jobs starting Tuesday.
Union officials who had gone to court hoping to stop the layoffs predicted that state services would be thrown into chaos. 
 "The state is going to be faced with unstaffing in many offices," said Vincent Trivelli, a lobbyist for the Communications Workers of America, the state's largest public employees' union. "In some cases you are going to have people in jobs who are unfamiliar with the work and you are going to have some people who are being forced to take $20,000 cuts in salaries."
 
Human Services Hit Hardest
 The layoffs, representing slightly more than 2 percent of the work force, are the largest in New Jersey history and are expected to save the state about $55 million annually.
They involve every department of state government except agriculture and banking. Hardest hit is the Department of Human Services, which is the state's biggest department with about 20,000 employees. The loss of 585 jobs will mean an immediate end to programs like fingerprint checks for potential employees of the department and the testing of newborns for tuberculosis and other disorders.
The Office of the Public Advocate, one of the strongest agencies of its kind in the nation, suffered 29 layoffs. Among them were all the jobs in two of its most important and controversial sections: the Office of Citizen Complaints, which investigated other state agencies, and the Division of Public Interest Advocacy, which handled legal issues like public housing, beach access and fees environmental cases.
The partisan sniping that has long surrounded the question of layoffs continued today. "I feel deeply for every rank-and-file worker who stands to lose a job because of the Florio administration's unwillingness to get rid of patronage plums and needless middle managers," said the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian. "I urge the administration to delay the layoffs voluntarily until this case is settled. The cost to the state would be minimal, and it is still possible for the plaintiffs to prevail."
The State Commissioner of Personnel, Anthony J. Cimino, gave the administration's response to the layoffs. "If the Legislature had worked with Governor Florio's no-layoff budget and explored more humane means of downsizing state government," he said, "this day of sadness and pain could have been avoided altogether."
 
Hearing on Oct. 13
 The Supreme Court's 5-to-2 vote today ended a brief reprieve for 1,510 state workers targeted for layoffs. The decision lifted an injunction that had protected their jobs for the last three days and allowed the state to proceed with the layoffs today.
But the justices also said that they would hold a hearing on Oct. 13 to consider two related questions: whether the Legislature's demand that the administration lay off only managers violated the separation-of-powers provisions in the constitution and whether the administration's decision to ignore that order was legal.
Coming four months after they were announced, two months after notices were issued and three days after a court-ordered respite, the layoffs were anticlimactic for most of those who lost their jobs today.
"It seems most of the farewells were last week," said Joe LaPlaca, owner of Joe's Mill Hill Saloon, one of Trenton's more popular nightspots. "We had a big number of laid-off state workers on Friday who were here bidding their farewells."
 
764 Jobs Said to Be Saved
 For the first time in weeks, there were no union protesters outside the State House today.
At midafternoon, Mr. Cimino distributed a three-paragraph memorandum to all departments, advising them of the court decision. "Accordingly," the memo said, "all layoffs and displacements which were scheduled to take effect at the close of business on Oct. 2, 1992, should be implemented at 5 P.M. today."
Mr. Cimino said the final layoff figure would be 1,510, including 113 nonunion employees who have been laid off in the last six weeks.
 
'Bumping' by Seniority
 In August, Mr. Cimino announced 2,376 anticipated layoffs, but he said today that 764 jobs had been saved by transfers to federally financed programs or to fee-supported jobs.
Mr. Trivelli said the impact of the layoffs will not match the disruption caused by "bumping," the Civil Service practice of allowing senior workers to displace junior colleagues within their departments.
Over the last two months, state personnel officials have held private interviews with all of the employees affected by the layoffs to determiine if they were able to bump and where.
Mr. Trivelli said that as many as 5,000 state workers who received layoff notices were able to stay on the payroll by bumping other workers. In many cases, he said, the senior workers will take drastic cuts in pay, will find themselves doing work they graduated from 20 years ago or will be faced with unfamiliar jobs.
"It is going to be a disaster," said Mr. Trivelli, whose union represents about 38,000 of the 70,000 state employees. "These layoffs are bad for everybody. It's bad for the economy, it's bad for the people who are losing service, and of course it's bad for the people who are being laid off."
A spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services, Winnie Comfort, said the level of disruption caused by bumping would depend on the jobs involved.
 
Little Changes, Big Changes
 "The process generally is that you can bump into the same title, and some titles are very specific and they define the role," she said, so some changes will have little impact.
She gave the example of a family-service specialist, the department's job title for a caseworker. "In that job title," she said, "some workers may have to take on new cases in new towns and may have to learn a new telephone system in a new office, but the job is the same kind of work."
At the other extreme, Ms. Comfort cited the position of quality-assurance specialist. Under that job title, she said, there are employees who oversee the siting and operation of group homes for the developmentally disabled. But the title also includes workers who survey heating systems in various government buildings.
"Conceivably, a quality-assurance specialist now working within the developmentally disabled system could wind up tomorrow inspecting heating systems," Ms. Comfort said.
 
Long, Partisan Debate
 The layoffs have been at the center of a long, frequently nasty partisan debate between Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, and the Republican-controlled Legislature.
Mr. Florio has charged that the layoffs result from a record $1.1 billion reduction in the state budget that the Republicans approved in June over his veto. The $14.6 billion budget included language that mandated layoffs, but it targeted 1,400 nonunion managers earning $50,000 or more annually. Later, the Republicans passed even stronger legislation to protect certain departments from layoffs and to demand that nonunion managers be laid off before any unionized workers were let go.
Mr. Florio, whose budget plan in January did not call for layoffs, said he found the Republican demands unworkable and unconstitutional.
The Communications Workers, joined last week by two freshman Republican legislators, Senator Richard LaRossa and Assemblyman John Hartmann, sued Mr. Florio to block layoffs among union workers.
Hours before the layoffs were to take effect on Friday, Judge Alan B. Handler of the State Supreme Court issued a temporary injunction barring the administration from proceeding until the full court had a chance to review the case today.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS REBUFFS BUSH IN OVERRIDE OF CABLE TV VETO

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Congress voted tonight to override President Bush's veto of legislation to regulate cable television companies, breaking his streak of 35 successful vetoes.
The bill itself, which would authorize regulation of minimum cable service and seek to encourage competition, was almost lost in the politics of the moment. Democrats, who have waited four years to defeat Mr. Bush on such a test of strength, exulted, and Republicans were split over what the vote meant. 
 Senator Bob Dole, the Republican minority leader, said of the vote, "This is politics" and an effort to embarrass Mr. Bush. But another Republican, Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, a sponsor of the bill, said it was only a "disagreement."
 
The President's Reasoning
 President Bush argued in his veto message that the bill would stifle the growing cable and telecommunciations industries, and that increased regulation would lead to higher, not lower, cable rates.
In the end, Republicans were critical to the 74-to-25 Senate margin, and to the 308-to-114 vote in the House, both well over the two-thirds majority required to override a veto.
Action on cable legislation was a theatrical high point for a typical, slogging pre-adjournment day of legislation. The long-awaited urban aid tax bill took hours and hours to finally emerge from conference. The House planned to stay in session all night to vote on the tax bill and other matters.
Filibuster threats killed handgun-control and fetal-tissue legislation in the Senate, and menaced both the energy bill and hopes of adjourning Tuesday. The oddest note of the day was that Senate action was delayed when 13 bills passed by the House were sent to a trash dump by mistake, and had to be reconstructed from notes and other copies.
As for Mr. Bush, his weekend efforts to win converts from his party on the cable issue were a failure. In the Senate, for example, 24 Republicans joined 50 Democrats in voting to override, with 18 Republicans and 7 Democrats voting to sustain.
The cable vote was both a setback for the President at a time when his struggling campaign for re-election hardly needs any reverses, and an apparent sign of his eroding political influence. And even though one overridden veto setback after a string of successes hardly proves his basic veto strategy a failure, it could undermine his campaign argument that legislative "gridlock" is caused by Democrats in Congress.
In this case, lawmakers -- who have their own elections to worry about -- were able to vote for legislation sure to please most cable television customers, regardless of how much the bill actually affects cable rates. And for the Democrats, this vote could be taken to show that for a moment at least, Mr. Bush was only an ineffective obstacle to doing something voters would like.
Mr. Bush's argument against the evils of regulation did not sway votes. Indeed, many lawmakers wondered privately why he had chosen to make a stand on this issue, concluding either that he felt strongly on the principle or had lost track of the likelihood of defeat.
When the Senate debate verged onto the merits of the bill, the arguments were familiar. Senator Joe Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, assailed the "highway robbery" of cable companies, which were deregulated in 1984. "In the absence of regulation," he said, "the cable industry has relentlessly raised rates on the American consumer, year after year."
 
Opposing Regulation
 Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, argued that it was a mistake to change the rules on the cable companies, which had been prospering and growing and creating employment. "We're starting down another path that is going to cost us jobs -- reregulation," he said.
Each side argued that the other's approach would be more costly to consumers, and each found ammunition in the many provisions of the bill. For besides allowing regulation of rates and seeking to encourage competition, the bill would also allow over-the-air broadcasters to seek payments from cable companies that carry their broadcasts. The movie industry bitterly opposed the bill because there was no provision for it to share in such payments.
The bill would also force big cable companies that produce programs like those on HBO to make their programs available to competing cable companies.
Several Republicans spoke out for overriding the veto. But the group that Mr. Bush had lobbied hard over the weekend, primarily Republicans not up for election this year, gave him no votes they had not cast when the Senate approved this bill on Sept. 22 by an identical tally of 74 to 25.
One of them, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, said: "Although I believe the cable industry needs some form of regulation, this was not an easy vote for me because I believe the whole legislative process on this matter has been manipulated by the Democrats to embarrass the President. However, in the final analysis, I think this bill is good for the consumers of America, and so I voted to override."
President Bush issued a statement saying, "We stood for lower cable bills for the consumer through increased competition."
As Congress met into the night, House and Senate negotiators worked on a compromise tax bill. The compromise had been approved in principle on Saturday night, but staff members and lawmakers had to iron out relatively minor disagreements before sending the bill forward for votes.
House Republicans caucused on the measure this afternoon, and some senior Republicans said there was considerable sentiment against it, if not enough to defeat it on the floor.
Assuming it is passed by both the House and Senate, the $27 billion measure, which includes both tax cuts and counterbalancing tax increases, faces the possibility of a Presidential veto.
President Bush was noncommittal when asked on the "Good Morning America" television program on ABC what he would do if the bill reached his desk. "I have some real reservations about part of it," he said, "but the problem is they always send me something that has some of the things I want, and then loaded up with, in this instance, taxes.
The tax bill includes billions of dollars in urban aid in the form of enterprise zones, housing incentives and the like. It also includes a $3 billion package of provisions meant to provide assistance to distressed families, for instance by providing money to states to pay social workers.
 
An Energy Bill Advances
 Before the cable issue came to the floor, the major legislative action of the day was the House's adoption of the House-Senate compromise on energy legislation. The measure, which passed by a comfortable margin of 363 to 60, would encourage the use of alternative fuels, efficient homes and appliances but do little directly to increase production of oil or reduce consumption of gasoline.
Even so, Representative Philip R. Sharp, Democrat of Indiana, the bill's floor manager, contended that the measure was a critical first step "to substantially reduce our dependency on foreign oil, reduce the risk to our economy of disruptions in price or supply, reduce the deficit, protect consumers and begin to control our own energy future."
"Unlike some of the major energy programs of the 1970's," he said, "we have done this in a way that relies on existing state and industrial programs and standards, rather than on developing Federal regulations and bureaucracy."
There indeed was a Congressional consensus behind the bill, from its acceleration of the licensing of nuclear power plants, to its attempts to enhance competition in electric power production, to lower mortgage rates for better-insulated homes and to promote energy-efficient light bulbs and shower heads.
But the bill was denied quick action in the Senate because Nevada's Senators opposed a provision that would accelerate the development of a nuclear waste storage project in their state. They threatened to hold up the Senate's planned Tuesday adjournment to fight the bill.
Before the energy bill came up, the House passed the last two spending bills of the year and sent them to the Senate. It adopted a $253 billion military spending bill on a voice vote, and a $13.9 billion foreign-aid bill that included $417 million for Russia and the other states of the former Soviet Union, and an increase in spending, to $350 million, on population control programs internationally.
Before getting around to actually voting on any legislation, Senate Democrats took the floor to complain that President Bush was not helping them persuade Republicans to allow votes on two contentious bills. One would have made it easier to do research on the use of transplanted tissue from aborted fetuses to treat Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease and diabetes. The other would have imposed a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, announced he would make the fetal-tissue legislation, which is part of a measure setting priorities for the National Institutes of Health, the first order of business when the Senate returns in January. He said he would keep the Senate in session until it is passed. The bill has only 12 opponents in the Senate, but in the waning hours of a Congress their filibuster threat was effective.
Senator Bob Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, said the bill would cost lives because "a mother somewhere may decide to have an abortion to donate tissue to a fetal-tissue bank." He said the bill would amount to "legalizing the harvest of fetal tissue from abortions."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, said Senator Smith was misrepresenting the legislation and its safeguards. He said this was further evidence of President Bush's subservience to "his extremist supporters in the anti-abortion movement."
"The issue of fetal tissue research should be decided by research doctors in their laboratories, not by spin doctors in the White House or Congress," he said.
The handgun legislation, known as the Brady bill for its chief outside sponsor, James Brady, the former White House press secretary, was also pushed by Mr. Mitchell. He cited the support for the bill from past Presidents and past Attorneys General, but under the parliamentary circumstances, he had to ask unanimous consent for its consideration.
Senator Larry Craig, Republican of Idaho, objected and the bill was dead. He said the bill would give the police too much power to deny handguns to people.
Senator Jocelyn Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, said the bill was not a panacea for crime but "would give us a little more assurance that those who are not in control of their faculties" would not be armed.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Poll;
Poll Finds Hostility to Perot And No Basic Shift in Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Ross Perot's return to the 1992 Presidential campaign has been greeted with overwhelming hostility by American voters, leaving the contest fundamentally unchanged, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Gov. Bill Clinton holds a persistent lead over President Bush as the campaign enters its final month.
Mr. Perot, who briefly surged to the top of some polls last spring, has a remarkably negative image in the new survey, with 80 percent of the people who once supported him but no longer do saying they do not trust him. 
 While Mr. Perot has yet to begin his advertising campaign, only 7 percent of the registered voters said they planned to vote for him, about the same as John Anderson's support in October 1980 and well below George Wallace's in October 1968. Seventy-two percent said he should not have rejoined the campaign, which he bolted in July.
 
Grim Findings for Bush
 The new survey, based on telephone interviews with 1,252 adults, also has grim findings for the Bush campaign, which has high hopes that Mr. Perot can splinter the anti-Bush vote and help shake up the race. Even in a three-way contest, Mr. Clinton retains a lead, with 46 percent of the probable electorate, to 38 percent for Mr. Bush and 7 percent for Mr. Perot.
More ominously, several of Mr. Bush's most important ratings remain poor. Only 37 percent of all adults approve of the way Mr. Bush is doing his job, down from 42 percent last month. Economic issues continue to dominate the voters' agenda, and only 16 percent in the poll approve of Mr. Bush's economic stewardship.
More voters do view Mr. Clinton unfavorably than did so in September, a central goal for the Bush campaign. But Mr. Bush's unfavorable rating has also risen, and he remains burdened with a much more negative image than the Democratic nominee.
 
Make-or-Break Opportunity
 In general, the poll underscores what is widely accepted in political circles: the coming series of three Presidential debates is a make-or-break opportunity for Mr. Bush to revive his campaign. Sixty-seven percent of the registered voters said it was very likely that they would watch the first debate on Sunday and 54 percent said they expected to learn something from it.
The survey, conducted Friday through Sunday, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Perot's long tease over re-entering the race, which culminated in his announcement on Thursday, carried a clear price in public esteem. The survey shows that only 11 percent of the registered voters accept Mr. Perot's argument that he re-entered the race at the behest of his volunteers.
Just 7 percent of the registered voters voiced a favorable opinion of Mr. Perot, while 59 percent viewed him unfavorably, a marked decline from last spring, when the Texas billionaire first burst onto the political scene and also from a CBS poll in late September.
Fifty-six percent of the voters said Mr. Perot's presence in the race had been a distraction, while 32 percent said it had helped focus the campaign on real issues. Mr. Perot was given the edge in one area: 51 percent said he was "tough enough to make the hard decisions necessary to reduce the Federal budget deficit," while 42 percent said the same for Mr. Bush, and 46 percent for Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Perot was also seen by 40 percent of the voters as saying "what he really believes most of the time," while 45 percent said he was saying what he thought the voters wanted to hear.
But the poll, in general, shows an enormous loss of influence by Mr. Perot. Eighty-eight percent said it would make no difference if he endorsed Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton. Only 1 percent said they expected Mr. Perot to win.
 
Concern About Mistakes
 Mr. Perot was no longer regarded as a legitimate agent of change; only 16 percent agreed that electing him would "bring about the kind of change the country needs," while 69 percent said it would not. And only 12 percent said Mr. Perot could "be trusted to deal with all the problems a President has to deal with," while 75 percent said they were concerned that he "might make serious mistakes."
The survey, while conducted before Mr. Perot begins his advertising campaign and enters the debates, nevertheless tends to support predictions by many analysts that he will eventually fare much as independent or third party candidates have fared in the recent past. Mr. Anderson, who was at 9 percent in the polls in October 1980, eventually received 7 percent of the popular vote. Mr. Wallace, who was at 15 percent in the October 1968 polls, received 14 percent of the popular vote.
On a national level, Mr. Perot seems to be drawing fairly evenly from both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton.
The overall race seems to have changed little from the last New York Times/CBS News Poll in mid-September; Mr. Clinton has an eight-point advantage among the probable electorate in the current poll, compared with a seven-point advantage in September. Mr. Perot was the choice of 13 percent then, and 7 percent now.
Results based on the probable electorate reflect each respondent's likelihood of voting. Among all registered voters, Mr. Clinton's lead in the latest poll was also eight points.
 
Symmetrical Toll
 The escalating attacks being exchanged by the Bush and Clinton campaigns have taken an eerily symmetrical toll: 33 percent said Mr. Clinton had not told the truth about his draft history, up from 25 percent last month, while 63 percent said Mr. Bush was hiding something that the public ought to know about the Iran-contra affair, up from 55 percent. But overwhelming majorities said those issues would not affect their votes.
In general, the public's attention remains riveted on the ailing economy, which may help explain why voters seem to be paying more attention to the Presidential campaign this year: 54 percent of the registered voters said they had been paying "a lot" of attention to this campaign, compared with 34 percent in October 1988.
The perception of the economy remains bleak, with 79 percent of all adults rating it bad or very bad. And they clearly hold the President accountable: 59 percent said the economy was "something that an effective President could do a lot about."
Mr. Bush retains some strengths. His approval rating for foreign policy is 54 percent, and he continues to hold a slight edge in trustworthiness to "handle all the problems a President has to deal with." Moreover, Mr. Clinton is considered by 35 percent of the voters as more likely to raise taxes, compared with 10 percent who said Mr. Bush was.
The poll indicates that expectations are high for Mr. Clinton in the coming debate: 41 percent said they expected Mr. Clinton to win it, while 24 percent predicted a victory for Mr. Bush, and 8 percent for Mr. Perot.
The survey shows an anti-incumbent mood among the voters about Congressional candidates, with 39 percent saying their representative deserved re-election and 51 percent saying it was time to give a new person a chance.
The Democrats have a slight edge in Congressional races; 44 percent of the probable electorate said they intended to vote for a Democrat for Congress, while 39 percent said they would back a Republican.
When asked to rate the parties, people gave the Democrats the edge on handling unemployment, the Republicans the edge on handling foreign economic competition and divided narrowly between the two over which was better at dealing with inflation.
The Times/CBS News poll was consistent with other new surveys. A Washington Post/ABC News poll released last night showed Mr. Clinton with 48 percent of likely voters, Mr. Bush with 35 percent and Mr. Perot with 9 percent, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. A USA Today/CNN/ Gallup Poll released yesterday showed Mr. Clinton with 47 percent, Mr. Bush with 35 percent and Mr. Perot with 10 percent, with a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Friday through Sunday with 1,252 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 994 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers.
Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
The findings related to voting are reported in terms of an overall "probable electorate" of 934 respondents, which uses responses to questions dealing with voter registration, past voting history, and the likelihood of voting in 1992 as a measure of the probability of particular respondents' voting in November.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in the country. The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for results based on registered men it is plus or minus five percentage points, while for registered women it is four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. For example, differences in the wording and order of questions can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Learning if Infants Are Hurt When Mothers Go to Work

SERIES: The Good Mother: Minding the Children -- Third article of a series:

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
An infant girl squirms among the toys at a day-care center, saying "ahh, ahh" and reaching out. The teacher, who is holding another infant in her arms, smiles at the girl, says "Want to play ball?" and reaches over to push a beach ball into the infant's lap.
It hardly seems the stuff of high science, let alone Presidential politics. But these everyday actions of teacher and baby, scored by a watchful researcher in dozens of categories like "responds to child's vocalizations" and "positive physical contact," are yielding specks of data in a vast national study designed to answer some of the most emotionally charged questions in science and society today: Do working mothers imperil their children's inner security and future happiness? Does day care at an early age put children on a slow track for life?
 
Complicated Research
 
 One of the most complex research projects ever undertaken in the behavioral sciences, the federally sponsored study of more than 1,300 randomly selected babies is searching for both the patterns of early care that may help a child thrive and patterns that may hinder learning or emotional development.
The goal is as incontestably good as motherhood, but the researchers pursuing it at 10 universities around the country know they are poking into giant passions. The issues at the heart of the research have generated acid exchanges among scientists, sown fear and guilt among millions of parents, been fashioned into rhetorical clubs for bashing or defending feminism and even provided raw material for this year's Presidential campaign.
The inner conflict and public debate reflect a swift transformation of the American family. It is not just that more mothers work. Since the 1950's, the change has been most striking among mothers of the youngest children.
By 1976, the first year the Census Bureau asked the precise question, 31 percent of mothers with a child under the age of 1 were in the labor force. By 1990, driven by economic need and changing attitudes about personal fulfillment, 53 percent of such mothers were. The trend was most pronounced among college graduates with infants less than a year old: 68 percent worked.
With the increased reliance on day care and baby-sitting arrangements came the questions and the defiant, often self-justifying assertions. Gradually, too, has come the research, which scientists agree has not yet provided conclusive answers.
"Most of the research up to now has assumed that all day care is comparable," said Bettye Caldwell, an expert on child development at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock and a leader of the new study. "But we know that's not true. There's excellent care and abysmal care, and care by the families differs dramatically, too."
In the late 1980's, Jay Belsky of Pennsylvania State University said accumulating evidence suggested that extensive, early nonmaternal care might be harming some children. His statement created a professional uproar, and the subject was hashed out on talk shows and in midnight discussions of countless working parents.
 
Some Broad Agreements
 While the debate continues today, there are also wide areas of agreement among the experts, including these items:
*The debate is largely over care in the first year of life. Even the minority of studies that raise alarms about extensive, early nonmaternal care find few differences in cognitive, social and behavioral traits when care begins after the age of 1, though of course the quality of care matters at any age.
*Any harm from early nonmaternal care itself is small, and most children of working mothers are unaffected in the traits that were measured.
*For children from poor families, early, high-quality day care often means improved scores.
*Even if early outside care does no harm, having a parent at home full-time for at least the first three or four months is an intrinsically good thing for both parents and children.
Whatever their views of the evidence, child-development experts lament the wearying stresses that afflict many two-earner families and are virtually unanimous in their calls for generous parental-leave policies, improved availability and quality of day care and greater flexibility in the workplace to allow, for example, more part-time work.
To some degree, a strident academic debate that came to be seen as a referendum on feminism and women's work has softened as experts acknowledged that most mothers are in the work force to stay. Attention has shifted to evidence that much of the day care provided in this country, both in centers and the private homes that provide most nonparental care, does not meet high standards in crucial areas like the number of children per adult, whether children see the same adults over time and whether children receive warm, responsive, individual attention.
"I'm very worried, not because so many women are working -- they are, and it's economic -- but because the quality of infant care in this country typically is not good." said Ellen Galinsky, co-president of the Families and Work Institute, a research group in New York.
 
Clarifying a Stand
 Dr. Belsky, an investigator in the new national study, clarified his assertions about possible risks of early maternal work in a recent interview. "I wasn't saying anything about the inevitable effects of day care," he said. "I was talking about care as we have it in this country."
Alison Clarke-Stewart, a psychologist at the University of California at Irvine, an investigator in the new study and a critic of Dr. Belsky, said: "I do think it is important for an infant to form a close attachment with a parent. I'm less convinced a mother can't still do that when she works.
"I think it's pretty hard to do if you are working long hours every day. In the best of all worlds, everybody would have access to part-time work."
Scholars in this field have mainly studied the role of mothers as primary care-givers, not out of sexist bias, they say, but because fathers who truly play this role remain so rare. Most say they believe that a father could take much the same place in an infant's life.
 
The Old Debate
A Study in 1986 Raised a Warning
 Much research on child care and development has focused on infant-mother attachment, a quality many psychologists consider a cornerstone of emotional and social development. This theory says children with a secure attachment, usually to the mother, in infancy are more likely to feel confident as they explore their surroundings, to have good relations with peers and teachers and to be more competent at solving problems, said Susan Spieker, a psychologist at the University of Washington. Scientists are unsure about how lasting and immutable the effects are.
Although researchers increasingly try to observe real-life interactions, the security of infant-mother attachment is usually measured in "strange situation" experiments. In such tests, babies at about 12 to 18 months are typically left alone in a room for a few minutes with a friendly stranger, then rejoined by their mothers, then left all alone before their mother returns again. Studying how the babies respond to the separations and especially the reunions, psychologists judge whether the child is securely or insecurely attached.
In 1986 Dr. Belsky created a furor when, citing data from several strange-situation studies and behavioral observations, he said that extensive nonmaternal care in the first year appeared to pose a degree of risk in development of insecure attachments in infancy and "heightened aggressiveness, noncompliance, and withdrawal in the preschool and early school years."
Many of his colleagues reacted sharply, asserting, among other things, that the differences he had found were small, that the study samples may have been biased, that the strange situation may be an inappropriate test for children accustomed to separations and, above all, that differing outcomes were almost certainly related to quality of care, rather than the fact of nonmaternal care.
At a "summit meeting" in 1987 the warring parties agreed with the proposition that when parents have access to "stable child-care arrangements featuring skilled, sensitive and motivated care-givers, there is every reason to believe that both children and families can thrive."
The gap was narrowed, but differences remain. Dr. Belsky, who believes he has been pilloried by ideologues, says he still believes it is possible that future evidence will show that early, extensive day care in and of itself is harmful to some infants.
"I think what we've got here is a cause for concern, nothing to call for alarm and hysteria," Dr. Belsky said. While most children are not harmed, he said, the small number who are would add up to a social problem. For example, it could be an extra disruptive child or two in a classroom.
But Deborah Phillips, a psychologist at the University of Virginia who is also participating in the Federal project, said: "There's a world of difference between saying that child care is harmful, and saying that when care falls below a threshold of quality it places a child at risk. Then you talk about quality, instead of who's providing the care. That's a very different issue. "
 
More Research
More Ambiguities, Fewer Certainties
 A new, more extensive analysis of 13 strange-situation studies, just published by Michael E. Lamb and others at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, also found a difference between babies whose mothers stayed home through the first year and those who received other care. But the difference was small: 71 percent of those with exclusive maternal care were judged to be securely attached, while 65 percent of those with regular nonmaternal care were. None of the studies measured the quality of care, and the families studied had above-average incomes and were almost all white.
A few other recent studies, looking at actual behavior and at cognitive tests in a large number of 3- and 4-year-olds, have also found small differences. But Jeanne Brooks-Gunn, a psychologist at Columbia University and an author of a study published in 1991, explained why the results should be received with caution. The detrimental impact of first-year maternal employment, while significant, accounted for only a minor part of the variations between the groups of children, the study found. Other factors like poverty, the mother's education and the number of adults in the household had greater effect, she said.
Numerous similar studies have suggested intriguing or surprising patterns. For example, some have found that children did better if the mother returned to work earlier rather than later in the first year, or that boys with nonmaternal care scored more poorly than girls. Some have found that infants raised by grandmothers or baby sitters in the home did as well as those raised by their mothers. But these results have sometimes been contradictory and were seldom presented with scientific confidence.
 
The New Project
Clear Answers Are Being Sought
 The new Federal study, sponsored by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, is intended through its large size, broad scope and intricate design to provide the clearest answers yet. Begun in 1991 and scheduled to last five years, it is registering not only the types of care that children receive but also evaluating the emotional texture of care, both from outsiders and from parents.
"We're trying to far more carefully identify the actual pattern of the child's experience than has been done in the past," said Robert Bradley, a psychologist at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. "We're looking at the place of care, we're looking at the same child at home with his mother, and we are also looking at the child's individual temperament and needs."
The children's development is being evaluated in several ways. At the age of 15 months, maternal attachment is measured in strange-situation experiments, but attachment will also be examined through direct observations in the home at the age of 2. Cognitive and language development, peer relations, self-control and compliance with parents and teachers will all be evaluated.
The newly detailed look at the home environment, for children of working as well as stay-at-home mothers, should provide far more subtle conclusions than ever before. "For example," Dr. Bradley asked, "if a child has problems, is it a function of the outside care, or is it because the mother is overworked and worried about money, and not enjoying child-rearing?"
Researchers may begin analyzing early data in about two years, said Sarah L. Friedman, project director at the national institute, but most results will not come until later. Despite the enthusiastic cooperation of academic foes and the unusual richness of data, experts warn that no study is apt to provide a simple blueprint.
"Both sides are excited about it for now," Dr. Belsky said. But "there will be different spin doctors" interpreting the data, and "to the extent people think they'll get a green light or a red light, they'll be disappointed," he added. For many mothers, work and child care are givens in any case, but better information may help them seek the care that is best for their child, and create the best home environment.
Whatever the study finds, none of the child-development experts are apt to advocate the kind of stressful return to work in as little as six weeks that some working women face today.
"I feel very strongly that mothers and infants need a certain period together after birth to learn the rhythms of each other's life," Dr. Caldwell said. "Once that happens and that attachment is there, we know it can survive."
She said there was ample reason to promote parental leave without assuming that early day care is harmful.
"The experience of being a mother of a young infant is a grand and glorious one," Dr. Caldwell said. "And the most precious thing in a relationship is time. I think there is a difference between saying that something is better to do, and saying something is wrong or harmful."

HEADLINE: Brazil Takes Turn to the Left; New Chief Makes Slow Start

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Only three days after Itamar Franco became Acting President, Brazil appears to be drifting toward left-wing nationalism, with the Workers' Party scoring strongly in mayoral elections and Mr. Franco attacking "foreign interests."
Slow to fill a power vacuum left by the impeachment of Fernando Collor de Mello last week, Mr. Franco is acting as Brazil's reluctant President. Although he denounced his predecessor's plans to maintain a "parallel government," Mr. Franco discussed his own Government today in terms of "however long it lasts." 
 "Second rate start," said the cover today of Veja, a major news weekly.
Reflecting the malaise, Sao Paulo's stock market index dropped 5 percent today, after an 8 percent drop Friday.
Results announced today from mayoral elections Saturday showed that candidates of the Workers' Party, a Socialist group that propelled the impeachment drive, reached runoff elections in four of Brazil's largest cities.
 
Party 'the Big Winner'
 "Post-impeachment Brazil has a left to center-left face," the newspaper, Folha de Sao Paulo, concluded today.
In Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, the Workers' Party candidate, Eduardo Suplicy, forced his rightist opponent, Paulo Maluf, into a runoff after volunteers papered the city with photographs of the rightist as best man at Mr. Collor's wedding in 1984.
Business disillusionment has spread with Mr. Franco's choice of a politician and lawyer from the impoverished northeast as Finance Minister of the nation with Latin America's highest inflation rate and the third world's largest foreign debt.
 
'Suffering People' Cited
 Responding to press criticism that his new Finance Minister does not speak English, Mr. Franco shot back that Brazil "needs to forget a little about New York, Manhattan, and think about its slums, its suffering people."
"What is modernity?" he asked, referring to a Collor slogan. "Is it defending foreign interests, or defending the interests of our country?"
Mr. Franco also charged that Mr. Collor planned to operate a "parallel government" out of "a bunker" during his trial on corruption charges. If Mr. Collor is acquitted, he will automatically reassume presidential powers.
On Saturday, Mr. Collor sent Mr. Franco a request for presidential privileges while out of power: offices, a professional staff of 20, a helicopter, official cars, free airline tickets, and the support of Brazilian embassies.
 
Prison Inquiry Urged
 While Mr. Franco grumbled about this list, Mr. Collor upstaged the acting President in his first crisis: the killing of more than 100 inmates in a Sao Paulo jail on Friday. While Mr. Franco has been mute on the scandal, Mr. Collor called the killings "horrifying" and urged an impartial inquiry.
The prisoners said 200 died in the police attack. Officials put the figure at 111.
Today, the Governor of Sao Paulo State, Luis Antonio Fleury, announced the dismissal of the prison director and five high-ranking police commanders involved in the violence.
