HEADLINE: Storm Left Hard Future For Hawaii's Lush Island

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIHUE, Hawaii, Oct. 1

 BODY:
For the last dozen years, Will Squyres, a former helicopter gunship pilot in South Vietnam, has carried tourists up over the spectacular natural wonders of Kauai. But this day he somewhat reluctantly agreed to fly a visiting photographer and reporter to see what Hurricane Iniki had done to what many consider the most beautiful of the Hawaiian Islands.
His Jet Ranger lifted over Kawaikini, the 5,243-foot volcanic peak. Below, stands of Norfolk pines, koa and eucalyptus trees could be seen flattened like match sticks. The Alakai swamp hardly looked touched, but soon the famed remote Na Pali Coast came into view, its spectacular bluffs scoured by storm erosion and the trail that is the only land access washed out. 
 "This will all come back soon," insisted Mr. Squyres, as much public relations man as pilot. "We are already starting to get green."
Three weeks after the fierce hurricane swept in from the southwest with 160-mile-an-hour winds, the residents of the oldest and westernmost important island of this archipelago state have begun to face a tough future with a mix of grit, weariness and a caring family spirit known here as ohana.
 
Astonishing Destruction
 A two-day tour of the 30-mile-wide island found astonishing destruction. Great tangled masses of downed electric and phone wires line almost every street, along with piles of mattresses, washing machines and other ruined household items. The lush gardens that gave the island its sobriquet, The Garden Island, are mostly gone now, though leaves have already sprouted. In spots, the lush rain forest looks as though a giant weedwhacker had rushed through.
Naturalists worry that four plant species may have been wiped out by the hurricane, and the population of certain rare birds may be even more precarious. The tourism industry is almost as hard hit, and the damage forced the Pentagon to postpone tests of new missile systems from a base here intended to help develop "Star Wars" weapons.
But the everyday problems take center stage for most residents.
Crews from as far away as Southern California are restoring the electric system, but so far only a fifth of the 24,469 homes and businesses have power, and only about half have telephone service. Most people, including Mayor JoAnn A. Yukimura, are still living in damaged homes with candles, flashlights and cold showers, praying that heavy rains will not come before they repair their roofs. About 7,000 homes were destroyed or rendered unfit for habitation.
But with help from 5,000 soldiers from the United States Army and the Hawaii National Guard, the roads were all clear by today. Electric generators roared everywhere, and grocery stores had reopened. On Rice Street, the main thoroughfare of Lihue, City Liquor was selling cold beer, Kawamoto's Barber Shop was open mornings and Dani's Restaurant was doing a thriving business feeding the construction and demolition workers.
 
Blow to Tourist Industry
 And folks were trading stories, like the one about the teen-age boys who returned home the other day from Honolulu with food and other survival donations from family friends. The boys spurned bags of rice, thinking that rice could not be cooked without an electric rice maker.
But it was not as easy to chuckle over the island's future, either from the point of view of the tourist economy or the fragile natural environment.
On a typical day, the island's 51,177 residents would be joined by nearly 20,000 tourists, who form the backbone of the economy. About half the island's work force of 28,700 people appears to have lost their regular jobs, although many have been able to shift to reconstruction work.
Nearly all the 7,846 hotel rooms have been wrecked, and most hotels do not expect to reopen before early next year.
"The immediate crisis is over," Mayor Yukimura said. "We have water, and food distribution is going fairly well." But she said the more difficult problem was restoring the tourist industry. "All our services are not at optimum," she said. "We cannot welcome visitors back now." But she expressed optimism that the natural environment would recover quickly.
 
Endangered Species
 Naturalists were less sure about what would grow back. Though hurricanes are part of the natural cycle here, numerous birds and plants have been pushed to the brink of extinction in recent decades by human introduction of outside plants that crowd out native vegetation and eliminate important habitats. The introduced species include banana poka, a Central American vine that smothers trees.
Among the endangered species are water birds like the Hawaiian duck and the Hawaiian coot and forest birds like the Kauai Akialoa and the Kauai thrush.
"A lot of these species are on the edge -- this didn't help," said Ronald L. Walker, wildlife program manager at the Hawaii Department of Land and Natural Resources.
Wildlife experts fanned out in recent days to assess the damage and are considering reseeding certain areas by air. There is also concern about fire, given all the dead trees.
Iniki has also raised questions about the Strategic Target System, a series of missile launchings the Army had planned to make from the western edge of the island as part of the Strategic Defense Initiative, or "Star Wars." The launchings, scheduled to start in November after years of protest and delay, are to send Polaris missiles southwest across the Pacific in a test to mimic intercontinental ballistic missiles to be shot down.
The program has been bitterly fought by some residents on the ground that a failed launching could damage the environment. The leader of this group, Elizabeth Freeman, a graphic designer in Hanaeli, traveled to Washington after the hurricane and lobbied for a moratorium. On Sept. 29, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, issued a vague announcement that the launchings had been postponed indefinitely until the island recovered from Iniki.
Still, the launchings have considerable local support. The military base, the Barking Sands Pacific Missile Range, employs nearly 700 people, and, with widespread unemployment after the storm, it has not gone unnoticed that the base was one of the few employers who retained all of its workers. The military's efficient and much appreciated relief efforts have not hurt either.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Day;
Clinton Pushes Hard in Florida, as Bush Support Slips

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 5

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore declared today that the Democrats would win Florida because President Bush had abandoned the state, which has been won by the Republicans in all but two Presidential elections since 1952.
The Democratic nominees for President and Vice President touched base with all of the important groups of voters that the Democrats have identified as winnable this year, including students, blacks and the elderly. 
 Their campaign swing here, which was capped by a dusk rally attended by thousands of supporters at the Southeastern Livestock Pavilion, followed Mr. Bush's weekend visit to the state, a trip that apparently became necessary after the Democrats began to show signs of reviving their local fortunes.
Three polls conducted before Ross Perot's return to the campaign have shown the race as a virtual dead heat between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. Florida, which has 25 electoral votes, is considered a vital ingredient in Mr. Bush's re-election bid. In the 1988 general election, Mr. Bush won more than 60 percent of the Florida vote.
 
Message to Ticket-Splitters
 In an area of Florida that Mr. Clinton's aides said was home to some of the state's most independent ticket-splitting voters, the Arkansas Governor tailored his message to Republican and independent voters today, remarking at one roadside rally in Leesburg, "I do not seek a victory of party."
Mr. Bush was campaigning in Dover, Del., today, striving to chip away at Mr. Clinton's credibility.
Speaking of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the President said Mr. Clinton "won't let the facts get in the way" of a politically popular position. On Sunday, Mr. Clinton gave a long-delayed endorsement to the trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, but he conditioned his support on changes that would appease its critics.
At the first stop of the Clinton-Gore bus tour today, in Daytona Beach, Mr. Clinton said the Republicans "have believed for years that they owned Florida in the general election," but he said that would soon end. "You can turn out the lights for trickle-down economics and open a new day for the United States of America," he said.
Mr. Clinton dismissed the possibility that the independent candidacy of Mr. Perot would have an impact on his vote-getting abilities here or elsewhere. A vote for Mr. Perot, he suggested, would be a vote for four more years of Mr. Bush.
"In the end, the American people are going to have to make up their minds whether they want to re-elect George Bush," by voting for Perot, he said. "They'll have to decide."
 
Bush Levels Attack
 Later this evening, Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton returned to the increasingly familiar political forum of a television talk show to criticize Mr. Bush for a tax plan that they said would cut Medicare benefits, an important issue for elderly voters in Florida.
"We said that since he promised not to fool with Social Security, the only way he could do would be to decimate the whole rest of the Federal domestic budget, including Medicare," Mr. Clinton said on the CNN program "Larry King Live."
In his weekend trip to Florida, Mr. Bush leveled his most personal attack of the campaign at Mr. Clinton, ridiculing the Democrat as a slippery character who has been untruthful about his military record and is seeking to scare the elderly by misrepresenting the President's position on Medicaid and Medicare spending.
 
Complaint About Bad-Mouthing
 Today, Mr. Clinton responded, telling the boisterous rally on the shorefront in Daytona Beach that the President was "bad-mouthing me in terms that wouldn't even be used in a race for local college student government."
With Bush-Quayle protesters chanting in the background, Mr. Clinton said the Republicans' campaign was made up of "the most cynical and manipulative bunch I have ever seen."
Mr. Clinton has begun appealing to the states that his strategists now thinks he can win by providing remote television interviews. On Saturday, he spoke to three television stations in Florida and others in Minnesota, Louisiana and North Carolina.
In each case, he has vowed to visit soon and described the Democratic ticket to local interviewers as progressive or conservative, whatever the locality seemed to call for.
In Delaware, Mr. Bush focused on Mr. Clinton's changing positions, with emphasis on the trade agreement. Mr. Bush told a crowd of about 4,000 at the State Capitol that he had fought for the trade pact "every step of the way because it's the right thing to do."
Of Mr. Clinton, he said: "Once upon a time, he said he was for Nafta, the free-trade agreement. Then the labor bosses told him that they were against it. So he said he wasn't sure if he was for it, or against it. Now he's looked at the polls, he's seen that the American people want Nafta, and just yesterday he said he's for it. And then again, maybe he's not.
"It doesn't matter what's right or what's wrong, he just tells people what he thinks they want to hear."
Trailing in public-opinion polls and driven to scramble for support even in tiny Delaware, which has but three of the 270 electoral votes he needs to win, Mr. Bush acknowledged in somber tones that these were "tough political times, and it's been about as ugly a political year as I've ever seen."
"The media has been rolling down the tracks in their own inimitable way," he said, "and it's not been very pleasant."

Quayle Encounters Hostility

 
 SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (Special to The New York Times) -- Vice President Dan Quayle ran into an unfriendly crowd in San Francisco's Chinatown today. After an appearance at a school, Mr. Quayle decided to walk several blocks to a fund-raising event at a restaurant.
But as he strolled along the narrow streets, a crescendo of hostile shouts grew. Chants of "Four more weeks!" and "Shame! Shame! Shame!" along with obscenities, battered the Vice President. Police officers in riot gear and Secret Service agents closed ranks around Mr. Quayle, who appeared stunned by his reception, and hustled him into a car that sped away.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Congress voted to override the veto of cable TV legislation, breaking President Bush's streak of 35 successful vetoes. [Page A1.]
The legislation will make life harder for the cable companies but may not necessarily aid consumers. News Analysis. [A18.]
The fate of unclaimed dividend and interest payments is to be decided by the Supreme Court. New York and Delaware have claimed money that banks and brokerage firms cannot forward to the customers for whom it was intended. [D2.] 
 The House overwhelmingly approved compromise energy legislation that would encourage the use of alternative fuels. But a Senate filibuster threat left final passage in doubt. [D15.]
 
Markets
The world's stock markets plunged, as investors reacted to the political uncertainties of an American election and continued monetary turmoil in Europe. But Wall Street managed to reverse direction and recover nearly 80 percent of its morning losses by the close, with the Dow industrials losing only 21.61 points. [A1.]
The market's volatility is unnerving to individual investors who have transferred money into equities, seeking higher yields. [D1.]
The European selloff was a reaction to the Bundesbank's decision on Friday not to cut interest rates, a move economists believe is essential to improving economic prospects. [D6.]
An interest rate cut by the Fed seems more likely in the wake of the stock market's plunge. [D6.]
Bond prices were little changed in contrast to the stock market's volatility. [D18.]
The dollar rose against most major currencies. [D19.] Cattle futures prices dropped sharply but gold rose. [D19.]
 
Companies
Richard S. Braddock, Citicorp's president, resigned unexpectedly. He was first in line to succeed John S. Reed as chairman, and the departure was called friendly. Citicorp also said that it would report third-quarter earnings of $80 million to $100 million. [D1.]
Marriott plans to spin off its healthy hotel-management business from its ailing real estate operations. [D1.]
Pen computing is languishing. Many industry executives had hoped it would reignite the industry's hypergrowth. [D4.]
G.M. has fallen further behind Ford and Chrysler in productivity, a forthcoming study of the industry shows. [D5.]
Sales of domestically produced vehicles dropped a scant seven-tenths of 1 percent in late September. [D5.]
USAir was struck by machinists and had to cancel a quarter of its flights, but many travelers found other seats. [D4.]
Genzyme priced one of its drugs too high, a Congressional research agency said. [D4.]
A new movie produced by HBO will run on that cable network in January and on NBC only a few months later. [D7.]
 
International
The Mexican Government voiced confidence that Gov. Bill Clinton's qualified endorsement of a North American Free Trade Agreement had cleared the path to its approval. [D1.]
An arm of the Chinese Government was accused by Federal prosecutors in Manhattan of conspiring with its American subsidiary to evade U.S. quotas on clothing imports by false labels. [B1.]
 
Today's Columns
No group is more ambivalent than organized labor on the guns-or-butter issue, for guns often mean jobs. Louis Uchitelle: The Business Scene. [D2.]
A coalition is working to kill a tax break for using certain U.S. savings bonds to pay for college costs. Market Place. [D8.]
A new round of agency mergers seems imminent, although more reasonably priced than the wave of buyouts that roiled the industry in the 1980's. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D21.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
What Worked in 1988 Is No Aid to Bush Now

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
If 1988 is remembered as the year they wrote the book on negative campaigning, 1992 may be the year the book was sent back for revision.
With just four weeks to go until Election Day, George Bush's campaign strategy is starting to look a lot like the one he used four years ago. He is attacking Bill Clinton's fitness to be Commander in Chief (shades of Michael S. Dukakis riding a tank), questioning the Arkansas Governor's patriotism (shades of the Pledge of Allegiance) and attacking his record on the environment (shades of Boston Harbor). 
 Just as they did in 1988, these attacks have a clearly defined goal: to load the opposition down with "negatives" until it eventually sinks under its weight. But unlike in 1988, the attacks do not seem to be having much effect.
In part, this is because of the country's circumstances: It is tough to turn the election into a referendum on your opponent when you have spent the last four years presiding over a recession.
In part, Mr. Bush may also be a victim of his own success. Having shown the country how a successful negative campaign is waged, the Bush campaign should not be surprised to find that the public and the press have become more discriminating.
"What you're seeing is a very self-protective electorate," said Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communications at the University of Pennsylvania, who has written extensively on the effects of negative campaigning. "We may have the first set of conditions to lead to a backlash."
Putting together a successful negative campaign is a lot like putting together a winning movie promotion; the point is to put out the same message through the press, paid commercials and eventually word of mouth. This kind of coordination requires a lot of teamwork and a lot of luck.
Studies of the last election indicate that Mr. Bush's critiques of Mr. Dukakis were effective largely because they were picked up by the press and used to shape the story of the day. In fact, by September 1988 attacks had become the most reliable way for either candidate to get his message on the evening news.
According to the Center for Media and Public Affairs, in the two weeks after Labor Day, 55 percent of all the network news stories quoting Mr. Bush pictured the then-Vice President criticizing Mr. Dukakis. Almost 50 percent of the stories quoting Mr. Dukakis showed him attacking Mr. Bush.
After the 1988 campaign was over, there was even more than usual amount of post-election hand-wringing in newsrooms across the country. The consensus grew among both journalists and political scientists that the press had focused too much on the daily back and forth -- most of it unflattering and much of it irrelevant -- and too little on the long-range issues confronting the country. News executives vowed to use more vigilance against the effects of negative campaigning, and by many standards, at least, they have.
In the two weeks after Labor Day this year, only 25 percent of the stories quoting the President showed him attacking Mr. Clinton; for Mr. Clinton the figure was down to 19 percent.
"There's no doubt that the experience of 1988 has been a factor in the coverage this year," said Bill Wheatley, who directs political coverage at NBC.
Further complicating the President's efforts to get some negative synergy going between his campaign and the press coverage is the economy. Whenever the economy is in the news, which is often, it tends to work against the President's paid advertising and for his opponent.
"The national economic news is an ongoing anti-Bush ad," Ms. Jamieson said.
Finally, there is some evidence that voters, who always maintain they are not affected by negative advertising, are actually resisting it this year.
The Clinton campaign put together mock Bush ads attacking Mr. Clinton, even tougher than those on television now; focus groups exposed to the ads expressed more discomfiture with the commercials than doubts about the Governor. And Shanto Iyengar, a professor of political science at the University of California at Los Angeles , found that six out of the seven candidates in the recent California Senate primary hurt themselves with voters by using negative commercials. In a similar study conducted two years ago, Mr. Iyengar found voters more likely to embrace candidates who used negative ads.
"You're a lot better off giving people an affirmative reason to vote for you," he said.
Given all this, voters might expect the Presidential candidates to spend the next four weeks accentuating the positive. They would be mistaken. The Bush campaign is planning to put new "comparative" commercials on the air this week highlighting further deficiencies in Mr. Clinton's record. The Clinton campaign is planning new attack ads of its own.
Both camps do agree, though, that barring any major new revelations, these attack ads will not have much impact on the outcome of the election.
"The task is much more difficult this time," one Bush campaign aide acknowledged. The ads, he said, can't just raise "fears and doubts and concerns. It has to be something really debilitating."

HEADLINE: Free-Market Ideas Grow on Russian Farms

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRIGOROPOLISSKAYA, Russia

 BODY:
Ask about the "free market" or "reform," and people out on these fertile South Russian plains still begin to snarl.
But ask about the price of wheat or the cost of fuel, and the animated patter tells a different story. A year after the Government began to wean agriculture from the hugely inefficient Soviet system, some tender new shoots of market are appearing in the hardened old collective farms, the kolkhozes. 
 Russian farmers have always had a capitalist streak of sorts. Even during the most Communist of times, peasants were allowed their private plots of land, which in some areas provided most of the meat and vegetables in local markets.
But rare was the farmer who felt any direct responsibility for the collective farm. This is what is changing.
The effect on production is hard to measure. Officials in Moscow say they expect 96 million tons of grain this year, short of the 115 million Russia needs, but 7 million tons above last year's harvest. While no one says the increase was a result of the fledgling market, it confounded the many skeptics who had warned that reforms would destroy agriculture.
The shortage, officials said, will be offset in part through purchases in Kazakhstan and Ukraine and in part through more imports from the West.
The key point, the change in attitude, has become evident over the past 12 months.
Last year, when the first decrees came down proclaiming the new era of the free market, virtually every member of the huge Rossiya collective here -- 1,900 workers on 55,500 rich, black acres in the wheat belt between Krasnodar and Stavropol -- signed a petition to the regional administration saying, in effect, "Leave us alone."
People still go on about "those cockroaches in Moscow" and complain, "What's this country coming to?" But these were some other recent remarks:
"We did a lot of barter last year, but now we can get up to 22 rubles at the exchange."
"We might sell our wheat in Russia and buy the cheaper stuff from Kazakhstan for feed."
"We'll put in less sugar beet next year. The plant is 1,000 kilometers away, and with new fuel costs ----"
"We're looking into our own sunflower press. We could easily pay it off in five years."
Despite all the doomsday warnings last year of collapse and famine after the breakup of the Soviet Union and the Communist system, the wheat crop was respectable, the corn and sunflowers pulled through the drought and the accounts ended up in the black.
 
A Real Cooperative
 The debate is far from over, of course. Kolkhoz members still argue vehemently against parceling out collective land for private farms, and Parliament has not yet crossed the hurdle of private land ownership.
But what is already clear is that the Rossiya kolkhoz, much like the country it is named after, is learning to look to the bottom line.
For one thing, it has become a real cooperative, in which all the workers and pensioners have a formal share. Even the fields look better, because workers have been far more careful harvesting.
On the next rung of the food chain, the grain elevator in the regional center at Novo-Aleksandrovskaya, Raisa Makarenko's job as deputy director used to entail little more than receiving and dispensing state-owned grain. Now she slips naturally into bargaining.
 
Learning to Bargain
 Discussing the ruble price per kilogram of wheat, she said: "If we buy at 12, we have to sell at 21 or 22 to make ends meet. Break-even is 17, with the value-added tax. But here's the problem: I just talked to Yaroslavl and offered them 3,000 tons for 25. They just said no. On the exchanges they're offering 20 to 22, so I had to go for 20."
That meant a loaf of the best bread in Yaroslavl, a city north of Moscow, will sell for about 15 rubles, roughly what it costs today.
Aleksei P. Zalkin, the head of the regional administration at Novo-Aleksandrovskaya, remarked: "We're not used to all this yet, of course. All our life we worked on stern diktat from above," he added, flicking a glance at the unsmiling Lenin still hanging over his desk. "We answered with our head and our party card for every head of cattle.
"But our psychology has changed a lot in the past year. Nobody counted money before. Now a day doesn't pass without a check on the balance sheet. People understand that it will never be, that it can't be, as it was."
And Lenin? "Oh, we'll get to that when we have time."
 
It Was the Peasants' Fault
 Here in Russia's heartland, it is hard to blame people for not rushing to take down their Lenins. Reforms came and went with brutal regularity under the czars and under the Bolsheviks, who granted land, then took it away, always binding the muzhik, or peasant, to the land -- and always in the end blaming him for the resulting disaster.
So it is little consolation here that the latest reforms are intended essentially to undo decades of disastrous manipulation and to restore elemental links among farmer, land and market.
"This is a country where we create problems and then take great pride in overcoming them," said Mikhail G. Solovyev, the chief agronomist of the Rossiya kolkhoz. "Just look there."
Outside the window of his office, a grand Russian Orthodox Church was in the last stages of reconstruction. The original church, the pride of the prosperous Kuban Cossacks who lived on these lands before they were scattered by the Bolsheviks, was blown up twice, once after the Revolution and again after World War II.
Mr. Solovyev's concern, shared widely in the conservative brotherhood of agriculture, is that the reforms not become simply another twist in the cycle of restoration and destruction.
 
Spending Priorities
 He concedes that the kolkhoz is not in bad shape: It earned enough to meet expenses and then some, and there are plans for a new sunflower press. Mr. Solovyev's dream is that instead of "wasting" dollars on imported grain, the state would spend them on imported combines and processing plants.
But market forces, he argues, have had a dual effect. Many collective farms are withholding grain from the state (which still buys 35 percent of the crop at a fixed price), hoping that prices will rise.
This year, the entire Stavropol region did not produce a single pound of top-class wheat, because the amount of fertilizer needed was too expensive. At the same time, it has become more profitable to sell grain than to raise livestock.
"The arithmetic is simple," Mr. Solovyev said. "The feed for a pig costs 12,000 rubles, and the pig fetches 5,000. So of course it's better to slaughter the livestock. But if we do, what happens to all the people and the facilities in which we invested so much? So we resist killing off the animals, but I don't know how long we can do that."
The other problem is that like most state and collective farms, Rossiya was built as a paternalistic Soviet state in miniature, responsible not only for production of food but also for the lives of its people. The names of surrounding farms bear testimony to that heritage: Lenin, Karl Marx, Friendship, Gorky.
 
A True Company Town
 Here in Grigoropolisskaya, the 8,000 residents depend on Rossiya: it built the roads, the school and the hospital; it sends people to its own rest homes on the Black Sea; it supplied the private plots and the seeds to plant them.
Wages have always been decent. Today, kolkhoz workers can earn between 3,000 and 5,000 rubles a month, well above the 2,000-ruble poverty line, plus a share of the crop and of the profits.
The kolkhoz fed its dependents through the lean years and rewarded them in good ones. And whatever the kolkhoz did not supply, the kolkhozniks could always steal, in time-honored Soviet tradition, pilfering fertilizer and fuel to maintain the lucrative private plots.
Rossiya, moreover, was a showcase. It once carried the name of Stalin himself, something only the most privileged enterprises could do, and it was a place to which Nikita S. Khrushchev and Mikhail S. Gorbachev brought visitors. When there was an American combine to try out, Rossiya got it.
 
Big, It Seems, Is Better
 Moreover, Mr. Solovyev argued, the economies of scale developed over the decades on these black-earth plains could be destroyed if the land is parceled out. Under the current kolkhoz organization, each worker and pensioner can claim a share of land, about 17 acres, only a small fraction of an average cornfield.
"However we go about these reforms, we will return to large associations," Mr. Solovyev said. "So why waste time? What would be the use? How can small farmers ever provide the roads, the schools?"
To the architects of the reforms, such plaints are reminiscent of Leonid I. Brezhnev's celebrated frustration with farmers who never ceased complaining about the weather. "The experience of many years has shown that unfavorable weather occurs almost every other year," the longtime Communist chief grumbled 12 years ago. "It should therefore not be viewed as an exception, but as a natural aspect of our climate."
Agriculture Minister Viktor N. Khlystun might well agree. The main challenge, he said in an interview in Moscow, is to change the consciousness of the farmer, to break the fatalism, the suspiciousness of the market, the dependence on the kolkhoz.
 
A Beginning, Anyway
 Yes, he said, there are problems with livestock, with disparities in prices, with wheat withheld from the market. Parliament is still dragging its feet on land ownership. Private farmers are only starting up, and basic market structures -- banks, cooperatives, equipment supplies -- are still rudimentary.
Mr. Khlystun said private farmers were expected to account for 3 percent to 3.5 percent of this year's agricultural production.
Many of the problems, he said, are predictable, and many can be resolved through some transitional juggling of prices, subsidies, interest rates and fuel discounts.
"But the main change has to be a change in mentality," he argued, echoing a conclusion reformers in all aspects of the economy have reached after the first nine months. "That's why we cannot accelerate the pace of reform, because it's linked above all to changing the mentality."
 
The Long-Term Goals
 Mr. Khlystun said the Government's goal was not to kill all the state or collective farms, but to make them self-sufficient and profitable. At the end of the transition, he said, he envisions that half of Russia's farms will be large associations, 20 percent small cooperatives and 20 percent individual farms, with 10 percent remaining with the state. "But the time is over when the Government gives money to ineffective structures," he said.
The immediate challenge is to survive the transition.
"We are now in a crisis period, in a period of survival," Mr. Khlystun said. "If there is no further cataclysm, we should finish the privatization by next spring. But it will take another 10 to 12 years to set up the banks, the services, the infrastructure. All that depends on the state of the economy."

HEADLINE: China's Communists Prepare Party Congress

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Communist Party is preparing for a rare congress that will convene next week to shuffle the national leadership and establish a party line that is supposed to last for the next five years.
The party congress, the first to be held since 1987, is expected to confirm the rise of more pragmatic, change-minded officials within the leadership and to launch a new slogan: the building of a "socialist market economy." 
 No one knows just what a "socialist market economy" is, and that may be part of the attraction: the term is vague enough to be acceptable to all groups, while still sounding bold and reform-minded.
The authorities have given few details about the party congress, the 14th since the Chinese Communist Party was formed more than seven decades ago, except that it will begin on Monday. Still, they have hailed its importance, with Prime Minister Li Peng describing it last week as "a major event in our country's political life."
"We are sure that it will give a fresh impetus to reform, opening up and our economic development, and become an important milestone in the history of the Chinese Communist Party and China's socialist modernization," Mr. Li said.
The party congress will approve a work report that is supposed to set the tone for the next five years, and it will also choose a new Central Committee. The Central Committee, in turn, will choose a new Politburo.
In fact, all the crucial decisions have been made in advance by the handful of octogenarians who hold ultimate power in China, and the congress is less a forum for decisions than a platform for self-promotion -- a Chinese version of a national political convention in the United States. Among the key differences are that party congress speeches can last for hours, many of the proceedings are secret, and there is no election afterward to put it all in perspective.
The 14th party congress is expected to be important in that it will presumably anoint the team of leaders who will preside over the transition after the death of Deng Xiaoping, the ailing paramount leader. But the same was said of the 13th party congress in 1987.
 
Deng Not Expected to Appear
 Mr. Deng appeared at the 1987 congress but there is no sign that he will turn up this time. He is 88 years old and rarely appears in public now.
Since the beginning of this year, Mr. Deng has been pressing behind the scenes for more rapid economic growth and restructuring, to the point of borrowing some elements from capitalism. The congress may be his last hurrah, and it is expected to endorse his preferred combination of free markets and one-party rule.
"There seems no question that the congress is intended to be a strong reaffirmation of the Deng Xiaoping line of reform and openness," said a Western diplomat in Beijing. "We expect that the new Central Committee and the new Politburo in particular will basically reflect that, in the sense that there will be a strengthening of the reform and moderate forces."
While the personnel decisions have presumably already been made, the rumors about who will be promoted vary considerably. By almost all accounts, the Politburo will be expanded from its present membership of 14, and most of the likely candidates are relatively young and enthusiastic about markets -- for goods if not ideas.
The most powerful rulers of China, all octogenarians like Mr. Deng, are nominally retired and will not be shuffled. Among the younger leaders who hold formal positions, the two most important -- Prime Minister Li and General Secretary Jiang Zemin -- are generally expected to hold onto their posts, at least for now.
 
Small Role for Delegates
 The 1,991 delegates to the party congress, which will last about a week, will be entrusted with a minor role in addition to approving decisions already made. They will elect a Central Committee from a list of names that is a bit longer than the number of positions, so that a small percentage of candidates will lose the election.

HEADLINE: Chinese Agency Indicted in Jeans Import Scheme

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors in Manhattan yesterday accused a Chinese Government agency of conspiring with a subsidiary in New York to evade United States quotas on clothing imports by falsely labeling thousands of jogging suits and pairs of blue jeans.
Yesterday's indictments in Federal District Court charged the China National Textiles Import and Export Corporation, which prosecutors said was the agency in charge of textiles and clothing trade, with conspiring to defraud the United States. It was the second set of indictments in a broad 17-month investigation by the Customs Service into Chinese textile export practices. 
 Prosecutors said China National, situated in Beijing, reported directly to China's Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade. Two officials of China National were also charged.
While they declined to accuse the Chinese Government directly, officials suggested that high-level officials must have been involved in the fraud.
"It would be very surprising for me to think that this doesn't come from a higher level than just freelancing officials," said Robert Van Etten, special agent in charge of the United States Customs Service. "This is widespread."
Although China National is controlled by the Chinese Government, it claims to be a private corporation and therefore can be indicted like any American corporation, said Milton L. Williams Jr., the assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who is in charge of the case.
Hundreds of customs agents have been investigating importers' efforts to evade quotas and duties by mislabeling textiles and clothing from China or by shipping them through other countries. Officials have estimated that such schemes may have involved $2 billion worth of goods last year.
In May, prosecutors charged officals from a provincial Chinese trade agency with conspiring with two American companies to defraud the United States of more than $100,000 in import duties.
 
Source of Friction
 Yesterday's indictments may provide a measure of political cover to the Bush Administration, which has been accused by critics of being too soft on China. Just last week, the President vetoed a Congressional bill to link China's trade status with improvement in its record on human rights, free trade and arms proliferation. Meanwhile, the Administration has set a deadline of Saturday for China to take further steps to open its markets to imports, but in the past it has let such deadlines slip, further angering Congressional critics.
Prosecutors said the principal victim in the scheme they described yesterday was the domestic textile industry, whose sales would be undercut by an uncontrolled flood of cheaper foreign goods. "The cost to the American textile industry in the loss of jobs doesn't have a dollar figure," said Mr. Van Etten of the Customs Service.
Despite the indictments, it is far from clear whether Federal prosecutors will be able to put China National on trial. "The question of whether or not they show up, that depends on them," he said. "We would have no jurisdiction over them if they decide not to show up."
The indictments outlined two schemes, running from September 1989 to February 1990, involving China National; Chinatex America Inc., a company on West 40th Street in Manhattan that prosecutors said is owned by China National, and the Oslo Trading Company, a defunct New Jersey trading concern.
In the first scheme, the indictments said Gu Shi Qiang, identified as an agent of Chinatex, arranged with an agent of China National identified as Tan Xiang Lin to submit paper work to the Customs Service that falsely declared 24,000 boys' acrylic jogging suits to be girls' suits, thereby dodging 1989 customs quotas on boys' suits.
The indictments charge that in the second scheme, another agent of Chinatex, who was identified as Bao Yu Ping, and Zhou Li of China National joined with Benny Chang of Oslo Trading in planning to have "Made in Egypt" labels stitched into 12,000 pairs of cotton denim blue jeans made in China. According to the indictments, they were planning to send the jeans to a company in Egypt, where they were to be repackaged. Unlike the jogging suits, the jeans were never imported, Mr. Williams said.
 
A Consulting Company
 An unnamed "American consulting company" was also mentioned in the indictments as participating in the second scheme. Mr. Williams declined to comment on whether the American company would be named or charged.
Reached by telephone at the Chinese Embassy in Washington, a man who identified himself as Gueng Liu, the commercial attache, declined to comment on the charges, as did a man who identified himself as a spokesman but declined to give his name.
A telephone message left at the office of Chinatex was not answered.
If convicted on all charges, China National and Chinatex each face up to $2 million in fines.
Yesterday morning, customs agents arrested Mr. Chang, who faces a maximum of 5 years in prison if convicted and $250,000 in fines, and Mr. Gu, who faces a maximum of 17 years in prison and $1 million in fines, surrendered voluntarily at Customs Service headquarters in New York.
Mr. Bao lives in Hong Kong, and officials have begun proceedings to have him arrested, Mr. Van Etten said. The other two men are in China, he said, and it had not been determined how or if they would be arrested. Mr. Bao and Mr. Zhou each face up to 5 years in prison and $250,000 in fines, while Mr. Tan faces up to 17 years and $1 million in fines.
Among those charged, Mr. Chang is the only American citizen, according to the United States Attorney's office.
 
Other Developments
 The office announced two other developments in the customs investigation yesterday.
In a case not previously disclosed, John Cheng and his company, China Silk Fabric House, on West 40th Street in Manhattan, pleaded guilty on Sept. 30 to charges of defrauding the Government of $82,909.70 in import duties on merchandise shipped from Hong Kong. Mr. Cheng also pleaded guilty to reporting his 1990 income as $2,173, when he actually earned $206,717. He faces up to 5 years in prison and a $500,000 fine.
And charges were announced yesterday against Frank Vuong, former president of All American Apparel Inc., for obstruction of justice. Prosecutors accused Mr. Vuong of submitting false documentation in response to a Customs Service inquiry.

HEADLINE: Citicorp President Resigns

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Richard S. Braddock, president of Citicorp and the first in line to succeed John S. Reed as chairman, resigned unexpectedly yesterday, raising the possibility that he had been blamed for some of the bank's ills or had simply decided that he was not likely to move up to the chairmanship.
Bank officials said that Mr. Braddock's departure was a friendly one. "He is a very vigorous guy, and he is looked upon as having done a very good job here," said John M. Morris, a Citicorp spokesman. But if Citibank sought to put a friendly spin on the resignation, many others in the world of American banking said Mr. Braddock's departure came as a big surprise and even annoyed them. 
 "I am chagrined to see him him go," said J. Richard Frederick, a bank analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "He was a very good manager, and I think it is a loss to the company."
 
 
'Great Contribution'
 The bank's three-paragraph announcement, released in the late afternoon after the stock market closed, said Mr. Braddock's duties would be handled by Citicorp's senior management team. The announcement quoted Mr. Reed as saying: "Rick's great contribution was to the growth of our consumer business. He has been an important part of the senior team during this turnaround."
Citicorp also announced late yesterday that it would report third-quarter earnings in the range of $80 million to $100 million, or between 8 cents and 13 cents a share. That would be a big improvement over a loss of $885 million in last year's third quarter, but not as good a showing as this year's second quarter, which produced net income of $143 million.
The earnings estimate announcement suggested, among other things, that Citicorp's loan collection problems with Brazil and Mexico had eased in the third quarter. But it added that reserves were increased to protect against potential losses from defaulted consumer and commercial loans. The action was taken "in view of economic uncertainty and a patchy recovery in the United States and Europe," the bank said.
 
 
Senior Management Team
 Mr. Braddock, who is 50 years old, had been named president in January 1990, taking a job that had been vacant for six years, since shortly before Mr. Reed became chairman. Mr. Reed had chosen not to fill the position, preferring a less hierarchical management structure. Now, with Mr. Braddock gone, the presidency will remain vacant again, the bank said. A five-member senior management team will take over Mr. Braddock's duties.
Mr. Braddock, who had been at Citicorp for 19 years, brought to the bank a marketing background in consumer products. As president for the last two and a half years, he had concentrated mainly on cutting costs within the bank, which has shrunk its work force. Before becoming president, he had been a vice president in Citicorp's New York Banking Group, and then chief of the bank's credit card business and European consumer operations. From 1985 until he became president, he had been in charge of all individual banking activity, a major Citicorp division.
Although Wall Street bank analysts said Mr. Braddock's resignation had surprised them, there was some speculation that he might have left because he had concluded that his career had reached a dead end and he would not succeed Mr. Reed. With little experience in commercial lending, he was not viewed as bringing to management a strong background in solving Citicorp's loan problems.
"Rick's background has been on the consumer side, while some of Citicorp's announced problems have been in other areas of the bank," Mr. Frederick noted.
Mr. Reed is only two years older than Mr. Braddock, but with Citicorp in trouble over commercial real estate loans that have gone bad and, lately, a rising number of mortgage loans in default, Mr. Reed's own imminent departure from the bank has been widely rumored. Some analysts suggested, however, that Mr. Braddock's departure might ease the pressure on Mr. Reed.
Mr. Braddock's resignation was the second major one for Citicorp in recent months; the other was that of Michael A. Callen, a vice chairman.
The bank's brief announcement said that Mr. Braddock "chose to resign after concluding that his best contribution to the recovery of Citicorp's momentum has been realized and, accordingly, he wants to pursue new career opportunities."
Mr. Braddock could not be reached by telephone. Mr. Morris said that Mr. Braddock had submitted his resignation yesterday, effective immediately. Before the announcements, Citicorp's stock had closed down 25 cents, at $15.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
With Mr. Braddock gone, the bank's management team is now composed of Mr. Reed; Pei Wuan Chia, senior executive vice president in charge of consumer banking, and three vice chairmen: Paul Collins, William Rhodes and Onno Rudding.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
U.S.-Made Vehicle Sales Fell in Late September

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced vehicles dropped a scant seven-tenths of 1 percent in late September, but automotive demand on a seasonally adjusted basis seemed to perk up a bit after months of sluggishness.
Sales of domestically produced cars were off 1.2 percent, to 250,367, for the Sept. 21-30 period, while sales of light trucks rose one-tenth of 1 percent, to 169,307. However, the seasonally adjusted annual rate for car sales was 6.8 million, compared with 6.1 million for mid-September and 7.2 million in late September last year. 
 Over all, sales of cars and light trucks, which include mini-vans, sport-utility vehicles and pickups, totaled 419,674. The 10-day period marked the end of the industry's 1992 model year, "a difficult one for the entire automotive market," Robert L. Rewey, vice president of sales for the Ford Motor Company, said.
 
 
Reduced Production Schedules
 Because of generally sluggish sales, the Big Three have recently been paring car and light-truck production schedules for the fourth quarter, which will mean less factory output, more hours of layoffs and thinner corporate earnings.
Remarking on the uptick in late September sales, David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company in New York, said, "We'll just have to wait for a few more periods to see whether the increase in activity is a trend or not."
Retail automobile dealers continued to report spotty demand, marked by consumer uncertainty over economic conditions. "I don't think there's a real turnaround yet," said Tom Castriota, general manager of Castriota Chevrolet in Pittsburgh. "We don't have back-to-back 10-day periods that are strong."
Kenny Coiner, general manager of Bachman Chevrolet-Geo in Louisville, Ky., said, "It's harder than it was to convince people to buy because they are worried about their jobs."
For the month of September, sales of all vehicles, imported and domestic, reached 1,072,340, a drop of 1.2 percent from the month a year earlier. Car sales were off 3.6 percent, to 674,014, and light-truck sales rose 3.1 percent, to 398,326.
The General Motors Corporation sold 222,399 cars in September, down 8.3 percent from a year earlier; G.M. sold 135,619 light trucks, down four-tenths of 1 percent.
The Ford Motor Company sold 150,289 cars, up 7.8 percent, and 121,241 light trucks, down 7 percent.
 
 
Chrysler Sales
 The Chrysler Corporation sold 61,654 cars for the month, down 7.4 percent, and 83,692 light trucks, up 35 percent. Light-truck sales were influenced by big increases in the sale of mini-vans and Jeep sport-utility vehicles.
The Honda Motor Company posted a 5.9 percent decline in car sales to 68,347.
The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 60,568 cars, an increase of 8.2 percent, and 7,789 light trucks.
The Big Three continued a yearlong trend of gaining back market share at the expense of Japanese auto makers. The Big Three's sales constituted 70.5 percent of September's automotive market, up from 69.5 percent a year earlier. Sales of Japanese auto makers dropped to 24.8 percent of the market from 25 percent. Sales of European and South Korean imports dropped to 4.7 percent of the market from 5.5 percent.
